In civil cases each party shall be entitled to six peremptory challenges, and in criminal cases the defendant shall be entitled to seven peremptory and the State five; and all laws governing the selection of jurors in the superior court shall apply to the city court of Waynesboro, except when they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Act. At each quarterly term of said court the judge presiding shall, in open court, draw from the jury-box provided for that purpose the names of twenty-four jurors (or thirty-six, in his discretion), who shall constitute the jury for the next quarterly term thereof; provided, that if, from any cause, the jury shall not be drawn as aforesaid, the judge of said city court may draw them at some other time, after entering an order on the minutes of said court, stating the reason why said jury was not drawn by him as hereinbefore provided. Jurors.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section 39 of said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out all of the words occurring between the word presiding, in the second line, and the word then, in the fourth line of said section, as published; and is further amended by striking out the word shall, in the sixth line of said section, as published, and by inserting in lieu thereof the word may, so that said section, when so amended, shall read as follows: Be it
further enacted, That whenever the judge of said city court is, from any cause, disqualified from presiding, then, upon the consent of the parties, or upon their failure or refusal to agree, said cause may be tried by a judge pro hac vice, selected in the same manner as is now provided for in the superior courts. Judge pre hac vice.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section 40 of said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out all of said section which occurs after the word thereof, in the third line, as published, and by inserting in place thereof the following words, to wit: and removable at his pleasure; said stenographer shall report all cases tried before a jury, both civil and criminal, in said court, and shall be entitled to receive therefor the sum of five dollars per day for each day's attendance, payable at the close of each jury session, out of the county treasury, upon warrant of the judge of said court. In all cases where a motion for a new trial is made, said stenographer shall, on request of counsel for movant, furnish a transcript of his report, for which he shall be entitled to charge not exceeding ten cents per hundred words, to be paid for on delivery, unless otherwise agreed upon between the counsel and said stenographer; but the judge of the court may, when satisfied of the movant's inability to pay costs, order the report transcribed and furnished without payment on delivery, but unless so requested, he shall not be required to transcribe any report; provided, however, that the presiding judge may, in his discretion, require the report of any civil case to be paid for by the parties in the manner and upon the terms named for the reporting of civil cases under the general law for the superior courts, in which event said stenographer shall not be paid anything [Illegible Text] the county for the time so occupied. Said city court stenographer shall be entitled to the same remedies to enforce the payment of his fees as is provided by law for the stenographers of the superior courts, so that said section, when so amended, shall read as follows: Be it further enacted, That there shall be a stenographer of the city court of Waynesboro appointed by the judge thereof, and removable at his pleasure; said stenographer shall report all cases tried before a jury, both civil and criminal, in said court, and shall be entitled to receive therefor the sum of five dollars per day for each day's attendance, payable at the close of each jury session out of the county treasury upon warrant of the judge of said court. In all cases where a motion for a new trial is made, said stenographer shall, on request of counsel for movant, furnish a transcript of his report, for which he shall be entitled to charge not exceeding ten cents per hundred words, to be paid for on delivery, unless
otherwise agreed upon between counsel and the stenographer, but the judge of the court may, when satisfied of the movant's inability to pay costs, order the report transcribed and furnished without payment on delivery, but unless so requested, he shall not be required to transcribe any report; provided, however, the presiding judge may, in his discretion, require the report of any civil case to be paid for by the parties in the manner and upon the terms named for the reporting of civil cases under the general law for the superior courts, in which event said stenographer shall not be paid anything by the county for the time so occupied. Said city court stenographer shall be entitled to the same remedies to enforce the payment of his fees as is provided by law for the stenographers of the superior courts. Stenographer.
Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: COUNTY COURT OF BROOKS COUNTY ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act to create a county court in each county of the State of Georgia, except certain counties therein mentioned, approved January 19, 1872, and all Acts amendatory thereof, so far as the same applies to the county of Brooks, and to provide for the disposition of all business pending in the county court of Brooks, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the above-recited Act and all Acts amendatory thereof, as now embodied in the Code of 1895, from section 4170 to 4217, inclusive, be, and the same are, hereby repealed, so far as they apply to the county of Brooks, and the county court of the said county of Brooks, is hereby abolished. County court of Brooks county abolished

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all books, papers, suits, mesne and final processes of whatsoever nature, and all criminal cases and business now pending in the county court of Brooks county be, and the same are, hereby transferred to the city court of Quitman for trial and final disposition. Business of transferred.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: COUNTY COURT OF JASPER COUNTY, JURORS, HOW DRAWN.
law.fulltitle: An Act permitting the judge of the county court of Jasper county, at his discretion, to draw and have summoned for each regular term of said court eighteen jurors; to provide for the method of striking said jurors; to repeal so much of the county court Act, approved January 19, 1872, as is in conflict with this Act, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That on and after the second Wednesday in January, 1905, the judge of the county court of Jasper county, from the jury-box, shall draw by lot the names of eighteen jurors instead of twelve, as is now provided for by law, to be summoned by the proper officer of said court to attend before him at the regular terms of said court, whenever, in his opinion, the business before this court demands the same. County court of Jasper county, jurors in.

Sec. 2. That the first twelve jurors shall be used to strike from whenever none of the jurors drawn are engaged in the trial of a case; provided, whenever any of the said first twelve jurors drawn are disqualified by the rules of law, that the first twelve jurors on the list of eighteen which are qualified shall be used to strike from. That whenever six of the jurors drawn are engaged in the trial of a case, the remaining twelve jurors drawn shall constitute twelve from which the defendant shall have four strikes and the State shall have two strikes.
Sec. 3. All laws and parts of laws, and so much of the county court Act, approved January 19, 1872, as is in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: COUNTY COURT OF TALIAFERRO COUNTY, JUDGE OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize and allow the officers of ordinary and judge of the county court of Taliaferro county (provided a county court shall hereafter be established for Taliaferro county) to be held by one and the same person at one time, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act the offices of ordinary and judge of the county court of Taliaferro county (provided a county court shall hereafter be established for Taliaferro county) may be held by one and the same person at one time; and that one and the same person may be commissioned to hold at one time the offices of ordinary and judge of the county court of Taliaferro county (provided a county court shall hereafter be established for Taliaferro county). County court of Taliaferro county, judge.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: COUNTY COURT OF WILKINSON COUNTY, JUDGE OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide that the ordinary of Wilkinson county shall, under certain circumstances, be judge of the county court of said county, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted, That from and after the passage of this Act the ordinary of Wilkinson county shall, by virtue of his office, be judge of the county court of said county; but the ordinary of said county shall not become said county judge until the term of office of the present county judge has expired, or
until there shall be a vacancy in office of county judge by his death, resignation, or otherwise. County court of Wilkinson county, judge of.
Sec. 2. Be it enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: COUNTY COURT OF WORTH COUNTY ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act to create a county court in each county in the State of Georgia, except certain counties therein mentioned, approved January 19, 1872, and all Acts amendatory thereof, so far as the same applies to the county of Worth; to provide for the transfer of all cases pending in the county court of Worth, and all unfinished business, books and records thereof to the city court of Sylvester, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the above-recited Act, and all amendments thereof, as now embodied in the Code of 1895, from sections 4170 to 4217, and all special amendments be, and the same are, hereby repealed, so far as they apply to the county of Worth, and the county court of said county of Worth is hereby abolished; provided, however, that this Act shall not go into effect until the passage and approval of an Act establishing the city court of Sylvester, in and for the county of Worth. County court of Worth county abolished.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all mesne and final process from the county court of Worth which has not been executed shall be returnable to the city court of Sylvester, and all [Illegible Text] and illegalities and other issues arising from the execution of such process shall be returnable as though such process had issued from the city court of Sylvester. Process and writs, where returnable.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all dockets, minutes, records, books and papers of the county court of Worth shall be turned over to the clerk of the city court of Sylvester. Books and records, disposition of.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: APPLING COUNTY, COMMISSIONERS FOR, APPOINTMENT, DUTIES, ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved July 16, 1903, entitled an Act to create a board of road and bridge commissioners for Appling county, define their powers and prescribe their' duties, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the above-recited Act be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By striking out section 2 of said Act and inserting in lieu thereof the following: That the judge of the superior court shall appoint the said board of commissioners immediately after the approval of this Act; one-third of said board shall be appointed for two years, one-third for four years, and one-third for the term of six years; each subsequent appointment shall be for the full term of six years. Any vacancies on said board due to death, resignation, or otherwise, shall be filled by appointment by the judge, and shall be for the unexpired term, and shall be made from the same district. The judge shall have power to remove any commissioner upon petition for inefficiency, corruption or refusal to perform the duties cited in this Act, after said commissioner has been given the opportunity to be heard in defense of the charges preferred. Appling county, appointment of board of commissioners for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That section 9 of said Act be amended by striking all of said section and inserting in lieu thereof the following: That the said commissioners of roads shall have the public roads worked after the following manner: First, by the organization of the misdemeanor convicts of this county, and such other convicts as may be apportioned to them, or hired from other counties, into chain-gangs for this purpose; second, in the event of no organized chain-gang in said county, the said commissioners shall work said roads by contract, according to specification, let to the lowest bidder. They shall advertise the same at the precinct of the district in which said road is located seven days prior to letting said contract. The commissioners shall have the right to reject any and all bids if in their judgment the same are excessive or exhorbitant. Third, hire of free
labor when the same can be employed more economically and to better advantage than by contract. Public roads, how worked.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That section 10 of said Act be amended by striking all of said section and inserting in lieu thereof the following: That the said commissioners shall assess a commutation tax on every person subject to road duty, not to exceed three dollars per annum, and in addition thereto may assess a tax on all real and personal property in said county for road purposes, not to exceed two-tenths of one per centum, and in addition to the above-cited tax, the commissioners may assess a tax not to exceed two and five-tenths mills on all real and personal property, for the purpose of constructing and repairing bridges in said county. Road and bridge tax.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That section 11 of said Act be amended by striking all of said section and inserting in lieu thereof the following: That all revenue derived from commutation tax, or taxation on property, shall be expended on the roads in the districts from which it was collected; provided, that the provisions of this section do not apply to the assessment and collection of a bridge tax, and that the tax-collector shall not be required to make report per district of the same. Road tax, how disbursed.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That section 18 of said Act be amended by striking all of said section and inserting in lieu thereof the following: That two commissioners are empowered to try all defaulters who refuse to pay the commutation tax assessed, or perform the necessary labor in lieu thereof on the public roads, They shall receive one dollar and fifty cents each for every day's service in the trial of defaulters, the same to be paid out of any money collected from fines in said district. Said commissioners shall hold court or courts for the trial of all defaulters at any time or times at any place or places in the county that may be fixed by said authority; provided, that five days' notice be given of the time and place, or times and places, to the said defaulters. Tax defaulters, trial of.
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That section 23 of said Act be stricken, and the following new sections be added:

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted, That the said road commissioners, before entering upon the duties assigned them, shall be sworn faithfully and diligently to perform their duties as such road commissioners, and they shall administer to the overseers, or superintendent, appointed by them, oaths for the faithful and diligent performance of their duties as such. The said commissioners shall require an approved bond of any person or persons, in the sum of twice the amount, for any moneys collected or disbursed, arising
from the commutation or property tax for road purposes in said county. Oath of commissioners and overseers. Bond of custodian of tax fund

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted, That for any failure to perform any duty by this Act imposed on them, or for making any fraudulent disposition of the funds hereby provided, or for any of the commissioners to be interested, directly or indirectly, in any contract authorized to be made under this Act, the commissioners so offending shall be guilty of and punished as for a misdemeanor. Penalty for violating act.

blockquote.p: Sec. 25. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: BIBB COUNTY, MISDEMEANOR CONVICTS, WORK AND HIRE OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act of the General Assembly, approved February 26, 1874, and the Acts amendatory thereof, entitled an Act to amend the road laws of the county of Bibb, so as to provide for the regulation and control of misdemeanor convicts, and other convicts in the county of Bibb, and to regulate the working the streets of the city of Macon with said convicts, and to regulate the amount of money to be paid by the county of Bibb to the city of Macon for the hire of convicts, as now provided by Act of the General Assembly approved August 15, 1903, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act it shall be the duty of the county commissioners of the county of Bibb and the road commissioners of said county to work the county chain-gang of said Bibb county upon the streets of the city of Macon outside the paved district, said streets to be under the supervision of the road board, the same as the other roads of the county, except that the mayor and council, or its authority, shall direct the manner in which said work shall be done. City of Macon, streets of to be worked by county chain-gang.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all expenses necessary for the proper working of the streets, including sewer-pipe across said streets, and everything necessary for the working and maintenance
of the streets of the city of Macon, shall be borne by the county of Bibb, except the items of guttering, curbing and intake basins. Expenses of, by whom paid.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That in consideration of the county of Bibb taking in charge the working of all the streets of the city of Macon, as herein provided, the obligation of the county to pay to the city of Macon eight thousand dollars per annum, as now provided by law, shall no longer be of force, and shall cease upon the beginning by the county of Bibb to take charge of the streets of the city of Macon under this Act. Obligation of county to city released.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That in no event shall the county of Bibb be liable for damages or claims of any kind that may arise on account of the working of the streets as herein provided by the county chain-gang; the liability of the city of Macon on account of the streets not to be in any manner affected by this Act, but to remain as now fixed by law. County not liable for damages from work.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: BIBB COUNTY, APPROPRIATIONS BY FOR LIBRARIES, HOW USED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved December 18, 1900, which authorized the board of county commissioners to appropriate certain fixed sums of money annually to each of the two libraries now established in the city of Macon; said amendment to provide for the use of said money for the repair and care, as well as for the purchase of books, magazines, newspapers and other periodicals; said amendment also to provide for making such rental charges for all books taken from each of said libraries as may, in the discretion of the managers or directors of either or both of said libraries, be found necessary to keep in good order and condition the circulating library, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of this State, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That to section 2 of said above-recited Act, which section provides for the payment of three hundred ($300) dollars for the purpose of
purchasing such books, magazines, newspapers, and other periodicals, as the directors or managers of said library may select for the particular library so applying, and also provides how and when said money shall be paid, there shall be added the following proviso: Provided, that the said board of directors or managers shall be authorized to use any portion of said fund for the purpose of repairing and caring for the books herein authorized to be purchased. Library fund for Bibb county, how used.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section 7 of the above-recited Act, which reads as follows: Be it further enacted, That the directors or managers of each of the two libraries herein referred to shall, at or before receiving these appropriations, bind themselves in writing to the Bibb county commissioners, that they will, as directors or managers of said library or libraries, subscribe for and take one leading daily newspaper from each of the following cities, to wit: the city of New York, the city of Washington, D. C., the city of Chicago, the city of New Orleans, the city of Savannah, the city of Atlanta, and two of the leading daily papers published in the city of Macon, shall be, and the same is, hereby repealed, and the following subtituted in lieu thereof: That the directors or managers of each of the two libraries herein referred to, may subscribe for and take any one of the daily newspapers in any of the cities of the United States that they may see fit, but it shall not be incumbent upon them to subscribe for any of said periodicals unless so desired by said directors or managers. Library, purchase of newspapers for.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That from and after the passage of this Act the directors or managers of each of said libraries shall be authorized, in their discretion, to provide for making such rental charges for any and all books taken from each of said libraries, as may, in the discretion of the managers or directors, be found necessary to keep in good order and condition the books of the circulating library. Any charge so made, however, shall not be less than two nor more than ten cents per volume for any book or books which may be taken from the library. But the carrying out of this provision shall not take away from the public the right to use free, and without any cost whatever, any books of the library as books of reference or otherwise, while so used in the rooms of the library, the purpose of this provision being to create and maintain a circulating library at the expense of those persons who use the books of the library as such. Rental charges for use of books authorized.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act shall be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: BUTTS COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act approved December 22, 1898, entitled an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in and for the county of Butts, to define the number of commissioners on said board, and to fix their duties according to the law regulating the authority and supervision of said commissioners over county matters as now provided.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, that the Act entitled an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues, in and for the county of Butts, to define the number of commissioners on said board and to fix their duties according to the law regulating the authority and supervision of said commissioners over county matters as now provided, approved December 22, 1898, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Butts county, board of commissioners for abolished.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the provisions of this Act shall not become operative until ratified by a majority of the qualified voters at the next general election held in the county of Butts. At said election those favoring the abolishment of said board of commissioners of roads and revenues of said county shall have written or printed on their ballots, which ballots shall be separate from the ballots cast for officers, the words Against Commissioners of Roads and Revenues, and those opposed to the abolishment of said board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall have written or printed on their ballots the words For Commissioners of Roads and Revenues. Returns of said election shall be made to the ordinary of Butts county, who shall consolidate the same and declare the result. If a majority vote at said election shall be in favor of abolishment of said board of commissioners of roads and revenues, then the provisions of this Act to become operative on the 31st day of December, 1904. Act to be ratified by voters.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: BUTTS COUNTY, CLAIM OF FORMER TAX-COLLECTOR.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to authorize the board of county commissioners of roads and revenues of Butts county to investigate the claim of A. J. Moore, former tax-collector of said county, against said county for commissions alleged to be due him as such tax-collector for the years 1874 and 1875, and for other purposes, approved December 16, 1901, by striking the words 1874 and 1875, in the sixth line of the first section of said Act, and in the fifth line of the second section of said Act, and substituting therefor the words 1875 and 1876, and by adding after the word commissioners, in the third line of the first and second sections of said Act, the words or county authorities.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That an Act entitled an Act to authorize the board of county commissioners of roads and revenues of Butts county to investigate the claim of A. J. Moore, former tax-collector of said county, against said county for commissions alleged by him to be due as tax-collector for the years 1874 and 1875, and for other purposes, approved December 16, 1901, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking the words 1874 and 1875, in the sixth line of the first section of said Act, and also in the fifth line of the second section of said Act, and substituting therefor the words 1875 and 1876, and by adding after the word commissioners, in the third lines of the first and second sections of said Act the words or county authorities, so that said Act, when amended, shall read as follows: Section 2. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the board of commissioners of roads and revenues, or county authorities of said county, are empowered to investigate the claim of A. J. Moore, former tax-collector of said county, against said county of Butts for commissions alleged
by said A. J. Moore to be due him as tax-collector for the years 1875 and 1876, being due and unpaid since said years 1875 and 1876. Butts county, claim of former tax collector.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if, upon investigation of the claim of A. J. Moore by the board of commissioners or county authorities of said county, it should be ascertained that the said county of Butts is indebted to said A. J. Moore as tax-collector of said county for the years of 1875 and 1876, said board of commissioners or county authorities is hereby authorized and empowered to order said claim, or such part of it as is approved by them, to be paid to said A. J. Moore from the county treasury of said county. Investigation and payment of.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: CARROLL COUNTY, REMOVAL OF OBSTRUCTIONS FROM WATERS OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act providing for the removal of all obstructions of all kinds, other than dams used for operating mills or machinery of other kinds, from creeks and other running streams of the county of Carroll, and for other purposes, approved August 15, 1903, by striking the words county commissioners wherever they occur in said Act, and inserting in lieu thereof the word ordinary, and by striking the word their, in line 6 of section 2, and inserting in lieu thereof the word his, and by striking the words one of their number, in lines 9 and 10 of section 2, and inserting in lieu thereof the word ordinary, and by adding at the end of section 4 of said Act the words nor to back waters of the Chattahoochee river, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That section 2 of the above-recited Act be amended by striking the words county commissioners, in line 6 of section 2 of said Act, and inserting in lieu thereof the word ordinary; and by striking the word their, in line 6 of section 2, and inserting in lieu thereof
the word his; and by striking the words one of their number, in lines 9 and 10 of section 2, and inserting in lieu thereof the word ordinary; and by striking the words county commissioners are, in lines 12 and 13 of section 2, and inserting in lieu thereof the words ordinary is, so as to make said section, when so amended, read as follows, to wit: Section 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That should any landowner in said county fail or refuse to remove the obstructions as provided in section 1 hereof by the first day of October of each year, from streams running through his lands, or from his half of streams dividing his lands from the lands of another, then, and in that event the ordinary, of his own motion, or at the instance of any citizen of the county, shall cause said obstructions to be removed in accordance with the provisions of section 1 hereof, under the direction of the ordinary, or of the sheriff, deputy-sheriff or any lawful constable or road overseer of said county, all expenses and costs to be taxed against the defaulting landowner. Said ordinary is hereby empowered, after said obstructions have been removed and the expenses thereof ascertained, to issue a fi. fa. for said costs and expenses against said defaulting landowner, which fi. fa. may be enforced as tax fi. fas., and shall be a lien upon all the property of the defaulting landowner, superior to all other liens, except liens for taxes. Carroll county, obstructions from waters of to be removed, by whom.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section 4 of said Act, which reads as follows: That this shall not apply to any stream where it is the dividing line between Carroll and other counties, be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding at the end of said section the words nor to back-waters from the Chattahoochee river, so that, when said section is so amended, it shall read as follows, to wit: Section 4. That this shall not apply to any stream where it is the dividing line between Carroll and other counties, nor to that part of creeks emptying into the Chattahoochee river, so far as back-water extends during high-water of said river. Streams excepted.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by authority of the same, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: CHATHAM COUNTY COMMISSIONERS, COMPENSATION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide that each county commissioner and ex officio judge of Chatham county shall receive salary or compensation for his services, payable out of the treasury of said county, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act each county commissioner and ex officio judge of Chatham county shall be paid out of the treasury of said county in the way of salary or compensation for his services the sum of ten ($10,00) dollars for each and every regular meeting of the board of county commissioners, and five ($5.00) dollars for each and every extra, called, recessed or adjourned meeting of said board. Chatham county commissioners, compensation of.
Sec. 2. Be it enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: COWETA COUNTY, HIRE OF MISDEMEANOR CONVICTS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to permit the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Coweta county to pay to the officers of the superior court of Coweta county, and the city court of Newnan, compensation for misdemeanor convicts turned over by said officers from said courts to work on the chain-gang of said county.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Coweta county are hereby authorized to pay to the officers of the superior court of Coweta county, and the city court of Newnan, compensation for misdemeanor convicts convicted in said courts and delivered to the chain-gang of Coweta county as follows: For first-class male
convicts the sum of not less than six dollars, nor more than seven dollars and fifty cents per month, in the discretion of said board of county commissioners; for second-class male convicts the actual costs incurred in convicting same, including the cost of commitment trial; for female convicts not less than fifty per cent., nor more than seventy-five per cent. of costs of conviction, including cost of commitment trial, in the discretion of the board of county commissioners. Coweta county, hire of convicts for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the money thus paid for any convict shall first be applied to the costs of that case, including jail fees and the costs of the justice of the peace and constable, if said case originated in a justice's court; and any sum so paid which may be in excess of the costs as aforesaid shall be applied to the insolvent cost-bills of the various officers of said courts and be distributed as by statute provided. Money paid for convicts, how disbursed.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That in deciding in which class any convict shall be placed, the chairman of the board of county commissioners and the sheriff of said county shall decide, if possible; and in the event they fail to agree, then the county physician of said county shall be called in as umpire, and his decision shall be final as to the classification of said convict. Convicts, classification of.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws conflicting with this Act are hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: DECATUR COUNTY, ACT ESTABLISHING BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to revise, consolidate and amend the Act establishing a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for Decatur county, approved December 13, 1871, and all Acts amendatory thereto, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act all the powers and duties of the ordinary of Decatur county, so far as the same relates to roads, bridges, ferries, public buildings, and other property, poorhouse and farm, jail fees and the management of the
jail, assessing and collecting tax, disbursing public money for county purposes, and all laws in reference thereto, are hereby conferred upon a county board of commissioners as hereinafter set out. Decatur county, board of commissioners for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the said board shall consist of five upright, discreet and intelligent freeholders, to be elected by the qualified voters of said county, as hereinafter provided, and that any three members of said board shall be capable and duly authorized to transact any business appertaining to their office. Composition of board.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That at the regular election for county officers next preceding the expiration of the term of each member of the present board a successor to said member shall be elected by the qualified voters at said election, for a term of four years, so that a successor to each member of the said board shall be elected by the qualified voters of the county at the election next preceding the expiration of the term of such member of said board. The said newly-elected member of said board shall qualify and enter upon the discharge of his duties as such, immediately upon the expiration of the term of that member of said board whom he has been elected to succeed. Said election shall be held in the same manner and at the same time as is provided for the election of county officers. Said board shall perform all the duties hereinafter prescribed; and in the event of the death, resignation or disability of either of said commissioners, or persons who may be elected as herein provided for, the vacancy shall be filled by the remaining commissioners until the next election for county officers, as aforesaid, at which time a successor shall be elected for the unexpired term caused by said death, resignation or disability. Election and terms of office of commissioners.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That each member of said board shall, before undertaking to act hereunder, take and subscribe to an oath before the clerk of the superior court of said county, which oath shall be recorded by said clerk, to faithfully and honestly discharge all duties herein prescribed. Oath

Sec. 5. That each member of said board shall receive two dollars per diem for each day actually served as such, and that the clerk of said board, to be appointed as hereinafter set forth, shall receive for his services one hundred dollars for each year he may serve. Compensation

Sec. 6. That the said board shall have the right, and is authorized, to appoint a clerk, who shall take the same oath and in the same manner as its members have, and whose term of office shall be four years. Clerk.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, etc., That the said board shall meet at the court-house of said county on the first Monday in each and every month, or on such other days as it may determine; that said board may adjourn from day to day; that it shall exercise the powers and duties as herein set forth, and that it shall keep a full and complete record of all its actions and doings, subject to the inspection of the grand juries of said county. Sessions.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That said board shall have power to assess, levy and collect such taxes as may be necessary to defray the current expenses and build and repair the public property of the said county; provided, however, that said tax shall not exceed seven-tenths of one per cent. per annum. Taxes, collection of.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the said board shall have the power to supply by appointment all vacancies in county offices and in ordinary elections to fill them in the same manner as said powers are given now to the ordinaries of counties. Vacancies in county offices filled by board.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the said board shall have power to approve all officers' bonds in said county, and to deliver the commissions of said officers sent them by the Governor, and to qualify said officers. Approval of bonds of county officers.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That said board shall have the same right to punish any and every person for contempt as judges of the superior courts of this State have. Contempt, power to punish for.
Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the treasurer of said county shall fully respect this Act. County treasurer to respect act.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That this Act shall not become operative until submitted to the qualified voters of the county at the next general election, and ratified by a majority of the ballots thus cast. Ratification of act by voters.
Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: DEKALB COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of DeKalb; to provide for the election of members thereof by the qualified voters of said county, to define their powers and duties, and for other purposes, approved December 18, 1902; provided, that this repealing Act shall not go into effect until ratified by the qualified voters of said county at an election to be held for that purpose, as herein provided, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the same, That the Act entitled an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of DeKalb; to provide for the election of members thereof by the qualified voters of said county; to define their powers and duties, and for other purposes, approved December 18, 1902, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. DeKalb county, board of commissioners abolished.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That upon this Act becoming effective, as and when hereinafter provided, all the rights, powers and duties heretofore exercised by, imposed upon or discharged by the said board of commissioners of roads and revenues, be, and the same are, hereby imposed upon and made the rights, powers and duties of the ordinary of said county, and shall be assumed, exercised and discharged by him, under the general laws of this State prescribing the duties, rights and powers of ordinaries in county matters, and in the same manner, as exercised by the ordinary of DeKalb county prior to the passage of the said Act creating said board of commissioners of roads and revenues. Powers and duties of imposed upon ordinary.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That this repealing Act shall not go into effect until the same shall have been voted upon and ratified by the favorable vote of a majority of the qualified voters of said county, at an election to be ordered by the ordinary and held for that purpose on the second Tuesday of December, 1904. Said election shall be held under the same rules and regulations as are elections for members of the General Assembly, and all qualified voters of said county qualified to vote under the last general registration-list for said county, shall be qualified to vote in said election. Sixty days' notice
of said election, and the object for which held, shall be given by the ordinary by publication in the newspaper in which the legal advertisements of said county are published once a week. At said election the official ballots shall be furnished by the ordinary, and shall have printed on them For Repeal of Act Creating Board of County Commissioners and Against Repeal of Act Creating Board of County Commissioners, and the voter shall erase For repeal, etc., or Against repeal, etc., accordingly, as he wishes to vote. Ratification of act by voters.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the ordinary shall consolidate the returns of said election and declare the result. If a majority of the qualified voters of said county vote for the repeal of the Act creating the board of county commissioners, then this Act shall become effective and go into effect on the first day of February, 1905, on which day said board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall cease to exist, and all their rights, powers and duties assumed, and on and after that day exercised and discharged by the ordinary of said county, the same as before the Act creating said board went into effect. Should a majority of the qualified voters of said county vote against the repeal of the Act creating said board of county commissioners, then this repealing Act shall not go into effect, but shall be null void and of no effect, and no further election shall be held hereunder.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: DODGE COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Dodge; to provide for the election of members thereof by the qualified voters of said county; to define their powers and duties, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Dodge, to consist of five (5) persons, is hereby created. Said commissioners shall be freeholders and qualified voters of
said county, and shall reside in the road district from which they are elected, which districts are to be defined later on in this Act. Dodge county, board of commissioners for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That for the purpose of this Act the said county of Dodge shall be divided into five (5) road districts, to be constituted as follows, to wit: That first road district shall be composed of Empire and Mullis districts, Georgia Militia. The second road district shall be composed of Jones' and Rawlins' districts, Georgia Militia. The third road district shall be composed of Clark's and Chauncey districts, Georgia Militia. The fourth road district shall be composed of Pondtown and Mitchell's district, Georgia Militia. The fifth road district shall be composed of Eddin's and Lee's districts, Georgia Militia. Road districts.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioners shall be elected at the regular election on the first Wednesday in October, 1904, in the same manner as other county officers are elected, to serve as follows: The commissioners from the first, second and third road districts shall serve for a term of two years, and the commissioners from fourth and fifth road districts shall serve for a term of four years. Thereafter the term of service of each commissioner shall be four years, the three from first, second and third districts to be elected at the regular election in 1906, and the two from the fourth and fifth districts to be elected at the regular election in 1908, and so on thereafter so long as this law remains of force and effect. Said commissioners shall qualify and begin their term of service on the first day of January immediately succeeding their election. Election and terms of office of commissioners.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid That members of the board of commissioners herein created shall receive as their compensation two dollars per day for each day of actual service, said compensation to be paid out of the county treasury by the county treasurer upon the certificate of the chairman and clerk of said board. The said commissioners shall elect the clerk of said board, whose duty it shall be to keep a record of the actings and doings of the board at the court-house in said county, and who shall perform such other duties as may be assigned him by said board. He shall receive such compensation for the performance of his duties as may be fixed by the board in advance of his election, not to exceed two hundred and fifty dollar per year. Said clerk shall not be a member of the said board of commissioners. The said commissioners shall, at their first meeting, elect a chairman of said board from their own membership, fix his term and prescribe his duties. Said commissioners
shall give bond in the sum of five hundred dollars each, with sufficient security, to be approved by the judge of superior court of said county, payable to the ordinary of said county and his successors in office, and conditioned for the faithful performance of their duties as commissioners. Before entering upon their duties said commissioners shall take an oath before the ordinary for the faithful performance of their duties. Compensation. Clerk. Chairman. Bond. Oath

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioners shall have exclusive jurisdiction and control over the following matters, to wit: In directing and controlling all the property of the county, as they may deem expedient, according to law; in levying taxes according to law; in establishing, altering or abolishing roads, bridges and ferries, according to law; establishing, abolishing or changing election precincts or militia districts; in supervising tax-collector's and tax-receiver's books, and allowing the insolvent list of said county; examining and auditing all claims and accounts of officers having the care, management, keeping, collecting or disbursing of money belonging to the county, or appropriated for its use and benefit, and bringing them to settlement; in controlling and managing the convicts of said county according to law; in making rules and regulations for the support of the poor of the county and for the promotion of health, and electing and appointing all minor officers where election is not otherwise provided for by law, such as superintendents and guards of convicts for chain-gang, janitor of court-house, superintendent of pauper farm, county physician and health officer, and other guards as needed and authorized by law; in regulating peddling, and to have and to exercise all powers before vested in the ordinary of said county when sitting for county purposes, and to exercise such other powers as are granted by, or as are indispensable to, the jurisdiction over county matters and county finances. Powers of board.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said board shall hold at least one session on the first Monday in each month at the county-site, and in the court-house building, where it shall keep a regular office. At the request of a majority of the board the chairman may at any time call an extra session, notice of which shall be served on each member. No less than three members of said board shall pass any order on any subject-matter, and this shall be shown on the minutes by a recorded yea and nay vote. The chairman shall vote on all measures before the board. Sessions.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That
any vacancies that may occur in said board by death, resignation, removal or otherwise, shall be filled at a special election called by the ordinary after thirty days' notice thereof shall have been published in the public gazette of the county and to be held under the same laws and regulations, as the regular October State elections, said election to be held for the unexpired term. Removal from any road district by a commissioner elected for such road district shall vacate his office. Vacancies, how filled.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the members of the board of commissioners shall be exempt from jury duty during their term of office. Commissioners exempt from jury duty.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the commissioners shall have published monthly in a newspaper generally circulated in said county a synopsis of the proceedings of each meeting of the board, showing plainly the business transacted at each meeting, paying for same out of the county treasury. Synopsis of proceedings to be published.
Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: DOOLY COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Dooly, to prescribe the duties and powers thereof, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That at the next regular term of the superior court of Dooly county after the passage of this Act, the grand jury of said county shall elect, by ballot, three discreet and upright citizens who are resident freeholders of said county, who shall constitute the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Dooly county, one of whom shall be elected for one year, one for two years and one for three years, and each succeeding grand jury at the fall term of said court shall elect one commissioner, who shall hold office for three years, unless removed by death, resignation, or by
recommendation of a majority of the grand jury for incompetency, malpractice in office, or until their successors in office are elected and qualified. Dooly county, board of commissioners for. Election and terms of office of commissioners.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That each of the persons so elected shall, before entering upon the performance of his duties, take and subscribe before the judge of the superior court of said county, or the ordinary of said county, an oath to faithfully perform the duties of commissioners of roads and revenues under this Act and the Constitution and laws of the State, which oath when taken and signed, shall be recorded in a book of minutes hereinafter required to be kept by the clerk of said board. Oath.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That said board of commissioners shall hold their regular meeting on the first Tuesday in each month at the court-house in the city of Vienna, said courts beginning on the first Tuesday in November after the term of court, when said commissioners shall have been elected as aforesaid; provided that the regular place and time of meeting may be changed to some other place within said county or time by orders on their minutes, of which due notice shall be given by publication in the official newspaper of said county, which orders shall remain of force until rescinded; and, provided further, said commissioners may hold special session at any time they may see fit and proper, or may be called together by a majority of said board for county purposes. Sessions of board.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That said commissioners shall have power to exercise exclusive and original jurisdiction and control in Dooly county over all county matters that are now vested by law in the ordinaries of various counties of the State, so far as relates to roads, bridges, public buildings, property, management of the county jail and its fees, the control and maintenance of its paupers, assessing and collecting taxes, disbursing public money for county purposes, and the execution of all laws in reference thereto. Powers.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That a majority of said commissioners shall constitute a quorum to transact business or exercise any power therein delegated pertaining to the duties of said commissioners. Quorum.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That said commissioners, at their first meeting in each year, shall elect one of their number as chairman, whose duty it shall be to preside at all meetings, to approve and sign minutes of each meeting, and to sign, as chairman, all orders and processes of said commissioners. Chairman.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the treasurer of said county
shall not disburse or pay out any of its funds from the county on any order unless the same shall have been signed by the chairman of said board and the clerk; provided, this shall not apply to jury-scrip, and orders drawn by the judge of the superior court. County funds, disbursement of.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, The board of commissioners shall elect their own clerk with such pay as the board may allow, and it shall be the duty of said clerk to attend all meetings of the commissioners and keep in a well-bound book, to be provided at the expense of the county, full and accurate records and minutes of all their transactions, to file in order of their date all original orders and other papers, and to arrange and keep in order of their filing all petitions and applications and other papers addressed to said commissioners, and to record in a separate book all orders given or approved by said commissioners for the payment of money by the county treasurer; and all books, files and records by this Act required to be used or kept, shall always be open at the county-site for inspection of any taxpayer of the county on demand. Clerk.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the commissioners shall at each term of the superior court prepare and submit to the grand jury a complete statement in writing of the condition of the county property, paupers, finances and public roads and buildings, and shall, whenever called upon by the grand jury, furnish full and distinct information concerning the public business of the county. Report to grand jury.
Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That said commissioners shall be commissioned in the same manner as justices of the peace. How commissioned.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That said board of commissioners shall require said clerk before entering upon the discharge of his duties, to take the same oath taken by them and to enter into bond with good security, payable to said commissioners and their successors in office, conditioned to well and truly do and perform the duties of said office, said bond to be in the sum of one thousand dollars. Clerk, oath and bond of.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That the ordinary of said county of Dooly shall deliver to said commissioners all books and papers relating to the jurisdiction and powers herein conferred upon said commissioners, and said ordinary shall have no power to exercise any of the powers herein conferred upon said commissioners after their election and qualification. Ordinary no longer in charge of county matters.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That said commissioners shall each receive the same pay as jurors for each day while occupied and engaged at the regular and special sessions in transacting
business for county purposes, to be paid by the treasurer of the county on an order drawn by order of the board and signed by the chairman and clerk; and said commissioners shall be exempt from road, jury and militia duty, and shall be subject to prosecution for malpractice in office in the same manner as justices of the peace. Compensation. Exemptions.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That all vacancies in said board shall be filled by the remaining commissioners until the next meeting of the grand jury, which shall fill out the unexpired term. Vacancies in board, how filled.
Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: DOUGHERTY COUNTY, NEW BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to create a new board of commissioners of roads and revenues for Dougherty county, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That a board of commissioners of roads and revenues is hereby created for the county of Dougherty; said board shall consist of three persons elected by the grand jury at the spring term of the superior court for said county and confirmed by the presiding judge; provided, however, that this Act, shall not affect the terms of office of the present incumbents who shall serve out the respective terms for which they have been elected. Dougherty county, board of commissioners for.

Sec. 2. Their terms of office shall be for the period of three years and until their successors are elected and qualified and the first election held hereunder shall be held at the spring term 1905, of the superior court for one commissioner and at each and every spring term thereafter for one commissioner. Terms of office of commissioners.

Sec. 3. That each member of said board before entering upon his duties shall take an oath to honestly and faithfully discharge all the duties of his office according to the Constitution and laws of the State of Georgia, which oath shall be subscribed by them
upon the minutes of the board and before some officer authorized by the laws of the State to administer oaths. Oath.

Sec. 4. That vacancies in office shall be filled by appointment of the judge of the superior court of Dougherty county until the next spring term of the superior court of said county, at which time the grand jury shall elect for the unexpired term subject to the confirmation of the judge of the superior court as hereinbefore provided. Vacancies in board, how filled.

Sec. 5. That said board at their first meeting after the spring term of the superior court in each year shall elect one of their number chairman, whose duty it shall be to preside at all meetings of the board and who shall retain his position for the term of one year and until his successor is elected. Chairman

Sec. 6. That said board shall hold regular sessions, on the first Monday in each month at the county-site, and may hold special sessions at any time, that their duties may require. At all such meetings the chairman, if present, shall preside, but in all cases two shall constitute a quorum, to do business, and the concurrence of two shall decide all questions. It shall be the duty of the sheriff, when required, to attend the sittings of the board, for which service he shall be allowed three dollars per day. Sessions.

Sec. 7. That said commissioners shall have exclusive jurisdiction and control over the following matters, to wit: In directing and controlling all the property of the county as they may deem expedient according to law; in levying taxes according to law; in establishing, altering or abolishing roads, bridges and ferries in conformity to law; in establishing, abolishing and changing election precincts and militia districts; in supervising the tax-collector's books, and allowing the insolvent list for said county; in settling all claims against the county, examining and auditing all claims or accounts of officers having the care, management, keeping, collecting or disbursement of money belonging to the county, or appropriated for its use and benefit, and bringing them to a settlement; in making such rules and regulations for the support of the poor of the county and for promotion of health as are not inconsistent with law; in regulating peddling; to have and to exercise all the powers now granted to the court of ordinary when sitting for county purposes. Jurisdiction and powers.

Sec. 8. The clerk of the superior court shall be ex officio clerk of the board of commissioners and shall attend the sessions of the Board and shall keep a record of the actings and doings of said board in a well-bound book to be provided at the expense of the county and shall receive such compensation as shall be
fixed by the board; provided, that the said compensation shall not exceed three hundred dollars per annum. Clerk.

Sec. 9. That said commissioners shall be paid out of the treasury of said county, as salaries for their services, the sum of two hundred dollars per annum for each commissioner and same shall be paid quarterly. Compensation.

Sec. 10. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the above and foregoing be, and the same are, hereby repealed; provided, however, that this Act shall not go into effect until a bill to be entitled, an Act to repeal an Act, approved August 20, 1872, establishing a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for Dougherty county, so far as said Act applies to Dougherty county, and to repeal the several Acts amendatory thereto, to wit: An Act approved February 22, 1873, an Act approved September 28, 1881, an Act approved August 26, 1891, an Act approved September 19, 1891 shall have become a law. Act to take effect, when.

law.shorttitle: DOUGHERTY COUNTY CHAIN-GANG TO WORK STREETS OF ALBANY.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize and require the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Dougherty county to work the county chain-gang upon the streets of the city of Albany; to prescribe the length of time of such work during each year; to prescribe the regulations under which such work is to be done, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Dougherty county be and they are hereby authorized and required to work the county chain-gang of said county of Dougherty upon the streets of the city of Albany for not exceeding three months in each year after the passage of this Act beginning with the present year 1904, except that said board are not authorized and required to work longer than forty days during the present year. At such times, all mules, plows, wagons, scrapes, utensils, guards and all other things pertaining to the convicts and to the road
equipment shall be used, if necessary, upon the streets of the city of Albany free of any charge to said city. The county convicts and road force shall do such work at such time as may be suitable to said board and at such places as may be designated by the mayor and council of the city of Albany, or its authority. The streets shall be worked and graded under the direction of such person or persons as are so authorized by the mayor and council of the city of Albany; and the mayor and council of the city of Albany shall not be called upon or required to pay any portion or any part of the expense of feeding, maintaining, guarding or caring for said county convicts. City of Albany, streets of to be worked by county chain-gang.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: DOUGHERTY COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act approved August 20, 1872, establishing a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for Dougherty county so far as said Act applies to Dougherty county, and to repeal the several Acts amendatory thereto, to wit: An Act approved February 22, 1873, an Act approved September 28, 1881, an Act approved August 26, 1891, an Act approved September 19, 1891.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the following Acts of the Legislature constituting the laws relative to the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Dougherty county, including the original Act creating said board and defining its powers and duties, together with the several Acts amendatory thereto, be, and the same are, hereby repealed as follows, to wit: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to establish a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the counties of Habersham and Lowndes; to define their duties, and for other purposes therein named, approved December 11, 1871, and to make the provisions of this Act and the Act to which it is amendatory applicable to the county of
Dougherty, approved August 20, 1872, and same is hereby repealed so far as said Act applies to Dougherty county; an Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to amend an Act to establish a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the counties of Habersham and Lowndes, to define their duties, and for other purposes therein named, approved December 11, 1871, and to make the provisions of this Act to which it is amendatory applicable to the county of Dougherty, approved August 20, 1872, approved February 22, 1873, and same is hereby repealed as far as the same applies to Dougherty county: An Act to provide for the compensation of the commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Dougherty, and the manner of paying the same, approved September 28, 1881; an Act to repeal an Act providing for the compensation of the commissioenrs of roads and revenues for the county of Dougherty, and the manner of paying the same, approved September 28, 1881, and substituting in lieu thereof a provision for the payment of a fixed salary to said commissioners, approved August 26, 1891; an Act to amend an Act approved February 22, 1873, and the Acts approved August 20, 1872, and December 11, 1871, to which the same is amendatory in so far as they relate to the establishment of a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for Dougherty county, and for other purposes relative to said county therein named by changing the term of office of said commissioners, prescribing the manner of their appointment, and for other purposes, approved September 19, 1891. Dougherty county, board of commissioners for abolished.

law.shorttitle: ELBERT COUNTY, DAMS ACROSS SAVANNAH RIVER IN, AUTHORIZED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize O. H. Sheffield, and his associates or assigns to construct a dam across Savannah River in Elbert county at a point between Mattox's Mill and the Seaboard Air Line Railroad bridge, and to authorize said parties to construct a dam across Savannah River at Gregg Shoals, near the mouth of Pickens Creek, in Elbert county, Georgia; and to also authorize Granville Beal, his associates, their successors and assigns, to construct a dam or dams across the Savannah River at Trotter Shoals in the county of Elbert, for the purpose of developing water-power for commercial uses, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia,
That from and after the passage of this Act O. H. Sheffield, of Fulton county, Georgia, his associates, successors and assigns, are hereby authorized and empowered to construct and maintain a dam for manufacturing, trade or commercial purposes, across the Savannah River at a point in Elbert county, Georgia, between the mill place known as W. H. Mattox's Mill and where the Seaboard Air Line Railroad bridge crosses said river in said county, and said parties are hereby authorized and empowered to construct and maintain a dam for manufacturing, trade or commercial purposes, across the Savannah River at Gregg Shoals, near the mouth of Pickens Creek in Elbert county, Georgia; and Granville Beal, his associates, their successors and assigns, are hereby authorized and empowered to construct and maintain a dam or dams for manufacturing, trade or commercial purposes across the Savannah River at a point or points in Elbert county along or across what is known as Trotter Shoals in said county; provided, that in the erection or construction of said dam or dams said parties building the same shall construct and keep in good order proper fish-ways or fish-ladders, so constructed and arranged that all species of fish in said stream can ascend or descend said stream; and provided further, that said parties constructing and maintaining said dam or dams shall not in anywise be exempt hereunder for the payment of all damages caused by or resulting form the maintenance of said dam or dams. Elbert county, dams across Savannah river in, authorized
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all conflicting laws are hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: FAYETTE COUNTY COMMISSIONERS, COMPENSATION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act reducing the number of county commissioners of Fayette county, approved December 12, 1901, by striking from the second section of said Act, the following words: Provided, the entire salary for any one year shall not exceed fifty dollars ($50.00), for each member of said board, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the
State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the Act approved December 12, 1901, reducing the number of county commissioners for Fayette county, and fixing their compensation, is hereby amended, by striking all of section 2 of said Act, after the word service, in the second line of said section, to wit: Provided, the entire amount of salary for any one year shall not exceed fifty dollars ($50.00), for each member of said board, so that said section of said Act will read as follows: Be it enacted further, that the compensation of said board shall be two dollars ($2.00) for each day's service. Fayette county commissioners, compensation of.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: McDUFFIE COUNTY, INSOLVENT COSTS, HOW PAID.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for the payment of the insolvent costs of constables, justices of the peace and notaries public of McDuffie county in misdemeanor criminal cases; provided, that there shall not be paid over ten dollars in any one case.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act, it shall be lawful for constables, justices of the peace and notaries public of McDuffie county, Georgia, to be paid all insolvent costs in misdemeanor criminal cases; provided, that the amount due and claimed in each case is not over ten dollars. McDuffie county, insolvent costs in.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That whenever there is a commitment trial in a misdemeanor criminal case in said county of McDuffie, the justice of the peace, who presides over said trial shall make out a bill of the costs due him and the constable or other officer serving the warrant and other papers in said case, and present the same to the ordinary of said county, or any other official or officials, who may have charge of county matters; and it shall be the duty of said ordinary, or other authority, to draw a warrant on the treasury of said county for the amount of the same; provided, that the bill so presented shall not exceed ten dollars in any one case, and provided further, that no bill for costs shall be presented to the ordinary, or such
other authority, until after there is a trial and conviction of the criminal who was committed by said justice of the peace. How paid.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That no cost shall be paid said officers under this Act whenever fines are imposed and paid, but in such event said officers must obtain their cost out of said fines. No costs when fines are paid.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That whenever the costs in any case amounts to over ten dollars, the ten dollars so paid shall be prorated between the justice of the peace or notary public and constable in proportion to what is due each. Costs, how distributed.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: McINTOSH COUNTY, PROTECTION OF STOCK IN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to protect the owners of live stock in the county of McIntosh, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, it shall be unlawful for any person to butcher in McIntosh county for the purpose of selling the same, any cow, bull, steer, heifer, yearling, sheep, goat, lamb, kid or hog of any age or description unless such person shall within twelve hours from the time of butchering exhibit to a registrar the ears of the stock so butchered and shall also give a full description of the stock killed. McIntosh county, ears of animal butchered to be exhibited to registrar.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the county commissioners for McIntosh county shall elect two or more registrars of stock for each militia district in said county, who shall hold office for one year and until their successors are elected; they shall be under the supervision and control of said commissioners. Said commissioners shall have the power to remove any registrar for cause and all vacancies among the registrars may be filled at any regular meeting of said commissioners. Registrars of stock.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the registrars so elected shall be furnished with a book by the county commissioners, in which shall be recorded the name of the person slaughtering, whether white or colored, date of killing, time when report is
made to him, a full description of the stock butchered as reported to him, and shall describe the ears as exhibited to him; for which service the registrar shall charge and collect the following fees: For each cow, bull, steer, heifer or yearling, 15 cents; for each sheep, goat or hog, 10 cents; for each lamb, kid or veal, 5 cents. Records of registrars, how kept. Fees of registrars.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That each registrar shall present to each and every grand jury of McIntosh county his said book of the record of butchered stock for examination. Grand jury to inspect records.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That nothing herein contained shall apply to incorporated cities or towns in said county of McIntosh. Incorporated towns excepted.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That any person violating the provisions of this Act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed in section 1039, volume 3 of the Code of Georgia of 1895. Penalty.
