Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: MITCHELL COUNTY, DISPENSARY FOR.
law.fulltitle: An Act to prohibit the sale of spirituous, vinous and malt liquors and intoxicating bitters and ciders in the county of Mitchell, except as in this Act provided; to regulate and control the sale thereof through the medium of dispensaries in each of the several incorporated towns of said county; to establish and perpetuate a board of commissioners to establish said dispensaries, and to prescribe their duties, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act it shall not be lawful for any person to sell spirituous, vinous or malt liquors, and intoxicating bitters and ciders in the county of Mitchell, except as provided for in this Act; and any person who may do so shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction shall be punished as prescribed by section 1039, volume 3 of the Code of Georgia of 1895. No municipal authority of any city or town in said county shall have authority to grant license or renew the same for the sale of spirituous,
vinous or malt liquors, or intoxicating bitters and ciders, to any person or persons after the passage of this Act. Mitchell county, sale of liquors or other intoxicants in.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the persons now holding the position of commissioners of roads and revenues of Mitchell county, and their successors to be elected, shall be known as the dispensary commissioners, in and for the county of Mitchell, and the same are hereby constituted a body corporate under the name and style of the dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county, for the purpose of establishing dispensaries in the several incorporated cities or towns in said county for the sale of the spirituous, vinous and malt liquors and intoxicating bitters and ciders. Dispensary commissioners.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That there shall be appointed as hereinafter provided, from among the citizens of said county, three upright persons for each of the dispensaries established under this Act, who shall be known as supervisors for said dispensaries, whose duties shall be to establish and maintain in each of said towns or cities at some suitable and convenient point, in each of said incorporated towns or cities, a dispensary for the sale of spirituous, vinous, malt liquors, or intoxicating bitters and ciders. Dispensary supervisors.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the supervisors provided for in section 3 of this Act shall be appointed and elected by the mayor and council of the town or city in which the dispensary is located at either a regular or called meeting of said city council, within thirty days after the passage of this Act, and if said supervisors are not elected by said city council within thirty days, then as soon thereafter as is practicable; the names of the three citizens so chosen to serve as supervisors shall be at once reported in writing to the board of county commissioners of Mitchell county, and at the next regular meeting held by said board, they shall have the right to object to either one or more of the supervisors so elected, and the objection shall be filed with the mayor of said town in writing within five days after said meeting of said board of county commissioners, and it shall then be the duty of said mayor to call together the city council of said town in special sessions for the purpose of electing other citizens to serve as supervisors in the place of those rejected by said board of county commissioners. Said three supervisors shall be appointed for each of the incorporated towns or cities of said county as above provided. The supervisors thus chosen shall hold their offices for two years from the date of their appointment and until their successors are appointed and qualified. Any
vacancy occurring in either board of supervisors shall be filled by the authority appointing them, as soon after said vacancy occurs as practicable. Any of said supervisors may be removed from office by the dispensary commissioners of said county at any time upon ten days' written notice for any neglect of duty or any other good cause shown; said supervisors shall select one of their number to act as chairman of the board for each of said incorporated towns or cities. Supervisors, election and term of office of.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the treasurer of town or city in which said dispensary is established shall be the treasurer of said dispensary, and for his services as such treasurer he shall receive one-half of one per cent. of all moneys handled by him provided his salary shall not exceed $75.00 per annum. Said treasurer shall give a bond with good security in a sum to be fixed by the dispensary commissioners, not to exceed two thousand dollars, payable to said dispensary commissioners, conditioned for the faithful accounting of all moneys that may come into his hands as such treasurer, which bond is to be approved by the dispensary commissioners. Treasurer.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the board of supervisors to be selected for each of the dispensaries established under this Act shall elect a man of good moral character and sober habits as dispensary manager of said dispensary. Said dispensary manager shall hold his office for two years from the date of his election, and may be removed from office by said supervisors for neglect of duty or for any good cause shown on ten days' written notice, and said supervisors shall, at any time, without notice have the power to suspend said dispensary manager, and put said dispensary in charge of another suitable person, to be selected by them, until the charges preferred against him are finally disposed of. In case of any vacancy for any reason arising in the office of dispensary manager, the board of supervisors for said dispensary shall elect a successor for the unexpired term. Such dispensary manager shall at all times be subject to the orders, the rules and regulations of said supervisors, and shall, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, give bond with good security in the sum of two thousand dollars, payable to the said dispensary commissioners, to be approved by them, conditioned for the faithful accounting for all goods and moneys that may come into his hands as such dispensary manager, and for the faithful performance of all duties required of him; and said dispensary manager before entering upon the discharge of his duties shall also take and subscribe an oath, before any officer authorized
to administer oaths in this State, that he will faithfully and honestly discharge his duties as dispensary manager. He shall receive such compensation as may be fixed by said board of supervisors, not to exceed seventy-five dollars per month, including all help furnished him by the said supervisors, but his compensation shall not in any way depend upon the amount of his sales. Manager.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That each of said boards of supervisors shall when appointed or selected, for and in the name of the dispensary commissioners of said county establish and maintain a dispensary in the town or city for which they were appointed for the sale of such liquors as before mentioned for cash only. Said boards of supervisors shall direct and control the purchase and sale of such liquors. All funds arising from the sale of said liquors or other sources connected with the operation of said dispensaries shall be deposited with the treasurer of the respective dispensaries. All debts incurred in establishing and maintaining any dispensary under this Act shall be paid out of the funds so deposited upon the order of the board of supervisors or a majority of them appointed for said dispensary. Each dispensary as established under this act shall be maintained and operated from the profits arising from the sale of liquors in said dispensary; provided, that to inaugurate a dispensary and to purchase the first stock therefor, the board of supervisors for such dispensary shall be authorized to borrow money or pledge the credit of the dispensary commissioners of said county; but they can not bind the county of Mitchell, or the town or city in which said dispensary is run, in any way. Each dispensary operated under this Act shall be separate from the others, and in no event shall the profits of one dispensary be used to maintain another, but each must be self-sustaining, and any unproductive dispensary shall be discontinued upon the order of the board of supervisors as soon as that fact is ascertained. Each of said boards of supervisors herein provided for shall, from time to time, make rules and regulations for the operation of dispensary under their supervision. The quantity of liquors sold to any one person at any one time by any of said dispensaries shall not exceed four gallons, and in no event shall such liquors be furnished in quantities less than one-half pint, and none of said liquors shall be drunk in the building, or on the premises where said dispensaries are located. The dispensaries established under this Act shall not be opened before sunrise, and shall be closed each day at sunset, except that during the winter season they may be opened at six o'clock a. m., and closed by six o'clock p. m. The manager
of each dispensary in addition to the regulations provided herein, and the rules and regulations that may be prescribed by the boards of supervisors, shall be bound by all the laws of this State regulating the sale of liquors to minors, drunken persons, and on Sundays and election days. Dispensaries. Sales.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no dispensary manager selected under this Act shall sell to any person or persons any of said liquors except in sealed packages, and whenever an original package is broken it shall at once be bottled up and sealed in the presence of said board of supervisors, or a majority of them. Said supervisors for each of said dispensaries shall make a monthly report in duplicate to the dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county, and the council of the town or city in which said dispensary is located, showing the amount of liquors bought, in an itemized statement of each original package and price paid for same, and also the amount of sales, the expenses and the stock on hand at the end of each month. Said supervisors shall receive a salary, that of the chairman of the said board of supervisors not to exceed one hundred dollars per annum, and the other two members of said board to receive a salary not to exceed fifty dollars each, to be fixed by said board of county commissioners, and no member of the board of county commissioners, or member of the council of the town or city in which said dispensary is located, shall be eligible to hold the office of supervisor during the term for which they have been elected. Packages. Supervisors, report and salary of.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the books of accounts, and all other papers connected with either of the dispensaries established under this Act, shall at all times be subject to the inspection of the mayor and town council of the town or city in which same is located, and the grand jury of said county. The chairman of each of the boards of supervisors selected under this Act shall be under the special duty of supervising the dispensary established and being operated by said board of supervisors, but he shall have no more power than any other supervisor. Each of said supervisors shall take and subscribe before any officer authorized to administer oaths in this State, an oath that he will not receive any gift, rebate, commission, or other gain from any source connected with said dispensary, either directly or indirectly, except the salary herein provided for. The oaths required to be taken and subscribed to by each of the officers to be chosen under this Act shall be taken and subscribed to in writing, and the same shall be filed with the board of county
commissioners of said county, and recorded by the clerk of said board on the minutes of said board of county commissioners. Books and accounts. Supervisors, duties of.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That each of the boards of supervisors selected under this Act shall, once every three months in the year, set aside as dividend or profits all moneys belonging to said dispensary that can be taken from it without embarrassing the continuance of said business, with a stock of such size as the board of supervisors of each dispensary may deem proper; provided, that said board of supervisors shall at all times have a right to retain a sufficient amount of funds to cash all bills, and to avail themselves of all discounts for cash on such bills. The money thus set aside as dividends or profits shall be at once divided as follows, to wit, one-half shall be paid into the treasury of the town or city in which said dispensary is located, and the other half shall be paid into the county treasury of Mitchell county, to be used in making and working the public roads of said county; said profits so deposited in said county treasury to be paid out on the order of the board of county commissioners for the purpose above named, in making and working the public roads of said county; and said county treasurer shall give such additional bond and security for the safekeeping and accounting for said money arising from the profits of said dispensary as may be fixed by said board of county commissioners, not to exceed ten thousand dollars. The compensation to be paid said county treasurer for receiving and paying out the funds coming into his hands from the profits of said dispensary shall be fixed by said board of county commissioners in a sum not to exceed one hundred and fifty dollars per annum. Profits.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That all license issued prior to the passage of this Act by any of the towns or cities in Mitchell county for the sale of any of the liquors named in this Act are revoked from and after the passage of this Act, and the board of supervisors to be selected to establish and operate dispensary for such town or city in said county as may have issued a license to sell said liquors in said town are authorized to purchase any stock of liquors that may be on hand and in the possession of such persons as may hold license from any such town or city, at the actual cost price laid down at the place of business in said town, and use such stock of liquors in establishing dispensary under this Act. Said dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county shall have authority to reimburse any person who may have been licensed to sell said liquors by any town or city in said county prior to the passage of this Act, for so much of the license
tax as may have not been realized by the profits of such business; provided, that this bill will not become operative until it is ratified by a majority of the qualified voters of Mitchell county at an election called for that purpose, and the same held under the supervision of the commissioners of that county. Licenses to sell revoked. Election for dispensaries.
Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: MONROE COUNTY, RUNNING OF AUTOMOBILES, ETC., IN, REGULATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to regulate the running of locomobiles, automobiles, motor-cycles, and all other similar machines, while using the public roads in Monroe county; to prescribe the duties of those in charge of said machines, and to provide for the punishment of said parties when this law is violated, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act it shall be unlawful for any one in charge of any automobile, locomobile, motor-cycle, or other similar machine, to run the same over the public roads in the county of Monroe, in said State, at a greater rate of speed than twenty miles an hour. Monroe county, running of automobiles, etc., in, regulated.

Sec. 2. That when any one in charge of or running an automobile, locomobile, motor-cycle, or other similar machine, on the public roads in the county of Monroe, is meeting or approaching any one who is driving or riding any horse or mule, he shall bring his machine to a full stop at least one hundred yards from said horse or mule, and shall shut off all his machinery and stop all noise being made by the same until said horse or mule has passed his machine and is at least fifty yards beyond the same. Approaching horses or mules being ridden or driven.

Sec. 3. That when any one running or in charge of any automobile, locomobile, motor-cycle, or other similar machine, on the public roads in the said county of Monroe, shall approach from the rear any one riding or driving any horse or mule, he shall blow his horn or whistle before he approaches within one hundred yards of said horse or mule, and shall continue to slacken
the speed of his machine so as to enable the person in front of him to unhitch his horse or mule or get out of the way of said machine. Approaching horses or mules from the rear.

Sec. 4. That when any one using a locomobile, automobile, motor-cycle, or other similar machine, on the public roads in said county of Monroe, is approaching a horse or mule hitched to a vehicle and tied to a post, tree or other fastening, he shall stop his machine at least one hundred yards from said horse or mule and give the owner of said horse or mule a chance to unhitch him from the vehicle, or remove him to a place of safety. Approaching horses or mules hitched.

Sec. 5. That the person running or in charge of a locomobile, automobile, motor-cycle, or other similar machine, violating either of the above provisions, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished for the same as prescribed by paragraph 1039 of the Criminal Code of Georgia. Penalty.
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: NEWTON COUNTY, ACT CREATING BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to establish a board of county commissioners for the county of Newton, approved February 27, 1877, by striking out of said Act, in section 1, line four, the word five, and inserting in lieu thereof the word three, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That section 1 of the above-recited Act be, and the same is, amended as follows: By striking out of section 1, line four, of said Act the word five, and inserting in lieu thereof the word three. Newton county, number of commissioners for.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: OGLETHORPE COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to abolish the board of county commissioners of roads and revenues, in and for the county of Oglethorpe, created by an Act of the General Assembly approved August 26, 1872, and to repeal said Act.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That on and after the first day of January, 1905, at noon, the board of county commissioners of roads and revenues, in and for the county of Oglethorpe, created by the Act of the General Assembly, approved August 26, 1872, be, and the same is, hereby abolished, and said Act creating the same is hereby repealed. Oglethorpe county, board of commissioners for abolished.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: OGLETHORPE COUNTY, OFFICE OF COMMISSIONER FOR CREATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to create the office of commissioner of roads and revenues in and for Oglethorpe county, provide the methods of the election of such officer, prescribe his duties and powers, fix his salary and term of office, provide for the management of county affairs in interim, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the office of commissioner of roads and revenues in and for Oglethorpe county, said State, is hereby created. Said commissioner shall be elected at the regular election to be held for State and county officers on the first Wednesday in October, 1904, and biennially thereafter in the same manner as other county officers are elected; and the said commissioner so elected at said election
shall, after qualification, enter immediately upon the discharge of his duties, and shall hold said office for the term of two (2) years, and until his successor is elected and qualified. Persons eligible to hold other county offices shall be eligible to hold said office. Should a vacancy occur in said office, the same shall be filled by special election, called and held in the same manner, and be governed by the same rules and regulations and qualifications, as to voters as apply to the election of clerks of the superior courts. In the interim the ordinary of said county shall perform all of the duties of said office and assume all of the responsibilities of the said commissioner, and receive the same compensation, at the same rate of said commissioner, to be prorated as to the length of time he shall serve. Oglethorpe county, office of commissioner for created.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the commissioner, as herein provided, shall be commissioned by the Governor of said State for the term of office for which he is elected, and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of said office shall subscribe to the oath now required by law of county officers, and shall also give a solvent bond in a solvent surety or guarantee company, to be approved by the ordinary of said county, payable to the Governor of said State and his successors in office, in the sum of ten thousand ($10,000) dollars, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties as such commissioner. Commissioner, commission, bond, etc.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioner shall have exclusive jurisdiction over all county matters, and shall be invested with all the powers and duties as to the revenues of Oglethorpe county in levying and collecting taxes, and over revenues of the county and in disposing of said taxes and revenues which have been heretofore legally exercised by said board of commissioners of roads and revenues of the county of Oglethorpe. Said commissioner shall have exclusive jurisdiction and control over all county property and all roads and bridges in the county, and shall be charged with the duty of maintaining and keeping the same in proper condition, and shall be vested with all the powers and charged with all the duties as required of county authorities as prescribed by law in reference thereto. He shall have exclusive jurisdicton over all subject-matters enumerated in section 4238 of the Civil Code of this State of 1895, and shall be vested with all other powers and duties conferred by the laws of this State upon ordinaries, when sitting for county purposes, and such as are conferred generally upon county authorities. Powers and duties.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioner shall hold a regular court for the transaction of the public business of the county connected with the county matters in the court-house in Lexington, in said county, on the first Tuesday in each month, or at such other time as he may fix and determine by proper order passed and entered upon his minutes. He shall keep, or have kept, accurate minutes of all county matters transacted by him, and shall keep, or have kept, proper and correct books of accounts of all public moneys received and expended under his direction, showing sources from which all such moneys are received and for what purposes expended. Such books shall be at all times subject to inspection by any citizen as other public books and records. He shall publish monthly in the newspaper published in said county in which the legal advertisements are published an itemized statement of all money received and expended by him during the month just preceding such publication, and the sources from which received and the purposes for which expended, the expense for such publication to be paid out of the county treasury. He shall have power to administer oaths and hear testimony as to all matters over which he has jurisdiction, and when setting as a court shall have power to punish for contempt under the same rules and regulations as are provided for other courts. Commissioner's court. Duties of commissioner.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That said commissioner shall receive for his compensation, to be paid out of the county treasury, a salary of eight hundred dollars per annum for his services, to be paid monthly at the end of each month's services; but the salary of said commissioner may be increased, if recommended by a majority of two successive grand juries of said county, to a sum not to exceed nine hundred ($900.00) dollars, said increase to be paid out of the county treasury. He is authorized to employ a clerk to keep his minutes and books, and to pay such clerk such salary as he may fix, not to exceed two hundred ($200.00) dollars per annum, to be paid out of the county treasury. He is authorized to employ a superintendent of roads, bridges and labor, who understands drainage and road building, and such overseers and other employees as may be necessary for the best interest of the county, for the purpose of maintaining and working the roads and public property of the county, and shall fix the compensation of such persons at such reasonable sum as he may think proper, except as otherwise prescribed by law. Compensation. Clerk.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That
said commissioner shall make a report to the grand jury at each regular session of said court should be held, then at the first session adjourned or special thereafter of such court, and shall accompany such report with an itemized statement of his receipts and expenditures, and the sources from whence received, and the purpose for which expended and the vouchers therefor, and also the number of persons in said county subject to road duty, and the number of such persons who have paid the commutation tax, and the amount of money received from all persons as commutation tax, and the number of persons subject to road duty who have worked out their time on the roads, and the number of persons subject to road duty who have neither worked their time on the road nor paid the commutation tax, why the work is not done, nor the commutation tax paid, and what steps, if any, are taken to enforce these duties. Report.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all duties heretofore imposed upon the board of commissioners of roads and revenues in the county of Oglethorpe, and all of the privileges granted to said board, shall be, and the same are, hereby conferred upon said commissioner. Duties.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all moneys for public road purposes arising from commutation tax shall be collected by, and shall be paid directly to, said commissioner, and no commission shall be paid to such commissioner, nor to the county treasurer, nor to any other officer or person for receiving, collecting or paying out the same. Commutation tax.
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this bill shall become operative and go into effect at noon from and after the 17th day of October, 1904. Act to become operative, when.
Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: PICKENS COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled an Act to provide a board of commissioners of roads and revenues of the county of Pickens, to define their powers and duties, and for other purposes, approved December 16, 1901.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That an Act entitled an Act to provide a board of commissioners of roads and revenues of the county of Pickens, to define their powers and duties, and for other purposes, approved December 16, 1901, and this Act is, hereby repealed, to take effect January 1, 1905. Pickens county, board of commissioners for abolished.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: PIKE COUNTY, MAKING INTOXICATING LIQUORS IN PROHIBITED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to make it unlawful to distill, manufacture, make or produce any alcohol, spirituous, malt or intoxicating liquors from grains from and after December 31, 1904, in the county of Pike, and to prescribe a penalty for violation of the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after December 31, 1904, it shall be unlawful to distill, manufacture, make or produce from grains any alcohol, spirituous, malt or intoxicating liquors in the county of Pike. Pike county, making of intoxicating liquors in prohibited.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That any person or persons, firm or corporation, their agents or employees, violating the provisions of this Act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed in section 1039 of the Code of 1895. Penalty.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: RICHMOND COUNTY, EMPLOYMENT OF MISDEMEANOR CONVICTS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize and empower the village of Harrisonville, in said State, to arrange with the proper authorities of Richmond county for the working on the roads or other public works of said county such persons as may be convicted in the municipal or corporation court of said village of Harrisonville, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that the village of Harrisonville, in Richmond county, Georgia, is hereby authorized and empowered through its legally constituted authorities, to make arrangements with the proper authorities of the county of Richmond for the working on the roads or other public works of said county such persons as may be convicted in the municipal or corporation court of said village of Harrisonville. Harrisonville, employment of misdemeanor convicts in village of.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be; and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: RICHMOND COUNTY, ACT ESTABLISHING REFORMATORY INSTITUTE AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend section 5 of an Act establishing a reformatory institute in the county of Richmond, in this State, approved October 5, 1885, and the Act amendatory thereof, approved October 22, 1887, by inserting after the word law, tenth line of the original Act, the words upon the conviction of any person, sixteen years of age and under, in the recorder's court of the city of Augusta, for violating any of the ordinances of the said city, the recorder shall have, and he is, hereby clothed with authority to sentence such person to said reformatory institute, there to be kept and governed according to law for a period of not more than three years, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia,
and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act section 5 of an Act establishing a reformatory institute in the county of Richmond, in this State, approved October 5, 1885, and the Act amendatory thereof, approved October 22, 1887, be, and the same is, hereby amended by inserting after the word law, tenth line of the original Act, the words upon the conviction of any person sixteen years of age and under, in the recorder's court of the city of Augusta, for violating any of the ordinances of the said city, the recorder shall have, and is, hereby clothed with authority to sentence such person to said reformatory institute, there to be kept and governed according to law for a period of not more than three years, so that said section, thus amended, shall read as follows: That the city court of Richmond county and the recorder's court of the city of Augusta may, upon the complaint of the mayor of said city, or any of the commissioners of the reformatory institute herein provided for, that any minor within the ages prescribed and indicated in section 4 of this Act lives an idle and dissolute life, and that his or her parents are dead, or, if living, do neglect to provide suitable employment, or to exercise salutary control over such minor, shall have power, on conviction thereof, to sentence such minor to said institute, to be there kept and governed according to law; upon the conviction of any person sixteen years of age and under in the recorder's court of the city of Augusta for violating any of the ordinances of said city, the recorder shall have, and he is, hereby clothed with authority to sentence such person to said reformatory institute, there to be kept and governed according to law for a period of not more than three years; provided, That nothing herein contained shall be construed to take away the right of appeal in the cases aforesaid from said city and recorder's court, respectively, to the superior court. Richmond county, reformatory in, period of confinement.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SUMTER COUNTY, INSOLVENT COSTS OF OFFICERS, HOW PAID.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Sumter county to pay to the officers of court the fees prescribed by law for such officers in each case of conviction, where the person so convicted is worked upon the chain-gang of said county; provided, the amount of the fee to be paid to the solicitor-general or the city court solicitor shall not exceed $10.50 in each case.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Sumter county is required to pay to the officers of court the fees prescribed by law for such officers in each case of conviction where the person so convicted is worked upon the county chain-gang of said county; provided, however, that the amount of the fee to be paid to the solicitor-general or the city court solicitor shall not exceed $10.50 in any case. Sumter county, insolvent costs of officers, how paid when convicts worked on chain-gang.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That before the officers of court shall be paid said costs, they shall make out the bill thereof and have it approved by the judge of the court imposing the sentence, and when so approved the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Sumter county is authorized to pay the same out of the general fund of said county, or out of such particular fund of said county as said board may direct.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SUMTER COUNTY, COMMISSIONERS OF, ELECTION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in the counties of Floyd, Berrien, Effingham, Schley, Sumter and Greene, approved December 13, 1871, and the several Acts amendatory thereto, so far only as the same relates to the county of Sumter, by changing the existing methods of electing such commissioners in and for said county of Sumter, and providing how such commissioners for Sumter county shall be hereafter chosen and elected, the time and manner of electing the same, and amending particularly the amendatory Act approved October, 5, 1885, so as to provide for the election of the members of said board of commissioners of roads and revenues for Sumter county by the qualified voters of said county, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the Act approved December 13, 1871, entitled an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in the counties of Floyd, Berrien, Effingham, Schley, Sumter and Greene, and the several Acts amendatory thereto, particularly amending hereby the amendatory Act approved October 5, 1885, be, and the same (in so far only as they relate to the county of Sumter) are, hereby amended by striking and repealing all of sections 2, 3, 4 and 5 of said amendatory Act so approved October 5, 1885, and inserting and enacting in lieu of said stricken and repealed sections the following: At the next general election after the passage of this Act, to wit, the general election to be held on the first Wednesday in October, 1904, there shall be chosen and elected by the qualified voters of Sumter county, Georgia, five persons to serve as a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for said county of Sumter, whose term of office shall begin on the first day of January, 1905, upon their election and qualification, as herein provided for, and it is herein and hereby enacted and provided that the official terms of the members of the present board of commissioners of roads and revenues for said county of Sumter shall cease and terminate upon the election and qualification of their successors, as herein provided for. And at the general
election in October, every fourth year after the October election, 1904, there shall be elected a board of commissioners for said county, consisting of five persons, citizens of said county, and chosen in the manner hereinbefore provided, to succeed the then existing board, and the election managers shall certify to the ordinary of said county of Sumter the result of such election, and thereupon each of the five candidates receiving the highest number of votes for commissioners of roads and revenues at such elections shall qualify by taking and subscribing before said ordinary to the oath as set forth in section 6 of the Act approved December 13, 1871, and it is hereby provided that all vacancies from death, resignation, or otherwise, which may occur in said board of commissioners, shall be filled by appointment of the ordinary of said county, pending the next general election succeeding such vacancy and appointment; and at such succeeding election incumbents for such unexpired terms shall be chosen, elected and qualified in the manner as by this Act contemplated. All citizens and residents of said county who are eligible to office as legislators shall be eligible to serve as such commissioners of roads and revenues of Sumter county. Sumter county, election of commissioners for.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: TALBOT COUNTY, COMMISSIONERS OF, ELECTION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act, approved December 8, 1894, entitled an Act to amend an Act to establish a board of commissioners of Talbot, approved February 16, 1876, so as to change the time of election.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the first section of the above-recited Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out of section 1 the word January in the third line in said section between the words in and next, and inserting therefor the word October, so when said sections are amended the same shall read as follows: The
board of commissioners provided for in said Act shall be elected on the first Wednesday in October next by the qualified voters of said county in the same manner as now prescribed for electing the clerks of the superior court, and the managers of said election shall, on the day after said election, meet in the court-house in the presence of the ordinary of said county and count said votes, and the candidate having the highest number of votes shall hold the office for three years, and the candidate having the next highest vote shall hold the office for two years, and the one having the next highest vote shall hold the office one year. And the ordinary of said county shall certify to the commissioners of their election as well as for the length of time for which they are elected. Talbot, commissioners of, election of.
Sec. 2. On the first Wednesday in each year thereafter there shall be an election for one commissioner, whose term of office shall be for three years. Term of office.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: TERRELL COUNTY, ACT ESTABLISHING DISPENSARY AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act creating dispensaries in Terrell county, approved December 10, 1897.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That section 3 of the above-recited Act be, and the same is, hereby repealed and the following be substituted in lieu therefor: Section 3. Be it further enacted, That the dispensary commissioners at their regular meeting in July of each year or as soon thereafter as practicable, shall elect a secretary and treasurer, and for his services as such officer he shall receive a sum to be fixed by the board of dispensary commissioners, annually to be paid by the commissioners out of any money arising from the dispensaries, and said secretary and treasurer shall give bond in the sum of not less than two thousand dollars with good security, to be approved by said board, for all moneys that may come into his
hands, and for the faithful performance of all duties required of him. Terrell county, dispensary in, secretary and treasurer for.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: WASHINGTON COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Washington; to provide for the election of members thereof by the qualified voters of said county; to define their powers and duties; to provide for their compensation; to provide the manner in which the road funds shall be collected and expended, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Washington to consist of five (5) persons is hereby created. Said commissioners shall be freeholders and qualified voters of said county and shall reside in the road district from which they are elected, which districts are to be defined later in this Act. Washington county, board of commissioners for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That for the purpose of this Act the said county of Washington shall be divided into five (5) road districts, to be constituted as follows, to wit: That the first road district shall be composed of the ninety-sixth (96), ninety-fifth (95), thirteen hundred and fifty (1350) and the one hundred and thirty-sixth (136) Georgia militia districts. The second road district shall be composed of the ninety-second (92), ninety-fourth (94), twelve hundred and fifty-third (1253) and the thirteen hundred and eighty-fourth (1384) Georgia militia districts. The third road district shall be composed of the ninety-seventh (97), ninety-third (93), one hundredth (100), and the thirteen hundred and fifteenth (1315) Georgia militia districts. The fourth road district shall be composed of the ninety-ninth (99), the ninety-eighth (98), the ninetieth (90), and the eighty-eighth (88) Georgia militia
districts; and the fifth road district shall be composed of the eighty-ninth (89), the ninety-first (91), the thirteen hundred and forty-fifth (1345), the thirteen hundred and ninety-ninth (1399), and the fourteen hundred and eighty-eighth (1488) Georgia militia districts. Road districts.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That at the general election for county officers for said county in October, 1904, and every two years thereafter, all of said road commissioners shall be elected by a popular vote in Washington county in the following manner, to wit: The elector shall have written or printed on his ticket the names of the persons voted for and the districts wherein such persons reside, and it shall be the duty of the managers of said election when they meet to consolidate the vote and to declare the result, to count all of said votes, and to declare the person elected who receives the highest vote in his district as the duly elected commissioner for that district and so on through all the districts, it being the purpose of this Act to restrict the board of county commissioners to one man from each road district and to render ineligible more than one man from the same road district. The terms of said commissioners shall begin on the first Monday in November, on which date said board elected as aforesaid shall organize with full power to act as a board of commissioners of said county, exercising jurisdiction over all county matters set forth by general enactment as well as all matters specially mentioned in this Act. Commissioners, election of.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That any vacancies that may occur in said board by death, resignation, removal or otherwise, shall be filled at a special election in that road district of which the commissioner whose place has become vacant was the representative, said election to be called by the ordinary after thirty days' notice thereof in the public gazette of the county and to be held at each precinct in said road district and governed by the general election laws of this State, said election to be held only for the unexpired term. Removal from any road district by a commissioner elected for such road district shall vacate his office. Vacancies in board, how filled.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That it shall require three of said commissioners to constitute a quorum to transact any business, and three of said commissioners must concur to pass any order or decree, or to transact any business pertaining to the duties of said commissioners. Quorum.
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That said commissioners, during their term of office, are exempt from militia, road and jury duty. Exemptions.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That said commissioners shall have exclusive jurisdiction, when sitting for county purposes, over the following subject-matter, to wit: First, in building and controlling all property of the county as they may deem expedient, according to law; second, in levying a general tax for general purposes, and special taxes for particular or special purposes, according to the provisions of the Code and special enactments of the General Assembly; third, in establishing, altering, building, repairing and abolishing all roads, bridges and ferries in the county of Washington, in conformity to law; fourth, in establishing and changing election precincts and lines of militia districts; fifth, in examining, settling and allowing all claims against the county of Washington; sixth, in examining, and auditing the accounts of all county officers who receive or pay out moneys of the county or State, and in examining and reviewing all matters of record as required to be kept by law; seventh, in collecting and disbursing all funds belonging to the county or appropriated for its use or benefit, and in bringing all debtors of the county to a speedy settlement; eighth, in making such rules and regulations for the support and maintenance of the poor of the county of Washington, and for the promotion of health, as are permitted by law, or not inconsistent therewith; ninth, in regulating peddling and fixing costs of license therefor. Powers.
Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That said board shall meet at the court-house in said county and hold their sessions at such times as may be agreed upon and advertised by them. Sessions.
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That said board shall be authorized to employ a secretary who shall be paid the same per diem as members of the board. Secretary.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That for each day's service rendered by members of this board they shall each receive the same per day as is received by jurors for jury duty. Said commissioners shall give bond in the sum of five hundred dollars each with sufficient security, to be approved by the judge of the superior court of said county, payable to the ordinary of said county and his successors in office, and conditioned for the faithful performance of their duties as commissioners. Before entering upon their duties said commissioners shall take an oath before the ordinary for the faithful performance of their duties. Compensation. Bond. Oath

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That the Acts and doings of said board shall be open to the investigation of each grand jury, and that said board shall make a full and complete report of the finances of the county and condition of the county offices as well
as such reports as may be deemed necessary concerning all officers of the county, at the spring term of the court. Reports.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That each commissioner shall have the roads and the collection and expending the commutation road tax of his road district under his immediate supervision, and shall inspect the same as often as it is necessary or expedient, and shall have the particular oversight of said road district subject to the general control and direction of the entire board. Commissioners, duties of.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That an account of the commutation road tax, that is, the tax collected in lieu of actual road work, collected in each district shall be strictly kept by said board in a book for that purpose, which book shall be open at all times to the inspection of the public, and said board is hereby further required to keep in said book as far as possible a strict account of how much money has been expended each year in each district, and said board is hereby required to spend in each district, each year, a sum equal or proportionate to that collected as commutation tax on the roads of said district in addition to such sums as may be spent in building or repairing bridges in said district. That said board is required, as far as practicable, to work the chain-gang in each district for a time during each year commensurate with the sum collected in that district as commutation road tax, the work of said convicts in said district to be charged against that district at the rate per day as is the daily cost of the maintenance of said gang. If the sum paid in by said district as commutation tax be in excess of the value of the convicts' labor, then the work of said convicts is to be supplemented by additional expenditures in said district to bring it up as near as practicable to the sum collected. Commutation tax.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That the said board shall have the exclusive control of the misdemeanor convicts of said county and shall have the right to lease or hire misdemeanor convicts from other counties whenever said board deems it necessary or expedient. Said board shall have the right to employ a superintendent of roads, should they think it wise, and to pay him such salary as they may think proper; provided, that said superintendent nor any other officer or person connected with said system of working roads shall not receive in any one year a salary exceeding six hundred dollars. Misdemeanor convicts. Superintendent of roads.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That the general fund arising from an ad valorem taxation for road purposes and for the building of bridges shall be used and expended by said board in their discretion, but first in the building and repairing of the
bridges of the county and the balance, if any, on the roads in such parts of the county in such a manner as they deem wise. Bridges and roads, repair of.
Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: WASHINGTON COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act approved December 15, 1897, creating a board of commissioners for roads, public property and finance for the county of Washington, defining the duties and powers of the same, and for other purposes, and also to repeal an Act approved December 20, 1898, amendatory of said first Act; to abolish said board of commissioners; to provide how the duties now performed by said board shall be performed, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That an Act entitled an Act to create a board of commissioners for roads, public property and finance for the county of Washington, and to define the duties and powers of the same, and for other purposes, approved December 15, 1897, and the Act approved December 20, 1898, amendatory thereof, are both hereby repealed. Washington county, board of commissioners for abolished.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all the duties heretofore exercised by said board of roads, public property and finance be vested in the ordinary of said county of Washington and that all books and papers of said board be turned over to said ordinary. Duties of board vested in ordinary.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: WILKES COUNTY, DISTILLING IN PROHIBITED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to make it unlawful to distill or manufacture spirituous or intoxicating liquors, or to set up or operate a distillery, or do any act towards setting up or operating a distillery in the county of Wilkes; to provide a penalty therfor, and for other purposes.
law.p: Sec. 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act, it shall be unlawful for any person, by himself, or agent, to distill or manufacture spirituous or intoxicating liquors or to set up or operate a distillery or do any act towards setting up or operating a distillery in the county of Wilkes, and any person who shall violate the provisions of this Act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as prescribed in section 1039 of the Penal Code of Georgia of 1895; provided, that nothing in this Act shall prohibit the manufacture of domestic wines. Wilkes county, manufacture of intoxicating liquors in prohibited. Penalty.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: WORTH COUNTY, COUNTY-SITE CHANGED FROM ISABELLA TO SYLVESTER.
law.fulltitle: An Act to change the county-site of Worth county from Isabella, in said county, to Sylvester, in said county, and for other purposes.
law.p: WHEREAS, heretofore, to wit, on the first day of February, 1904, a petition was filed with the ordinary of the said county of Worth, in the State of Georgia, signed by more than two-fifths of the poll-tax payers of the said county, as shown by the last tax digest made out for said county, asking that an election be held at the various election precincts in said county for the purpose of changing or removing the county-site of said county from Isabella, in said county, to Sylvester, in said county; and,

WHEREAS, on the same day, to wit, on the first day of February, 1904, the same being the first Monday in February, 1904, the said ordinary of the said county of Worth, upon due consideration of the said petition so filed with him, in terms of the law applicable thereto, did then and there pass an order calling and providing for an election to be held at the various election precincts in the various militia districts of said county on the sixteenth day of March, 1904, for the purpose of changing and removing the county-site of the said county from Isabella to Sylvester, as asked by the petitioners, which said order was duly passed, entered upon the minutes of the court of ordinary and published in the Worth County Local, the newspaper in said county in which the sheriff of said county publishes his legal notices, as provided by section 391 of volume I of the Code of 1895 of said State; and,

WHEREAS, on the date set forth in said order, to wit, on the sixteenth day of March, 1904, said election was held at the various election precincts in said county in accordance with the said order of the said ordinary of said county, and upon consolidation of the returns of the said election in terms of the law, it appearing that 2541 legal votes were cast at said election, of which 2126 were for the removal of the county-site of said county from Isabella to Sylvester, and 415 against removal, therefore, that more than two-thirds of the legal votes cast at the said election were in favor of the removal and change of the county-site of the said county from Isabella to Sylvester, which was duly declared to be the result of the said election and return thereof made to the Secretary of State, who certified the same to be true as above stated and as shown by the said return; and,

WHEREAS, it appears that notice of intention to apply for the passage of this Act has been duly posted and published as required by the Constitution and laws of this State, and that each and all of the requisites of the law in the premises have been fully complied with; now, therefore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the county-site of the said county of Worth, in said State, be, and the same is, hereby changed and removed from Isabella, in said county, to Sylvester, in said county. Worth county, countysite changed.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: WORTH COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to create and establish a board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Worth county; to fix and prescribe their jurisdiction, powers and duties; to provide for the election, appointment and qualification of the members and officers of the said board, and to fix their salaries and fees and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in and for Worth county, Georgia, be and the same is, hereby created and established, the same to be composed of five members, who shall constitute the said board, the same to be known and styled, The Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Worth county, Georgia. Worth county, board of commissioners for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the following-named persons, to wit: D. H. Davis, J. D. Bridges, H. C. Woolard, T. J. Pinson and J. S. Westberry, five citizens of the said county, be, and they are hereby appointed as members of, and are hereby made to constitute the first board of, commissioners with authority to organize and enter upon the discharge of their duties without commission, immediately upon the passage and approval of this Act, to serve until their successors are elected and qualified as hereinafter provided. Members of board.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That successors to D. H. Davis and J. S. Westberry, two of the members above-named, shall be elected at a regular election for county officers to be held in October, 1904, whose term shall begin January 1, 1905, and who shall serve a term of four years thereafter, and until their successors are elected and qualified; successors to J. D. Bridges, H. C. Woolard and George Price, three of the members above-named, shall be elected at the regular election for county officers of said county to be held in October, 1906, whose term shall begin January 1, 1907, and who shall serve for a term of four years thereafter, and until their successors are elected and qualified; the members of the said board shall thereafter be elected by twos and threes alternately every two years at the same time and in the
same way as other county officers of the said county are now or may hereafter, be elected, each to serve for a term of four years beginning on the first of January after his election, and until his successor is elected and qualified. Before entering upon the discharge of his duties each member-elect of the said board shall take and subscribe the following oath, before the ordinary or clerk of superior court of the said county, to wit: I do solemnly swear that I will well and faithfully discharge all of the duties devolving upon me as a member of the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Worth county, Georgia, during my continuance in that office, according to law, to the best of my knowledge and ability and without favor or affection toward any one; so help me, God, which oath, duly attested by either the ordinary or clerk of the superior court of said county under the seal of their office, shall be transmitted to and filed in the executive department of this State, and thereupon the Governor shall issue to the members elect of the said board a commission in the same way as to other officers of said county. Successors.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the said board shall at their first meeting, upon organizing under this Act, elect a clerk, who shall not be a member of the said board, but who shall be a citizen of the said county, any bona [Illegible Text] citizen being eligible, to serve until the first meeting of the said board in January, 1907, and until his successor is elected and qualified; the said board shall, at their first meeting in January, 1907, or as soon thereafter as practicable, and at their first meeting in January each two years thereafter, or as soon after such meeting as practicable, elect a clerk of their board for a term of two years, or until his successor shall be elected and qualified, which clerk shall perform all duties fixed by law, and all that may be prescribed by the said board from time to time; the said board shall at the time of electing the clerk, fix his salary or compensation for the services to be performed by him, which shall be paid monthly out of the county treasury upon warrant of the said board. The members of said board shall each receive two dollars per day for time actually engaged in the discharge of his duties. Clerk. Commissioners, compensation of.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That no person shall be eligible to election on the said board of commissioners who is not twenty-seven years of age, and who has not been a bona fide citizen of Worth county at least five years immediately prior to his election. Qualifications.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That all vacancies on the said board occurring from death, resignation, or otherwise, shall be filled by the remaining members of the said board; the persons chosen
to fill vacancies shall take, subscribe and file the oath prescribed, and shall be commissioned by the Governor to fill the unexpired terms of the commissioners whom they are elected to succeed. The board shall have the right to remove the clerk at any time in their discretion, for good cause in their judgment, charges to be preferred by them in writing, and a hearing to be given the clerk so charged, and their judgment to be final; they shall fill all vacancies in the office of clerk occurring from removal, death, resignation, or otherwise. Vacancies in board. Clerk.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That all powers and duties now vested in, and which have heretofore been exercised by the ordinary of the said county of Worth relative to roads, bridges, fences, public buildings, and all other property of the said county; the management and maintenance of the jail, the misdemeanor convicts and chain-gangs of the said county, the poorhouse and farm, assessing and collecting taxes for any and all purposes of the said county, disbursing money for any and all county purposes, and any and all other county matters, are hereby conferred upon, vested in, and may be exercised by, the said board of commissioners; the said board to have full control and jurisdiction over each and all of the said matters and things, in as full and complete a manner as the same may be given under the Constitution and laws of this State. The said board shall have jurisdiction over, and shall exercise all powers and duties over any and all matters pertaining to any and all of the above matters and things, and any and all of the affairs of the said county, in the same way and to the same extent as the inferior courts of this State before they were abolished. All laws applicable thereto not inconsistent with the present Constitution and laws of this State being hereby reenacted and made of force and applicable to the said board. Board of commissioners, powers and duties of.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That the said board of commissioners shall have, and the same is, hereby given original, exclusive and general jurisdiction and control over the following subject-matters, when sitting for county purposes, to wit: 1. In directing and controlling all of the property of the county as they may deem expedient, according to law. 2. In levying a general tax for general, and a special tax or taxes for particular county purposes, according to the provisions of the Constitution and laws of this State. 3. In opening and establishing, altering, changing and abolishing all roads, bridges, ferries and public highways of every kind in conformity to the law. 4. In establishing and changing election precincts and militia districts. 5. In examining, settling and allowing all claims against the county.
6. In examining and auditing the accounts of all officers having the care, management, keeping, collection or disbursement of money belonging to the county, or appropriated for its use and benefit, and to bring them to settlement and in settling with them. 7. In making such rules and regulations for the support of the poor of county, for county police and patrol, for the promotion of health and quarantine, as are granted by law, or not inconsistent therewith. 8. In regulating peddling and fixing the costs of license therefor. Jurisdiction.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the said board of commissioners shall keep, through their clerk, a full and correct record of all of their actings and doings, and of all proceedings before them, and shall submit the same for inspection to each grand jury at each session of the superior court of said county. Records.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That said board of commissioners shall be, and the same is, hereby constituted a body corporate under the name and style of The Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Worth county, Georgia, and may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, have and use a seal, make contracts, negotiate loans, and exercise all necessary and proper corporate powers with reference to any and all matters over which they have jurisdiction; provided, that no judgment, decree or order of any court, and no contract, obligation, or other liability of any kind incurred in the regular course of their duties, and with reference to county matters over which they have jurisdiction, shall not in any way operate against the members of the said board of commissioners as individuals, but shall be a charge against the said county. Body corporate.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That the said board shall have and the same is, hereby granted full and ample authority and power to bind the said county of Worth, either in their own corporate name, or in the name of the said county, in any way that may be legitimate and proper in the regular course of their business, when sitting for county purposes, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State. All contracts and other obligations of the said board shall be approved by the board after due consideration shall be executed in the name of the board, or of the county, shall be signed by the chairman of the board and be countersigned by the clerk thereof, and shall be entered upon the minutes of the board before the same shall become binding and of force. Contracts.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That the said board shall, at their
first meeting after the first of January after each two year's election, elect one of their number chairman, who shall serve for a term of two years, or until his successor is elected and qualified; they shall also elect another of their number vice-chairman, who shall act and perform all of the duties of the chairman in the event the chairman is absent, disqualified, or for any reason can not, or will not serve, the chairman, or the vice-chairman, when serving, shall be the executive officer of the said board, and shall preside at all meetings, and shall see that all of the orders, rules, regulations, and other enactments of the board are duly executed. Chairman and vice-chairman.
Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That a majority, that is to say, any three members of said board, shall constitute a quorum for all purposes. Quorum.
Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

contentslist.p: Ashburn, public schools for, system amended.
Blue Ridge, public schools, diplomas in.

Swainsboro, school district of, incorporated.
