law.shorttitle: ASHBURN, PUBLIC SCHOOLS FOR, SYSTEM AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved December 17, 1901, establishing a system of public schools for the town of Ashburn, so as to incorporate the same as the public school system of the city of Ashburn, in the county of Worth, State of Georgia; to provide for the support and maintenance thereof, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act an Act approved December 17, 1901, establishing a system of public schools for the town of Ashburn, Worth county, Georgia, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out the word town wherever and whenever used in said Act, and substituting therefor the word
city, so said Act, when amended, shall read, An Act to establish a system of public schools for the city of Ashburn, Worth county, Georgia, and for other purposes. City of Ashburn, public schools for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all power, authority, rules and regulations of the board of education, as established by Act approved December 17, 1901, be, and the same is, adopted and conferred by this Act on the present board of education as a board of education for the city of Ashburn. Board of education, powers of.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said board of commissioners shall make a list of the amounts necessary to run white and colored schools in said city for the next succeeding twelve months, and submit the same to the city council of the city of Ashburn at their monthly meeting in February of each year, beginning in February, 1905, and yearly thereafter at said time specified in this Act. Report to city council.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and council of the city of Ashburn shall cause to be levied and collected a special ad valorem tax for the purpose of supporting and maintaining a free school system in said city, of Ashburn on all the property in said city, both real and personal, a sum not exceeding one-half of one per centum, which said fund shall be first collected by the said city authorities and at once turned over to the board of education of said city of Ashburn, said board being created by Act approved December 17, 1901, of which this is an amendment, and becomes a part thereof with all the powers therein conferred, as well as by the additional powers of this Act. Special tax to be levied.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: BLUE RIDGE PUBLIC SCHOOLS, DIPLOMAS IN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act incorporating the public schools of the city of Blue Ridge, Fannin county, Georgia, approved December 19, 1899, so as to empower the president and trustees to issue diplomas to students graduating in said schools in branches normal, business or literary.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State
of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the Act incorporating the public schools of the city of Blue Ridge be so amended as to empower the superintendent or president and trustees of said schools to issue diplomas to students graduating in any department, normal, business or literary. Blue Ridg public schools, diplomas in.

law.shorttitle: DANBURG, SCHOOL DISTRICT OF IN WILKES COUNTY, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the Danburg school district, in Wilkes county, and define the boundaries of the same; to establish a board of education therein, and to confer on said board certain powers; to regulate the management and control of schools in said district, and to provide revenue for the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act there shall be established a corporate school district in and about the town of Danburg, in the county of Wilkes, to be known as the Danburg School District, which district shall take in all that territory beginning at that point where Newford creek intersects the Lincoln county line, and running thence south to the point of intersection of Morris creek with said county line; thence west along said creek to and taking in the lands of J. A. Sutton; thence in a northerly and northwesterly direction along the lines of said Sutton to and taking in the lands of J. C. Robert, along the west and north boundary lines of said Robert to and taking in lands of O. L. Fortson, along the west line of said Fortson, along north line of Fortson and others, to and taking in the lands of W. L. Sutton, along west line of said Sutton to and taking in the lands of J. A. Sutton's McLendon farm, along the south and west lines of said McLendon farm to point on north; thence east along the north lines of said McLendon farm, Mrs. C. Quinn and A. S. Anderson's Bradford place to a point along the east lines of said Bradford place and Heard and Sutton's place south to said Newford creek, and then along said creek to that point where said creek intersects the Lincoln county line. Danburg school district incorporated.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the management and control of all schools in said district shall be vested in a board, known as the board of education, composed of seven persons, and which board, by that name and style, shall have perpetual succession, have and use a common seal, have a right to sue and be sued, and shall have power to purchase, receive and hold, to them and their successors in office for school purposes, any estate, real, personal, and of every kind and character. Board of education.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That O. L. Fortson, J. K. Standard, W. L. Sutton, John D. Bunch, E. D. Beard, N. A. Willis and A. S. Anderson are hereby constituted and appointed a board of trustees to carry into effect the provisions of this Act; and that the terms of office of said board of trustees shall be perpetual, and they shall have power to fill all vacancies on said board by appointment or otherwise, and said board may prescribe such rules for their own government as they may think proper. Said board of trustees shall take charge of all school buildings, or other property within said school district, and shall be, and are, hereby entrusted with the organization of the schools to be taught therein. They shall have authority to employ teachers for said schools, fix their salaries, fix the tuition to be paid by each pupil, make the rules for the government of said schools, and to do and perform all other acts and things necessary or proper for the purpose of carrying out the objects of this Act. Members of board.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the said board of education shall, immediately after this Act goes into operation, organize by electing a president, vice-president, secretary and treasurer from their own number. The treasurer and secretary shall each give a good and sufficient bond. Officers.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That said board of education shall have power to adopt a system of public schools in said district, to elect a superintendent and prescribe his duties, and remove him for cause, in their discretion; to employ, suspend or remove teachers and fix their compensation by salary or otherwise; to provide schoolhouses, and by rent, building, purchase, or otherwise, to make and hold title to such property; to make such rules and regulations for the government of themselves and such schools as they deem proper, not in conflict with the laws of the State, and to do any and all things promotive of the above educational interests of said district, not in conflict with the provisions of this Act, or the laws of this State. Powers.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That there shall be established a school for not less than seven nor more than ten scholastic months
in each year, the length of said term to be in discretion of the board. Scholastic term.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That after the ratification of this Act it shall be the duty of the county school commissioner of Wilkes county, and he is hereby required, to pay over to the treasurer of said board of education, under such rules as the said board may prescribe, not in conflict with the rules and regulations of the county board of education, the portion of public school fund of said county to which the schools established under this Act for said district may be entitled under the rules of distribution of the public school fund. Public school fund.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That immediately after the ratification of this Act, and by the first Wednesday in January of each succeeding year, the board of education shall determine what amount of money it shall be necessary to raise by taxation to defray the expenses of said schools for the scholastic year, and said board shall, through their secretary, be required to levy and collect the same, and said secretary shall be the tax-collector, and exercise all the powers as a tax-collector, or in the collection of said taxes; provided, that the said amount does not exceed one-half of one per cent. of the taxable property of said district. Said tax shall be collected annually, that is, by the first day of November of each year, and when collected shall be turned over to the board of education, and together with the amount received from the public school fund, the admission and tuition fees which may be collected, and any other funds that may be placed in their hands for that purpose, shall constitute a school fund to be expended in defraying the expenses necessary for the maintenance of said schools, and shall be paid out only on order of the board of education. Taxes.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the board of education of Wilkes county shall not establish any other school or contract with any other person to teach a school of any character in said district, nor shall any of the State school funds be paid to, any other school in said district, than the schools herein provided for. Other schools not established in district

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That in case any school property acquired by said board of education under any provision of this Act, or otherwise, be sold, the fund derived from such sale shall be reinvested in other property, to be used for school purposes. School property, sale of.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That before this Act shall become operative its adoption shall be submitted to the legally qualified voters of said district, for which purpose the persons hereinbefore named shall, within six months after its passage, order an
election, for which ten days' notice shall be given by posting in five conspicuous places in said district, in which notice the time, place and purpose of said election shall be stated, and which election shall be held under the same rules and regulations as the election of the mayor of the town of Danburg. The legally qualified voters only of such school district shall be allowed to vote in said election, and the registration-lists last prepared by the registrars, before any such election, shall constitute the highest evidence of who are qualified voters in said district, and no one shall vote in said election except those who registered for the last preceding State election. At said election those favoring public schools shall have printed or written on their ballots For Establishment of Public Schools, and those opposing public schools shall have printed or written on their ballots Against the Establishment of Public Schools, and if two-thirds of the qualified voters in said district in said election shall vote for the establishment of public schools, this Act shall become immediately operative, and said board shall put said schools in operation beginning with January, 1905. Should the result of the election herein provided for be against the establishment of public schools, the board of education of said district may order another election once every year thereafter until public schools are adopted. Act to be ratified by voters.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That the board of education shall annually make a report to the public in writing of the condition of said schools, and oftener, if they deem necessary, and they shall accompany their reports with the treasurer's report of a full and itemized statement of all moneys received and expended by said board. Board of education, report of.
Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That the tax shall be levied and collected on the tax returns made for State and county purposes for the year last preceding said tax levy. Tax.
Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: HOSCHTON, GRADED SCHOOL OF, IN JACKSON COUNTY, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate Hoschton graded school of the town of Hoschton, Jackson county; to regulate the management of the schools of said town; to provide for revenue for running the same; to define its boundaries; to provide for the election of trustees, and to define their powers; to provide for the issue of ten thousand dollars six per cent., twenty-year bonds, and to provide for the interest and redemption of said bonds.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act there shall be established a public graded school in the town of Hoschton, Jackson county, Georgia, to be known as Hoschton Public Graded School, with the corporate limits of said town extending from the depot of the G. J. S. Ry. as a center, for school purposes only, two miles in every direction, or four miles square; provided, said corporate limits shall coincide with the school district established by the county board of education. Hoschton, graded school of incorporated.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the management and control of all schools in said town shall be vested in a board of trustees, to be known as a Board of Education, composed of five persons, which board, by name and style, shall have perpetual succession, have a common seal, have a right to sue and be sued, and shall have power to purchase and receive and hold to them and their successors in office, for school purposes, any estate, real or personal, of every kind and character. Board of education.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That upon the passage of this bill the mayor and council of the town of Hoschton are hereby authorized and empowered and required to elect said board of education for a term of two or four years, as they may choose. Election of.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the said board of education shall immediately upon their election organize by electing a president, vice-president, secretary and treasurer from their number, or the superintendent of said schools may be secretary and treasurer. Officers.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That said board of education have power to adopt and establish, and are hereby required so to do, a system of public schools in said town, one for the white children
and one for the negro children; to elect a superintendent, who may, or may not be, ex officio secretary and treasurer of said board; to prescribe his duties, to fix his term for four years or less, to employ, suspend or remove teachers, if the board so determines; to fix their salaries; to provide schoolhouses by rent, building, purchase or otherwise, to make and hold title to such property; to make such rules and regulations for the government of themselves and such schools as they may deem proper, not in conflict with the laws of the State, and to do any and all things promotive of the above educational interests of said town not in conflict with provisions of this Act, or the laws of this State. Powers and duties.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That said board of education shall establish a school not less than eight, and not more than ten months each year. All children entitled to the benefit of the public schools under the laws of this State, and whose parents, guardians or natural protectors reside within the incorporated limits of said town, as above set forth, shall be admitted to the aforesaid schools, the white children to the white schools and the negro children to the negro school, upon the payment of such fee or tuition as said board of education may deem necessary and prescribe, and not otherwise; provided, said board may fix further conditions in case of contagious diseases. Schools.

Sec. 7. Non-resident children may be admitted to said schools and receive the benefit of the public fund to which they would be entitled of they attended the schools in their respective districts or county, which funds shall be paid to the treasurer of said board by the county supervisor of such county from which said pupil may attend, under such rules as said board may prescribe, not in conflict with the laws of this State. Non-resident children, how admitted to schools.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That the county school commissioner of Jackson county is authorized and required to pay over to the treasurer of said board the portion of the public school fund of said county, or other funds from the State, or otherwise, in which said town, as above incorporated, is entitled to a pro rata under the rules for the distribution of said fund; provided, said county school commissioner shall pay over the full regular daily pro rata for each pupil who attended said school one hundred days, or less, any time during the calendar year. Public school fund.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That said board of education shall exercise sole and exclusive control of all schools in said town, and shall make all necessary reports to the county school commissioner. Board of education, authority and reports of.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That in case school property acquired by said board of education under any provisions of this Act, or otherwise, be sold, the fund thereof shall be reinvested in other property, to be used for school purposes. School property, sale of.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That said board of education shall annually make a report, in writing, to the public, with a sworn statement of the receipts and expenditures of all moneys which pass through their hands. Board of education, annual report of.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and board of aldermen or council of the town of Hoschton shall have full power and authority, and are hereby empowered and required to levy and collect a tax on all real and personal property in the limits of said town, as above incorporated, for school purposes only; provided, the interest and redemption fund for any bonds said mayor and council may issue for school purposes under the authority of this Act, shall be regarded for school purposes; to defray the expenses of maintaining said schools in said town, of erecting, preserving or renting school buildings, and other property belonging to said town, but the rate of taxation shall never exceed one per centurm, ad valorem. School tax.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That the said mayor and council are hereby authorized and required to issue and sell bonds not to exceed ten thousand dollars of the denomination of $100.00 each, to be due and payable twenty years after date, but redeemable at par after ten years, and to bear six per cent. interest, payable annually, such bonds to be sold to the highest bidder, or otherwise, as said mayor and council may determine. School bonds.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall pay off and cancel at least one-tenth of said bonds issued by the end of the eleventh year from their date, and pay off and cancel a like amount each succeeding year until all of said bonds shall be fully paid and cancelled; provided, however, that they shall pay the interest on all outstanding bonds on the first day of each January out of any funds arising from the provisions of this Act, and pay over to the treasurer of said board of education all other funds arising from the provisions of this Act.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That all owners or holders of real estate or personal property in said town, as above incorporated, shall list the same under oath with the tax-assessor or collector of said town as soon as this bill shall become operative under the terms herein, and in the month of August or September of each succeeding year, and a failure so to do shall subject said taxpayer to a double tax. The assessor or collector of said town shall receive for listing and collecting said taxes five per cent.
upon all taxes collected. He shall pay all moneys collected under the provisions of this bill to the treasurer of said school board, except such amount as may be due and payable for interest or redemption of said bond; the mayor and council shall appoint three freeholders of said town, as above incorporated, who shall act as a tax revising board. Said revising board shall meet not later than November 1st of each year, and revise and correct said tax-list, and may increase the value of any property which they may consider has been returned below its cost value; provided, they shall notify the holder or owner of property affected by such increase by giving five days' notice, after which he may be heard in person, or by attorney, before said revising board, whose decision shall be final. They shall receive $2.00 per day for such services. Said taxes shall be collected as all other taxes of said town, and fi. fas. and levys made as prescribed for said town. The said taxes shall be due and payable not later than November of each year, but said mayor and council may change said time of payment, or time for assessment and revising said tax-list. Taxes. Tax revising board.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, That before section 12 and section 13 shall become operative, their adoption shall be submitted to the legally qualified voters of said town, as above incorporated. For which purpose the mayor of said town shall call an election, to be held as other elections in said town are held, first giving twenty days' notice of said election at three public places. The clerk or secretary for the council of said town shall open, and keep open, not less than fifteen days of the said twenty days' notice, a book of registration, in which all legally qualified voters of said town, as above incorporated, shall register before they may vote in said election. Those who favor section 12, or section 13, shall have on their tickets For Section 12, and For Section 13, respectively, and those who oppose either of said sections shall have on their tickets Against Section 12, or Against Section 13; and if either section 12 or section 13 shall receive a two-thirds majority of those voting in said election, then said bill shall become operative as to said section or sections, respectively; but if either section fail of such constitutional majority, then said mayor and council may order an election to vote upon either of, or both, of said sections as often as they may deem expedient, until said section or sections are adopted; provided, no part of this bill shall become effective until section 12 shall have been adopted, as above provided. Bonds and school tax, election for.
Sec. 17. Be it further enacted, That all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: KIRKWOOD, PUBLIC SCHOOLS FOR, SYSTEM ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the town of Kirkwood to provide a system of public schools, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the town of Kirkwood, in DeKalb county, shall have authority to establish and maintain a system of common schools for the instruction of children whose parents reside within the corporate limits of said town, in the elementary branches of an English education. Kirkwood, system of public schools for, established.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted as aforesaid, That the schools established in pursuance of the authority herein granted shall be and remain under the direct control and management of the town council, which body shall be ex officio the school board in and for said town, and shall have full power and authority to choose the teachers for said schools, prescribe the duration of their terms, fix their pay, and to make from time to time such rules and regulations for the government of said schools, as in its judgment and discretion may be necessary and proper. School board, powers of.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted as aforesaid, That said town, through its constituted authorities, shall have full power to provide schoolhouses, furniture and apparatus for said schools, and to levy and collect for the support, maintenance and equipment of said schools, such tax upon all real and personal property in said town as in the judgment and discretion of said town authorities may be necessary and proper, which tax shall be levied at the same time as the other taxes of the town, and in the same ordinance, and shall be collected in the same way and by the same officers, but shall be kept separate therefrom, and in separate accounts; provided, nevertheless, that the tax levied and collected under this Act shall not exceed in any one year more than one-half of one per cent. upon the taxable property. School tax

Sec. 4. The proper proportion of the educational fund due to said town, or the schools thereof, according to the general laws of the State, shall from time to time be paid over directly to said board by the State School Commissioner, to be by said board used in maintaining said system, and without the intervention of the
county school commissioner, or the board of education of said county of DeKalb; and said school board of Kirkwood shall be responsible directly to the State Commissioner, and deal directly with him. Public school fund.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted as aforesaid, That said town shall have power, whenever it shall so decide, to issue bonds upon the credit of the town to an amount not to exceed five thousand dollars, for the purpose of raising money with which to purchase a school lot, and build, equip and furnish a schoolhouse or schoolhouses in pursuance of the authority hereinbefore granted; provided, however, that the amount of bonds shall not exceed the limit fixed by the Constitution of the State; and provided further, that in all details touching the ordering of said bonds, provision for payment thereof, election by the people, public notices, etc., due regard shall be had to the Constitution of said State and the statutes for such cases provided. School bonds.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted as aforesaid, That this Act shall not go into effect until the same has been submitted to a vote at an election to be called for that purpose, in which election all the qualified voters resident within the corporate limits of said town shall be allowed to participate, nor unless it shall receive two-thirds of the votes cast. Said election shall be ordered by the town council at such time as it may decide, and notice thereof shall be given by advertising the same once a week for four weeks in the county gazette. It shall be held under the usual laws governing elections, and the polls shall remain open from six o'clock in the morning until six o'clock in the evening. The returns shall be certified by the managers of election to the town council at its next regular meeting, and the result shall be thereupon announced and declared by that body and duly recorded on its minutes. Ratification of act by voters.
Sec. 7. All laws in conflict herewith are repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: McDONOUGH SCHOOL DISTRICT, IN HENRY COUNTY, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the McDonough school district in Henry county; to define the boundaries of same; to provide a system of public schools therefor; to regulate the management of the schools in said district; to provide revenue for said schools; to provide for the election of persons to be known as the board of education of McDonough school district, and to confer on them certain powers, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act there shall be established a corporate school district in and about the town of McDonough, in the county of Henry, to be known as the McDonough School District, which district shall at all times be coextensive with the town limits of said town. McDonough, school district of, incorporated

Sec. 2. Be it enacted, That the management and control of all schools in said district shall be vested in a board to be known as the Board of Education, composed of five persons, and which board, by that name and style, shall have perpetual succession, have and use a common seal, have a right to sue and be sued, and shall have power to purchase, receive and hold to them and their successors in office, for school purposes, any estate, real, personal, and of every kind and character. Board of education.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That A. N. Brown, H. J. Copeland, D. J. Green, H. B. Neal and T. A. Sloan shall be, and are, hereby constituted the board of education, to carry into effect the provisions of this Act until the regular election of the members of said board, which shall take place at the time and place of the election of the mayor and councilmen for the town of McDonough. The first election under this Act shall be held on the first Wednesday in December, 1905, at which time two of the members of the board shall be elected for two years, and three for four years. Their successors in office shall serve for a term of four years, beginning from the date of their respective elections. The board of education shall fill all vacancies occurring in said board, until the regular election for members of said board. The persons herein named shall serve until the first election above specified, and should any member or members of said board named
above fail or refuse to serve until the first election, then, in that event said vacancy or vacancies are to be filled by the town council of McDonough. Members.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the said board of education shall, immediately after this Act goes into operation, organize by electing a president and vice-president. The clerk of the town council shall be ex officio secretary and treasurer of the board, but shall have no vote on any question arising before said board. No member shall receive compensation for his services except the secretary and treasurer, whose compensation shall be fixed by the board at the beginning of his term. The secretary and treasurer shall give such bond as shall be required of him by said board. Officers.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That said board of education shall have power to adopt a system of public schools in said district, to elect a superintendent and prescribe his duties and remove him for cause, in their discretion; to employ, suspend or remove teachers, and fix their compensation by salary or otherwise; to provide schoolhouses by rent, building, purchase or otherwise, to make and hold title to such property; to make such rules and regulations for the government of themselves and such schools as they deem proper, not in conflict with the laws of the State, and to do any and all things promotive of the above educational interests of said district, not in conflict with the provisions of this Act, or the laws of this State; provided, that said board shall not have power to purchase property or sell it without the consent of the majority of the town council of McDonough. Powers.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That there shall be established a school for not less than six, nor more than ten scholastic months in each year, the length of said term to be in the discretion of the board. The curriculum in said schools shall be only such as is taught in the system of public schools maintained by the State, but the board may provide for a higher curriculum, to be paid for by the patrons who may send children to said schools. There shall be one, and only one, school for white children, and one, and only one, school for colored children. All children entitled to the benefit of public schools under the laws of Georgia whose parents, guardians or natural protectors reside within the corporate limits of said district, shall be admitted to the aforesaid schools, the colored children to the colored school, and the white children into the white school, upon the payment of such admittance fee only as the board of education may deem necessary. Children of non-residents, and such others as may not be entitled
to the benefit of these schools shall be admitted upon such terms as may be prescribed by the board of education of said town, not in conflict with the laws of this State. Schools.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of the county school commissioner of Henry county, and he is hereby required, to pay over to the treasurer of said board of education of McDonough, under such rules as the board may prescribe, not in conflict with the rules and regulations of the board of education of Henry county, the portion of the public school fund of said county to which the school established under this Act for said district may be entitled under the rules of distribution of public school fund. The amount to be determined by a census of the school children of said district, to be held under the supervision and direction of the board of education of McDonough. Public school fund.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That the board of education of Henry county shall not establish any other school, or contract with any person to teach a school of any character in said district, nor shall any of the State school funds be paid to any other school in said district than the schools herein provided for. Other schools not established in district.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That in case any school property acquired, or title to any property that may now rest in the town council of McDonough, or the board of education of McDonough, under any provisions of this Act, or otherwise, be sold, the fund derived from such sale shall be reinvested in other property, to be used for school purposes. School property sale of.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That the board of education shall annually make a report to the town council, in writing, of the condition of said schools, and oftener, if they deem necessary, and they shall accompany their reports with the treasurer's report of a full and itemized statement of all moneys received and expended by said board. Board of education, annual report of.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of the town of McDonough, Georgia, shall have full power and authority to lay and collect a tax on all real and personal property within the limits of said McDonough school district for school purposes; provided, however, that this applies only to limits of said school district coextensive always with the town limits of McDonough, to defray the expenses of carrying on schools in said district that said board of education shall deem to be to the best interest of said schools; but that the rate of taxation shall never exceed one-half of one per cent., and that the tax so levied and collected shall be on same basis as taxes are laid and collected for the expense and maintenance of the town of McDonough.
This section shall not become operative until after it shall have been ratified by the requisite constitutional majority of the voters of said town of McDonough at an election called for that purpose by the mayor and council of said town at any time they may see fit and proper after the expiration of one year from December 31, 1904. School tax
Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: MITCHELL, PUBLIC SCHOOLS FOR, SYSTEM ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to establish a system of public schools in the town of Mitchell, creating a board of education, fixing the term of office of each member, directing the State School Commissioner to pay over to the treasurer of the board of education of said school district all money due from all sources under this Act; to define the boundary thereof, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act a system of public schools be established in the town of Mitchell, Glascock county, Georgia. Mitchell, public schools for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the following named persons, to wit, O. L. Kelly, T. L. Kitchens, C. C. Kelley, Charlie Snider, B. B. Kitchens, John P. Allen, J. C. Kelly, A. M. Kitchens and James Neal, are hereby made the board of education of said town, and shall enter upon their duties as such as soon as this Act is approved by the Governor of this State. Board of education.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the term of office of the first four shall expire January 1, 1905, and the others annually thereafter in the order of their names above written, and their successors shall be elected by the remaining number of said board at the first meeting of said board after the expiration of term of office of any member or members, and the term of office shall be for three years. In case of vacancies, otherwise than by expiration of term of office, said board shall elect members to fill said
vacancies at the next meeting of said board after said vacancies occur, or so soon thereafter in either event as practicable. Terms of office, etc.

Sec. 4. That the officers of said board of education shall be a president, vice-president, secretary, treasurer and superintendent of public schools; that no member of said board, or officer thereof, except the secretary and treasurer, shall receive any compensation for his services, who shall not receive more than $25.00 per annum, to be fixed by the board. The treasurer shall give good and sufficient bond in the sum of five hundred dollars for the faithful discharge of his duties, which said duties shall be designated and prescribed by said board. The term of office of each shall be for one year, and their successors shall be elected by ballot on the first Tuesday in June. The principal of the white school shall be superintendent of the public schools of said town. The said board of education shall hold monthly meetings at the white schoolhouse, on the first Tuesday, to transact such business as may be necessary to carry on said schools. Officers.
Sec. 5. That the necessary funds for the establishment, conducting, maintaining and supporting such public schools shall be as follows: School funds.

First. The town council of Mitchell is hereby authorized, empowered and required to levy each year a special tax, as the board may recommend, not to exceed one-half of one per cent., on all property not more than $5.00 per capita per annum in said town, subject to taxation by said town, to collect the tax and pay it over to the treasurer of said board of education.

Second. That the town council of Mitchell is hereby authorized, empowered and required to pay the treasurer of said board all sums collected by the town authorized for license of all kinds, for special tax on all business of any kind.

Third. That the State School Commissioner of the State of Georgia is hereby authorized, empowered and required to pay over to the treasurer of said board the pro rata share of the State school funds for the children within school age, who are residents of said district, the boundary of which shall extend in all directions It shall be the duty of said board to have prepared and furnished to the State School Commissioner on the fifteenth of December annually, a census report of all children of the legal age in said district upon which he shall base his calculation.

Fourth. That the county school commissioner of the said county of Glascock shall pay over to the treasurer of said board of education the pro rata share of the school fund of Glascock; residents of said county and not residents of said district, but who are attending the public schools of said district.
Fifth. That the said board of education may provide for the admission of pupils upon payment of such matriculation and incidentals as they, the board, may deem just and reasonable.

Sec. 6. That any member of said board shall, for malfeasance or nonfeasance, be removed from office by a majority of votes of the other members of said board, constituting a quorum, and the unexpired term resulting therefrom shall be filled by the remaining members constituting a quorum. Board of education, removal of members.

Sec. 7. The county board of education shall have no authority or voice in the management of the schools in the Mitchell school district, established by the board of education of said district. Local board to have exclusive control.
Sec. 8. The term of public schools for said district shall not be less than five nor more than ten months in each year. Scholastic term.
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: PINEVIEW, ACT INCORPORATING SCHOOL DISTRICT OF, IN WILCOX COUNTY, AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to incorporate Pineview school district, etc., approved August 17, 1903, so as to provide for the better collection of the school tax therein specified, to provide for costs and their collection, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That section 8 of the above-recited Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding after the words Pineview, Georgia, are levied and collected, in the tenth line of said section, and before the words said tax, the following words, to wit: Provided, however, that said execution shall bear the test of the president of the board of trustees of the Pineview school district, and shall be signed by the secretary and treasurer of said board, and shall be directed to the marshal of said town, and to all and singular the constables and sheriffs of said State. Said secretary and treasurer of said board shall have for issuing each of said school tax fi. fas. the same costs allowed justices of the peace for issuing fi fas., and the levying officers shall have for their services the same fees as those allowed constables with justice court processes; provided further, that whenever the
marshal or constable can not find sufficient personal property of the defendant to satisfy said fi. fa., he shall make such entry, and then it shall be permissible for said marshal or constable to levy on, advertise and sell any real property of the defendant in the same manner as sheriffs levy on, advertise and sell real estate, which sales shall be at the court-house door of Wilcox county, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows: Section 8. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That as early as practicable after the ratification of this Act, and by the fourth Saturday in June of each year succeeding, the board of trustees shall determine what amount of money it will be necessary to raise by taxation to defray the expenses of said school for the scholastic year, and said board shall, through their officers, be required to levy and collect same, provided said amount does not exceed three-fourths of one per centum of the taxable property of said district, in the same manner as other taxes of said town of Pineview, Georgia, are levied and collected; provided, however, that said execution shall bear the test of the president of the board of trustees of the Pineview school district, and shall be signed by the secretary and treasurer of said board, and shall be directed to the marshal of said town, and to all and singular the constables and sheriffs of said State. Said secretary and treasurer of said board shall have for issuing each of said school tax fi. fas. the same costs allowed justices of the peace for issuing fi. fas., and the levying officers shall have for their services the same fees as those allowed constables with justice court processes; provided further, that whenever the marshal or constable can not find sufficient personal property of the defendant to satisfy said fi. fa., he shall make such entry, and then it shall be permissible for said marshal or constable to levy on, advertise and sell any real property of the defendant in the same manner as sheriffs levy on, advertise and sell real estate, which sales shall be at the court-house door of Wilcox county. Said tax, when collected, shall be turned over to the board of trustees and, together with the amount received from the public school fund, such admission and tuition fees as may be collected, and any other funds that may be placed in their hands for that purpose, shall constitute a fund to be expended only by order of the board of trustees in defraying the expenses necessary for carrying on such schools. Pineview school district, collection of school taxes in.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SHELLMAN, SCHOOL DISTRICT OF, IN RANDOLPH COUNTY, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the Shellman school district, in Randolph county, State of Georgia; to define the boundaries of the same; to establish a system of public schools therein; to provide for a board of education therefor, and define their powers; to provide revenue and the distribution of the same for said schools; to require the county school commissioner of Randolph county to pay over to said board of education such part of the State school fund as may be the pro rata share of said district, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act there shall be established in Shellman school district, situated in Randolph county, Georgia, a system of public schools, to be maintained, supported and controlled, as provided for in this Act. Shellman school district, public schools for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the incorporate limits of said district shall include all territory lying in the county of Randolph, State of Georgia, included within the following described limits, to wit: Beginning at a point three miles from the present site of the railroad depot in Shellman, in a northeasterly direction, on the county line between Randolph and Terrell counties, thence from said point with a radius of three miles on the northern, western and southern sides, describing a circumference to the county line in a southeasterly direction from Shellman, thence in a northerly direction along said county line to the point of beginning, so that the boundary of said district shall be three miles distant from said railroad depot in every direction, except as affected by the county line, on the eastern side of said district, between Randolph and Terrell counties. Territorial limits.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That H. O. Crittenden, J. F. Crittenden, W. T. Jay, M. W. Cox, T. E. Allen, T. R. Arthur, W. R. Terry, C. M. Cheney and I. A. Martin, shall be, and are, hereby constituted the board of education of said school district of Shellman, to carry into effect the provisions of this Act until the regular election of members of said board, which shall take place within thirty days after the passage of this Act.
The manner and form of electing said board under this Act shall be the same as now provided under the corporate powers of the stockhkolders of Shellman Institute; provided, any citizen of said school district shall be eligible as a member of said board. Board of education.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the board of education of said school district of Shellman shall be authorized to devise, design, adopt a plan of public instruction in said school district, to be maintained as hereinafter provided; to modify the same from time to time; to establish such schools as they see proper; to prescribe the curriculum; fix the rates of tuition, matriculation and incidental fees; appoint teachers for said schools and a superintendent for the same, if necessary; suspend or remove such teachers or superintendent; fix the compensation and time of payment; provide school buildings by rent, purchase or building of same; to rent or purchase all necessary school furniture, supplies, apparatus, musical instruments, libraries, and such other things as the board may deem necessary for the best interests of said schools; to have vested in them and their successors in office the title to all property, both real and personal, of which they may in any way be possessed; to keep all such property in good repair and insured; to sue and be sued, to make such by-laws, rules and regulations for their government and that of the superintendent, teachers and pupils of said schools as may be necessary and not contrary to the laws of this State. Powers of board.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the board shall elect from their number a chairman and a vice-chairman. A treasurer shall be elected who may be either from their body or any citizen of the district. A secretary shall be elected who may be either from their body or the superintendent of the schools; provided, none of the board members shall receive any pecuniary compensation for their services. Officers

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said board of education shall keep a record of all their proceedings, and all records kept by said board shall be open to the inspection of the public. Records.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That one or more schools for white children, and one or more schools for colored children shall be established and maintained under the provisions of this Act for terms not less than five, and not more than nine, months during each scholastic year. All children who are entitled to the benefit of the public school fund under the laws of this State, and who are bona fide residents of said district, shall be admitted to the aforesaid schools upon compliance with
the demands and rules of said board of education not contrary to the laws of this State. The said board of education may refuse to admit any child or children to said schools, or may expel them from the same, at any time that, in their judgment, it would be detrimental to the moral and general welfare of other pupils therein to allow such rejected pupils to remain or to enter. Schools

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That after the ratification of this Act the board of education of Randolph county shall not contract with any person to teach a school of any character in the limits of said district without the knowledge and consent of the board of said district, and that the authority over the schools of said district by the county board of education shall be confined to such reports of teachers, officers of the board and superintendent of said district as are, and may be, essential to complete the records of the county school commissioner. County board to have no authority over schools.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall be the duty of the teachers employed in the schools of said district to make all necessary reports that may be required by the board of said district, and it shall be the duty of the superintendent and secretary of the district board to make all necessary reports to the county school commissioner of Randolph county at such times, and in such manner as he may require of other teachers in the county. It shall be the duty of the treasurer to file with the county commissioners at the close of each scholastic year an itemized statement of all moneys received and disbursed by the board of education of the Shellman school district during that year. Reports of officers of board and teachers.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That as soon as practicable after the ratification of this Act, and as often thereafter as the county board of education may order a census of the other school children of the county, it shall be the duty of the board of education of said district to have made a census of all the pupils and children residing in said district entitled to the benefits of the State school funds, and as soon as practicable after the making of said census they shall furnish to the county school commissioner of said county a list of the names of the school population of said district, the same to be accompanied with the age, sex, color, and such other information as is usually secured in taking a school census. A like copy shall be filed with the State School Commissioner. Census.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the county school commissioner of Randolph county shall pay over to the treasurer of the board of education of said school district
of Shellman, out of the annual apportionment of the public school funds to Randolph county, made by the State board of education, such a proportion of said funds as the number of children enumerated in said district bear to the number of children in said county as shown by the last census of the school population, exclusive of said district. The proportionate division of the public funds shall also apply to any balance in the State treasury to the credit of Randolph county from the apportionment for the year 1904. School fund.
Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SWAINSBORO, SCHOOL DISTRICT OF INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the Swainsboro School District, in Emanuel county, and define the boundaries of the same; to establish a board of education therein; to provide for the election of the same, and to confer on said board certain powers; to regulate the management and control of schools in said district, and to provide revenue for the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, and the ratification of the same, as hereinafter provided, there shall be established a corporate school district in and about the city of Swainsboro, in Emanuel county, to be known as the Swainsboro School District, which district shall extend from the court-house in said city, as a center, outwards in all directions a distance of one mile. Swainsboro school district, public schools for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the management and control of all schools in said district shall be vested in a board to be known as the Board of Education of Swainsboro School District, composed of seven persons, and which board, by that name and style, shall have perpetual succession, have and use a common seal, have a right to sue and be sued, and shall have power to purchase, receive and hold to them and their successors in office, for
school purposes, any estate, real, personal, and of every kind and character, and to sell, or otherwise dispose of the same, as hereinafter provided. Board of education.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That Jesse Thompson, Sr., William Warren, J. Alex. Smith, James L. Moore, S. G. Williams, J. R. Rountree and F. C. Brannen shall be, and are, hereby constituted the board of education, to carry into effect the provisions of this Act until the regular election of members of said board, which shall take place on the second Wednesday in December of each year. The first election under this Act shall be held on the second Wednesday in December, 1905, at which time there shall be three members for said board elected for one year, and four for two years from said date. Their successors in office shall serve for a term of two years from the date of their respective elections, and until their successors are elected. The board of education shall fill all vacancies occurring in said board. The persons hereinbefore named shall serve until the first election above specified. Members of board.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That said board of education shall, immediately after this Act goes into operation, organize by electing a president, vice-president, secretary and treasurer, which president and vice-president shall be members of said board, and which treasurer may, or may not, be a member of said board, and which secretary shall not be a member of said board. No member shall receive compensation for his services, except the secretary and treasurer, whose compensation shall be fixed by the board at the beginning of their terms, and shall not be thereafter changed during said terms. The secretary and treasurer may be removed from office by the board for sufficient cause, in their discretion. The secretary and treasurer shall each give good and sufficient bond, to be fixed and approved by the board. No person shall be a member of said board, or fill the office of secretary or treasurer who is not a bona fide resident of said school district. Officers.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That said board of education shall have the power to adopt a system of public schools in said district, to elect a superintendent, and prescribe his duties, and to remove him for cause, in their discretion; to employ, suspend or remove teachers and fix their compensation by salary or otherwise; to provide schoolhouses by rent, building, purchase or otherwise, to take and hold title to such property, to make such rules and regulations for the government of themselves and such schools as they may deem proper, not in conflict with the laws of this State, and to do any and all things to promote the educational
interests of said district not in conflict with the provisions of this Act, or the laws of this State; provided, that said board shall not have the power to purchase property, where the purchase price exceeds one hundred dollars, or sell it without the consent of a majority of the qualified voters of said district, to be ascertained by an election to be held for that purpose, notice of which election shall be given by said board for twenty days prior to the holding of the same, and which election shall be held in accordance with the laws governing the election of members of the Legislature, and in which election the returns shall be made to the board of education, who shall publish the same; and any citizen may contest the legality of said election, or the correctness of said returns in the same manner as contests are made in the elections of justices of the peace and constables; provided, further, that said board may purchase property sold under tax executions issued by its authority, as hereinafter provided, as well as fuel, crayons, erasers, and other articles of necessity to meet the current demands of the schools without an election. Powers of board.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That there shall be established a school for not less than seven nor more than ten scholastic months in each year, the length of said term to be in the discretion of the board. The curriculum in said schools shall be only such as is taught in the system of public schools maintained by the State, except that the board may provide for a higher curriculum to be paid for by the patrons who may send pupils desiring to be taught in said higher curriculum. There shall be one, and only one, school for white children and one, and only one, school for colored children in said district. All children entitled to the benefit of public schools under the laws of this State, and whose parents, guardians or natural protectors reside within the corporate limits of said district, shall be admitted into the aforesaid schools, the colored children into the colored school, and the white children into the white school, upon the payment of such admittance or incidental fee only as the board of education may deem necessary. Children of non-residents and such others as may not be entitled to the benefit of these schools may be admitted upon such terms as may be prescribed by the board of education, not in conflict with the laws of this State. Schools.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That after the ratification of this Act, it shall be the duty of the county school commissioner of Emanuel county, and he is hereby required, to pay over to the treasurer of said board of education, under such rules as the said board may prescribe not in conflict with the rules and regulations
of the county board of education, the portion of the public school funds of said county to which the schools established under this Act for said district may be entitled under the rules of distribution of the public school fund. School fund.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That immediately after the ratification of this Act, and by or on the first Wednesday in January of each succeeding year, the board of education shall determine what amount of money it will be necessary to raise by taxation to defray the expenses of said schools for the scholastic year, and said board shall be required to levy and collect the same, and said secretary shall be the tax-collector and exercise all the powers of a tax-collector in the collection of said taxes; provided, that the said amount shall not exceed one-half of one per cent of the taxable property in said district. Said tax shall be collected annually, or semi-annually, or at such time or times as the board of education may fix and direct and when collected, shall be turned over to the treasurer of said board, and together with the amount received from the public school fund the admission and tution fees, which may be collected, and any other funds which may come into the hands of the board for school purposes, shall constitute a school fund to be expended in defraying the expenses necessary for the maintenance of said schools, and shall be paid out only on the order of, and as directed by, the board of education. School tax.
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the tax shall be levied and collected on the tax returns made for State and county purposes for the year last preceding the said tax levy.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That the sheriff of Emanuel county shall be, ex officio, the executing officer of said district, to serve all writs, tax fi. fas., make sales thereunder, and perform such like duties; but the board may select or appoint a resident of said school district, who shall not be a member of said board, or fill any other office thereunder, to perform such acts and duties as pertain to the executing officer of said district, to act whenever the sheriff, for any reason can not act, declines to act, or it is not convenient for him to act, and either the said sheriff or said appointed bailiff may legally serve all writs, notices and all papers and levy tax fi fas. and make sales thereunder. That, for issuing fi fas. against tax delinquents the secretary shall be entitled to a fee of fifty cents for each fi. fa. issued, to be taxed against and paid by, such tax delinquents, and for levying and settling each tax fi fa., the sheriff or bailiff shall be entitled to the sum of one dollar, to be paid by the defendant in fi fa., and for making
sales under said fi fas., the said sheriff or bailiff shall be entitled to the same commissions as allowed to the sheriffs of this State, to be paid by the defendant in fi fa. For other services rendered by said sheriff or bailiff he shall receive such compensation as may be fixed by the board. All sales of real estate under tax fi. fas., shall be advertised once a week for four weeks in the newspaper in which sheriff's sales for Emanuel county are advertised, before said sales shall take place, which sales shall be made before the court-house door in Swainsboro, Ga., as sheriff's sales are made, and of personal property, notice of sale shall be posted at the court-house door in said city of Swainsboro, for four weeks, at which tax sales the said board of education may bid and buy in property to be held and used for school purposes, under the same rules as to redemption as are provided by the laws of this State. When property is levided upon under tax fi fas., the same defenses only, and the same rules as to claims, and the same modes and requirements and methods of procedure shall prevail, as obtain under the laws of this State, in like cases, except that claims to realty shall be returned to the superior court of Emanuel county and other issues shall be returned to the city court of Swainsboro, or such other court as may take the place hereafter, of said city court. Writs, etc., to be served by sheriff. Tax sales.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That the board of education of Emanuel county shall not establish any other school or contract with any other person to teach a school of any character in said district, nor shall any of the State school funds be paid to any other school in said district than the schools herein provided for. Other schools not established in district.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That in case any school property acquired by said board of education, under any provision of this Act or otherwise, be sold, the fund derived from such sale shall be reinvested in other property to be used for school purposes. School property, sale of.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That before this Act shall become operative, its adoption shall be submitted to the legally qualified voters of said district, for which purpose the persons hereinbefore named, shall, within six months after its passage, order an election, of which ten days' notice shall be given by posting in five conspicuous places in said district, in which notice, the time, place and purpose of said election shall be stated, and which election shall be held under the same rules and regulations as the election of mayor of the city of Swainsboro. The legally qualified voters only of such school district shall be allowed to vote in said election, or in any other election, held in said school district
for any purpose, and the registration lists last prepared by the county registrar before any such election herein provided for shall constitute the highest evidence as to who are qualified voters in said district, and no one shall vote in said elections hereunder except those who registered for the last preceding State election. At said election of adoption, those favoring the adoption of this Act, shall have printed or written on their ballots For the establishment of public schools, and those opposing the adoption of this Act shall have printed or written on their ballots Against the establishment of public schools, and if two-thirds of the qualified voters in said district shall vote in said election for the establishment of public schools, this Act shall immediately become operative, and said Board shall put said schools in operation as soon as practicable thereafter. Should the result of the election herein provided for, be against the establishment of public schools, the board of education of said district as hereinbefore constituted, may order another election once every six months thereafter, until this Act and public schools are adopted. Ratification of act by voters.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That the board of education shall annually make a report to the public in writing of the condition of said schools, and oftener if they deem necessary, and they shall accompany their reports with the treasurer's report of a full and itemized statement of all moneys received and expended by said board. Board of education, annual report of.
Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: THOMASVILLE, PUBLIC SCHOOLS FOR, SYSTEM AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved November 30, 1900, establishing a system of public schools in the city of Thomasville, Thomas county, Georgia, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted, That from and after the passage of this Act, the above-recited Act be amended by adding at the end of section 5, and as a part of said section, the following:
Said board shall provide and adopt rules for the examination of all teachers employed in said school and no teachers shall be employed by them whose written examination does not average eighty-five (85) per cent. Thomasville, public schools of, examination of teachers for.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: WADLEY, PUBLIC SCHOOLS FOR, SYSTEM AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to establish a public school system for the town of Wadley, Georgia, approved August 6, 1903, so as to strike out certain sections, and sub-sections of said Act, and to insert other sections in lieu of said stricken sections, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That sub-section three of section five and all of section seven of an Act approved August 6, 1903, amending the public school system of the town of Wadley, in the county of Jefferson, be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Wadley, school system for, amended.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, all funds coming into the hands of the county school commissioner of the county of Jefferson, from the State school fund, be paid over by said county school commissioner to the treasurer of the board of education of the said town of Wadley, Georgia. School funds.

Sec. 3. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: WARESBORO, SCHOOL DISTRICT OF IN WARE COUNTY, ACT INCORPORATING AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend section nine (9) of an Act incorporating the Waresboro school district in Ware county, approved August 18, 1903, by striking from the second and third lines of said section the words coming into the hands of the county school commissioner, and by striking from the fifth line of said section the words said commissioner, and inserting in lieu thereof the words the State School Commissioner. ' And by amending section 2 of said Act by striking all of section 2 after the word shall in the second line of said section and inserting in lieu thereof the following: include and extend to the outward bounds of lots numbers 37, 38, 39, 40, 52, 53, 54, 55, 56, 81, 82, 83, 84, 85, 86, 87, 88, 97, 98, 99, 100, 101, 102, 103, 125, 126, 127, 128, 129, 130, 131, 132, 133, 134, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 148, 149, 150, 151, 172, 173, 174, 175 and 177, and all being situated in the eighth district of Ware county Georgia, making a district of forty-eight lots.
law.p:
Sec. 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, section nine (9) of the Act incorporating the Waresboro school district, in Ware county, approved August 18, 1903, be amended by striking from the second and third lines of said section the words coming into the hands of the county school commissioner, and by striking from the fifth line of said section the words said commissioner and inserting in lieu thereof the words State School Commissioner, so that said section when so amended shall read as follows: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all funds coming into the hands of the State School Commissioner to which the schools in this district are entitled shall be paid directly to the secretary and treasurer of said board of trustees by said State School Commissioner. All children who are entitled to the benefit of the public school funds of this State shall be admitted to said schools. The said trustees may, by a majority vote, refuse to admit any child or pupil to said school, or may expel them from the same, at any time, if, in the judgment of said trustees, it
would be detrimental to the moral or general welfare of said school or pupils therein to allow them to enter or remain in said school. Waresboro school district, school funds for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Act incorporating said Waresboro school district in Ware county, Georgia, from and after the passage of this Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking from said section all of said section following the word shall in the second line of said section, and inserting in lieu thereof the following: include and extend to the outward bounds of lots Nos. 37, 38, 39, 40, 52, 53, 54, 55, 56, 81, 82, 83, 84, 85, 86, 87, 88, 97, 98, 99, 100, 101, 102, 103, 125, 126, 127, 128, 129, 130, 131, 132, 133, 134, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 148, 149, 150, 151, 172, 173, 174, 175 and 177, all being situated in the eighth (8th) district of Ware county, Georgia, making a district of forty-eight lots, so that said section, when so amended shall read as follows: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the corporate limits of said district shall include and extend to the outward bounds of lots numbers 37, 38, 39, 40, 52, 53, 54, 55, 56, 81, 82, 83, 84, 85, 86, 87, 88, 97, 98, 99, 100, 101, 102, 103, 125, 126, 127, 128, 129, 130, 131, 132, 133, 134, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 148, 149, 150; 151, 172, 173, 174, 175 and 177, all being situated in the eighth (8th) district of Ware county, Georgia, making a district of forty-eight lots. Territorial limits of district.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: WEST POINT, PUBLIC SCHOOLS FOR, SYSTEM AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to authorize the city of West Point, in Troup county, to organize a public school system independent of the public school system of the State of Georgia, and for other purposes, approved February 7, 1877, by providing how the proportion of the public school money due this system shall be paid, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That section 1 of the above-recited Act be, and the same is hereby, amended by adding at the end of said section the following words, to wit: Said officer shall file a copy of said reports with the county school commissioner of Troup county, and said public school system of West Point shall draw its pro rata share of the public school money apportioned each year to said county, and the county school commissioner shall pay the same over to the person authorized to receive it. So that said section amended shall read as follows: Section 1. That the city of West Point in the county of Troup, be and is hereby authorized to organize a public school system independent of the public school system of this State. That said organization shall draw its pro rata share of all educational funds raised by the State; and that the chief executive officer of this organization shall make the same regular reports to the State School Commissioner as are required from the county commissioners of the public school system of this State. Said officer shall file a copy of said report with the county school commissioner of Troup county, and this public school system shall draw its pro rata share of the public school money appropriated each year to said county, and the county school commissioner shall pay the same over to the person authorized to receive it. West Point public schools, public school fund for.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: ABBEVILLE, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Abbeville as the city of Abbeville, and to confer additional powers on the said corporation, and to codify, amend and supersede all previous Acts incorporating the town of Abbeville, and granting a new charter to the said town, under the name of the city of Abbeville, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That section sixteen of the Act entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Abbeville, as the city of Abbeville, and to confer additional powers on the said corporation and to codify, amend and supersede all previous Acts incorporating the town of Abbeville, and granting a new charter to the said town, under the name of the city of Abbeville, and for other purposes, approved December 2, 1897, be, and the same is, hereby repealed, and in lieu thereof the following is enacted: The mayor and council of the city of Abbeville are hereby empowered and authorized, and it shall be their duty to require every male citizen between the ages of sixteen and fifty, except such as are exempt from road duty by the general laws of this State and who have been bona fide citizens of said city for the space of ten days, to work the streets of said city not to exceed ten days in any one year; and it is hereby made the duty of such persons to work on said streets, not to exceed said period, when duly required so to do, by said mayor and council; provided, nevertheless, that any person so ordered or required to work on said streets may relieve himself of said duty by paying in lieu thereof, a sum, not to exceed four dollars in any one year, that may be fixed by said mayor and council; and in case no less amount shall have been fixed for said purpose, then, by paying over to the clerk of said city, the full sum of four dollars; the payment of which shall exempt the party so paying from working said streets for the term of one year. On failure to work as aforesaid, or to pay said amount, as aforesaid, the offender, on conviction, shall be punished by fine not to exceed $100, or by imprisonment in the common guard-house not to exceed sixty days, or by labor on said streets or on the public works of said municipality, under the proper officer, not to exceed ninety days. Abbeville, street work or commutation tax in.

law.shorttitle: ADRIAN, TOWN OF, INCORPORATED.
