The incorporate limits of the city of Broxton shall be as follows, to wit: Commencing at the well in the front yard of the residence of Jesse Lott, Esq., as the center of a circle and extending a distance of one mile in every direction from said center, thus creating a circle two miles in diameter. The said territory so covered by said circle includes all of what has been heretofore known as the village of Broxton. Corporate limits.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the municipal government of the city of Broxton shall be vested in a mayor and four aldermen, who shall be elected in the manner hereinafter set out and who shall compose the city council of Broxton. City council.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the expiration of the term of office of the Hon. E. H. Moore, the present mayor of the town of Broxton, which expires the first Thursday in January, 1905, there shall be elected annually a mayor for said city for a term of one year. Mayor

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That at the next annual election held the first Thursday in January, 1905, there shall be elected four aldermen, one from each of the four wards of the city, to hold office one year each, and annually thereafter there shall be elected four aldermen. Aldermen.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and aldermen
in all cases shall hold their offices until their successors are elected and qualified, and in the event that the office of mayor shall become vacant by death, resignation, removal or otherwise, the mayor pro tem., or in case his seat is vacant, a majority of the council shall order an election by giving at least ten days' notice in any one or more papers, or at two or more of the most public places in the city. And said election so held shall be managed in the same manner as the election to be held in chief according to the provisions of the charter; provided, however, that if the office of mayor shall become vacant at any time three months of the expiration of his term of office, the mayor pro tem. shall act as mayor during the balance of said term, and exercise all the rights and powers of mayor of said city. Vacancies in offices, how filled.

Sec. 7. The mayor shall be the chief executive of said city; he shall see that all the laws and ordinances of said city are faithfully executed, shall examine and audit all accounts against the city before payment; shall receive a salary to be fixed by the council preceding his election, said salary never to exceed fifty dollars for every five hundred inhabitants of said city, which shall not be changed during his term of office; he shall have power to convene the council in extra session whenever in his judgment the exigencies require it. Mayor, executive powers and compensation.

Sec. 8. The mayor, or in his absence the mayor pro tem., shall have full power and authority to hold at such times and places and under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by ordinances a mayor's court for said city for the trial of offenders against the ordinances of said city, and impose such penalties for the violation thereof as may be prescribed by ordinance, not exceeding one hundred and fifty dollars and imprisonment or labor on public works for one hundred days for each offense; except special cases mentioned in section 51 of this charter, a like authority may be exercised by any three members of the council in the absence of the mayor or mayor pro tem. Mayor's court.

Sec. 9. The mayor and each alderman shall be, to all intents and purposes, a justice of the peace so far as to enable them, or any one or either of them, to issue warrants for offenses committed within the corporate limits of said city, which warrants shall be directed to the chief of police, or police, and by them executed, and to commit to jail in the county of Coffee, or to admit to bail offenders (provided the offense is bailable), for their appearance before a court of competent jurisdiction in the county of Coffee; and it shall be the duty of the jailer of said county
to recive all such persons so committed and safely keep the same until discharged by due course of law. Mayor and aldermen to exercise powers of justices of the peace.

Sec. 10. The mayor shall have no vote except in case of a tie; he shall have the revision of all ordinances, orders and regulations passed by the council, when such order, ordinance or resolution directs, contemplates or authorizes the payment of any sum of one hundred dollars by the city, or liability of the city, and the said mayor shall have four days at the meeting at which the council voted therein, in which to file with the clerk, in writing, his dissent; but the council may, in the manner prescribed by this charter for voting on such questions, pass the order, ordinance or resolution, notwithstanding the veto, by vote of two-thirds, to be taken by yeas and nays, and entered on the minutes. In the absence of the mayor this power may be exercised by the mayor pro tem., provided such veto power shall not be used to prevent the will of the city, as the same may be expressed by an election for any particular purpose, from being carried out. Mayor, powers of.

Sec. 11. Before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office he shall take and prescribe the following oath before some judge of the superior court, judge of city court or ordinary, or justice of the peace: I, (A. B.), do solemnly swear that I will, to the utmost of my ability, discharge the duties of mayor of the city of Broxton, during my continuance in office; so help me, God. Mayor oath of.

Sec. 12. Be it enacted, That the city shall be laid off into four wards, said wards to be as nearly square as practicable, considering population and territory. One alderman shall be elected from each ward at the next annual election, by voters qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly, to be elected for a term of one year. City wards Aldermen.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That before an alderman enters upon the discharge of the duties of his office, he shall take and prescribe the following oath before some justice of the peace, judge of city court, or retiring mayor: I, (A. B.) do solemnly swear that I will, to the utmost of my ability, discharge the duties of alderman of the city of Broxton, during my continuance in office; so help me God. Aldermen, oath of.

Sec. 14. It shall be the duty of the mayor at the first meeting after his qualification or as soon thereafter as practicable in each year, to appoint the following and such other standing committees as the mayor may direct. 1, street committee; 2, finance committee; 3, health committee; 4, ordinance committee; 5, police committee; 6, public school committee. Said committees shall
consist of three members of the aldermen, the first-named to be the chairman of the committee appointed. The several committees herein provided for shall have special supervision of their respective branches of the city government as is designated by the name of each committee. Any member may be removed from his committee by a majority vote of all the aldermen at any time for lack of capacity, neglect of duty, and upon removal the mayor shall fill such vacancy by appointment. Standing committees, mayor to appoint.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no resolution or by-law, having for its object the increase of the indebtedness of the city, or the expenditure of its revenues and moneys, shall become a law and binding until the same shall have received a majority of the council. When any such vote or resolution or by-law is passed, any alderman may give notice of a motion to reconsider, and such notice shall operate to delay the question until said reconsideration can be acted on at the next regular meetings of the council, which shall be the first Tuesday evening of each month; each member shall have the right to call for the yeas and nays, which shall be recorded on the minutes The mayor or presiding officer shall have no vote except in case of a tie; three shall constitute a quorum of the council for the transaction of business; provided, the mayor or mayor pro tem. constitutes one of the number, and in all cases a less number may adjourn from time to time and compel the attendance of absentees. Municipal revenues, how expended.

Sec. 16. That the mayor and council shall have full power of authority to pass all by-laws and ordinances respecting public buildings and grounds, water-works and electric light plants, parks, work-houses, public houses, ponds, mill slab pits, wagons, carriages, carts, drugs, pumps, saw-mill plants, dry-kilns, artesian wells, wells, fire engines, care of the poor, suppression of disorderly houses, houses of ill-fame, cruelty to animals, for the prevention and punishment of disorderly conduct and conduct likely to disturb the peace and tranquility of any citizen, or citizens thereof, every other by-law, regulation and ordinance that may seem to them proper for the security of the peace, health, order and good government of said city. Police powers.

Sec. 17. The said mayor and council shall have authority and power to prescribe adequate penalties for all offenses, by fines not to exceed one hundred and fifty dollars and imprisonment in the city jail, not exceeding one hundred days for each offense, except in special cases mentioned in section 51 of this charter, to enforce the payment of fines by compelling offenders and those who refuse
or fail to pay said fines, by work on the streets or public works of said city; they shall have authority to compel offenders sentenced to imprisonment in the city jail as aforesaid, to labor on the public works or streets, to be regulated by ordinance. Penalties for offenses, mayor and council to prescribe.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted, That the chief of police and police shall have the right and power and privilege to release any person arrested for violating a city ordinance within the corporate limits of said city, upon some person giving a bond, to be approved by the chief of police, or mayor of said city, payable to the city of Broxton, conditioned to pay the obligees in said bond an amount fixed by the chief of police or mayor of said city, in the event said person arrested does not appear before corporate authorities at the time and place specified in said bond, and from time to time until said person arrested is tried for the offense for which he or she was arrested; provided, that the city authorities may refuse to release on bond any and all persons whose appearance in said city would likely be dangerous, indecent, or in violation of any city ordinance. Appearance bond.

Sec. 19. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person who has been arrested, charged with the violation of any law or ordinance of the city of Broxton, and has given bond for his or her appearance before the proper corporate authorities to answer such charge, fails to appear at the place and time fixed and recited in bond, said bond shall be forfeited, and a rule nisi be directed at the principal and securities, shall issue directing and requiring them to show cause before the mayor's court, at a sitting of said court to be held not less than sixty days from the time of the forfeiture nisi, why the bond shall not be absolutely forfeited, copies of which rule nisi shall be served on the principal and securities on said bond at least twenty days before the sitting of the court to which it is made returnable, either personally, or by having same at the most notorious place of abode of the person upon whom service is perfected, or by publishing the same once a week for four weeks prior to the sitting of the court to which the same is returnable, in the newspaper published in said city or county in which the sheriff's advertisements are published. If, at such return term no sufficient cause be shown to the contrary, the forfeiture shall be made final and absolute; and execution shall issue against the principal and securities in said bond, or such of them as have been served, for the full amount thereof and all costs, which execution shall be signed by the clerk of the council and the mayor of said city, and shall have the same lien and binding effect upon the property of the defendants therein
as executions issued upon judgments in justice or superior courts. Said execution shall be directed to the chief of police of the city of Broxton, or any marshal or police thereof, and to all and singular the sheriffs or deputy-sheriffs or constables of this State, by any one of whom the same may be executed. Appearance bond, how forfeited.

Sec. 20. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the city council of Broxton shall have power and authority to contract debts and issue bonds of said city under and in accordance with the limitations provided in the Constitution of the State and from the funds arising from the sale of any bonds thus issued may establish and maintain a system of water-works, a system of electric lights, a system of public schools, erect school buildings and city hall, erect public library, or grounds for parks, or any other improvement, convenient or necessary for the use or convenience of the citizens of said city, for any other lawful purpose and under the limitations therein stated, and to levy a tax of five-eighths of one per cent. for each annually upon the assessed property of said city to discharge such debts. Municipal bonds.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That with the consent of two-thirds of the qualified voters of said city, the mayor and council shall have power and authority to issue bonds for the erection of public schools in said city and to levy an annual tax not to exceed five-eighths of one per cent. upon the assessed taxable property of said city to maintain said schools; that the pro rata amount raised from such levy upon the property of the negro shall be used to establish and maintain public schools for the negro; and the money thus raised by levy upon the property of the whites shall be used to establish and maintain public schools for white persons. The mayor and council shall provide for the election of nine members of the board of public school trustees, who shall be elected by the people to serve during good behavior, all vacancies to be by regular election sixty days after vacancy occurs. Said trustees shall receive no compensation for services. Two trustees to be elected from each ward on the first Thursday in January of each year and shall serve for one year. One trustee serving as chairman of said board of public school trustees, shall be elected from the city at large and shall serve one year, and elected on the first Thursday in January of each year thereafter. Said board shall have the authority to employ a superintendent, and other teachers for said public schools and to prescribe their duties and to suspend or discharge them for good causes, to prescribe the terms upon which pupils shall be admitted to said public schools, and to make such rules and regulations
and by-laws as they deem right and proper for the maintaining a system of public schools for said city. Said board of public school trustees shall have the power to fix the compensation of all teachers employed in said public schools and to pay same. Said board shall keep the minutes of each meeting, which shall be open to the inspection of the mayor and aldermen or any other citizen of said city. The public schools shall be under the supervision of the mayor and aldermen. That after such public school system shall be adopted by said city, the board of education of Coffee county shall not grant any license to or contract with any person to teach a school of any character in said city, nor shall any of the State fund be paid to any school than herein provided for, and it shall not be lawful for said county board of education to establish or maintain any school or schools within two miles of the corporate limits of said city, without the consent of said board of public school trustees of said city. Public schools, bonds and tax for. Public school; trustees.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted, That the State School Commissioner is hereby authorized to pay over to the chairman of the board of public school trustees of the city of Broxton for the use of the public schools therein, under such rules and regulations as said board may prescribe, the just and full proportion of the common school funds arising from any and all sources belonging to, or due said city, to be by said board of public school trustees expended in the establishment and maintenance of said public schools in said city of Broxton, as may be authorized by the Constitution and laws of this State. Common school fund.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That with the consent of two-thirds of the qualified voters of said city, the mayor and council shall have power and authority to issue bonds to erect a school building for the high school or public schools of said city, to purchase a site within said city for building; and issue and sell bonds of said city to pay for said building; to levy and collect a tax on all property within said city, from year to year to pay accruing interest on muturing bonds issued to pay for said building; and to levy an annual tax, not to exceed five-eights of one per cent. upon the assessed taxable property of said city to maintain and pay for said building by the issuance of school building bonds. School building, bonds for.

Sec. 24. Be it enacted, That on the first Thursday in January, 1905, there shall be held an election, and annually thereafter, under the supervision of the freeholders residents of said city, who shall take the usual oath prescribed for managers of elections for State and county purposes; that said election managers
shall make a return to the mayor and council of said election by noon of the day following after said election, and the persons so elected at said election shall be sworn in by the mayor of the outgoing council; that persons residents of said city and who are entitled by law to vote for members of the legislature from Coffee county, who have been residents aforsaid for the space of ninety days, shall be deemed qualified voters for mayor and council aforesaid. City officers, election of.

Sec. 25. Be it further enacted, That the next annual election, to be held on the first Thursday in January, 1905, and annually thereafter, there shall be elected by the qualified voters of said city a clerk and treasurer, said election to be conducted as election for mayor and aldermen, the duties and requirements of said clerk and treasurer shall be fixed by ordinance. The compensation of said clerk and treasurer shall be fixed by the mayor and aldermen, and shall be paid out of a fund arising from taxes collected annually for the expenses of said city. Clerk and treasurer.

Sec. 26. Be it further enacted, For the purpose of enabling the members of the council to know at all times the true financial condition of the city, the clerk shall prepare and read and enter upon the minutes at each regular session a balance sheet showing the gross revenue of the fiscal year, and expenses voted by the council and disbursed as before provided, up to that time, also the amount of the several sums, estimated as aforesaid, and what part of the same has been up to that time appropriated and what part remains unappropriated. Clerk to prepare balance sheets.

Sec. 27. Be it further enacted, That the treasurer of the city at the close of each fiscal year shall make a full tabular statement of the assets and resources of the city, and at the end of each fiscal year shall make an itemized estimate for the probable and necessary expenses for the ensuing year, which statement and estimate shall be published and verified by the finance committee; no greater amount of revenue shall be raised the ensuing year than the amount of said estimate, together with salaries of officers, unless in case of emergency, to be judged by the council. Treasurer to make estimate of expenses for ensuing year.

Sec. 28. Be it further enacted, That when said new council have been installed, at their first regular meeting they shall proceed to elect a police force, consisting of a chief and such other force as may be necessary for the protection of said city, said election to be determined by ballot, and the person receiving a majority of votes cast shall be deemed elected; that no person shall be eligible except he be a resident of said city and possessing the same qualification of voters as before specified. Police force.

Sec. 29. Be it further enacted, That the chief and other police as may be elected shall take an oath faithfully and impartially to discharge the duties imposed on them by law and give the city ordinances, and shall give such bond as may be required of them by city ordinance. Their salaries shall be fixed by the council electing them, and their term of office shall commence on the day of their election and continue one year. Policemen, oath, etc.

Sec. 30. The compensation of the said chief and such other officers as may be elected, shall be prescribed by ordinance and shall not be increased or diminished during their respective terms, no extra pay or allowance or cost shall be made to them or either of them. It shall be their duty to make arrests in the manner prescribed by law of persons violating any penal law of this State; they shall perform such other duty as shall be imposed by the laws of this State or ordinance of the city council. It shall be the duty of the chief of police and such other police officers to prosecute offenders before the superior court of Coffee county. For a failure to perform any duty required by law, he or they may be suspended or removed from office by the mayor and council. The mode of preferring accusation against him or them shall be prescribed by city ordinance. The chief and police shall be uniformed and armed as to be readily recognized by the public as a peace officer. Such arms and uniforms to be furnished by the city and to remain the property of the city. Compensation and duties.

Sec. 31. For the purpose of raising revenues for the support and maintenance of said city government, said mayor and council shall have full power and authority, and they shall provide by ordinance for assessment, levy and collection of an ad valorem tax on all real and personal property within the corporate limits of said city, not exceeding one-half of one per cent. thereon. Ad valorem tax.

Sec. 32. The mayor and council shall have full power to elect at the same time the other city officers are elected three persons, freeholders, residents of said city as assessors, who shall hold their office for one year unless removed by the mayor and council for cause to be judged by them. It shall be the duty of the assessors to assess the value of the real estate within the corporate limits of said city, said assessors shall make return to said mayor and council and the said mayor and council shall place such assessment so returned in the hands of the clerk and treasurer, who shall enter the same on his book with other taxes, and the same shall be collected as other taxes of the city; provided, that if any tax-payer is dissatisfied with said assessment of assessors he or she may appeal to the mayor and council of the city of Broxton for a correction of said assessment within fifteen days
after assessors' return has been completed and handed in as provided for in this charter and the judgment of the mayor and council shall be final as the assessment; provided further, that the mayor and council shall publish each year as early as practicable in a paper in the city of Broxton, this section and section forty. Tax assessors.

Sec. 33. The said assessors before the enter on the discharge of their duties, shall take and subscribe an oath before the mayor faithfully and truly to assess all real estate within the corporate limits of said city, and to return such assessment to the mayor and council thereof, with the names of the owners thereof, and shall receive for their services such sums each as the mayor and council shall order. The mayor and council shall have full power and authority to elect at the same time the other officers are elected, a tax receiver and collector for said city, who shall be elected and hold his office for one year, unless removed for cause, to be judged of by the mayor and council; he shall give bond and good security to be fixed and judged by said mayor and council, payable to the city of Broxton for the faithful performance of his duties. He shall receive for his services such compensation as the mayor and council may prescribe, which shall not be increased or diminished during his term of office. His duties shall be prescribed by ordinance. Oath and compensation of assessors. Tax receiver and collector

Sec. 34. The said mayor and council shall have full power and authority to require any person, firm, company or corporation engaged in prosecuting or carrying on any trade, business, calling or avocation within the corporate limits of said city, to register their names and business, calling or avocation or profession annually and to require such person, company or association to pay for such registration, and for license to engage in, prosecute or carry on such business, calling or profession aforesaid, not exceeding $50.00 per annum; this restriction not to apply to the business of selling spirituous or intoxicating liquors, and not to apply to manufacturing industries, all manufacturing industries being by this Act exempt from tax for the next ten years. Business licenses.

Sec. 35. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the sale of spirituous or intoxicating or malt liquors, or bitters or commercial ciders, or domestic wines not of their own manufacture, or liquors of any kind, which, if drunk to excess, will produce intoxication, be, and the same are, hereby forever prohibited within the corporate limits of the city of Broxton, and in order to carry out the spirit and effect of this section, that the mayor and council of said city shall have the power to enter
any place of business where it is suspected that any part or parts of this section is being violated, and to have any drink that is there being sold or offered for sale, analyzed to ascertain whether or not said drink will intoxicate when drunk to excess. Intoxicating liquors, sale of prohibited.

Sec. 36. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council may have authority and power to issue executions against the property of any person or persons, who fail to pay subscriptions for water and lights to said city of Broxton, and said executions shall operate as tax executions. Water and light subscribers, executions against.

Sec. 37. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall have executive power and authority to grant franchises to person or persons for the purpose of erecting water system, light system and telephone system, and any other purpose for which the public streets of said city are used; provided that no person or persons shall be given an exclusive franchise. Water, light and telephone systems, franchises for.

Sec. 38. The said mayor and council shall have power to pass such ordinances as they may see proper, in regard to granting or not granting license to theatrical companies or performances or for shows or other exhibitions; provided, the price to be paid for such license, when granted shall not exceed $100.00 for each performance or exhibition. Shows and other exhibitions, licenses for.

Sec. 39. The mayor and council shall have full power and authority to prohibit the selling of lager beer or other fermented drinks without obtaining of a license for that purpose. They shall have full power and authority to license billiard tables and ten-pin alleys, and all public billiard tables kept or used for the purpose of playing, gaming or renting, and all public ten-pin alleys and nine-pin alleys, or alleys of any kind which are kept or used for the purpose of renting the same and charge for said license a sum not exceeding $50.000 on each table, alley or track. Lager beer, etc., sale of. Games, license of.

Sec. 40. The said mayor and council shall have full power and authority to assess a tax on such persons carrying on the brokerage business in said city, if not more than three hundred dollars per annum, in addition to all other tax they may pay. They shall have power to license pawnbrokers within their respective jurisdiction, define by ordinance their power and privilege, to impose taxes upon them, to revoke their license, and generally to exercise such superintendence over pawn-brokers as will insure fair dealings between them and their customers. Brokers, tax on.

Sec. 41. Be it further enacted, That the said mayor and council shall have power to levy and collect from itinerant traders, who may directly or indirectly, by themselves or others, sell any goods, wares or merchandise in said city, such tax as to them
may seem proper; provided, that no person or persons shall be prohibited from selling free from tax any number of books, maps, charts or mathematical instruments made in this State, or elsewhere within said city. Peddlers.
Sec. 42. Be it further enacted, That the annual expenses of the city of Broxton be so restricted as not to exceed the annual income of the city. Annual expenses.

Sec. 43. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall make or cause to be made an early assessment of city property, so that the returns of the assessors can be completed and handed in by the first day of May of each year, and after all other returns for taxation shall be made, which in all cases shall be made by the first day of June of each year. Upon the return of the assessors being handed in as above provided, the said mayor and council by the twentieth day of June thereafter, shall cause an estimate to be made up and entered on the minutes showing the gross amount of the income of the city for the fiscal year, ascertain by the assessment of a tax, not exceeding one-half of one per centum on the taxable property of the city, and a reasonable estimate of the other taxes and sources of revenue, and shall apportion and set apart the same as follows: First, reduction of any debt; second, street force; third, police; fourth, salaries; fifth, contingent funds; which several sums taken in the aggregate shall not exceed the amount of income from all sources for the year in question. The annual appropriations as made by the council may be varied as to the amounts distributed to the several heads at the first meeting held in August and November. These variations not to retract on expired quarters and to enlarge in any manner the aggregate appropriations for the year, and no money shall be drawn from the city treasury except by the order of the mayor or approved by the finance committee, which order shall specify the fund from which it is drawn, and unless it so specifies the fund from which it is to be drawn, it shall be void, and the said mayor and finance committee shall be liable to the city for the refunding of any amounts drawn upon such orders, to be recorded in an action brought in any court of this State having jurisdiction thereof, in the name of the clerk and treasurer for the use of the city and twelve and one-half per cent. of the recovery shall be his compensation; and if he fails to bring action within thirty days, the said sums may be recovered of him and his bondsmen at the suit of any citizen, and no action brought under this section or right of action shall be settled without
the consent of the judge before suit is pending upon the exhibition of the facts, and such consent entered on the minutes. Assessment and return of property for taxation. Appropriations.

Sec. 44. The mayor and council shall have full power and authority to open, lay out, to widen, straighten or otherwise change streets, alleys, squares and triangles in said city of Broxton, and condemn private property for these purposes. Whenever that said mayor and council shall exercise the power above-delegated, they shall appoint one freeholder, and the owners of said lot fronting on said street or alley shall on five days' notice, appoint one freeholder who shall proceed to assess the damages sustained, taking into consideration the advantages derived by the owner or owners of said lots in consequence of the opening, widening, straightening or otherwise changing said streets and alleys, and in case said assessors can't agree, they shall select a third freeholder, the said assessors to take an oath that they will faithfully discharge their duties, and either party to have the right to enter an appeal to the superior court of Coffee county within ten days from the rendition of said award. Streets, alleys, etc.

Sec. 45. The said mayor and council shall have full power and authority to establish and fix such a system of grading and draining the streets of said city as they may deem proper. Streets, grading and draining of.

Sec. 46. All persons liable to perform road duty under the road laws of the State of Georgia, and residents of said city, shall be liable and subject to work on the streets of said city under the direction and control of the proper officers of said city; provided, that the mayor and council of said city shall have power to levy a street tax in lieu thereof; and, provided further, that all persons who shall fail or refuse to pay said street tax on or before such day as said mayor and council shall by ordinance require, the person failing shall be required, upon three days' notice, to do and perform street work as aforesaid, and upon a failure thereof such defaulter shall be liable to be dealt with by the mayor and council as for violation of other ordinances of said city, or may be compelled to work on the public works of said city, and no action brought under this section, or right of action, shall be settled without the consent of the judge before whom the suit is pending, upon exhibition of the facts, and such consent entered on the minutes. Street work and commutation tax.

Sec. 47. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall have power and authority to employ competent counsel for the city of Broxton, whose salary, term of office and duties shall be fixed by ordinance. City attorney.

Sec. 48. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That
the city council shall have power and the right to provide for the inspection of steam-boilers, to regulate and prevent the storage of gunpowder, tar, pitch, rosin, coal, oil, benzine, naptha, turpentine, hemp, cotton, petroleum, nitro-glycerine, dynamite, or any other combustible or explosive substances or material, and the use of lights in stables, shops and other places, and the building of bonfires; also to prevent and regulate the use of fireworks, firecrackers, torpedoes, roman candles, sky-rockets and other pyrotechnic displays. Combustibles and explosives.

Sec. 49. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the city council shall have a right and power to declare what shall be a nuisance, and to abate the same, and to provide for the punishment of the person or persons who may create, continue or suffer nuisances to exist; to appoint a board of health for the city of Broxton, and to prescribe their duties and powers; to establish and maintain a quarantine against contagious or infectious diseases; to do all acts and make all regulations which may be necessary and expedient for the promotion of the morals and health of the residents of said city, or for the suppression of disease; to establish and regulate cemeteries within or without the corporation, and to acquire lands therefor by gift, inheritance, or otherwise; provided, however, that the present cemetery shall not be extended in any but a northerly direction, and that the fund now in the city treasury and funds arising from the sale of lots in the present cemetery, known as the cemetery fund, shall not be used for any purpose except to maintain and beautify the present cemetery, and to require burial permits to be issued before anybody can be interred within the city limits. At any time the mayor and council of the city of Broxton may abolish the present cemetery and purchase lands for a new one, to compel the owner and user of any cellar, stable, pig-sty, privy, sewer, or any unwholesome or nauseous place or house, to cleanse, abate or remove the same, and to regulate the regulation thereof; to prohibit the slaughtering of any kind of animal within the corporate limits of said city. Municipal powers.

Sec. 50. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council of the city of Broxton shall have power and authority to punish by fine or imprisonment all vagrants and persons loitering about the streets of said city. Vagrants.

Sec. 51. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council of the city of Broxton shall have power and authority to elect at the first meeting of said council, or as soon thereafter as practicable, after the annual election on the first
Thursday in January, an engineer for said city, whose duties, salary and term of office shall be fixed by ordinance. City engineer.

Sec. 52. The said mayor and council shall have power and authority to establish and define the fire limits of said city, and from time to time, in their discretion, to extend and enlarge same, within which fire limits so established, and to be established, it shall not be lawful for any one to erect other than fire-proof buildings or structures of any kind, other than fire-proof, and should any one erect, or cause to be erected, within said limits so established any such buildings or structures, said mayor and council, after giving five days' notice, shall cause the same to be removed at the expense of the owners of such buildings or structures, the said expenses to be collected by executions issued by the clerk of the council; and said mayor and council shall have power to determine what buildings or structures are not fire-proof. Fire limits and buildings in.

Sec. 53. That the mayor and council shall have power and authority to provide for registration of voters prior to any municipal election in said city, to make all needful rules and regulations for the same, and require that no person be permitted to vote unless registered as aforesaid. Municipal elections.

Sec. 54. The mayor and council of said city shall have sole right to try all impeachments; when sitting for that purpose they shall be under oath or affirmation; when the mayor is to be tried, the council shall select one of their number to preside, and no person shall be convicted without the concurrence of all members present; judgment, in case of impeachment, shall not extend further than removal from office, and disqualification to hold any office of trust, honor or profit under this charter; but the party convicted shall, nevertheless, be liable and subject to trial and punishment according to law. Impeachments.

Sec. 55. Whenever any personal property has been levied on in the city of Broxton, if of a character to render its removal to the place of holding marshal's sales (which place shall hereinafter be fixed by ordinance) of more than ordinary expense or inconvenience, the same may be sold at any place within the corporate limits of said city at public outcry within the hours now provided by law, and after having given the notice required by law, provided the owner thereof gives his or her consent. Municipal sales.

Sec. 56. The mayor and council are hereby authorized to make proper arrangements for work on the public streets and public works of said city, or to farm out all persons sentenced to imprisonment for violation of the ordinances of said city. Convicts, work and hire of.

Sec. 57. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the
clerk and treasurer, or such other person as may be designated by the mayor and council, shall open a list or book for the registration of voters, ample notice of which shall be given by publication in a paper of said city, or by posting in two or more places for at least twenty days prior to any election, which list or book shall be finally closed for registration five days before said election, after which time no person shall be allowed to register. Each and every person registering shall give the number of the ward that he lives in, and the same shall be so recorded by the registrar, and each and every person applying to be registered shall make oath before the registrar in whose possession the list or book of registration is, who is hereby authorized to administer the same, which oath shall be written or printed on said list or book of registration as follows: I swear that I am twenty-one years of age, or will be by the time of the election now next to be held in said city of Broxton. By the next municipal election in the city of Broxton, I will have resided in the State of Georgia twelve months, and in Coffee county six months, and in the city of Broxton ninety days. I have paid all taxes, State, county and municipal required of me, except for the present year, and I am not otherwise disqualified to vote at said election. Any person registering and voting not qualified according to the foregoing oath shall be guilty of the offense of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished as prescribed in section 1039 of the Code of 1895. Registration of voters.

Sec. 58. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the registrar shall furnish the list or book of registration to the managers of the election, with an alphabetical list of the names of the registered voters, at the opening of the polls, and a like list of names from the different wards, and the managers shall be the judges of the qualification of all registered voters. Registration list.
Sec. 59. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: BRUNSWICK, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the city of Brunswick by providing new method of assessment of property and equalization of values; by providing that all salaries of officers shall be fixed yearly; by providing that all officers may be suspended by mayor and discharged by mayor and council; by providing a change in method of compensation of aldermen; by providing that all ordinances, except pertaining to fire, health and quarantine, shall be referred to committee before passage; by providing method of declaring a forfeiture of town commons leases; by providing that recitals in deeds by marshals and marshal's sales shall have the same force and effect as sheriff and other judicial sales; by providing that wherever a bond is required it shall be competent to accept a cash bond; by providing that execution of laws and ordinances shall be by officers or boards created by the mayor and council; by providing definite time for annual meeting; by defining what can be done at regular, and what at special meetings of the mayor and council, and how special meetings may be called and held; by providing that a specific proportion of the city revenues from taxes in excess of all moneys derived from taxes and rentals of town commons be set apart each year and applied to educational purposes; by providing that all licenses or specific taxes may be collected by execution; by providing rate of compensation for aldermen; by providing proportions to be paid by owners of property for street paving and repairing; by providing that publication of resolutions, ordinances, rules and regulations shall be sufficiently published by posting at court-house and city hall copy thereof, and that city printer shall give bond, and to amend the charter of the city of Brunswick generally, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia and it is hereby enacted by authority thereof, That for the year 1905, and all succeeding years assessment of the property of the city of Brunswick for taxation shall be made once every three years, commencing with the year 1905, except as to improvements upon real property and increase or decrease of personal property, which shall be assessed each year, and a board of equalization shall be elected for the year 1905 by the mayor and council
of the city of Brunswick, namely, to consist of three members of the citizens of the city of Brunswick, to serve for one, two and three years respectively, and one new member to be elected each succeeding year by the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick each election after the first being for a period of three years, and such board of equalization for the year 1905, and for each period of three years thereafter, after taking an oath to be provided by ordinance to faithfully perform the duties prescribed, shall examine the assessor's valuations of all property for taxation, hear evidence thereon, where deemed necessary, and equalize the valuation for taxation. Sitting at each three years' period not more than thirty days, and shall meet and pass upon valuations for intervening years of improvements of real estate and upon personal property assessed to procure an equalization thereof, and shall not sit in such intervening years more than ten days, and the final valuations of such board shall be binding on all property owners of the city of Brunswick, and upon the mayor and council of said city. This is to take the place of arbitrations of values. City of Brunswick, board of equalization for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the salaries of all officers of the city of Brunswick, whether elected by the people or the mayor and council, of the city of Brunswick, shall be fixed yearly, and not increased or diminished during the year for which fixed. City officers, salaries of.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all officers and members of boards elected by the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick may be suspended for cause from duty by the mayor or acting mayor, or by the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick, and such suspension continued by the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick, and at any regular meeting of the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick any such officer may be tried after ten days' notice upon charges of conduct unbecoming an officer and gentleman, such charges specifying in what such conduct consists, and a judgment of a majority of the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick finding such officer guilty, after such trial, of conduct unbecoming an officer and gentleman shall have the effect of discharging said officer from service as such officer, and shall be final and not reversible by any court. City officers, suspension and removal of

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all ordinances, except health, quarantine and fire ordinances, having a permanent character shall be referred to an ordinance committee, whose duty it shall be to report whether such ordinance is
provided for in any charter or ordinance provision in force before such ordinance shall be put upon its final passage. Ordinances, how passed.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the method of forfeiture of town commons leases which shall authorize the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick to reenter and take possession of the property described in such lease shall be by publication of a notice in the official journal of said city that rental or taxes, or both, are due, and that such possession will be taken into the custody of said city unless the same are paid within said thirty days. Or by publication by the clerk of the mayor and council of such notice by posting at the city hall and county court-house for said thirty days. Town commons, forfeiture of leases of.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all recitals in marshal's deeds and all marshal's sales shall have the same force and effect as in judicial sales under the laws of Georgia. Marshal's deeds and sales.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That wherever a bond is required in the city of Brunswick it shall be competent to accept a cash bond upon which judgment may be entered as against other bonds. Cash bonds authorized.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the execution of laws, ordinances and resolutions shall be by officers of said mayor and council of the city of Brunswick, or by boards created by said corporation for such purposes, such officers and members of all boards created for any purpose to be liable to trial and discharge as provided in section 3 of this Act, and the powers and duties of such officers and boards to be prescribed by ordinances not in conflict with the charter of said city of Brunswick. Executive powers.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That any act which may be lawfully done by the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick may be lawfully done at any special meeting of the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick. Mayor and council, special meetings of.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That for each and every year, commencing with the year 1905, there shall be appropriated by this Act for expenditure for public schools in said city, under the direction of the board of education of Glynn county, one-tenth of one per cent. on the taxable values assessed and collected for such year, separate from and exclusive of taxes and revenues collected from town commons. This section to take effect only after a vote of the lawful voters of Brunswick, at an election at which such question shall be voted upon under the Constitution and laws of Georgia. Public schools, appropriation for.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the annual meeting of the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick shall be held on the first Monday in January of each and every year, commencing with January, 1905, between 10 a. m. and 4 p. m., of that day; provided, that if providentially prevented, it may be held on any succeeding Monday in said month of January between the hours aforesaid. Mayor and council, annual meeting of.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all specific taxes or licenses may be collected by execution issued as is now provided for the collection of other taxes in the city of Brunswick. Specific taxes, how collected.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That each alderman shall receive a salary of $100.00 per year, payable in quarterly installments; provided, that a deduction of $2.00 shall be made for each failure to attend a regular meeting of the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick at such time as the mayor and council may fix, failure to be present by the time the roll is called to require such fine. Aldermen, salary of.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the city printer shall be required to give bond, to be fixed by the mayor and council of the city of Brunswick, for the faithful performance of his duties, and the publication of ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations of the mayor and council aforesaid; but such ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations shall, in the discretion of said mayor and council, be fully published when an emergency arises demanding it, by posting a copy thereof certified by the clerk of said mayor and council at the city hall, and also at the court-house of Glynn county. City printer, bond of. Ordinances, etc., publication of.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That whenever streets of the city of Brunswick are paved or repaired, the owners of property on each side of the street shall pay one-third for each side, and the city shall pay the remaining one-third for such paving or repair. Streets, paving and repairing of.
Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: BUFORD, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the present charter amendment of the city of Buford, Gwinnett county, approved August 8, 1903; to provide for reducing the present city corporate limits; to change the time of holding elections for mayor and council, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act section 1 of the Act amending the charter of the city of Buford, approved August 8, 1903, be amended by striking from said section the words the same date after the word on, and before the word an, in the second line thereof, and inserting in lieu thereof the following, to wit: the first Saturday in December, and also by adding at the end of said section the following: Buford, mayor and councilmen of.

The mayor thus elected shall serve for one year from the first day of January after said election, until the 31st day of December, or until his successor is elected and qualified. The councilmen so elected shall serve for two years, beginning January 1st, after said election, and ending two years thereafter on December 31st, or until their successors are elected and qualified, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act section 8 of said Act, approved December 23, 1896, be amended as follows: By adding after the word Act, in the fifteenth line thereof, and before the word after, the following: All elections shall be by ballot, and shall be held at such place or places as the mayor and council shall determine. The polls shall open at 7 o'clock a. m., and close at 6 o'clock p. m. The mayor and council may provide for the pay of managers and clerks. Also by striking therefrom the words the same date, before the word an, and after the word on, in the second line thereof, and inserting in lieu thereof the words the first Saturday in December; also by adding at the end of said section the following:

The mayor thus elected shall serve for one year from the first day of January, after said election, to the 31st day of December,
or until his successor is elected and qualified. The councilmen so elected shall serve for two years, beginning January 1st, after said election, and ending two years thereafter, on December 31st, or until their successors are elected and qualified, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows:

Section 8. Be it further enacted, That on the first Monday in January, 1898, and annually thereafter on the first Saturday in December, an election shall be held for mayor and councilmen for said city. The mayor and council shall appoint three free-holders, who shall be electors under this Act as managers of such election, whose duty it shall be to receive and count the votes polled; and the mayor shall cause to be published, either in the newspaper of said city, or by posting the names of the managers and the place where the said election shall be held, at least ten days previous to the day of said election. Said managers, before proceeding with said election, shall be sworn as prescribed in sections 1283 and 1284 of the Code of Georgia; provided, however, that the first election held under this Act shall be held according to the provisions of section 7 of this Act, and the persons elected at said first election shall hold office according to the provisions of section 4 of this Act. All elections shall be by ballot, and shall be held at such place or places as the mayor and council shall determine. The polls shall open at 7 o'clock a. m., and close at 6 o'clock p. m. The mayor and council may provide for the pay of the managers and clerks. After all votes for mayor and councilmen shall have been duly counted by the managers, they shall cause two copies of the tally-sheets to be made out, one of which they shall deliver to the mayor, and the other shall be retained by them. The persons elected shall be notified of the same by a certificate issued by the mayor. The mayor thus elected shall serve for one year from the first day of January, after said election, to the 31st day of December, or until his successor is elected and qualified. The councilmen so elected shall serve two years, beginning January 1st, after said election, and ending two years there-after, on December 31st, or until their successors are elected and qualified.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That section 4 of said Act be amended by striking therefrom the word thirty, in the fourth line thereof, and inserting in lieu thereof the word twenty, so that said section, when so amended, shall read as follows: Section 4. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have power and authority to issue bonds of said city for any of the purposes mentioned in the preceding section, not to exceed in
the aggregate, the sum of twenty thousand dollars, of such denomination or denominations, payable at such time, or such times, not more than thirty years from the date of the issue thereof, as said mayor and council may determine, and with such rate of interest, not exceeding six per cent., and have such covenants and conditions as the mayor and council shall deem best. Said bonds to be issued and sold for the purpose, or purposes, of establishing, maintaining and operating or contracting with any other person or corporation for the establishing, maintaining and operating a system of water-works and electric light or other light plant, or gas plants, schoolhouses, public buildings, sewers, paving, grading, laying out and improving streets in and for said city. Said bonds to be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the clerk under the corporate seal of said city, and shall be negotiated in such manner as said mayor and council shall determine to be for the best interest of said city; provided, however, that said bonds for any purpose shall not be issued until the question of issuing the same shall have been submitted to a vote of the qualified voters of said city, and approved by a two-thirds vote of the qualified voters of said city, as hereinbefore provided for. Bonds, amount of.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That section 5 of said Act be amended by striking therefrom the words and shall be held by the same persons, in the eighteenth line of said section, and by inserting between the words and and the, at the end of said eighteenth line, the word in, so that said section when amended, shall read as follows: Section 5. Be it further enacted, That whenever it is deemed expedient or desirable by the mayor and council of said city to issue bonds as prescribed in the preceding section, they shall order an election to be held in said city for the purpose of determining whether any or all of said bonds, as such order may recite, shall be issued, and shall give notice thereof for the space of thirty days next preceding the day of election, in the newspaper in which the sheriff's legal advertisements appear at that time, in the county of Gwinnett, notifying the qualified voters of the city of Buford that on a day named an election will be held in said city to determine the question whether bonds shall be issued by said city, which notice shall specify the amount of bonds to be issued by said city, for what purpose, and what rate of interest they shall bear, when the interest is to be paid, how much of the principal and interest is to be paid annually, and when said bonds shall be fully paid off. Said election shall be held on the day named in said notice, at the place for holding elections for mayor and councilmen, and in same
manner and under the same rules and regulations that elections for mayor and councilmen for said city are held, as at the time of said election is required for elections for mayor and councilmen; that the voting shall be by ballot, and the ballots cast at said election shall contain the words `For Bonds' or `Against Bonds'; and unless `For Bonds' shall receive two-thirds majority of the qualified voters of said city, said bonds shall not be issued; but if `For Bonds' shall receive said two-thirds votes, said bonds shall be issued. The test of qualified voters shall be determined from the registration-list for said bond election. The result of said election shall be declared as provided for elections for mayor and councilmen for said city. Bonds, elections for.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That section 16 of said Act be repealed and a new section 16 enacted, which shall read as follows: Section 16. Be it further enacted, That the corporate limits of the city of Buford be changed, so that after the passage of this Act said corporate limits of said city of Buford shall begin at the city limit post on the Buford and West Buford line, in the center of the track of the Southern Railway Company, and run from thence along said railroad track through the city of Buford one and one-half miles, and for the entire distance of said one and one-half miles said limits shall extend one-half mile, at right angles, on either side of said railroad track, thus making the city of Buford one and one-half miles in length, one mile in width, and the said railroad track the middle of said city. Corporate limits.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That section 19 of said Act be amended by inserting after the word closed, and before the word an, in the eighth line thereof, the following: and shall provide for the selection of three competent citizens, who shall constitute a board of registrars for said city, prescribe by ordinance their terms of office, duties and salary, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows: Section 19. Be it further enacted, That the registration law of said city embraced in section 9 of said Act, approved December 23, 1896, be repealed, and that provision be made for the registration of voters as follows: That said mayor and council shall provide by ordinance for the registration of all voters in said city for the punishment for illegal registration, when the book or books of registration shall be opened, by whom kept, and when closed, and shall provide for the selection of three competent citizens, who shall constitute a board of registrars for said city, prescribe by ordinance their terms of office, duties and salary, and no person shall be allowed to vote in any election held for officers of said city, or for other
purposes, except those who, at the time of the election, are duly qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly of Georgia, and who have resided within the limits of said city continuously for six months next preceding the election, have paid all taxes, State, county and city, including street tax, that may have been required of them, or that they may have had an opportunity to pay up to the year of election, and have duly registered on the registration book for the voters of said city. Registrars, board of created.
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: CAMILLA, AMENDMENT OF NEW CHARTER OF REPEALED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the town of Camilla, Georgia, approved October 24, 1887, so as to add to section 26 of said Act the following proviso, to wit: Provided that said mayor and council shall not have power and authority to issue any license to any person whatsoever to sell ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, ciders, or other intoxicants within the corporate limits of said town, except upon the written consent of two-thirds of the bona fide resident freeholders of said town owning real estate within the corporate limits of said town, approved September 2, 1889.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act an Act entitled an Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the town of Camilla, Georgia, approved October 24, 1887, so as to add to section 26 the following proviso, to wit: Provided, that said mayor and council shall not have power and authority to issue any license to any person whatsoever to sell ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, ciders, or other intoxicants within the corporate limits of said town, except upon the written consent of two-thirds of the bona fide resident freeholders of said town owning real
estate within the corporate limits of said town, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Camilla, sale of intoxicating liquors in.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: CANON, BONDS OF FOR PUBLIC SCHOOLS AUTHORIZED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the mayor and council of the town of Canon, Georgia, to issue bonds for the purpose of purchasing, building and equipping school buildings and properties in the town of Canon, Georgia, and to authorize the said mayor and council to provide for the payment of the principal and interest of said bonds by levying a tax therefor, and to provide for an election to ratify the provisions of this Act, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the mayor and council of the town of Canon be authorized and required to issue and sell bonds not to exceed in the aggregate five thousand dollars, of the denomination of one hundred dollars each, to be due and payable at such time or times within twenty-five years after the date of the issue thereof, as said mayor and council may determine, and bear not exceeding six per cent. interest per annum, payable annually, such bonds not to be sold below par. Canon, public schools, bonds for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Canon shall pay over to the town treasurer the proceeds of the sale of said bonds, after first requiring and securing a good and sufficient bond from him. Sale of bonds.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of said town be, and the same are, hereby authorized to levy and collect a tax upon the taxable property in said town, such as will be necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this Act, and to pay the interest and principal on said bonds as they mature. Tax to pay principal and interest.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of the town of Canon shall order an election, due notice being given as required by law of such election, at which election shall be
submitted to the qualified voters of the town of Canon the question of issuing bonds; and should the required majority not vote in favor of issuing bonds at said first election, then, and in that event, an election shall be held semi-annually until the provisions of this Act are adopted. Said election shall be held under the same rules and regulations as elections for representatives. Election for bonds.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That the erection, furnishing and equipping of said school building, as aforesaid, shall be under the direction of the seven trustees of the Canon public school district, as provided by an Act of the General Assembly, approved August 18, 1903. A majority of said board of trustees shall constitute a quorum. That said trustees shall have authority to sell or dispose of the present school building and the site on which it stands, should they deem it necessary, and the proceeds of such sale, if not necessarily used in the purchase of a new site, shall be applied to the equipment of the new building. School building.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That said board of trustees may have full power to accept by donation, or to purchase a site on which to erect said school building, to let contract for the erection of same, to enforce in the name of said trustees any agreement or contract entered into with them, together with such other powers as are granted said board of trustees in Act referred to in section 5 of this Act. School building.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the vouchers upon which the treasurer of said town of Canon shall pay out money or funds arising under this Act for the purposes herein mentioned, shall bear the signature of the chairman and secretary of the board of trustees of said school district, and the treasurer of said town shall be required to pay all bills arising under this Act, when properly made out and presented. Vouchers on school fund, how drawn.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That said board of trustees shall take charge of said school building when completed and accepted by them, and shall be, and are, hereby entrusted with the organization of the school or schools to be taught therein, with such other duties as are already conferred on said board of trustees by an Act of the General Assembly, already referred to in section 5 of this Act. Board of trustees, powers of.
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: CANTON, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act to authorize the establishment of a system of public schools in the town of Canton; to provide for acquiring of property and buildings, and raising of revenues to maintain said schools, and for other purposes, approved December 18, 1893, by naming the time for the beginning and ending of each school year; changing the manner and time for which members of the school board shall be elected, and when and how vacancies in the board shall be filled; to provide that no person shall at the same time fill the offices of mayor or councilman and member of the board of education; to provide that the treasurer of the board shall, before entering on his duties of office, make, file and have approved by the board of education an oath and bond to faithfully perform the duties as treasurer, which shall be filed with the president of the board, who shall be the custodian of the bond, and which shall be recorded on the minutes after it has been approved by the board; to empower the board of education to bring suit in any of the courts of this State for any breaches that may occur on the treasurer's bond, the proceeds that may arise from any breach or from any suit, on account of any breach, to be paid to the treasurer of the school board, to be applied to school purposes; to provide for regular meetings of the board monthly, time of meetings to be fixed by the board; to provide how taxes shall be collected, levied and paid over to the treasurer of board; to provide that the attendance on public schools of said town shall be reported to the county school commissioner of said county, and that he shall pay to the school authorities of said town the pro rata share that each pupil has attended during the school year; that the pupils of said school have the right to make up their time which is allowed for the school term year in other schools of the county any time during the school year for said town, under such rules as may be adopted by said town board; to provide that the board of education of said town shall be a body corporate, under the corporate name of Board of Education of Canton, with the right to sue and be sued in this name, to have a perpetual succession, to have and use a common seal, and shall have power to receive and hold to them and their successors in office, for school purposes, any estate,
real and personal, of every kind and character; to provide for keeping of minutes, and how to be used; to provide that the board shall make annual reports of the condition of the public schools each year and to provide for the publication of the same, and to provide when said reports shall be made; to provide for the payment by the county school commissioner for the attendance of any pupils of the county entitled to school fund, who may not live in said town; to provide for a charge of tuition for all persons attending said schools who are over or under school age; to provide for an incidental fee of all pupils for purpose of defraying expenses of janitoring the buildings, providing for fuel, chalk, and other incidental expenses of the schools; to provide for tuition for children of school age who are pursuing other branches than those taught in the public schools of the State, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the above-recited Act be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: That each school year shall begin with the first Monday in September of each year, and close on the day of the following year next before the first Monday in September, during which time the schools for such year shall be taught, and each of which periods shall be known as a scholastic year. Canton public schools, terms of.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That there shall be an election for the officers of said board, which shall be by written ballot, election to be held at the first regular meeting of the board, which is held in June of each year, and it shall require a majority vote of the whole board to elect. The officers shall hold their office for a term of twelve months, and until their successors are regularly elected. All elections for officers must be held on a regular meeting of the board. In case of vacancy by death, removal, resignation, or otherwise, such vacancy may be filled by the Board at the next regular meeting occurring after such vacancy. School board, officers of.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That no person who is mayor or councilman shall be eligible as a member of the board of education. School board, who eligible as members.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That members of the board of education shall be elected by the town council, said election to apply to the successors of the members of the present board, as their various terms of office expire, said election to be held at the regular meeting of the council next preceding the end of the spring term of the schools. All vacancies in the board shall be
filled by the council at the next regular meeting of the council after notice to that body of a vacancy in the board. School board, election of.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That the treasurer shall, before entering on the duties of his office as such, make an oath to faithfully perform all duties of office. That he shall, at the time of filing his oath of office, make a bond to faithfully perform all the duties of treasurer, in such sums as shall be fixed by the board, which shall be ample to protect the town against any breach, which bond shall be payable to the board of education of Canton, and shall be recorded on the minutes after it has been approved by the board at a regular meeting. The president of the board shall be the custodian of the treasurer's bond. Treasurer, oath and bond of.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the board of education shall have power to bring suit in any of the courts having jurisdiction on the bond of the treasurer for any breach of his bond as treasurer; that any proceeds that may arise from any of said breaches, or from any suits that may be brought on said bonds, shall be paid over to the treasurer of the board, to be applied to school purposes. Treasurer, breach of bond.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the board shall hold regular monthly meetings, which shall be fixed by the board, but may meet as often as necessary to discharge the duties that may devolve on them as a board. School board, sessions of.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That said board of education shall, as early as practicable each year, by resolution, require the mayor and council of said town to levy and collect an ad valorem tax on all taxable property within the corporate limits of said town for school purposes for that year, an amount not to [Illegible Text] three-tenths of one per cent., which shall be turned over to the board as soon as collected, to be used for the purposes of this Act; and it shall be the duty of the mayor and council of said town, when said resolution has been passed by said board and presented to them by the president or secretary of said board, to levy, collect and turn over said money as provided in this Act; that said tax shall be levied and collected by the first day of November in each year, which amount so levied and collected shall be for the year beginning each first Monday in September. School tax.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the superintendent of said schools shall make regular reports of the attendance of all pupils of school age who may attend the schools of said town to the county school commissioner of Cherokee county, as are required of other public schools of the county; that for such children so reported, whether they reside in said town or elsewhere in the
county, the county school commissioner shall pay for such pupils to the treasurer of said board the pro rata share of the public school funds of the county to which such pupils so reported may be entitled, which attendance may be made up any time during the school year, under such regulations as may be provided by the board. Superintendent of chools, report of.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That the board of education shall be a body corporate under the corporate name of board of education of Canton, with the right to sue and be sued in that name, to have a perpetual succession, to have and use a common seal, to have and receive to them and their successors in office for school purposes any estate, real and personal of every kind and character. Board of education, a body corporate.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That the board shall keep minutes of all its meetings, which shall contain all Acts as a board; that a transcript of the records of said minutes shall be evidence in any of the courts of said State, which shall be made by the secretary of the board, for which he shall have same fees as are allowed the clerk of the superior court for similar services. Board of education, minutes of.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That the board shall make annual reports of the conditions of the schools of said town, which must be made by the first day of July in each year; which shall be published in the paper in which the sheriff's advertisements of said county are published and which must also be recorded on the minutes of the board. Board of education, reports of.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That pupils of school age who are non-residents of the town shall be admitted in said school for the same length of time that they are permitted to attend other public schools of the county and on same terms that resident pupils are admitted. The time so attended by non-resident pupils of the county shall be reported by the superintendent of the schools to the county school commissioner. And their pro rata part of the school funds shall be paid for such attendance.
