Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council may enact any and all ordinances, rules and regulations necessary to lay out a fire district in said town, and to enlarge, change, or modify its limits from time to time; to prescribe when, how, and of what material buildings in said limits may be erected, how thick the walls must be, how the chimneys, stovepipes and flues are to be constructed, and generally to do all such things as they may deem necessary in order to protect said town, as far as possible, from danger from fire, and to prevent the spread of fire from one building to another. They shall also have authority to order any changes in the construction or arrangement of buildings, chimneys, stovepipes or flues, or to order the removal thereof when, in their judgment, the same are dangerous, or likely to become so, and to make the owner of the premises pay the expenses of such change or removal, which expense may be collected as taxes are collected; and if any person, firm or corporation shall erect or maintain any building that is not in accordance with the laws and ordinances of said town, said mayor and council may order such building removed or altered; and if such person, firm or corporation shall not remove or alter such building after notice to do so, then said mayor and council shall have authority to remove or alter the same at the expense of the owner, which expense may be collected as taxes are collected. Fire district and buildings therein.

Sec. 34. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council of said town shall have full and complete control of the streets and sidewalks, alleys and squares of said town, and shall have full power and authority to condemn property for the purpose of laying out new streets and alleys, and for widening, straightening or grading, or in any way changing the street lines and sidewalks of said town; and when the mayor and council of said town shall desire to exercise the power and authority granted in this section, it may be done, whether the land sought to be condemned is in the hands of the owner or a trustee, executor, guardian or agent, in the manner provided by sections 4657 and 4686 of volume 2 of the Code of Georgia 1895, and the Acts amendatory thereof. The mayor and council shall have full power and authority to remove, or cause to be removed, any buildings, steps, fences, gates, posts, or other obstructions or nuisances in the public streets, lanes, alleys, sidewalks, or other public places in said town, and to enforce the provisions of this section by appropriate ordinances. Streets, sidewalks, etc.

Sec. 35. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of said town shall have full power and authority to pass all ordinances concerning the draining and proper maintenance and care of the streets, alleys and sidewalks, and other public places of said town, to provide for the paving of the same, or any part thereof whenever, in their judgment, the same becomes necessary, and to provide how said paving, maintenance or care should be paid, whether by said town or whether by the adjacent land owners, or by both. Streets, sidewalks, etc., draining and improving.

Sec. 36. Be it further enacted, That the town of Riddleville shall only issue its bonds, either for the payment of its debts or for public improvement,s under the provisions of section 377 to 381, inclusive, of volume 1 of the Code of Georgia of 1895. Municipal bonds.

Sec. 37. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall have full power and authority to tax and grant licenses to persons keeping markets in said town; also to tax and license theaters, shows, exhibitions and fairs of all kinds, as well as itinerant dealers of all kinds. License taxes.

Sec. 38. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall not have the power and authority to license or to authorize persons to sell intoxicating liquors of any kind, but may punish, by ordinance, the sale of any patent medicine which, if drunk to excess, will produce intoxication, and may also punish any person keeping or storing within the corporate limits intoxicating liquors for the purpose of illegal sale. Intoxicating liquors and patent medicines.

Sec. 39. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have full power and authority to require any person, firm or corporation, whether a resident or non-resident of Riddleville, engaged in or carrying on, or who may engage in or carry on, any trade, business, vocation or profession within the incorporate limits of said town, either by themselves or by their agent, or agents, to register their names and business, calling, vocation or profession, annually, and to require such person, firm or corporation to pay for such registration and for license to prosecute, carry on, or engage in such business, calling, or profession, such amount as the mayor and council may, by ordinance, require. Said mayor and council may, by ordinance, provide for the punishment of all persons, firms or corporations who are required by ordinance to pay the said special tax and to register who shall engage in, or offer, or attempt to engage in, such business, calling or profession, without first complying in all respects with the ordinances of said town in reference thereto. Business registration and tax.

Sec. 40. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council are hereby given authority to pass such ordinances as may be necessary and proper in order to carry the foregoing section into effect. They are also empowered to classify business and to arrange the various business, trades and professions carried on in said town into such classes of subjects for taxation as they may deem just and proper. Ordinances. Taxation, classification of subjects for.

Sec. 41. Be further enacted, That the mayor and council of Riddleville shall have power and authority to levy and collect a tax annually of not exceeding one-half of one per cent. upon all and every species of property, both real and personal, within the limits of the town of Riddleville, including bonds, notes, debts, choses in action, money employed in banking and otherwise.

Sec. 42. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall at their first meeting in January of each year, elect three intelligent, discreet and upright persons, citizens and qualified voters in said town, and owners of real estate therein as tax-assessors of said town, whose terms of office shall be one year. Said tax-assessors shall at any time be removed from office by the mayor and council for good and sufficient cause to be judged by said mayor and council, and all vacancies occurring from any cause may be filled by the mayor and council at any time. It shall be the duty of said tax-assessors to assess the value of real estate in said town for the purpose of taxation by said town, and it shall be their duty to examine the tax returns placed before them by the officers receiving the same, and increase the valuation of personal property thereof when, in their judgment, the value placed thereon is too small. The mayor and council shall have the authority to prescribe rules for the government of said town tax-assessors. Said assessors shall make returns of the assessments made by them to the mayor and council each year of such time as the mayor and council may, by ordinance. direct. If any taxpayer is dissatisfied with the assessment made of his property, either real or personal, by said assessor, such taxpayer shall within ten days after the assessors have made their returns to the mayor and council, file written notice with the clerk of council of his dissatisfaction, and shall name in his said notice arbitrator to represent him in fixing the value of his said property. Upon such notice being filed with the said clerk it shall be his duty to notify the mayor of the fact, and it shall be the duty of the mayor to forthwith name an arbitrator to represent said town in fixing the value of the property in dispute, and the two arbitrators so
selected shall be immediately notified by the town clerk, and shall forthwith select an umpire, and the board of arbitration so constituted shall immediately proceed to give their award as to the value of such property, which award shall be returned to the town clerk and shall be final on both the town and the taxpayer. The town assessors shall take such oaths and receive such compensation as the mayor and council may prescribe; they shall have the power to require any taxpayer to furnish them a list of all notes, accounts, mortgages, stocks, bonds, and other securities and investments, whenever, in their opinion, the same is necessary for a correct assessment, and to punish for contempt as may be prescribed by ordinance for failure or refusal to do so. The mayor and council shall have power and authority to pass such ordinances as are required to effectuate this section. Tax assessors. Assessments, arbitration of disputed. Assessors, oath, compensation and powers.

Sec. 43. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of said town shall have power and authority to provide by ordinance when the taxes of said town shall fall due, in what length of time said taxes shall be paid, when tax executions shall issue against defaulters and to fix a penalty for the non-payment of taxes when due. Taxes.

Sec. 44. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That executions for any and all taxes or licenses or demands of any sort due the town or its corporate authorities by any person, firm or corporation, or against any property subject thereto, shall be issued by the clerk of said town, signed by him, bear test in the name of the mayor, and be directed to the marshal of said town and his deputies and to all and singular the sheriffs, deputy-sheriffs and constables of this State, commanding them that of any property belonging to the defendant against whom said execution is issued, or of certain property described in the execution, they make by levy and sale the amount due on the execution, with all cost. The mayor and council shall, by ordinance, provide for the time and place of, the method of conducting, and all regulations governing the marshal's sales under said executions. The sheriffs, deputy-sheriffs and constables of this State shall proceed in the same manner to levy and collect executions issued by the town of Riddleville as they levy and collect executions issued from the respective courts of which they are executive officers. Executions for debts due town. Marshal's sales.

Sec. 45. Be it further enacted, That nothing in this Act shall affect the present officers of the town of Riddleville as to their fees or salaries or the tax rate fixed by the ordinances of said town for the year 1904. Act not affect officers and tax rate for 1904.

Sec. 46. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That nothing in this Act shall be construed to repeal or modify in any manner the legislation incorporating the Mount Vernon Institute in said town, or such parts of the Acts of December 17, 1859, December 6, 1866, and October 18, 1879, regulating the sale of spirituous liquors within a radius of three miles from said Institute, but that the same shall remain in full force and effect. Mount Vernon Institute not affected by act.

Sec. 47. Be it further enacted, That authority to carry out and effectuate, by ordinance, each and every power, granted to the town of Riddleville in this Act is hereby expressly conferred on the mayor and council of said town, and said mayor and council shall have generally, the power and authority to make and pass such rules, by-laws, and ordinances as shall appear to them necessary or requisite for presrving or promoting the peace, dignity, health, good order and welfare of said town of Riddleville. Ordinances. General welfare.

Sec. 48. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of said town shall have the right to elect such other municipal officers, beside those herein specified, as may to them seem necessary and proper, providing therefor, when necessary, by ordinance, and in the same manner prescribing their duties and fixing their compensation. Other municipal officers may be chosen.

Sec. 49. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all ordinances and resolutions now of force in said town of Riddleville, and not in conflict with this Act, shall remain in full force and effect until repealed by the mayor and council of said town. Ordinances.
Sec. 50. Be it further enacted, That all laws, or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: RISING FAWN, ACT INCORPORATING REPEALED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act incorporating the town of Rising Fawn, Dade county, Georgia.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and the same is hereby enacted, That on and after the passage of this Act, an Act passed by the General Assembly of Georgia incorporating the town of Rising Fawn, Dade county, Georgia, and providing a charter for same, approved September 15, 1887. Said Act of incorporation together with all its amendments are hereby repealed; provided, nothing herein contained shall be so construed as to interfere with license issued by the present board of town commissioners, which expires on the Saturday in January, 1905. Rising Fawn, act incorporating repealed.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this law, are hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: ROCKMART, NEW CHARTER FOR.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend, consolidate and supersede the several Acts incorporating the town of Rockmart in the county of Polk, to confer additional powers upon the corporate authorities thereof, and otherwise to amend the charter of said town; to provide a new charter for the town of Rockmart, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the municipal government of the city of Rockmart, in the county of Polk, shall consist of a mayor and five councilmen, who are hereby constituted a body corporate, under the name and style of the city of Rockmart, the corporate powers of which shall be exercised by the mayor and councilmen hereinafter provided for. Rockmart Mayor and councilmen.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That an election shall be held
in the city of Rockmart on the first Saturday in December, annually. In December, 1904, a mayor and five councilmen shall be elected. The term of the mayor and two councilmen to expire on the first Tuesday in January, 1906, the term of the three councilmen to expire on the first Tuesday in January, 1907, the councilmen to determine by lot who will fill long and who short terms. In December, 1905, and every two years thereafter, a mayor and two councilmen shall be elected, and in December, 1906, and every two years thereafter three councilmen shall be electedeach of said officers shall serve until their successors are elected and qualified. No mayor or councilman hereafter shall be eligible to succeed himself. That W. Ferguson be and is hereby appointed mayor, that George F. Morgan, James Heaton, M. D. McGinnis, T. E. McBryde and James F. Deaver be, and are hereby, appointed councilmen of said city of Rockmart, to hold their office until the first Tuesday night in January, 1905, or until their successors are elected and qualified, as hereinbefore provided. At the first meeting of the mayor and council of Rockmart, or as soon thereafter as practicable, one of said councilmen shall be chosen mayor pro tem. Mayor and councilmen. Mayor pro tem.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of the city of Rockmart shall elect a city clerk and treasurer hereafter, annually, at the first regular meeting of the city council in each year, beginning with the year 1905, a majority vote being necessary to elect. That A. H. Graefer, the present clerk be, and he is, hereby appointed to hold the office of clerk until his successor is elected and qualified, as herein provided. That T. J. Morris, the present treasurer, be, and he is hereby, appointed to hold the office of treasurer until his successor is elected and qualified as herein provided. Clerk and reasurer.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That in case of a vacancy in any of the offices mentioned in the preceding section by death, resignation, failure to elect, removal from office, removal from the city, or otherwise, a special election shall be ordered by the mayor and council of Rockmart within thirty days, giving ten days' notice by publication, to fill such vacancy; provided, if such vacancy shall occur within three months of the expiration of the term of office of such officer, it shall be the duty of the mayor and council of Rockmart, or in case of a vacancy in the office of mayor, the council to fill said vacancy by selecting a qualified citizen or citizens of said city to fill said vacancy for the unexpired term. Vacancies, how filled.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That all elections held under
the provisions of the charter of the city of Rockmart shall be superintended and managed by three freeholders, citizens of said city, said managers to be appointed by the mayor and council, and they are hereby empowered to hold any election in said city, as provided by its charter, and in compliance with the State law for holding said elections; said managers shall cause to be kept three tally-sheets and three lists of voters. Before entering upon his duties each manager shall take an oath, before some officer qualified to administer an oath, that he will impartially conduct said election and prevent all illegal voting to the best of his skill and power. Election managers.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That all elections held under this charter shall be held at the city hall in said city, or at such other place or places as the mayor and council may direct, and that polls at every such election shall be opened at 9 o'clock a.m., and closed at 4 o'clock p.m.; the person or persons receiving the highest number of votes cast at such election for mayor or councilman shall be declared elected. Elections.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That after the votes at any election shall have been counted by the managers, they shall certify the list of voters and the tally-sheets, and shall place one of said tally-sheets with the ballots in the ballot-box, and shall seal said ballot-box and deposit the same with the clerk of the superior court; and the other lists of the voters and tally-sheets shall be filed by the managers with the city clerk. The said clerk of the superior court, after the expiration of sixty days, shall destroy the contents of said ballot-box, without examining said ballots or allowing same to be done; provided, no notice of contest shall be filed or pending. Ballot-box.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That on the first Tuesday in January, after each election, or as soon thereafter as practicable, all persons elected shall appear at the council chamber and take and subscribe the following oath before any judicial officer of this State, and shall forthwith enter upon the duties of his office, to wit: I, A. B., do solemnly swear that I will well and truly perform the duties of mayor (or councilman or clerk, as the case may be,) of the city of Rockmart to the best of my skill and ability, without fear, favor or affection; so help me, God. Official oath.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That all persons qualified to vote for members of the Legislature, and who shall have paid all taxes legally imposed and demanded by the authorities of the city, and shall have resided three months within the city prior to the opening of the registration list, and registers as
hereinafter provided for, shall be qualified to vote at said election for mayor and for councilmen. Electors.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That the clerk shall open a list for the registration of voters on the third Saturday in October in each year, which list shall be kept open from nine o'clock a.m. until twelve m., and from two o'clock until six o'clock p.m., each and every day (Sunday excepted), until the third Saturday in November, when it shall be finally and absolutely closed; in which book shall be kept a separate list of white and colored voters, in which book shall be subscribed the names of the persons entitled to vote in said city, his age and occupation. Said clerk must not permit any one to register who is not entitled to do so, and if he does so knowingly he shall be discharged from office. No person who is not registered shall be allowed to vote at any regular election in said city. The mayor and council may prescribe such rules and regulations as they may see fit and proper, not in conflict herewith. Registration of voters.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of the clerk to furnish to the managers presiding at any such election, at the opening of the polls on the day of such election, a complete list of all names, arranged alphabetically, which shall be registered according to the foregoing provisions, certified under the hand of said clerk and the corporate seal of said city, which list shall be kept before the presiding managers during said election, and when said election is over it shall be deposited in the office of the said city clerk, to be by him safely kept. Registration lists.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That any person voting at any such election, not qualified to register, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, on conviction before the superior or city court of Polk county, shall be punished as prescribed in the Penal Code of Georgia 1895, section 1039. Illegal voting.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That no person shall be eligible to the office of mayor or councilman or clerk of the city of Rockmart, unless he be of the age of twenty-one, a citizen of the United States of America, and shall have resided in the city one year immediately preceding his election, and shall have paid all taxes due and demanded by said city. Eligibility.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council, clerk and treasurer, shall have an adequate salary, to be fixed by annual ordinances at the first regular meeting in November for the next succeeding year, beginning the first Tuesday night in January; provided, that the mayor's salary shall not exceed
$50 and councilman's salary shall not exceed $25 until after the year 1910. Compensation of municipal officers.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That the corporate limits of Rockmart, in the county of Polk, shall extend to and embrace all the territory included within the boundary lines described as follows: Embracing all of land-lots Nos. 793, 794, 863, 864, 865 and 866 in the eighteenth district and third section; and 849, 850, 851, 852, 853, 854, 923, 924 and 925 in the twenty-first district and third section of Polk county, Georgia. Also, all the land within the following boundary: Commencing at the east end of East avenue, on south side of said avenue, and on the western boundary line of land-lot 863 in the eighteenth district and third section, and running east sixty feet, thence north along the eastern boundary of Piedmont avenue 606 feet to the southwest corner of the land of Piedmont Institute; thence east 425 feet; thence north 572 feet to the northern boundary of College street; thence west along the north line of College street to the western boundary of land-lot No. 794. That the city limits may be extended upon petition of two-thirds of the tax-payers of the territory sought to be included; any part of the territory inside of the city limits may be excluded upon a two-thirds vote of the qualified voters of said city, voting at a regular election, or an election to be called for that purpose; said election to be called by the mayor and council. Corporate limits.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall have perpetual succession; shall have a common seal; be capable in law and equity to purchase, have, hold, receive, enjoy, possess and retain to them and their successors, for the use of the city of Rockmart, its mayor and council, any estate or estates, real or personal of whatsoever kind or nature, within or without the jurisdictional limits of said city for corporate purposes; and shall have the right to rent, lease, sell and dispose of any of said property; and shall by the said name be capable of suing and being sued in any court of law or equity in this State; and shall succeed to all rights and liabilities of the corporation of the town of Rockmart. Mayor and council, corporate powers.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have full and complete control of the streets, alleys, sidewalks and squares of said city; and shall have power and authority to open, lay out, widen, straighten, close or vacate, curb, pave, and keep in good order and repair, or otherwise change all streets, sidewalks, alleys and squares in said city; that said mayor and council are authorized to condemn property
which may be needed for said purposes, in the judgment of the mayor and council, the condemnation proceedings in all cases to conform to the laws of the State authorizing and regulating the condemnation of private properties for public uses. Streets, sidewalks, etc.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council of the city of Rockmart, shall have the power and authority, by proper ordinances, and upon such terms as the said mayor and council may determine, to grant franchises to any person or corporation, the right to use the streets, sidewalks, squares and alleys of said city, for the purpose of laying out, constructing and operating railroads, tramways, dummy lines, street car lines, telephone and telegraph lines; the said railroads, tramways, dummy lines and street car lines may be run and operated by horse-power, steam-power or electricity, or such other motive power as in their discretion may be desirable. Franchises to use.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rockmart, shall have full power and authority to establish and fix such a system of grading and draining of streets of said city, as may be deemed proper, and shall have the power to compel owners and lessees of property to curb, pave and construct and keep in good repair streets, sidewalks and open sewers in their front, if any owner or lessee shall fail to comply with the requirements of the mayor and council in this regard, the work shall be done under the direction of the city and execution shall issue for the cost and expenses thereof against such owners or lessees, to be collected as other executions issued by the clerk. Draining and improvement

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted, That the clerk of said city shall in no case be allowed to vote on any question or measure coming before said body, and that the mayor shall only be allowed to vote in case of a tie vote of the councilmen present. Clerk and mayor, vote of in council.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rockmart, shall have power to fix and establish fire limits, and from time to time enlarge the same; to provide and maintain a fire department and a system of fire alarm within which fire limits as established it shall not be lawful for any one to build or cause to be built other than fireproof buildings, and in case of any offense against ordinances passed in pursuance of this Act, the said mayor and council, after five days' notice given shall cause the said not fireproof building to be removed at the expense of the owner or builders thereof, to be collected by execution as other executions issued by the city, and the said mayor and council shall have the right to determine what are not fireproof buildings. Fire limits and buildings therein.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council
of Rockmart, shall have the power and authority to establish and regulate markets; prescribe time for holding the same; to prevent injury or annoyance to the public or individuals from anything dangerous, offensive or unwholesome; to prevent dogs, hogs, cattle, sheep, horses, mules, goats, asses, and all other animals and fowls of every kind from going at large in said city in any prescribed territory therein; to protect places of divine worship; to abate or cause to be abated, anything which in the opinion of the council is a nuisance; to regulate the keeping and selling of gunpowder, kerosene, and all other combustible or hazardous articles of merchandise; to guard against danger and damage by fire; to regulate the running and managing of steam engines and locomotives, whether for factories, furnaces, cotton-gins or railroads, within the corporate limits of said city, or for any and all sorts of vehicles however drawn or propelled, that may traverse or cross any street, avenues, alleys, lanes or roads; to guard against and prevent the fast driving and riding of any horses or bicycles on the streets of the said city; to provide places for the burial of the dead, and to regulate interments therein; to provide for the regular building of houses or other structures; the drainage of lots by proper drains and ditches; to define the duties and prescribe the powers of all officers or agents appointed by them; to fix their salaries and term of office; to require and take from them such bonds as will protect the tax-payers of said city. Mayor and council, powers of.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rockmart, shall have full power and authority to maintain and control a system of water-works and sewerage for said city, and to compel lot owners to connect with said sewers, and to pay for same and the use thereof, payments to be enforced as the mayor and council may by ordinance direct; and may purchase or condemn any property within or without the city that may be necessary for either of said public works; in case it shall become necessary to condemn any property under this section, or for any other public works, the provisions shall be the same as in section 17 of this charter. Waterworks and sewerage.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have the power and authority to light the streets of said city by means of gas, electricity or otherwise, as they may see proper, and for this purpose they may have power to lay mains or pipes along the streets or highways in said city. Street lighting.

Sec. 25. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rockmart shall have power and authority to establish police rules and regulations; to pass all laws and ordinances not in
conflict with the Constitution and laws of the State of Georgia, which tend to promote the safety, health, good order, morality and general welfare of the inhabitants of said city. Police powers.

Sec. 26. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council of Rockmart, shall have authority to regulate, restrict or prohibit the sale of spirituous, malt or intoxicating liquors or bitters in said city, and may, for any violation of the laws and ordinances of said city, declare any license void and punish by fine and imprisonment. Intoxicating liquors.

Sec. 27. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rockmart, shall have the power and authority to borrow money and contract temporary loans to meet casual deficiencies, subject to restrictions of the Constitution of the State of Georgia and Code of 1895, section 5897, subdivision 7. Temporary loans, power to make.

Sec. 28. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rockmart, shall have the authority to pass such ordinances as they may deem best for the exempting from city or municipal taxation any manufacturer, person or corporation for a period of not longer than five years. This section to take effect so soon as the Constitution of the State of Georgia is changed so as not to be in conflict hereiwth. Tax exemptions.

Sec. 29. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rockmart shall have power and authority to appoint a board of health for said city; also water and light commissioners; also street commissioners; city attorney, recorder, and such number of marshals and deputy marshals as they may deem proper and necessary; and such other officers and agents as may be necessary to the interest of said city; to prescribe their duties and fix their compensation, and may at discretion suspend, remove or discharge them at any time, with or without cause. Board of health and other municipal officers.

Sec. 30. Be it further enacted, That the mayor shall be the chief executive of the mayor and council of Rockmart; he shall see that all laws, ordinances, regulations and rules of the city are faithfully executed and enforced; that all officers of the city shall faithfully discharge the duties required of them; he shall have the general jurisdiction of the affairs of the city; he shall preside at all meetings of the mayor and council, he shall have five days after the meeting at which any ordinance, order or resolution was passed, in which to file with the city clerk, in writing, his dissent thereto, which, when filed, shall have the effect to defeat such ordinance, order or resolution; but any ordinance, order or resolution may be passed over his veto by a four-fifths vote of all the members of the council. In the absence
of the mayor, the veto power may exercised by the mayor pro tem. Mayor, executive powers. Veto.

Sec. 31. Be it further enacted, That there shall be a court for the trial of all offenders against the laws or ordinances of the city, to be held by the mayor, and in his absence or disqualification, by the mayor pro tem. Said court shall have the power to preserve order and compel the attendance of witnesses, to punish for contempt by imprisonment not exceeding five days or fine not exceeding $25.00, one or both; that the mayor, or in his absence, the mayor pro tem., shall, as often as may be necessary, hold a police court, to be known as the Mayor's Court, for the trial of all offenders against the laws and ordinances of said city of Rockmart. Said mayor's court shall have full power and authority, upon conviction, to sentence such offender to labor upon the streets or public works for a period not to exceed sixty days, or to impose a fine not to exceed $100.00, or confine in the city prison not to exceed fifty days, either one or all of said penalties may be imposed, in the discretion of the mayor. There shall be an appeal within four days to the mayor and council of said city after judgment is entered, the defendant paying all cost and giving bond in such sum as the mayor may fix for his personal appearance, and to abide the final judgment in said case. Mayor's court. Contempts Punitive powers. Appeals.

Sec. 32, Be it further enacted, That the mayor and each of the councilmen shall be bound to keep the peace and shall be ex officio justices of the peace, so as to enable them to issue warrants for the violation of the criminal laws of the State committed within the city of Rockmart, and shall have full power, on examination, to commit offenders to jail, or compel them, if the offence be bailable, to appear before the court having jurisdiction. Mayor and councilmen ex officio justices of the peace.

Sec. 33. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rockmart shall have power and authority to establish a recorder's court and elect a recorder when in the discretion of the mayor and council the said court may be established and a recorder elected; said recorder's court shall take the place of the mayor's court, hereinbefore described, and the recorder shall perform all duties specified for the mayor to perform in connection with said court. Should the recorder be disqualified in any case, the mayor shall appoint some one to hold said court, in said disqualified case or cases; said recorder to have no salary; his compensation shall be derived solely from his fees. Recorder's court.

Sec. 34. Be it further enacted, That the city clerk shall be the
custodian of the records of the city; shall keep a full and correct account of all the acts and doings of the mayor and council; shall be the clerk of the mayor's court or recorder's court, should one be established; he shall issue all processes, shall make up the tax digest and shall discharge all duties that may be required of him by the laws, ordinances, rules, resolutions and regulations of the mayor and council, and shall give such bond as the mayor and council may require; that the treasurer shall be the custodian of the funds of the city, and that he shall pay out said funds only as the mayor and council may by ordinance direct. City clerk, powers and duties. Treasurer.

Sec. 35. Be it further enacted, That for the purpose of raising revenue for the support and maintenance for the city government, the mayor and council of Rockmart shall have full power and authority and shall prescribe by ordinances for the assessment, levy and collection of an ad valorem tax on all real and personal property within the corporate limits of said city, to defray ordinary annual expenses of the city government, a tax not to exceed one-half of one per cent. per annum; to pay the principal and interest on the bonded indebtedness of said city, should any exist, and to support a public school system for said city should one be established, and to pay any other extraordinary expenses of the city government, such taxes as may be necessary in the discretion of the mayor and council. Ad valorem tax.

Sec. 36. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rockmart shall have power and authority to license, regulate and control all taverns, hotels, cafes, restaurants, boarding houses, livery stables, hacks, drays and other vehicles, auctioneers, vendue masters, itinerant traders, theatrical performances, shows, circuses and exhibitions of all kinds, itinerant lightning rod dealers, emigrant agents, clock and stove peddlers, peddlers of all kinds, itinerant dealers in jewelry, and all other traveling or itinerant vendors of articles, goods, wares and merchandise of every nature whatsoever; every keeper of a shooting gallery, ten-pin alley, upon the keeper of any other table, stand or place for the performance of any game or play, whether played with sticks, balls, rings or other contrivance; upon the keeper of flying-horses, bicycle, velocipede or skating rinks, insurance agents, life and fire insurance companies, brokers, dealers in futures, loan agents and agents for any other business or calling whatsoever; keepers of slaughter-houses, beef markets, green groceries, dealers in fish, oysters, vegetables, fruits, breads and other articles of food; upon every junk-shop, pawnbroker; upon all other establishments, businesses,
calling or avocation not hereinbefore mentioned, and which, under the laws and Constitution of the State of Georgia, are subject to license or a special tax. License taxes.

Sec. 37. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rockmart shall have power and authority to require every male inhabitant of said city who is subject to road duty under the laws of this State, to work such length of time on the streets of said city as such mayor and council shall by ordinance direct, or they may prescribe a commutation tax to be paid by such person in lieu of such work; and they shall have power and authority to enforce obedience to their laws and ordinances under this section by fine and imprisonment, or either, and no tax paid in lieu of such work, or any money arising from fines or forfeitures for failure to perform such work, shall be used for any purpose except in payment for work done or improvements put on streets or sidewalks. Street work and commutation tax.

Sec. 38. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Rochmart shall have power and authority to enforce, by execution the collection of any debt, demand, or any amount due or to become due to it, such execution to be issued by the clerk against the person, corporation or firm by whom any such debt may be due or may become due, which execution may be levied by the marshal on the property of the owner against whom such execution shall issue, and the same sold as provided by Code of 1895, sections 732, 733, 734 and 735 for municipal sales for taxes. Executions and sales.

Sec. 39. Be it further enacted, That the city clerk shall open the tax books for receiving tax returns from all persons owning or claiming real estate and personal property of any and every kind, sort or description, subject to taxation, and all businesses, special or license taxes, on the first day of April of each year, and keep the same open until the first day of June, in which returns of all property, both real and personal of every kind and description, owned by the person, firm or corporation on the first day of April, must be included, and should any person or firm begin a mercantile business in said city, or any other business after the first day of April, then the mayor and council shall have power and authority, and it shall be their duty to levy and collect an ad valorem tax from said person, firm or corporation, for the year in which he or they began business; said tax shall be due and collected at the time of beginning business. Said returns to be made out on blanks prepared by the mayor and council of said city, said blanks to be made as to accurately describe all real estate, and any person
firm or corporation returning taxes must answer under oath any and all questions on said blank, and must sign and swear to said return before the city clerk, who is hereby authorized to administer and attest oaths, and should any person, firm or corporation make a false return they shall be subject to prosecution for false swearing. Said clerk shall turn over all of said tax returns to the tax revisers, on or by the tenth day of June of each year. Tax returns.

Sec. 40. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall have power and authority to appoint three tax revisers, not members of their body, freeholders, residents of said city; whose duty it shall be to scrutinize carefully each return of property, real and personal, made by every tax-payer of said city, and if, in their judgment, they shall find the property embraced in said return, or any portion thereof, returned below its value, they shall assess its true value. And said tax revisers shall also assess the value of all property in said city not returned for taxation; and all property not returned as hereinbefore provided for shall be taxed twenty-five per cent. above the regular rate, as a penalty for failing to return the same which penalty shall not in any case be relieved or remitted. The tax revisers shall give notice, in writing, to every person whose property they have revised; and any one dissatisfied with the assessment of his or her property may enter an appeal, in writing, within fifteen days from the date of the notice given, to the mayor and councilmen, whose decision in the matter shall be final and conclusive. The said revisers and said mayor and council shall have power and authority to subp[oelig]na witnesses for the city and for the complaining party and hear evidence as to the true value of said property. Mailing a notice to the person or their agents whose property has been raised, addressed to them at their last known postoffice, shall be sufficient compliance with this section as to giving notice. Tax revisers.

Sec. 41. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall also make or cause to be made by the persons having such matters in charge a quarterly statement and account, under oath, of the financial condition of said city; such account shall be a full and itemized statement of all moneys collected, when and from what source collected of all amounts paid out, the sum due the city and from what source due, the existing liabilities of the city and the balance on hand. Each statement and account shall be published. Quarterly statement of finances to be made.

Sec. 42. Be it further enacted, That it shall not be lawful for
any person holding any office in said city, whether by election or appointment, to be interested either directly or indirectly, in any contract to which said city is a party; and any contract made in violation of this section shall be void as against said city, and any officer violating this provision shall be dismissed from office. Municipal contracts, officers not to be interested in.

Sec. 43. Be it further enacted, That any and all ordinances rules and regulations now of force in said city of Rockmart, and not inconsistent with this Act shall be and remain of full force and effect, until altered, amended or repealed by said mayor and council. Ordinances.
Sec. 44. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: ROME, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the mayor and councilmen of the city of Rome to pave, grade, and otherwise improve for travel and drainage the streets, lanes and alleys of said city; to provide for an assessment of a portion of the cost of such improvements on real estate abutting on each side of street improved, and on street railways traversing the same, and to provide for the equalization of such assessments, and for the manner of collecting the same, and declaring such assessments liens on the property so assessed, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the mayor and councilmen of the city of Rome shall have full power and authority, in their discretion, to grade, pave and otherwise improve for travel and dfain-age the streets and public lanes and alleys of said city; to put down curbing, cross-drains, crossings, and otherwise improve the same. Rome, streets, improvement of.

Sec. 2. That the mayor and councilmen of the city of Rome shall also have full power and authority to assess thirty-three and one-third per cent. of the cost of grading, paving, constructing side-drains, cross-drains, and otherwise improving the roadway or street proper on the real estate abutting on the
street improved, to wit: Not exceeding sixteen and two-thirds per cent. of said cost on real estate on each side of such street, or portion of a street, which shall be so improved; provided, that the persons owning real estate which has at least one-half of the frontage on the block or portion of the street the improvement of which is desired, shall, in writing, request the mayor and councilmen of the city of Rome to make such improvements, and the said mayor and councilmen of the city of Rome shall by a two-thirds vote have approved the same, and shall by ordinance direct the said work to be done; and provided further, that every street railroad company having tracks running through the streets of said city shall be required to pave, as the said mayor and councilmen of the city of Rome may direct, to wit: between the rails and two feet on each side of every line of track now in use, or that may hereafter be constructed, by said company. Cost of, how assessed.

Sec. 3. The mayor and councilmen of the city of Rome shall have full power and authority to adopt by ordinance such a system of equalizing assessments on real estate for the above purposes as may be just and proper, estimating the total cost of each improvement made and prorating the cost thereof on the real estate according to its frontage on the street or portion of street improved. It shall be wholly discretionary with the mayor and councilmen of the city of Rome whether any work asked for is desirable or necessary, and shall be done or not; and no application shall be received and no work done for less than a block; provided, that the owners of one-half or more of the frontage on a block shall not, by a failure to apply for work, or by objections thereto, defeat an application of owners of one-half of the frontage of more than a block, when such application shall be regularly made. Assessments for street improvement Work on streets.

Sec. 4. The amount of assessment on each piece of real estate shall be a lien on said real estate from the date of the passage of the ordinance providing for the work and making the assessments. Lien of assess ments.

Sec. 5. The mayor and councilmen of the city of Rome shall have the authority to enforce the collection of the amount of any assessment so made for work, either for the streets or sidewalks, by execution to be issued by the clerk of council against the owner thereof at the date of the ordinance making the assessment. This execution may be levied on said real estate by the marshal or deputy-marshal of said city, and after advertisement and other proceeding, as in cases of sales for city taxes, the same may be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder,
and such sale shall vest an absolute title in the purchaser; provided, that the defendant shall have the right to file an affidavit denying that the whole or any part of the amount for which the execution issued is due, and stating what amount he admits to be due, which amount so admitted to be due shall be paid or collected before the affidavit is received, and the affidavit received for the balance; and all such affidavits so received shall be returned to the superior court of Floyd county, and there tried, and the issue determined as in cases of illegality, subject to all the pains and penalties provided for in cases of illegality for delay; further provided, that this Act shall in no way repeal or affect the present charter of the city of Rome with reference to cost of laying down sidewalks, as now provided for in said charter. Assessments collected by execution and sale. Illegalities.
Sec. 6. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be, and the same are hereby, repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SAVANNAH, SALE OF PORTION OF WRIGHT STREET IN, CONFIRMED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to confirm the sale by the mayor and aldermen of the city of Savannah to the Savannah Gas Company of a portion of Wright street described as follows: Beginning at a point on the south side of Wright street seventy-seven and seven-tenths (77.7) feet east of the eastern line of East Broad street and running east along the southern line of said Wright street seventy-six and two-tenths (76.2) feet to the brick wall of the Savannah Gas Company, thence in a northerly direction along said wall sixty (60) feet to the northern line of Wright street, thence in a westerly direction along the northern line of Wright street seventy-six and six-tenths (76.6) feet, thence perpendicularly across Wright street to the point of beginning, and containing four thousand, five hundred and eighty-four (4,584) square feet, more or less.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the sale by the mayor and aldermen of the city of Savannah, a municipal corporation of said State, to the Savannah
Gas Company, a corporation of Savannah, Georgia, of a portion of Wright street, in the city of Savannah, described in the above title be, and the same is confirmed, and the said municipal corporation is fully authorized to make a deed conveying the said portion of Wright street to the said Savannah Gas Company. Savannah, sale of portion of street confirmed.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SCOTT, TOWN OF, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the town of Scott in the county of Johnson; to provide for a mayor and councilmen and other officers; to prescribe their duties, and to provide for the enacting of all necessary ordinances; to provide penalties for the violation of the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the town of Scott, in the county of Johnson, be and the same is, hereby declared to be incorporated under the name and style of the town of Scott, and as such shall be entitled to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and do such other acts as may be authorized by this Act. Scott, town of, incorporated.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the corporate limits of said town shall be one-half mile in every direction from the depot in said town. Corporate limits.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That an election be held on the first Saturday in October, 1904, and on the first Saturday in October in each year thereafter, to serve one year, or until their successors are elected and qualified; said election to be conducted in the same manner as an election for the members of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and all persons living within the corporate limits of the town of Scott who shall qualify to vote for members of the General Assembly shall be qualified to vote for mayor and councilmen of said town, and shall be qualified to hold the office of mayor or councilmen. The person receiving the highest number of votes for the office
of mayor shall be declared elected, and the five persons receiving the highest number of votes for the office of councilmen shall be declared duly elected, and as soon as they take the oath of office shall enter upon the discharge of the duties of their respective offices. Mayor and councilmen, election for. Electors.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That before the entering upon the discharge of the duties, the mayor and councilmen shall subscribe the following oath, which may be administered by any person authorized by law of this State to administer oaths: I do solemnly swear that I will discharge all duties devolving upon me as mayor or councilmen, as the case may be, of the town of Scott, to the best of my ability and understanding, so help me, God. Oath.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and councilmen shall have power and authority to pass all laws and ordinances that they may deem necessary for the government of said town, and protection of property from loss by fire and damage therein: and for the protection of the lives and persons of the citizens generally; provided that they be not repugnant to the Constitution and laws of Georgia and the United States. Ordinances.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and councilmen shall have power and authority to levy and collect taxes not to exceed one per cent. upon all property, both real and personal, within the corporate limits of said town; the collection of said taxes may be enforced by execution issued by the clerk in the name of the mayor, and the levy and sale of property as in other cases of the sale of property. All the levies of the tax executions shall be made by the marshal or deputy, and all sales shall be conducted as the sales of the sheriffs of this State in case of the levy of tax executions. The said mayor and councilmen shall have power to require all persons within said corporate limits who are subject to road duty under the laws of this State to work the streets of said town for a period of fifteen days in each year, or they may prescribe a commutation tax, of not exceeding three dollars, which may be paid in lieu of the work upon the streets. Ad valorem tax. Street work and commutation tax.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the mayor of said town and in his absence the mayor pro tem., who shall be elected by the councilmen from their own number, shall be chief executive officer of said town. It shall be his duty to see that the ordinances, by-laws, rules and orders of the councilmen are fully executed, and it shall be his special duty to see that the peace and good order of said town are preserved, and that persons
and property therein are protected, and to this end he may cause the arrest and detention of rioters and disorderly persons in said town. He shall power to issue executions for all fines, penalties and costs imposed upon them, and issue warrants for the arrest of all disorderly persons in said town, and in default of the immediate payment of all fines and penalties and costs imposed he may imprison the defendant for a period of not exceeding sixty days, or sentence him to work upon the streets of said town not exceeding sixty days. The fines imposed by the mayor shall not be more than fifty dollars. Mayor, powers and duties.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, that said mayor and councilmen at their first meeting, or as early as possible, after they have been elected and installed, shall elect a clerk, who may be one of their number, or any citizen of said town, and at the same time shall elect a marshal, and if necessary, a deputy marshal. These officers, before entering upon the discharge of their duties, shall be required to take and subscribe to the oath before the mayor, and they and each of them will well and faithfully discharge their several duties as clerk, treasurer or marshal, as the case may be, to the best of their skill and knowledge. Clerk and marshal. Oath
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the clerk and marshal shall receive such salaries, to be determined before the election of said clerk and marshal. Compensation.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and councilmen shall have the power to tax all shows to which admission fee is charged, and in addition the ad valorem taxes levied; shall have power to tax all business enterprises as they may deem to be best interest of the town. Specific taxes.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and councilmen of the town of Scott shall have the power to close, open, alter, lay out and keep in good order and repair the roads, streets and alleys, sidewalks, crossways, street crossings and ditches, for the use of the public and the citizens thereof, and keep them free of obstructions, and abate or cause to be abated what, in the opinion of the majority of the whole council, should be a nuisance, and enact all necessary rules and regulations to protect the health of the town, and for general sanitary purposes. Streets, sidewalks, etc. General welfare.
Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SHADY DALE, NEW CHARTER FOR.
law.fulltitle: An Act to establish a new charter for the town of Shady Dale, in the county of Jasper, State of Georgia; to prescribe and define the limits of said town; to provide for a mayor and council, and for other officers of said town; to prescribe the rights, duties and powers of the officers, and for their election; to grant certain rights and privileges to said town, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the municipal government of the town of Shady Dale, in the county of Jasper, State of Georgia, shall consist of a mayor and five councilmen, and they and their successors shall constitute the body corporate under the name and style of the Town of Shady Dale, under which name and style they shall have power to enter into contracts, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in in any of the courts of this State, to have and use a common seal, to hold all property, both real and personal which may now belong to said town, or which may hereafter be acquired, to acquire both real and personal property, by gift, purchase or otherwise as may be deemed necessary for the welfare of said town for public use, and manage, use, sell, improve, lease or rent said properties, as may be deemed best for the corporate interest, by the authorities of said town. The town of Shady Dale, as it shall be constituted under this charter, shall succeed to all the rights and liabilities of the present corporation of said town, and the officers herein provided for shall have perpetual succession, and shall have the power, from time to time, to make, ordain and establish such rules, by-laws, ordinances, resolution and regulations as shall appear to them necessary and proper for the good government, security, general welfare and interest of said town of Shady Dale, and for the preserving of the health and morals, peace and good order of the same, in such manner as will not conflict with the Constitution of said State, or of the United States; Shady Dale, mayor and councilmen. Corporate powers. General welfare.

Provided, however, That the present councilmen of said town of Shady Dale, to-wit: W. D. Wynn, Chairman; C. R. Hodge, S. R. Baynes, T. C. Tucker and W. E. Baynes, councilmen, shall be and constitute the body corporate of said town of
Shady Dale, and shall exercise and have all the rights and powers, duties and liabilities granted and conferred on the corporate authorities of the town of Shady Dale under the provisions of this Act, until their successors are elected and qualified under the provisions of this Act. Councilmen appointed.

Sec. 2. That the corporate limits of said town of Shady Dale shall extend as they do at present, that is to say, one-half mile in every direction from the well at the residence of H. H. Ezell, except that the corporate limits shall extend no further south than the corporate limits of the town of Machen. Corporate limits.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That on the second Monday in January, 1906, there shall be an election held for a mayor and five councilmen, whose term of office shall be two (2) years from the second Tuesday in January, 1906, or until their successors are elected and qualified, and there shall be an election held biennially for mayor and councilmen on the second Monday in January, whose term of office shall be two years from the second Tuesday in January, beginning with the second Tuesday in January, 1906. Mayor and councilmen, election for.

Sec. 4. The elections provided for in section 3 hereof shall be held by a justice of the peace and two freeholders, residents of said town of Shady Dale, or in the event from any cause the justice of the peace does not assist in the holding of said election, then any three freeholders, residents of said town, may hold said election, the justice and freeholders, as the case may be, shall take and subscribe the same oath as is prescribed by law for superintendents of election for members of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia. They shall have all the powers incident to superintendents of elections, and to administer oaths to voters as to their qualification and right to vote in said election. They shall keep a numbere list of those voting at said election, and shall place on each ballot a number corresponding to the number appearing opposite the name of the voter. At the close of the election they shall count the ballots, keeping two tally-sheets thereof, and shall at once declare the result of the election, and shall issue certificates of election to the persons receiving the highest number of votes polled. They shall then place all the ballots cast in said election, together with a list of the voters voting at said election and one of the tally-sheets, in a sealed package, the list of voters and the tally-sheet being duly certified by the managers of said election, to be correct. They shall then deposit with the clerk of the town of Shady Dale the remaining tally-sheet and list of voters duly certified to be correct, which tally-sheet and list of voters shall
be safely kept by said clerk, together with the sealed package containing the list of voters, tally-sheet and ballots, which shall not be opened by any one, except in case of contest, but shall, at the expiration of sixty days from the date of said election (unless in case of contest), be by said clerk destroyed without examination. The managers of said election shall be paid the sum of one dollar each by the clerk of said town, upon the certificate of the mayor as to their services. The mayor-elect, within five days from his election, shall take an oath before some officer authorized by law to administer oaths, to well and truly perform all the duties of his office, and the mayor, after his qualification, and at the first meeting of the council shall administer to the councilmen a similar oath, which oaths of the mayor and councilmen, shall be entered upon the minutes of the board. In the event of a failure to hold the election at the time herein provided for, it shall at once become the duty of the mayor, or mayor pro tem., to call an election, giving at least ten days' notice thereof by posting notices at three public places in said town. No person shall be qualified to hold the office of mayor or councilmen, who is not entitled to vote in said election, and no person who is a candidate at said election shall be qualified to hold or assist in holding said election. Election managers. Powers and duties of. Compensation. Mayor and councilmen, oath of. Election. Eligibility.

Sec 5. Be it further enacted, That in the event the office of mayor or of any one or more of the council shall become vacant by death, resignation, or otherwise, such vacancy shall be filled by a person or persons elected by ballot by the board of councilmen, at a regular meeting of said board, and the person or persons so elected shall hold said office or offices until the next regular election, or until their successors are elected and qualified. Vacancies.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the clerk of said town of Shady Dale, or other person who may be selected by the board of councilmen, shall open a list for the registration of voters at least thirty days prior to any municipal election held for any purpose in said town, which list shall be kept open each and every day, except Sundays, and during such hours as shall be prescribed by the town council, until four days prior to such election, not counting Sundays, when the said list shall be finally and absolutely closed. During the time when said list is open, it shall be the duty of the clerk, or other person having charge of said list, upon the application of any person who will be entitled to vote in the coming election, to register the name of such person, giving name, age, occupation, business
or profession, and place of residence, and shall require of the person registering the following oath, to be taken and subscribed by him, to wit: You do solemnly swear that you are a citizen of the United States of America, that you will have resided in the State of Georgia one year immediately preceding this election, and in the county of Jasper and the town of Shady Dale six months next preceding this election, that it is your intention to remain a resident of said town of Shady Dale, continually until the day of said election, that you are twenty-one years of age, or will be by the day of election, that you have paid all taxes due the town of Shady Dale, that you have made all returns required by the ordinances of said town, and that you will be qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly by the day of election, so help you, God. It shall be the duty of the registration officer to furnish a list of the registered voters, arranged alphabetically, to the superintendents of the election, duly certified to be correct. The superintendents of the election shall keep said list before them, and no persons shall be allowed or permitted to vote in said election who have not complied with the requirements of this section. Any person voting in violation of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, tryable in the State court having jurisdiction, and shall be punished as prescribed in section 1039 of the Penal Code of Georgia. And no person shall be permitted or allowed to vote at any election held for any purpose in said town, who has not duly registered in accordance with the provisions of this section. Registration of voters. Registration lists. Illegal voting.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That at the first meeting after the mayor and councilmen have qualified, the new council shall elect one of their number as mayor pro tem., whose term of office shall be coincident with that of the mayor, and who shall have all the powers and duties of the mayor, in the absence of the mayor, or in case of his disqualification, both as a presiding officer and ex officio justice of the peace as well as chief executive officer of said town. And in the event of the absence or disqualification of both the mayor and mayor pro tem., the board of councilmen shall select one of their number to perform the duties of mayor during such absence or disqualification. Mayor pro tem.

Sec. 8. At the first meeting of council, after their election and qualification, they shall elect some person to act as clerk and treasurer of said town, such person to be one of the body of councilmen, or some other citizen of said town who is qualified to hold the office of councilman. The term of office of
said clerk and treasurer shall be two years, or until his successor is elected and qualified. He may be removed by the council for inefficiency, neglect of duty or other cause, in the discretion of the council. He shall keep the minutes of the council in well-bound books, furnished him by the council and shall preserve them and all other records and vouchers entrusted to him. He shall receive tax returns, and collect all taxes due said town, the collection of which is not otherwise provided for herein. He shall issue all licenses and collect the license tax as shall be provided for by ordinances, rules and regulations of the council. He shall receive all money due said town, and keep a correct account thereof, showing from what source the same was derived. He shall issue execution for all taxes which are not paid at the time fixed by council for paying the same, which executions shall be directed to the marshal of said town, or to his deputy. He shall be the custodian of the funds of said town, as well as of the records of same, and shall perform all duties that may be required of him by the mayor and council. He shall have power to appoint some fit and proper person as his deputy, who shall have the same powers as said clerk and treasurer, and for whose acts he and his bondsmen shall be liable in the same manner as if the acts were done by himself. He shall be required to give bond with good and sufficient security, to be approved of by the mayor, in such sum as the council shall prescribe, payable to the mayor of the town of Shady Dale, and his successors in office, conditioned faithfully to collect and pay over all taxes and account for the same, as well as other income and moneys that may come into his hands belonging to said town, from whatsover source derived, and to perform the duties imposed on him by this Act, and such others as may be required of him by council of said town. Clerk and treasurer, powers and duties. Deputy clerk.

Sec. 9. That three of the board of councilmen shall constitute a quorum of the body. The mayor shall preside over the meetings of said council, and shall vote only in the case of a tie, in which case he shall cast the deciding vote. He shall be the chief executive officer of said town; shall take care that the by-laws, orders, rules, regulations, ordinances and Acts of said council are faithfully executed; he shall have ex officio the powers and duties of the justice of the peace within the limits of said town, except that he shall have no jurisdiction of civil cases, as such justice; he shall have control of the marshal and his deputies and of all special officers appointed by council, for any purpose, and he shall have the power to appoint special marshals upon any special occasion when the exigencies of the
case may require it; he shall have power to cause the arrest and detention of all boisterous, riotous and disorderly persons before issuing his warrant therefor. The mayor shall have the right to veto any ordinance or resolution of the council, in which event the same shall not become a law unless it shall subsequently be passed over his veto by the vote of at least four councilmen, on a yea and nay vote of the council duly recorded on the minutes of the council. But unless the mayor, within four days from the passage of any ordinance or resolution, shall file with the clerk of council his veto, together with his reasons for vetoing the same, such ordinances and resolutions shall become law in the same manner as if signed by the mayor and affirmed by him. The mayor, or in his absence or disqualification, the mayor pro tem., or in the absence or disqualification of the mayor and mayor pro tem., then one of the councilmen, who shall be selected by the council, shall preside over the police court hereinafter provided for, and shall have power to punish for contempt, both before the town council and the police court, in a sum not to exceed twenty-five dollars, or by imprisonment in the guard-house for not more than five days, either or both, or any part thereof, in the discretion of the mayor or presiding officer. Quorum Mayor, powers and duties. Police court. Contempts of, punishment for.
Sec. 10. That the mayor and other officers of said town shall receive such salaries as shall be prescribed by the council, as compensation for their services. Compensation of officers.

Sec. 11. That the mayor of said town, or in his absence the mayor pro tem., or in the absence or disqualification of both, a member of council, as provided for in section 9 hereof, shall hold a mayor's court for the trial of all persons charged with the violation of any of the ordinances, orders, rules, by-laws, or regulations of said town, and, on conviction, shall punish such offenders by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars, or by compelling them to work on the public streets of said town of Shady Dale for a period of not more than ninety days, or by confinement in the guard-house of said town, or common jail of said county of Jasper, for a period of not more than sixty days, and, in the discretion of the presiding officer, all, or any part of each, may be imposed. Said court shall have full power and authority to issue executions directed to the marshal and his deputies for the enforcement of any and all fines imposed, and for the collection of all costs; shall have power to provide by ordinances for the enforcement of all its sentences. When any sentence shall be for fine and imprisonment, until the fine is paid, the jailor of said county of Jasper, upon application of the
mayor of said town of Shady Dale, shall receive said person so fined and confine him in the jail of said county, in accordance with the terms of the said sentence; and in like manner, he shall receive prisoners sentenced to imprisonment. The jailor shall receive the same compensation as is paid him for keep of State prisoners, which shall be paid by the town of Shady Dale, as other obligations are paid by said town. The presiding officer of said court shall assess bond in all cases brought before him, in cases where any municipal law is violated, as well as in State cases, where the defendant is required to answer for any offense bailable by justices of the peace. But when a person is sentenced to confinement for contempt of the mayor's court, for violation of any municipal law, the defendant may, at the discretion of the mayor, be confined in the guard-house of the town of Shady Dale, instead of the county jail. Mayor's court. Punitive powers. Fines and costs collected by execution. County jail, prisoners confined in. Bail bond.

Sec. 12. That where executions are issued for municipal ad valorem taxes, license taxes or other fees, the cost shall be the same as in case of executions for State and county taxes, and the costs of the marshal shall be the same as the sheriff receives for the collection of State and county taxes. And in all cases before the mayor's court, where the defendant is bound over for a State offense, the cost shall be the same as that received by justices of the peace in like cases, which costs, together with that of the marshal, shall be paid into the town treasury, unless, in the case of the marshal, the council shall allow said cost to the marshal in addition to his salary. Executions, cost of. State offense, cost where prisoners committed for.

Sec. 13. All persons convicted in the mayor's court shall have the right to appeal to the council, in writing, and immediately after conviction, and the cost then accrued must be paid or, in lieu thereof, an affidavit in forma pauperis shall be filed with said appeal. For the purpose of trying appeals, the board of couucilmen shall have the right to convene at any time. They shall have the right and power to reduce, increase, modify or nullify the previous sentence. Pending the appeal, the accused shall have the right and shall be allowed to give bond for his appearance, if he is able to do so, otherwise he shall be confined in the guard-house or jail. The person before whom the case was originally tried may conduct the examination of witness in the new trial, unless counsel be employed, but he shall not be competent to sit as member of the court of appeals. Appeals. Appearance bonds.

Sec. 14. That the town council shall have power and authority to assess, levy and collect an annual ad valorem tax upon all property, real and personal, of whatsoever character or kind, except such property as is exempt from taxation by the Constitution
and laws of the State of Georgia, which is in the corporate limits of said town; to prescribe rules and regulations for the same and to fix penalties for non-compliance therewith; to fix the time for making tax returns and the time for paying taxes, notice of such times being given at least four weeks prior to such fixed times, by posting a notice at three public places in said town. For the ordinary purposes of municipal government, the council shall have the power to assess an ad valorem tax of not more than six-tenths of one per cent.; for the purposes of improving and working streets, opening new streets, and for other extraordinary expenses, they shall have the power and authority to levy and additional tax of not more than fourtenths of one per cent. The council shall have the power to appoint three freeholders, citizens of said town, but who are not members of the council, as tax assessors, whose duty it shall be to assess for the purposes of taxation all realty lying within the incorporate limits of said town, which is subject to State and county taxes, and make a return thereof to the council, under such rules as the council may prescribe, at such time as they designate. The clerk and treasurer of said town shall receive the returns for taxation of all personalty owned or situated in said town by any person, resident or non-resident, in a well-bound book to be kept by him for that purpose, appropriately designating in marked columns the class of personalty returned. Ad valorem tax. Tax assessors. Tax returns.

Sec. 15.
