In addition to the ad valorem tax herein provided for, the council shall have power and authority to collect a special tax upon all persons running a billiard table or tables, or pool table or tables, ten or nine-pin alley, or other alley of like character; also upon all wheels of fortune, ball or slot machine or other like device, or machine or device of any kind kept or had for hazard or chance, or for the purpose of inducing trade, or for private gain, in said town; also upon all shows, circuses, sleight-of-hand performances, or any other performances or play, except those held for charitable purposes, or religious purposes, or exhibitions by the schools of said town, or those exempt from tax under the laws of this State. They may levy a tax upon all ball games of any character, when admission fees are charged or collected; also upon all fire and life insurance companies doing business in said town; also upon all telephone and telegraph and express companies; also upon all building and loan companies, persons or firms loaning money, operating mills of any kind, and any business carried on in said town; they may tax the buying and selling of cotton-seed,
the running of public warehouses, all guano dealers, markets for selling of fresh fish and meats, or either, the dealers of fresh fish and meats, and all other lines of business carried on in said town. They shall also have power to tax and license all livery stables, feed stables, and sale stables, drays, hotels, public boarding-houses, and persons running a public boarding-house, hotel, dray, wagon, cart or other device for the public or for hire. They shall also have power to levy and collect a special tax from all transient persons doing business in said town, upon all trades or occupations carried on in said town, and upon all itinerant tinkers, traders or peddlers plying their vocation or offering their wares for sale in said town, except such professions, trades, business or callings as are exempt from taxation by the laws of the State of Georgia. All special taxes herein provided for shall be paid to the clerk and treasurer of said town before the person shall engage in the business or calling; and any person who shall fail to so pay the same before engaging in the business or calling for which he is subject to tax, or who shall fail or refuse to pay upon notice that he is liable therefor shall, upon conviction, be fined an amount double the amount of such tax, together with cost, or be imprisoned in the guard-house, or put to work on the public streets of said town, for a period of not more than fifty days. In case of corporations and non-resident firms, the agent representing such corporations and non-resident firms who transacts business for them shall be subject to the penalties herein prescribed for doing business without first obtaining a license and paying the tax. Specific taxes.

Sec. 16. That the council shall have full power and authority to lay out, widen, straighten, open or close, alter, drain and keep in good repair, all roads, streets, alleys, crosswalks, sidewalks and bridges in said town, for the use of the public, and to dig, fill up, or repair any public well in said town; to provide proper drainage and sewerage for said town; to provide punishment for filling up any drainage or sewerage, either on public or private property by fine, imprisonment or labor on the public streets. And to this end they shall have power and authority to condemn and appropriate any lands in said town, and if necessary for sewerage or drainage, beyond the limits of said town, but they shall be liable to the owners of said condemned lands in a reasonable sum therefor, when damages have resulted and are claimed, and when the council and the owners of such condemned lands cannot agree upon the price to be paid as damages, then the same shall be submitted to arbitration of
three freeholders of said town, each party to choose one, and the two so selected shall select the third man, and they three, after being duly sworn before officer authorized by law to administer oaths, or before the mayor, to do justice and equity between the parties, shall proceed to assess the damages resulting from such condemnation, after duly considering all the facts, including the advantages resulting to the owner, if any. But in no event shall the betterment exceed the amount of damages allowed. They shall, within ten days from their appointment, make their return, which shall be final, and if accepted by the council, shall be entered upon the minutes by the clerk and treasurer. Streets, side walks, etc. Condemnation of land for.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all persons subject to road duty under the laws of this State, who reside within the incorporate limits of the town of Shady Dale, shall be liable to street duty in said town, not to exceed fifteen days in any one year, under the direction of the officers of said town; provided, however, that the board of councilmen may provide a commutation tax in lieu of such work on the streets, not to exceed five dollars, which, when paid, shall relieve the party from street duty that year. Said street tax shall become due on the first day of February each year, and if it is not paid when demanded by the marshal, or if the work demanded is not performed when required, the marshal shall return such as defaulters, and, unless a satisfactory excuse is rendered before the mayor, such defaulters shall be fined double the assessed tax, or not more than thirty days labor on the streets, in the discretion of the mayor. All the moneys collected as street taxes shall be applied to the improvement of the streets of said town and to no other purposes. Street work and commutation tax. Defaulters Street tax, proceeds of, how applied.
Sec. 18. The council shall have power and authority to levy a tax on dogs, not to exceed two dollars per head per annum, which tax shall be added to the general tax funds of said town. Dog tax.

Sec. 19. That said council shall have power and authority to remove or cause to be removed from the streets of said town, or sidewalk, alley, or cross-way, at the expense of the owner, all buildings, porches, steps, fences, or other obstruction therein; to abate, or cause to be abated, any nuisances in any of the streets, sidewalks or alleys, or any other nuisance in said town, and to determine and declare what are nuisances, and to abate the same; to acquire and own property in or near said town for a cemetery, to regulate interment therein, and to punish any and all persons injuring or destroying the property, or shrubbery
and plants therein. They shall have power to regulate privies, water-closets, butcher pens, wood and blacksmith shops, stores and store-flues and chimneys in said town, and to cause to be removed, cleansed or repaired at the expense of the owner or tenant, any of said places or buildings that may become dangerous to the health of the citizens, or dangerous to the public or private property in said town; they shall have power to regulate the keeping of all domestic animals, and to prevent the same from running at large in said town; to provide for the impounding of and sale of the same; to regulate the keeping of public or private stables, gunpowder, kerosene oil, gasoline, turpentine, and all other property that may become dangerous or offensive to the citizens or property of said town. They shall have power to lay out and define fire limits, and to prevent the building of or erection of any building within the same that would tend to increase the risk of fire, and to prescribe of what material buildings erected within said limits shall be, and prescribe and fix punishment for persons violating the ordinances regulating buildings and the erection thereof, and shall have power and authority to cause to be removed at the expense of the owner any building erected in violation of the ordinances concerning buildings within said fire limits. Council, powers of. Fire limits and buildings therein.

Sec. 20. That said council shall have power and authority to pass all ordinances to prevent the blockading of the streets, alleys, avenues and sidewalks, including railroad crossings in said town, to prevent the hitching of mules, horses or other work animals, except at such places as may be designated, and to prescribe punishments for violations of the same. They shall also have power to regulate the use of firearms, fireworks, or other dangerous, noisy and offensive explosives used in sports or otherwise in said town. Streets, blockading of. Explosives, regulation of use of.

Sec. 21. They shall have power, upon proof of the existence of any bawdy or lewd house, gaming house, or house where intoxicating liquors are stored or kept for illegal sale, to abate the same, and to this end the marshal shall have power and authority upon the affidavit of any person, or upon reasonable grounds of suspicion that any house is used for the purposes above enumerated, to enter the same and make search, and may seize any property found therein, or arrest any person therein, when such property is therein kept or stored for illegal purposes, or the persons therein are found to be therein for illegal purposes or practices, bring said property and persons before the mayor to be dealt with in accordance with the ordinances in such cases made and provided. Lewd, gaming, etc., houses, abatement of.

Sec. 22. Said town council shall have power and authority to grant franchise to electric light companies, waterworks companies, telegraph and telephone companies, and any other corporations desiring to do business in said town. Corporate franchises.

Sec. 23. Said town council shall have power to establish a chainging in said town to be composed of all violators of the ordinances of said town, who may be sentenced thereto, or who may fail or refuse to pay the fines imposed, and of such other convicts as the council may see fit and proper to employ or hire. This gang shall be under the control and direction of the marshal of said town, or his deputy, or such other person as the council may select. The person in charge of such convicts shall compel them to obey orders and to perform good work, and to that end he is hereby authorized and empowered to whip any and all refractory convicts. Chaingang.

Sec. 24. Said municipal corporation shall have all the rights and privileges and powers incident to such corporations, which are not in conflict with the Constitution and laws of this State, nor of the United States. Corporate powers.

Sec. 25. The council shall have power and authority to enact ordinances in regard to the observance of the Sabbath day (Sunday), and to prohibit any and all persons from opening their places of business for the purpose of trade, or making a sale, or plying their several vocations, cases of emergency, necessity or charity excepted; may prohibit all games or any form of amusement within the limits of said town, and which are not consistent with the proper observance of said day. Sabbath observance, ordinances in regard to.

Sec. 26. At the first meeting of the new council, a marshal shall be elected, whose term of office shall be the same as that of the mayor, or until his successor is elected and qualified. He shall be required to give bond in such sum as the council may prescribe, conditioned for the faithful discharge of his duties, and for the accounting for and paying over to the clerk and treasurer any and all moneys that may come into his hand belonging to said town of Shady Dale, which bond shall be payable to the mayor of said town and his successors in office. The marshal may be removed by the council at any time for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or any other cause, in the discretion of the council. The council may also appoint one or more deputy marshals, as they may deem necessary, to assist the marshal in his duties, such deputies to hold office only for such time and on such terms as may be prescribed by council. Said marshal and his deputies shall have full power and authority to arrest all persons violating any of the penal ordinances of
said town, and to confine them in the guard house of said town or the common jail of Jasper county, or take bond for their appearance before the mayor's court, the amount of such bond to be fixed by the mayor; they shall also have full power to arrest all persons violating the penal laws of the State, within the limits of said town, in the same manner that sheriffs may arrest for such offenses, and to confine such persons in the guard-house of said town or the jail of said county, subject to trial before the mayor's court or some magistrate as provided by law; said marshal shall execute and enforce the ordinances rules and regulations of said council, as may be provided therein; they shall levy and execute all processes issued from the mayor's court, and all executions for municipal taxes and shall advertise and sell all property levied upon in the same manner that the sheriff is required to advertise and sell property levied upon for State and county taxes, except that the advertisements for sales shall be posted at the council-room door and three other public places in the town of Shady Dale, and the sale shall be had before said council-room door; said marshals shall have control of the chain-gang of said town, shall have charge of the street working and persons liable to street duty, and shall perform all the duties imposed upon them by the council. Said marshals shall collect all street taxes and all fines imposed in the mayor's court and shall perform all special duties required by council. Marshal. Bond. Removal. Deputy marshal. Arrests. Executions and sales. Chaingang, marshal to control. Street taxes and fines, collection of.

Sec. 27. The present charter of Shady Dale shall remain of force until the passage and approval by the Governor of this Act, and after which, all the ordinances now of force in said town shall remain of full force and effect until the same shall be repealed. Old charter of force until approval of this act. Ordinances.

Sec. 28. Said council shall have full power and authority to establish quarantine against any person or place that may be infected with any contagious disease, and to enforce the same. They shall also have the right to establish pest-house and maintain the same, when it may be deemed necessary to prevent the spread of any contagious disease, and to enforce such rules as may be necessary to enforce the observance of the quarantine. Quarantine.

Sec. 29. Be it further enacted, That the mayor or any member of the council, upon conviction before said board for neglect of duty or malpractice in office, shall be removed and his or their office declared vacant, and the same shall be filled as herein provided. The mayor and councilmen shall be liable to the same punishment as other persons for the violation of any of the ordinances of said town. Mayor and council, malpractice in office.

Sec. 30. Be it further enacted, That the town council of
Shady Dale shall have the power and authority to establish and maintain a system of public schools, or common schools within said town, by first complying with the following conditions, to wit: Before any public or common schools shall be established in said town, to be wholly or partially maintained at the expense of said town, the mayor upon recommendation of a majority of the council, shall advertise an election, by posting a notice of the same at not less than five public places in said town, at least thirty days before said election is to be held. All persons who are qualified to vote for mayor and councilmen of said town, shall be qualified to vote in this election, and said election shall be conducted in the same manner that other elections are held under the provisions of this Act. It shall be the duty of the voter in said election to endorse on his ticket or ballot Public Schools or Against Public Schools, and if two-thirds of all persons qualified to vote at said election, shall be found to have voted Public Schools, then, and in that event, but not otherwise, it shall be lawful for said town council to establish one or more public schools for each of the two races in said town, to be maintained in whole or in part at expense of said town, by local taxation; provided, however, that the rate of taxation levied for school purpose shall not exceed one-half of one per cent. in any year; and provided still further, that in no event shall the sum appropriated to the support and maintenance of the schools for whites exceed the pro rata of taxation paid by the white citizens of said town for school purposes, and the amount appropriated each year for the support of schools for colored children shall in no event exceed the sum paid by the colored citizens of said town as taxes for school purposes. And the clerk and treasurer of said town, in the event public schools are established in said town, shall keep a separate list of the white and colored taxpayers, and the council may appropriate to white schools a sum equal to the amount of taxes paid by whites for school purposes. And the town council may appropriate to the support of schools for colored children a sum equal to the amount colleeted from and paid by the colored citizens of said town for school purposes, but in no event shall an amount greater than the sum paid by each color be appropriated to the support of schools for each color. In the event two-thirds of the qualified voters are found to have voted in favor of public schools, then the council of said town is hereby authorized to take all necessary and proper steps to organize, maintain and operate a system of public schools in said town and to this end may receive by gift, purchase or otherwise, any
real estate, may improve the same or erect buildings thereon for school purposes they may deem necessary for the welfare of said schools. Public schools. Election for. Taxation and appropriation for.

Sec. 31. The mayor by and with the consent of the council, to be determined by a vote at any regular meeting or a special meeting, may upon proper grounds, revoke any license granted to any person, when it shall appear that said person or persons are keeping a place for immoral or illegal purposes, or who permit the gathering of boisterous and riotous assemblages in or around their places of business. The council may declare such places nuisances, and may abate the same as such. Licenses, revocation of. Town contests, officers not to be interested in.

Sec. 32. No officer of said town shall have any interest in any contest, either directly or indirectly, in which the town is interested or is a party; neither shall any member of the council be allowed to vote upon any question in which he has any personal interest whatever. Councilmen not to vote when personally interested.

Sec. 33. All elections held under the provisions of this Act shall be held between the hours of 9 a.m., and 6 p.m., and in no event shall the polls be closed before 4 p.m., meridian time. Polls, hours to renfain open
Sec. 34. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SOCIAL CIRCLE, TOWN OF, ACT INCORPORATING REPEALED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act, entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Social Circle, in the county of Walton, and to appoint commissioners for the same and to point out the mode of electing commissioners and for other purposes, etc., approved March 18, 1869, and all other acts amendatory thereof, so as to repeal the charter of said town.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the Act entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Social Circle, in the county of Walton and to point out the mode of electing commissioners and for other purposes, etc., approved March 18, 1869. And all other acts amendatory
thereof, be and the same are hereby repealed, so as to repeal the charter of said town of Social Circle. Social Circle, town of, charter repealed.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SOCIAL CIRCLE, CITY OF, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An act to incorporate the city of Social Circle in the county of Walton, define its limits, to provide for mayor and council and other officers, and the manner of their election; to provide for government of said city of Social Circle, and for other purposes therein contained.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the inhabitants of the territory embraced within the limits of one mile in every direction from the public well, at the intersection of Madison, Monroe, Covington and Gibbs streets in the town of Social Circle, Walton county, be, and they are hereby incorporated under the name and style of the City of Social Circle; and by that name shall be and are hereby invested with all the powers, rights, and privileges incident to municipal corporations in this State, as well as all the rights, powers, titles, property easements, and hereditaments now belonging or in anywise appertaining to the town of Social Circle, heretofore incorporated; said city of Social Circle created by this Act, is hereby made responsible as a corporate body for all legal debts, liabilities, and undertakings of said town of Social Circle as heretofore incorporated. Social Circle, city of, incorporated.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the government of said city shall vest in a mayor and four councilmen. That the present mayor and council of the town of Social Circle, namely: W. B. Spearman, mayor; H. L. Conner, J. H. Adams, E. L. Newton, and R. L. Paine, councilmen, shall continue in office until the expiration of the term for which they were elected, and until their successors are elected and qualified, and they and their successors shall have and exercise all the rights, powers, and duties hereby conferred on the mayor and council of said city of Social Circle by this Act. That all rules, regulations and ordinances of said town of Social Circle not inconsistent with
and authorized by this Act remain of full force and effect as the rules, regulations, and ordinances of said city of Social Circle, until changed or repealed by said mayor and council of said city. Mayor and councilmen.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person shall be eligible to the office of mayor and councilmen of said city who has not been a resident thereof for six months or more, continuously, next preceding his or their election and who has not attained the age of twenty-one years. Eligibility.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That under and by virtue of this Act there shall be an election held for a mayor and four councilmen on the first Wednesday in December, 1904, and biennially thereafter. In said elections the polls shall be opened in the city hall, or such other place as may be designated by ordinance, at nine o'clock a.m., and closed at four o'clock p.m. Said election shall be under the management and control of a justice of the peace, or notary public and ex officio J. P., and two freeholders, or of three freeholders of said city, which said justice of the peace, or notary public and freeholders, shall be elected by the mayor and council then in office. The managers of said election may appoint two clerks and shall, together with said clerks receive such compesation as may be agreed upon by the mayor and council, not exceeding three dollars per day. Election.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the managers of election in said city shall take before some officer authorized to administer an oath, or administer to each other the following oath: I, , do solemnly swear that I will faithfully perform the duty of manager of this election to the best of my ability, prevent illegal and fraudulent voting, without fear or favor, so help me, God. Oath of managers of election.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That immediately after the polls are closed, said managers shall count the ballots cast, and after the ballots have been counted, the tally-sheets and list of voters shall be certified, in writing, by said managers in the following language, to wit: We do certify that the foregoing pages constitute the tally-sheets (or list of voters, as the case may be) of an election forheld by us this day of, and that they are an accurate and faithful record of the names and number of voters at said election. This day of Tally-sheets, certificate to.
Manager.
Manager.
Manager.

Manager.
The tally-sheet and list of voters shall then be sealed up together in an envelope, delivered to the clerk of the city, and filed of record in his office. The ballots shall likewise be sealed in an envelope, delivered to the clerk, and filed of record in his office. Tally-sheets and ballots, disposition of.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That on the day next succeeding such election, the managers thereof shall file a written report of the result with the acting mayor and councilmen, showing the number of votes cast and for whom cast. Upon the filing of said report the mayor and council shall declare the result of said election, and shall enter it of record on the minutes of the city clerk. Result of election, managers to file report of.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That if after ten days from the day of said election, no notice of contest is given as to the result of said election, the clerk aforesaid shall destroy the ballots. Should any person, except under an order from the superior court of Walton county, for any cause whatever, inspect either the tally-sheets, list of voters, or ballots of said election, after they have been filed with the clerk of the city aforesaid, he shall be liable to fine or imprisonment, in discretion of the mayor's court of said city. Ballots, destruction of. Tallysheets, etc., inspection of illegal, when.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the term of office of mayor and councilmen shall be two years from Monday, after the first Wednesday in December, after their election. The mayor and councilmen-elect shall meet in the city hall and there shall severally take before some officer authorized under the laws of Georgia to administer oaths, the following oath of office, to wit: I do solemnly swear that I will well and truly demean myself as mayor (or councilmen, as the case may be) of the city of Social Circle for the ensuing term, and that I will faithfully enforce the charter and ordinances of said city to the best of my ability and knowledge, so help me, God. Should the mayor or any councilman-elect be absent from said meeting, he or they shall take said oath of office as soon as possible thereafter. Mayor and councilmen, term of office. Sessions, where held. Oath.

Sec. 10. Be it enacted, That all persons residing in said city of Social Circle, who are qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly of the State, who have paid all the taxes and done all the work on the streets required by the authorities of said city, and shall have resided in said city for the full term of six months previous to the date on which said election may be held, and shall have registered as hereinafter provided, shall be considered electors and qualified to vote. Electors.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That the clerk of said city
council shall keep a book in which voters of said city shall register their names and ages, or if the person who desires to register can not write his name, the clerk shall sign his name for him in said book, the person swearing and subscribing to the same: I do solemnly swear that I am twenty-one years of age, or that I will be by the time of the election now next to be held in said town: I have resided in the State of Georgia twelve months, or will have resided in said State twelve months by the time of said election; I have resided in the city of Social Circle, or will have resided in said city six months by the time of said election; I have paid all taxesState, county, and municipalrequired of me, except for the present year, and I am not otherwise disqualified to vote in said election. Registration of voters.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That said clerk of council shall open said registration book thirty days before any election to be held in and for said city of Social Circle, and shall proceed to register the voters of said city as already provided, and shall keep said registration book open until ten days before the city election, when he shall close said book and allow no other person to register; and shall immediately file said book of registered voters with the registrars of said city hereinafter provided for, and said clerk shall write his certificate at the close of said list of registered voters so registered, stating that same is a true and correct list of all the voters registered by him, and that he has not allowed any one to register that was not, in his opinion, entitled to register and vote under the laws of said city in the election next to be held. Registration book.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted that the mayor and council of said city shall within thirty days after their qualification, appoint three intelligent and upright freeholders of city as registrars of voters for the city of Social Circle, the said mayor and council having the right to fill vacancies in said board of registrars at any meeting of mayor and council when a quorum is present. And it shall be the duty of said registrars to receive the certified list of registered voters, and from it, make out a complete list of the qualified voters of the said city. Said registrars shall place no name on said list that does not appear on the list filed with them until it be made to appear that such names were illegally withheld from said list of the clerk; and they shall be satisfied that all names taken from the clerk's list are qualified to vote in the next election before they place said names upon the list prepared by them. Registrars.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That in preparing said list and investigating the qualifications of voters, said registrars shall
have the same power to subp[oelig]na and compel the attendance of witnesses, hear evidence under oath, and punish for contempts, that the mayor of said city has under the charter while holding his court, and they shall have the same power to require the marshal or police of said city to subp[oelig]na witnesses and perform other services necessary to said investigation. Powers.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That said registrars, after they have completed said list, shall certify the same, to be completed and a correct list of the registered voters of said city, and on the day on which the election is to be held, at the time of opening the polls, shall place the said list in the hands of the managers at the precints of said election, and said managers shall permit no person to vote whose name does not appear on said list, and after said election is closed and the result is certified to by the said managers, said list of registered voters used by said managers shall be by them filed with the mayor and council to be kept as the other papers in said election. Registration list.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, That any person who shall register in the book kept by the clerk of the council who is not entitled to register under the laws of said city, or if the clerk allows any one to register whom he knows is not entitled to register in said book, or if the registrars of said city allow any one to register whom they know that is not entitled to register, or if the clerk or registrars shall knowingly make a false certificate to said list, for any one of said violations of this law by any of the persons named, the person who violates the same, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and be punished as prescribed by section 1039, of volume 3 of the Code of 1895, after an indictment or presentment of the grand jury of Walton county. Illegal registration and improper conduct of registrars and clerk, penalty for

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted, That for purposes of raising revenues to defray the ordinary current expenses incident to the proper support and maintenance of the city government, the said mayor and council shall have power and authority to levy and collect an ad valorem tax upon all property, both real and personal, in the corporate limits of said city, not to exceed one-third of one per centum, but when that amount becomes insufficient, the mayor and council shall have the authority to levy an additional tax in the manner provided by the Constitution and laws of the State of Georgia, and said mayor and council shall be empowered to enact and adopt such ordinances as may be necessary for the carrying out of this power. Ad valorem tax.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have power and authority to levy and collect an annual tax of not less than one dollar per head from the owners of all
dogs within said city, and to enforce said tax as other taxes are enforced; in addition to which they shall have authority to authorize by ordinance the police officers of said city to impound or kill all dogs for which the tax be not paid. Dog tax.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid; That said mayor and council shall have power to provide for the levy and collection of a business or occupation tax upon any trade, business, profession, or occupation, except such as are exempt by law, carried on within said city. And upon the inhabitants of said city, who engage in, or offer, or attempt to engage in any profession, trade, business, or occupation in said city; and on such persons who live without said city, but who engage in, or attempt to engage in, any profession, business, trade, or occupation not exempt by law, within the limits of said city, as said mayor and council may deem expedient for the safety, benefit, convenience, or advantage of said city. This tax may be in the nature of a license, which must be paid in advance of engaging in such profession, trade, business, or occupation. And said mayor and council shall provide by ordinance for the punishment of all persons required by ordinance to pay such occupation tax or take out license for same, who engage in or offer or attempt to engage in such business, trade, profession, or occupation before paying such tax or taking out such license and complying fully with all the requirements of said mayor and council made in reference thereto. Business tax.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and council shall have full power and authority to license, regulate, and control by ordinance all hotels, boarding houses, restaurants, saloons for sale of ices, creams and drinks of all kinds, livery, feed, or sale stables and lots, public hacks, drays, and other vehicles, auctioneers, vendue masters, itinerant traders, itinerant venders of all or any kind of articles of merchandise, goods, wares or other things, peddlers of any kind of merchandise whatsoever, theatres and theatrical performances, shows, circuses, and exhibitions of all kinds, every keeper of billiard, pool or other tables, ten-pin alley, shooting-gallery, or other table device, stand, or play for the performance of any game or amusement; all manufacturing enterprises, itinerant lightning-rod dealers, immigrant agents, book agents, life, fire, and accident insurance agents, and companies, loan agents, agents of any and all kinds of business, banks and bankers, brokers and commission merchants; keepers of slaughter-houses, beef markets, green grocers, dealers in fresh oysters or fish, vegetables or fruits, breads or other articles of
food. And upon all and any other establishment, business, trade, calling or occupation not heretofore mentioned, and which under the laws of the State of Georgia are subject to license. Mayor and council, power to license and regulate.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have full and absolute power and authority to control, regulate and license the sale, by retail or wholesale, of all and every kind of whiskies, brandies, beers, wines, ciders, or any and all intoxicating liquors, bitters, beverages, or drinks in said city. That it shall be unlawful to sell said liquors in said city without first procuring from said city a license to sell the same. That said mayor and council shall not grant or issue to any person a license to sell said liquors for a sum less than ten thousand dollars, which must be paid in advance, and that no license shall authorize the sale for any time beyond the fiscal year in which it was issued. And that said full amount for said license shall be paid in advance without regard to the time when the dealer takes out the same or begins business. And that before any license issue, the person applying for same, must file with the mayor and council a petition signed by the majority of the freeholders living in said city, showing his fitness to hold said license, and asking the granting to him of the same, provided always, that it shall be discretionary with said mayor and council to grant or withhold said license. And provided further, that this section of this Act be of force only when and so long as it is lawful to sell liquor in Walton county by retail. Intoxicating liquors.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of said city have authority to establish by ordinance a fiscal year in their discretion, from which and to which all licenses shall date. That said mayor and council shall not prorate the amount of any license but collect the full amount required for the fiscal year, regardless of the part of the year already passed, and that all licenses shall expire and terminate with the fiscal year in which they were issued. And that all licenses issued under this charter shall be paid in full at the time of issue. Fiscal year. Licenses issued for.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have full power and authority over the public streets, sidewalks and other public thoroughfares in said city, and it shall be their duty to keep the same in repair. They shall have the power and authority to open up new streets, widen, extend, or alter existing streets, sidewalks or alleys, and if in the exercise of this power it becomes necessary to take or damage private property for the public use and purpose, and the same can not be procured by contract, said private property shall be condemned
in the way and manner now provided by the laws of said State of Georgia as embraced in the Code of 1895. Streets, sidewalks, etc. Condemnation for.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have the power to require all persons within the incorporate limits of said city, who are subject to road duty under the laws of this State, to work on the streets of said city, or they may prescribe a commutation tax which may be paid in lieu of work on said streets. Upon failure to work on said streets or pay said tax, said mayor and council shall have authority to provide suitable regulations and punishments therefor as for other violations of the ordinances of said city. Street work and commutation tax.

Sec. 25. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have full power and authority over the cemeteries of said city, wherever they belong to said city or individuals, provide all proper rules, regulations, and ordinances for the proper, decent and sanitary interment of the dead. That they may provide as necessity requires, other lands for cemetery purposes either in or outside of the city limits. Cemeteries.

Sec. 26, Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall elect a mayor pro tem., a clerk of council, a city treasurer. Such officers shall also be members of said council, to hold their offices so long as their term as councilmen continues. They shall also elect a chief of police and such other police, one or more, on such terms and for such compensation as they may determine. The duties of said officers shall be determined by this charter and the ordinances made and adopted by the authority of the same. And that they may require of said officers such bonds for faithful performance of their respective duties as they may deem necessary. Mayor pro tem., clerk and treasurer. Police force.

Sec. 27. Be it further enacted, That the mayor, or in his absence the mayor pro tem., shall be the chief executive officer of said city. He shall see that the laws and ordinances of the city are executed. He shall have power to convene the council at any time, to preside over its meetings, but shall not vote except in case of a tie. It shall be his duty, or in his absence, the duty of the mayor pro tem., to hold the mayor's court as often as may be necessary for the speedy trial of such persons as may be brought before him. He shall have the powers of a justice of the peace as to the commitment of violators of the State laws. Mayor, powers.

Sec. 28. Be it further enacted, That the salary of the mayor shall be fixed at the last meeting of the mayor and council for the next official year at a sum of not less than one hundred dollars and not more than two hundred dollars. That mayor and council may pay their clerk of council and treasurer any amount not to exceed fifty dollars per year each for their services. Compensation.

Sec. 29. Be it further enacted, That the mayor of said city, or in his absence the mayor pro tem., shall hold a mayor's court at such time as he may deem necessary for the speedy trial of all persons charged with violations of the rules, regulations, and ordinances prescribed for the government of said city. And may punish violators of the same by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars, imprisonment not to exceed sixty days, by work on streets of said city not to exceed sixty days. And any one or more of said punishments may be ordered at the discretion of said mayor. When sitting as a court, said mayor may fine for contempt not exceeding twenty-five dollars, or twenty-five days imprisonment or twenty-five days at work on streets of said city. He shall have authority to issue subp[oelig]nas for witnesses and compel their attendance. From the discretion of said mayor or said mayor's court imposing punishments or penalties for violations of such rules, regulations, or ordinances of said city there shall be no appeal, except by certiorari to the superior court of said county. Mayor's court. Powers of mayor. Certiorari.

Sec. 30. Be it further enacted, That the mayor of said city, the consent of the council being first had and obtained, may commute, suspend, or remit any fine or other penalty he may have imposed when he believes that the ends of justice require it. Mayor, power to remit penalties.

Sec. 31. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council may establish a chaingang for said city for the purpose of working those persons convicted and sentenced by the mayor's court, to work on the streets of said city. And shall have the power to establish suitable rules and regulations for the conduct of same. Chaingang.

Sec. 32. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have the power to take up and impound any horses, mules, cows, hogs or other animals and fowls running at large in said city and to make and enforce all ordinances which they may deem necessary for the proper regulation and control of said animals and fowls in said city. Stock pound.

Sec. 33. Be it further enacted, That the taxpayers of said city shall be required to make return of all their real and personal property to the clerk of the city council on such day as the mayor and council may by ordinance direct. That in the event the said clerk should consider the return of any taxpayer either too low or too high it shall become his duty to assess the property in said return at its true market value and give notice to the taxpayer of said assessment. Should said assessment be unsatisfactory to the taxpayer he may in writing
enter an appeal to the mayor and council and they shall appoint a time to try said appeal and assess the property of the return at its true market value, and their decision and their assessment shall be final. Should any taxpayer fail or refuse to make return of his property, it shall be the duty of the clerk to assess his property and double-tax the same without notice. Said taxpayer may, however, enter an appeal from said assessment and be heard by said mayor and council as other taxpayers. Tax returns and assessments.

Sec. 34. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of the chief of police of said city to collect the city tax, fines, levies, and assessments, and in case the same is not paid within thirty days after they are placed in his hands for collection, the mayor and clerk of council shall issue executions therefor. That all taxes, assessments, fines and penalties recoverable by this Act may be enforced by execution. That all writs, processes and subp[oelig]nas issued in behalf of said city shall be directed to the chief of police of said city and signed as executions. All executions issued in behalf of said city for the collection of any tax, fines, forfeitures, or other purposes shall be directed to the chief of police and signed by the mayor, or mayor pro tem. and clerk of council. And all sales of personal property by said chief of police shall be advertised in three public places in said city for ten days before the sale; if real estate, he shall advertise the same for four weeks in a public gazette of said city if any, if none, in that publishing notice of sheriff's sales for county of Walton, and shall sell the same before the city hall in said city, make and execute titles thereto. Should an illegality of claim be interposed, said chief of police shall not sell but return the same in case of personal property to the justice court of the district in which said city is situated unless the amount exceeds the jurisdiction of said court; in that event, or when claim or illegality be interposed to sale of real estate, the same shall be returned to the superior court of Walton county and tried as other claims and illegalities in said court. Taxes, fines, etc., collected by execution. Writs, processes, etc., how directed and signed Sales. Illegalities and claims.

Sec. 35. Be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for chief of police of said city, any regular or special policeman thereto, to arrest without warrant any and all persons within the limits of said city, who, at or before said arrest, has been guilty of the violation of any of the rules, regulations, or ordinances of said city, and to hold said person until a hearing of the matter before the proper court can be had, and to this end may imprison said person in the city guard-house for a reasonable
length of time. Said chief of police shall have the authority, as well as the regular or special police, to call to his assistance for the arrest of such offenders any citizen of said city or by-standers, and such person, when so summoned, shall be bound to assist and aid said officer, and should they fail or refuse to do so, shall be prosecuted in mayor's court and, on conviction, punished as may be by ordinance provided in such cases. Arrests

Sec. 36. Be it further enacted, That the chief of police, regular or special policeman, shall have the authority, at his discretion, to release any person arrested in said city for a violation of any rule. regulation, or ordinance of said city upon said person giving bond with good security, payable to the city of Social Circle, conditioned to pay the said city and amount named in said bond in the event said person does not appear before the corporate authorities of the city at the time and place specified in the bond, and from time to time until tried for the offence for which said person was arrested. Appearance bonds.

Sec. 37. Be it further enacted, That when a bond has been given for an appearance before the mayor's court and the person fails to appear at the time and place fixed in said bond, said bond shall be declared forfeited and a rule nisi directed to the principal and securities shall issue requiring them to show cause before the mayor's court to be held not less than thirty days from the time of the forfeiting nisi why the bond should not be forfeited, copies of which rule nisi shall be served upon the principal and securities at least twenty days before the sitting of the court to which it is made returnable, either personally or by leaving a copy at the most notorious place of abode of the person sought to be served. If at such return term, no sufficient cause to be shown to the contrary, the forfeiture shall be made final and absolute, the execution shall issue against principal and securities on said bond, or such of them as have been served, for the full amount thereof and all costs, which execution shall be signed by the clerk of council and mayor or mayor pro tem. of said city; and shall have same lien upon property of defendant as execution issued upon judgments in justice and superior courts of this State. Said execution shall be directed to the chief of police of said city and to all and singular the sheriffs and constables of said State by any one of whom the same may be executed. Forfeiture of.

Sec. 38. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council
have the authority to contract debts, issue bonds of said city, under and in accordance with the limitations provided in the Constitution and laws of the State applicable to municipalities, and with funds arising from the sale of said bonds, establish and maintain a system of water-works, a system of lights, erect public buildings, or make other improvements of necessity or convenience of the citizens of said city. Contracts and bonds for public improvements.

Sec. 39. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council may grant to individuals or corporations the use of the streets, alleys and commons of said city, for the maintenance in said city of gas-works, electric or other lighting plants, waterworks, and street railways, under such rules, regulations, and restrictions as they may deem proper; and may contract with such persons for furnishing to said city light and water, and may by ordinance limit the rate to other consumers in said city. Mayor and council shall at all times have exclusive jurisdiction over said plants and regulate their operation, and impose on the owners such duties, obligations and liabilities as they may deem just and reasonable for the protection of the citizens and municipal government. Lightin plants, water-works and street rail ways.

Sec. 40. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have the power to declare what shall be a nuisance and to abate the same, and to provide punishment for those who may create or suffer nuisances to exist, to prevent the establishment of any unwholesome or offensive business or establishment in said city; to compel the owner of any cellar, stable, pig-sty, privy or any other unwholesome or nauseous house or place to cleanse, abate or remove the same, and to regulate the locations thereof; to prevent the storage or keeping for any illegal purpose within the limits of said city wine, beer, malt, alcoholic, or intoxicating liquors of any kind, and to punish any persons for violating said laws or ordinances relating thereto. Nuisances. Intoxicating liquors, storage and keeping of.

Sec. 41. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have power to summarily and forcibly remove at any time and without notice to any one, and all obstructions of any character whatever from the streets, sidewalks, alleys and commons of said city. They shall have power to prevent tramps, street-walkers, vagrants, loiterers, idle peddlers, lewd females, and beggars from walking or occupying the streets and sidewalks of said city, and may punish them by any punishment authorized by this Act for violating any ordinance relating thereto. And when it shall appear to said mayor that any room, house, building or cellar in said city is being used as a
house of ill-fame, as a residence of a lewd woman, as a place where liquors are sold in violation of law, or when gambling or other immoral, or illegal or disorderly practices are carried on may order the police of said city to enter said places by force, if necessary, and arrest the occupants thereof and bring them before the said mayor to be dealt with according to law. Said mayor and council shall have the power to regulate traffic and sales on the streets and public places in said city; and to regulate the speed of animals and vehicles of locomotion; to establish and to fix fire limits in said city; to regulate and to prescribe buildings, and provide by ordinance the enforcement of same. Mayor and council powers.

Sec. 42. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have authority to employ and pay detectives when they deem necessary; that they have authority to offer and pay rewards for detection, prosecution and conviction of persons committing within said city crimes against either the laws of the State of Georgia or said city. Detectives and rewards.

Sec. 43. Be it further enacted, That when any vacancy shall occur from any cause in the office of mayor or in the council, the vacancies shall be filled by appointment by mayor and council, or council, in case of vacancy in mayor's office, from any among the citizens of said city eligible under the charter. Mayor and council, vacancies in offices of.

Sec. 44. Be it further enacted, That to carry in effect the provisions of this Act, or any further Act amendatory, and for the preservation of the health, peace, good order, temperance, and morality of said city, the said mayor and council shall have authority to make and pass all needful by-laws, ordinances, rules and regulations not contrary to the Constitution and laws of this State. Legislative powers.
Sec. 45. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act, be and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: STATESBORO, CITY OF, ACT INCORPORATING AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the city of Statesboro, approved December 6, 1902, by striking from the fifth line of section 3 of said Act the words, one per cent. of, and inserting in lieu thereof the words, two and one-half mills on, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That from and after the date of the passage of this Act, section 53, line 5, of an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the city of Statesboro, approved December 6, 1902, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from said line of said section, the words one per cent. of, and inserting in lieu thereof the words two and one-half mills on, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council of said city of Statesboro are hereby authorized to levy and collect an annual tax upon all the property, real and personal, in addition to that now authorized by law, not to exceed two and one-half mills on the taxable property of said city, as shown by the regular tax digest of property prepared for the purpose of city taxation, for the purpose of supporting the schools of said city, upon first complying with the following regulations, to wit: Before any school shall be supported at the expense of the city, the mayor, upon a recommendation by the board of trustees of the schools of said city, shall advertise an election in the official gazette of Bulloch county, once a week for four weeks, to be held at the court-house in said city, at which election all persons qualified to vote for mayor and council in said city shall be qualified to vote; said election to be conducted in all particulars as now provided by law for elections in said city. The elector at said election shall endorse on his ballot For Tax, or Against Tax, and if two-thirds of the qualified voters be For Tax, then and in that event said corporate authorities shall levy the tax prescribed in this section for the support of schools of said city. In the event the schools of said city are thus supported, the amount paid to the white schools shall be the pro rata part of the tax paid by the white taxpayers of said city, and the amount paid to the colored schools shall be the pro rata
part of said tax paid by the colored taxpayers of said city, as shown by the tax digest of the city. Statesboro, publicschools, tax for. Election for tax.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: STATHAM, TOWN OF, ACT INCORPORATING AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to incorporate the town of Statham, in Jackson county, approved December 5, 1902, so as to authorize the mayor and council of the town of Statham to issue bonds for the purpose of purchasing, building and equipping a school building in the town of Statham, and to authorize the said mayor and council to provide for the payment of the principal and interest of said bonds by levying a tax therefor and to provide for an election to ratify the provisions of this Act, and to extend the limits of said town one mile in all directions from the center of the waiting-room of the depot, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the mayor and council of the town of Statham be, and they are hereby authorized and empowered to issue bonds of said town for the sum of five thousand dollars, of not less than the denomination of one hundred dollars each, to become due and payable at such time or time or times not exceeding thirty years from date of issue thereof, as said mayor and council shall determine, and bear interest not to exceed six per cent. per annum, said bonds to be issued, sold and hypothecated for the purpose of purchasing, building and equipping school building in said town. Statham, school buildings, bonds for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council of the said town are hereby authorized and empowered to levy, assess and collect annually, sufficient tax upon and from the taxable property in said town, real and personal, to pay the principal and interest of said bonds as they shall become due, and also a sufficient amount for a sinking
fund with which to pay off said bonds. This tax shall be separately levied, assessed, and collected, for the specific purpose herein designated, and shall not be used for or applied to any other purpose whatever. Said mayor and council are hereby authorized and empowered to issue interest coupons, payable annually, for the interest on said bonds. Tax to pay bonds.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said bonds shall be signed by the mayor and clerk of the council of said town, and negotiated, sold and hypothecated in such manner and in such sums, and at such times as the mayor and council shall determine for the best interest of said town, and the speedy execution of the objects of this Act; and the money arising from the sale of said bonds shall be used by said mayor and council in building, purchasing and equipping suitable school buildings in said town, upon such terms and in such locality as may be properly selected and procured for said purpose. Bonds, proceeds of sale, how used.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the provisions of this Act shall not go into effect and become operative until the question of issuing said bonds shall have been submitted to a vote of the qualified voters of said town under rules and regulations adopted by the mayor and council of said town and approved by a two thirds vote of the persons qualified to vote at an election held for that purpose in accordance with the Constitution of this State, which election shall be held under an order of the mayor of said town, and shall be advertised for thirty days immediately preceding such election at the city hall in said town and in the newspaper published in Jackson county in which the sheriff's advertisements are published; the ballots to be cast in said election shall have written or printed on them for bonds and against bonds. If the question submitted at said election shall be decided affirmatively, in accordance with the terms of this Act, it shall be the duty of the corporate authorities of said town to issue and dispose of said bonds in accordance with the various sections of this Act in relation thereto, but should the question be decided negatively at such an election, the effect shall be only to suspend the various sections of this Act in relation thereto. Election for bonds.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if at said election, or any future election held under section 4 of this Act, the question voted on shall be decided against issuing said bonds, it shall be the duty of the mayor of said town, upon the written application of twenty-five qualified
voters of said town, to order another election, which shall be held as required by this Act.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That any election held under this Act shall be governed by the same rules and regulations as the elections for mayor and council of the town of Statham. Elections, rules to govern of.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the corporate limits of said town shall from and after the passage of this Act be as follows: Beginning at the center of the waiting-room of the Seaboard Air Line depot and extending one mile in all directions. Corporate limits
Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: STILLMORE, TOWN OF, ACT INCORPORATING, AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Stillmore, in the county of Emanuel, and for other purposes connected therewith, found in Acts of 1889, page 1079, and approved November 13, 1889; to provide for working offenders of said town law on the streets of said town in default of payment of fine imposed.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, section 5 of the Act creating the town of Stillmore, Acts of 1889, page 1079, approved November 13, 1889, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By striking from said section the word or between the words fine and imprisonment in the sixth line of said section, and inserting in lieu thereof a , and by adding to said section and between said word imprisonment and the word and in the sixth line of said section, the words or to work upon the streets of said town, in the discretion of the mayor, not to exceed thirty days. So that said section when amended shall read as follows: Section 5. Be it further enacted, That said board of mayor and aldermen shall have full power
and authority to alter the rules and regulations herein prescribed for the management of elections; to pass all ordinances and bylaws for the government of said town not to conflict with the laws of this State, or of the United States, and to enforce the same by execution, by fine, imprisonment, or to work upon the streets of said town, in the discretion of the mayor, not to exceed thirty days, and may sentence in the alternation; said board may provide for the trial of cases and offenders before the mayor, and for an appeal from his decision to a full board, or a majority of them. Stillmore, mayor and aldermen, punitive powers.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SUMMERVILLE, BOARD OF HEALTH FOR, CREATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for the creation of a board of health for the village of Summerville, in Richmond county, Georgia, and to prescribe its powers, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the village of Summerville, in Richmond county, Georgia, may, from time to time, by ordinance, provide for the creation of a board of health, and may also, at its discretion, abolish said board or re-create it. Summerville, board of health for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That any board of health, which may be created under the terms of this Act, shall consist of three persons, one of whom shall be one of the commissioners of the village of Summerville, and one a doctor of medicine, fully qualified under the laws of the State and the village of Summerville to practice medicine in said village; the other a freeholder, resident in said village. The three members shall be elected by the commissioners of said village. Members.

Sec. 3. The members of such board of health shall hold office for such terms as the ordinance of the village creating the same shall provide. Such member of the board as is also a commissioner of the village shall receive no compensation. The medical member of the board may be paid a compensation not to exceed three hundred dollars per annum. Terms of office and compensation.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the board thus created and chosen, or a majority of it, shall have the power and authority to prescribe all reasonable rules and regulations for the preservation of the health of the residents of the village of Summerville and to prevent the spread of contagious diseases therein; and the rules and regulations of such board of health shall be published in the same manner as prescribed for the publication of ordinances of the village of Summerville, and when so promulgated and published, shall have the same binding effect as the ordinances of the village of Summerville, and the violation of such rules and regulations of the board of health shall be punished in such manner as the board of commissioners may from time to time by ordinance prescribe. Powers.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SYLVESTER, TOWN OF, ACT INCORPORATING REPEALED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act approved December 21, 1898, entitled, an Act to incorporate the town of Sylvester, in the county of Worth, and to define its limits; to provide for a mayor and council, and other officers of the said town, and to prescribe their powers and duties; to provide for all matters of municipal concern and cognizance, and for other purposes, to repeal all Acts amendatory thereof heretofore passed, and all Acts constituting the present charter of the town of Sylvester, Worth county, Georgia, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That an Act approved December 21, 1898 (Acts of 1898, page 269) entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Sylvester, in the county of Worth, and to define its limits; to provide for a mayor and council and other officers of the said town, and to prescribe their powers and duties; to provide for all matters of municipal concern and cognizance, and for other purposes, and all Acts amendatory thereof be, and the same are, [Illegible Text] [Illegible Text] Sylvester, town of, act incorporating repealed.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That this Act shall go into effect immediately upon the passage and approval of an Act creating and establishing the city of Sylvester. Act to take effect upon approval.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: SYLVESTER, CITY OF, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate and create the city of Sylvester, in the county of Worth, and prescribe the limits thereof; to provide for a mayor and councilmen and other officers of the said city, and prescribe their powers and duties and the manner of their election; to declare and define the police powers of the said corporation, and provide for all matters of municipal concern and cognizance; to provide that all valid legal contracts heretofore entered into by the authorities of the town of Sylvester shall be good and valid for and against the city of Sylvester; to provide that the city of Sylvester succeed to all of the rights and liabilities of the town of Sylvester, and that all property now held and owned by the town of Sylvester shall be and become the right and property of the city of Sylvester; to provide for the erection and maintenance of a system of waterworks, sewerage, electric lights and such other public improvements as the authorities may see proper to establish from time to time and to authorize taxation and the issue of bonds for any and all of said purposes; to provide for the condemnation of private property for public use, and for compensating the owners thereof; to continue the present school system of the town of Sylvester, and establish the same as the school system of the said city, and provide for the maintenance of the same; to provide for ad valorem and special taxation; to create the city of Sylvester, and grant a charter to that municipality to create the city of Sylvester, and grant a charter to that municipality under that corporate name and style, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the
State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the municipality heretofore known and designated as the town of Sylvester, in the county of Worth, said State, the location and limits of same being hereinafter fully set forth, be, and the same is, hereby created one of the cities of the said State, and the same is, hereby created and constituted a body corporate under the name and style of the city of Sylvester, under which it shall have perpetual succession, the municipal government thereof being hereby vested in a mayor and four councilmen, to be elected as herinafter provided, who shall constitute the said body corporate. Sylvester, city of, incorporated.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said body corporate, under the name and style of the city of Sylvester, shall have a common seal, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in any court of law or equity, and do any and all other acts and exercise any and all other rights and powers necessary and proper in the course of the government and affairs of the said municipality not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the said State. Corporate powers.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said corporate body, under the name and style of the city of Sylvester, shall have the right and power to purchase, acquire, lease, receive, hold and enjoy for the use and benefit of the said city, any real, personal or other property necessary and proper for any of the purposes of the said city; and shall also have the right and power to sell, convey, lease, transfer and assign any and all the property of the said city whenever it is deemed necessary and proper to do so; and all rights, titles, properties, easement, hereditaments and all and every thing now belonging to or in any wise appertaining to the present corporation of the town of Sylvester shall succeed to and become the property of the city of Sylvester, created by this Act. Said city of Sylvester, created by this Act, is hereby made responsible for all legal debts, liabilities, contracts and undertakings of every kind of the said town of Sylvester. Corporate powers. Town of Sylvester, obligations of city liable for.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the corporate limits of the said city of Sylvester, over which the authorities of the said city shall have and are hereby given jurisdiction for all purposes under and by virtue of this Act, and the general laws of this State, shall be, and the same are, hereby fixed as follows, to wit: Over and including all of lots of land numbers three hundred and fifty-eight (358) and three hundred
and thirty-three (333) both in the seventh (7th) land district of Worth county, Georgia, each containing four hundred and ninety (490) acres more or less, the entire original lines of the said lots to be the corporate limits of the said city. The mayor and council of the said city shall have, and they are, hereby granted, authority to fix and prescribe by ordinance the official survey and plat of the said city, and have the same recorded as such; and they may alter or change the same from time to time as they see proper. Corporate limits.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the government and legislative power of the said city of Sylvester shall be, and the same is, hereby vested in the mayor and four councilmen, who are hereby given full authority to enact and enforce in the manner hereinafter provided, all laws, by-laws, ordinances, rules and regulations necessary and proper, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State, for the government of the said city which shall be binding on themselves and the other officers of the said city. All citizens thereof and the public generally. All laws, by-laws, ordinances, rules and regulations enacted and passed by the mayor and council of the said city, and all orders and acts of the same, shall become effective and of force as soon as the same shall be placed upon the minutes thereof, unless otherwise provided in the face thereof by the mayor and council. The said mayor and council shall have authority to prepare and publish in book or pamphlet form, a Code of laws, by-laws, ordinances, orders, rules and regulations for the government of the said city, the same to become effective and of force so soon as approved and adopted by them by order on their minutes, which Code may be amended and revised by them from time to time as they see proper. In the meantime and until otherwise provided by the mayor and council of the said city of Sylvester, the Code and all laws, by-laws, orders, rules, regulations and Acts of the present town of Sylvester shall be, and the same are, hereby declared to be of force for and in the city of Sylvester, created by this Act. Mayor and councilmen. Legislative powers. Laws to take effect, when. Code of laws.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the present mayor and councilmen and all other officers of the town of Sylvester continue in office, and they are hereby declared to be the officers of the city created by this Act, to serve until the expiration of their respective terms and until their successors are elected and qualified. The election for officers of the said town shall be held annually on the first Wednesday in January
of each year, by three freeholders of the said city, the same to be conducted in the same manner as elections for members of the General Assembly of Georgia; the polls shall be opened at some convenient place in the said town to be designated by the mayor and council at 10 o'clock A. M. and shall be closed at 3 o'clock P. M.; the managers shall before proceeding to hold said election, take and subscribe the following oath, to wit: All and each of us do solemnly swear that we will faithfully superintend this day's election; that we will make a true return thereof; that we will not knowingly permit any one to vote who is not entitled to do so, nor knowingly prevent any one from voting who is entitled to do so; that we will not divulge for whom any vote was cast unless called upon in some court of law to do so; so help us, God, which oath may be taken before any officer authorized by law to administer oaths or the managers may swear each other; the managers shall certify the result of the election to the acting mayor and council, which certificate shall be filed with the clerk of the city council, together with one of the tally-sheets and one of the voters' lists, each duly signed by the managers, and the ballot-box duly sealed, and the returns thus made shall remain of file in the clerk's office of the city council until noon of the following day, and, if no notice of contest is filed with said clerk by that time, he shall proceed without delay to record the certificate of the result of the said election upon the minutes of the council, and shall issue and deliver to each officer-elect a certificate of his election, showing to what office he has been elected and this certificate shall be sufficient authority to the person so elected to enter upon the discharge of his duties as such officers; at any time before noon of the day following the day of the election, any candidate appearing to have been defeated may institute a contest of the said election, and claim the office for which he was a candidate, by giving notice to the clerk of the city council, and serving a copy of same upon the candidate appearing to have been elected, proceeding in this and otherwise in the same manner as provided by sections 107 to 109, inclusive, of the Code of this State, volume 1, the same to be finally determined by the judge of the superior court of Worth county as therein provided. The mayor and four councilmen shall be elected by the qualified voters of the said city, at the annual election above provided for. The mayor shall serve for a term of one year from the date of his election, and until his successor shall be elected and qualified, the successor of the present incumbent to be elected
at the regular election on the first Wednesday in January, 1905. Two of the councilmen shall be elected for a term of two years from the date of their election at the regular election on the first Wednesday in January, 1905, to succeed the present incumbent, whose terms expire on that date; and the other two councilmen for a term of two years from the date of their election at the regular election in January, 1906, to succeed the present incumbents, whose terms expire on that date, and so on thereafter, two being elected at each annual election for a term of two years, and until their successors are elected and qualified. Mayor and councilmen. Election or. Contest. Mayor and councilmen, terms of office.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person shall be eligible to the office of mayor or council of the said city who is not a qualified voter therein, and who has not been a bona fide resident of the said city for at least one year prior to his election. Eligibility.

Sec. 8.
