Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person shall be qualified to vote at any election held in the said city under and by virute of this charter that is not qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly of Georgia under existing laws at the time of the election and who has not been a bona fide citizen of the said city for six months next preceding the election, and who has not paid all taxes imposed upon him by the authorities of the said city, and who has not registered and been entered on the voters' list of the said city as hereinafter required. Electors.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case of a vacancy in the office of mayor and councilmen an election shall be called to fill the vacancy by a majority of the remaining council or by the clerk of the council, of which election ten days' notice shall be given by posting notice of same in three conspicuous places in the said city, the order calling the same to be entered on the minutes of the council; the voters' list prepared for the last annual election next preceding such special election to be used at such special election. In case of a vacancy in the office of mayor, the mayor pro tem. shall perform all of the duties and exercise all of the powers of the mayor until the vacancy is filled as above provided. Vacancies.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That at the first meeting of the mayor and council after each annual election, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the mayor and council shall elect a clerk of council, treasurer, marshal, chief of police, a board of three tax-assessors and such other officers
as they may deem necessary and proper, they being empowered to create from time to time any office, board, committee or commission they may deem necessary and proper, and to regulate the time and mode of the election of persons to any and all of the said positions; to fix their qualifications, prescribe their oaths, take bonds, prescribe their duties and fix their salaries and fees, and to remove them from office or any position which they may hold for neglect of duty or other sufficient cause, at their discretion, they to have general supervision and control over the same at all times. Municipal officers, mayor and council to elect.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall be the duty of the clerk of the council of the said city to open a registration book or books at his office for the purpose of registering the qualified voters of the said city twenty days before each regular annual election for officers of the said city, on the first page of which book or books there shall be printed or written the following oath, to wit: I do swear or affirm that I am a citizen of the United States; that I am twenty-one years of age, or will be on or before the date of the next election to be held in the city of Sylvester, for which election I am now registering; that I have resided in this State for one year, and in the city of Sylvester for six months immediately preceding the date of this oath, or will have so resided on or before the date of the next election to be held in the said city, for which election I am now registering; that I have paid all State and county taxes required of me since the adoption of the Constitution of the State of Georgia of 1877, except taxes for this year, and all taxes required of me by the city of Sylvester up to the date of taking this oath; that I am not disfranchised from voting by reason of any offense committed against the laws of this State, and I further swear or affirm that my age, occupation, residence, street and number and all other information stated opposite my name below is true as stated; so help me, God, which oath shall be taken by each person registering in said book or books, the said book or books to be kept open at the said office during business hours for a period of fifteen days, at the expiration of which time they shall close, and it shall be legal to enter the name of any voter on the list who registered after the books close. After the books close, it shall be the duty of the mayor and council to meet and make up the voters' list for the election for which such registration is taken, a majority of the mayor and council constituting a quorum for this purpose, no candidate being qualified to act and, in the
event there are not three of said body who are not candidates, those who are qualified may select one or more of the freeholders of the said city who are not candidates for any office, in the place of those disqualified, and thus make up a quorum. It shall be the duty of this body to go carefully through the list of registered voters, and satisfy themselves as to the qualification of each and every voter whose name appears on the registration books, and they shall not enter the name of any voter upon the voters' list until they are thoroughly satisfied that he is qualified in every way to vote. If the name of any person appears on the registration books whose qualification as a voter is questioned by the said body, it shall be their duty to notify such person in writing of the time and place of hearing on the question of his qualification as a voter, which notice may be served by the marshal or any person appointed by the said body, by handing the same to such person, or by leaving the same at his place of residence entered opposite his name in the registration book, or by leaving same at his most notorious place of abode, at least the day before the hearing is to be had the next day. The said body shall, in their investigation as to the qualification of voters, have access to the records of the county and city, and shall have power to require the production of books, papers and other documentary evidence instanter, by subp[oelig]na duces tecum or notice to produce, and shall have power to subp[oelig]na and require the attendance of witnesses and hear and consider oral testimony, all subpoenas, notices and other process to be issued and signed by the clerk of the city council and bear test in the name of any member of the said body; and the said body, or any member thereof who shall be presiding at the time, shall have and is hereby granted power to punish for non-attendance, failure to comply with orders and processes of the said body and for contempt, the same as to the same extend and in the same manner as justices of the peace may, with reference to their courts, under the laws of this State. The said body is hereby granted power and authority to pass upon the qualification of any and all voters, being guided by the charter and laws of the said city, and by the laws of the State, and to make up and certify the list of qualified voters of the said city; and it shall be the duty of the said body to prepare and certify an alphabetical list of the qualified voters of the said city, and place the same, or a copy of same, in the hands of the managers of the election, at or before the time fixed for the polls to open which list shall be followed by the managers, no person
to be allowed to vote whose name does not appear thereupon. In the event any should be allowed to vote whose name does not appear upon said voters' list, by mistake or otherwise and the same be discovered before the final count, such vote shall not be counted by the managers. At all special elections held in the said city for any purpose, the voters' list made up as above provided, for the last annual election, preceding such special election, shall be used, and only those whose names appear thereupon shall be allowed to vote, unless otherwise provided by the general law of this State. Registration of voters. Registration lists, how made up.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That before receiving their certificates of election and entering upon the discharge of their duties, the persons elected to the offices of mayor and councilmen shall take and subscribe before some officer authorized by the laws of this State to administer oaths, the following oath: I, , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will well and truly perform the duties of mayor (or councilman, as the case may be) of the city of Sylvester; that I will not vote for or adopt any measure that is not in my judgment, to the best interest and for the general welfare of the citizens of the said city; so help me, God, which oath shall be filed with the clerk of the city council and recorded upon his minutes. Official oath.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council, as hereinbefore provided, shall constitute the legislative department of the city government the mayor shall be the presiding officer of the said body, and shall be the chief executive officer of the said city; it shall be the duty of the mayor to see that the laws of the State of Georgia, and the laws and ordinances of the said city, and the by-laws, rules, resolutions, orders, and all other enactments of the body over which he presides, are faithfully and strictly executed and enforced throughout the territory over which they have jurisdiction, and to the full extent of their power; it shall be his duty to supervise the work of all subordinate officers, committees, and all other persons connected in any way with the city government, and to report any failure, neglect or misconduct on the part of any one of them to the body over which he presides; he shall audit and approve all accounts against the said city, and no money shall be paid out of the treasury of the said city except upon warrant of the mayor, countersigned by the clerk of council, except as herein otherwise provided; and the mayor shall not draw his warrant upon the
treasurer for any purpose, except when and for the purposes authorized by the body over which he presides by general or special ordinance, resolution or order entered upon the minutes; he shall keep the said legislative body advised from time to time of the general condition of the said city, and shall recommend the enactment of such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient; the said body shall fix its own time of meeting, and shall meet at least once a month, and when the time of meeting is changed, which may be done at any time, notice of such change shall be published in one issue of a newspaper published in said city, or be posted in two conspicuous places therein, the mayor may call a special meeting of the said body at any time he may deem it necessary for any purpose; a majority of the five constituting the said body shall constitute a quorum; no measure shall become of force unless voted for by at least two of the councilmen and approved by the mayor, or other officer presiding; provided, that, in the event the mayor or other officer presiding shall decline to approve, or veto any measure, the same shall be reconsidered, but shall not become of force until approved by three of the councilmen, in writing; in addition to the foregoing express powers, the said body is hereby granted full power and authority to do any and all other acts and things as may be or become necessary and proper for the government and general welfare of the said city, not inconsistent with the laws of this State; it shall be the duty of the said body, at their first meeting after each annual election, or as soon thereafter as practicable, to elect one of their number to act as mayor pro tem., who may exercise the same authority in all matters as is given the mayor, and shall perform all of the duties of the mayor, whenever the mayor, for any reason, can not, or will not, act; if at any time both the mayor and mayor pro tem. are absent, or cannot, or will not act for any reason, any one of the councilmen may act with the same authority and perform all of the duties of the mayor; the officer presiding over the said body shall have, and is hereby granted, authority and power to keep order at all meetings of the said body, and to punish any person for contempt by fine, not to exceed twenty-five dollars, by imprisonment in the city jail not to exceed two days, or by compulsory work upon the streets of the said city not to exceed five days. Mayor, executive powers. Mayor and council, sessions. Measures. General welfare. Mayor pro [Illegible Text]. Contempts of council.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the salary of the mayor shall be fixed by any three members of the council, the same not to be changed during his term of office; the
councilmen shall receive no compensation for their services, but shall be exempt from street tax and street duty. Mayor, compensation. Councilmen, exemptions.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That should the mayor, or any member of the council, be guilty of malpractice, wilful neglect of duty, gross and wilful abuse of the powers entrusted to them, or for any reason become incompetent or unfit to fill such office, in the judgment of any three members of the council, they, the three members of council jointly, may bring a rule against such offending officer setting up the charges against him before the judge of the superior court of Worth county, who shall issue a rule nisi thereupon, requiring the said offending officer named therein to appear and show cause before him, at such time and place as he may therein designate, and require the same to be served upon the said officer by handing a copy of the petition and rule nisi to him in person, or by leaving a copy at his most notorious place of abode, at least three days before the hearing, and the said judge is hereby granted power and authority to hear testimony and pass upon the said rule, and may, in his judgment, remove the officer therein charged and declare the office vacant, and his judgment shall be final. Malpractice in office.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council of the said city shall, at their first meeting after each annual election, or as soon thereafter as practicable, designate and appoint, by order on their minutes, the clerk of the council, or some other fit and proper person to receive the tax returns of the said city, who shall enter upon the discharge of his duties immediately upon his appointment; it shall be the duty of such receiver to prepare and furnish from his office, when called for blanks for the return of taxes, the said blanks to be prepared according to the laws of this State, and the ordinances of the said city, and to be approved by the mayor and council; the said receiver shall serve for a term of one year, and until his successor is qualified; provided, that the mayor and council shall have the right to remove such person and appoint another in his place at any time in their discretion; the mayor and council shall, at the time of his appointment, fix his compensation for the entire service to be performed by him during his term. It shall be the duty of persons owning property, franchises, or anything else subject to taxation by the State and county, or that may at any time be made subject to taxation by the same, to return the same for taxation to the said receiver, returning all they own or may be interested in, directly or indirectly, or that they may represent
in any capacity, within the limits of the said city on the first day of March of the year in which such return is made, the same to be made and filed with the said receiver between the dates of March the first and June the first of each year, the time for making returns to expire on the first day of June of each year, all of which returns shall at once thereafter be delivered and turned over by the said receiver to the board of tax-assessors hereinafter provided for, at their first meeting in June of each year, the mayor and council shall appoint, by order on their minutes, three freeholders of the said city, who have resided therein at least two years prior to their appointment, who shall constitute a board of tax-assessors for the said city, whose duty it shall be to go over and carefully consider the tax returns delivered to them by the receiver, as above provided, and it shall be their duty, and they are hereby granted power, to assess and fix a just and equitable valuation on all property and other things returnable for taxation, as above provided, and to enter the valuation fixed by them opposite the return on said blanks; they shall also fill out blanks and enter a return of all property subject to taxation within the limits of said city that has not been returned that may come to their knowledge, marking the same unreturned and fixing a valuation thereupon, it being their especial duty to be diligent in their effort to see that all property subject to taxation has been returned; the valuation placed on property by this board shall be final, and the same shall be taxed accordingly. The receiver above provided for shall act as clerk of this board, and when their work of assessing said property has been finished, the said clerk shall proceed to make out a tax digest for the said city similar to that made out by the tax-receiver of the county, entering the valuations fixed by the board of assessors, and shall file the said digest with the clerk of the council not later than July the first of each year. It shall be the duty of the mayor and council to meet not later than September the first of each year, and to consider the amount of money needed by the said city to defray all expenses of the said city, liquidate its debts, meet all appropriations and obligations of every kind, and for any and all other legitimate purposes, up to the time of collecting taxes for the next ensuing year, and to fix by order on their minutes the aggregate amount thereof, and in the same way to levy and fix a rate of taxation upon all of the property appearing upon the tax digest made out for the year in which such levy is made, as above provided, sufficient to raise the amount needed as above determined, all of which the said mayor and council are hereby empowered to do, and all of the property
entered upon the said tax digest, in the manner above provided, being hereby made subject to taxation by the said city for any and all necessary purposes; it shall then be the duty of the clerk of council to make out a correct schedule showing the amount of taxes due by each party making return, the amount to be doubled in case no return is made, and to make a record of same, either upon the tax digest or a book to be kept for that purpose; all taxes shall be due and payable from October the first to December the twentieth of each year, the time for collecting taxes to expire on the twentieth day of December of each year; it shall be the duty of the marshal, or his deputy, or deputies, to collect all taxes and receipt for same, and, after the time expires for collecting taxes, as above provided, to immediately report to the clerk of council all who have failed to pay; and it shall be the duty of the said clerk to, without delay, issue an execution for the said amount due by each party making return, and upon all property unreturned, whether the owner is known or unknown, in the same manner as executions are issued by the tax-collectors of this State, and deliver the said executions to the marshal of the said city, and the same may be directed to, and may be levied by the marshal of the said city, or his deputy, or by any sheriff or constable of this State, the same to be enforced by sale in the same manner and under the same rules and regulations as sheriff's sales under tax executions for State and county taxes under the laws of this State. The mayor and council is hereby granted power to fix the salary and fees of any and all of the said officers and persons above mentioned; to fix the time and terms of payment; to prescribe their oaths, fix the amount and conditions of and require them to give bonds; enact rules and regulations for their government and guidance, not inconsistent with this charter; to remove any of those appointed by them at will, and appoint others in their places, and to do any and all other acts necessary in the premises. The power of the mayor and council with reference to taxation shall only be limited by the Constitution and general laws of this State. The mayor and council shall, in addition to the ad valorem tax above provided for, and they are hereby granted power to assess, levy and collect a specific or occupation tax on all businesses, occupations, callings, trades, etc., carried on or exercised in the said city; to fix the time of collecting same, and to provide a method of collecting and enforcing same. Tax-receiver. Tax returns. Tax assessors. Tax digest Rate of taxation mayor and council to fix. Double tax. Taxes, when due. Defaulters. Fees of tax officers. Specific taxes.

Sec. 17. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the
police court of the said city shall be known and designated as the Recorder's Court of the city of Sylvester, which court is hereby created and established. The mayor and council shall, at their first meeting after each annual election, or as soon thereafter as practicable, elect a fit and proper person to the office of recorder, which office is hereby created, to serve from the time of his election for a term of one year, or until his successor is elected and qualified. Said recorder shall preside over and constitute the said court. The said court shall have, and is hereby given, jurisdiction to try and power to punish all offenders against any of the laws, ordinances, by-laws, rules, orders, and other enactments of the mayor and council of the said city; he may punish all violations of the same by fine not to exceed one hundred dollars, imprisonment in the city jail not to exceed theiryt days, or by compulsory labor upon the streets, or other public works of the said city, for a term not to exceed three months, either one or all of the said punishments, in his discretion. In the event a fine is imposed, the recorder shall enforce the payment of same by imprisonment or work upon the streets, or other public works of the said city, within the limits above provided; he is empowered to keep order in his court, punish for contempt, fix rules for the conduct and government of said court, and may punish all disorderly persons, persons in contempt, and all who violate any of the said rules by fine, imprisonment, or work upon the streets, or other public works of the said city, within the limits above provided; he shall have power to compel the production of testimony, require the attendance of witnesses, hear and admit testimony of all kinds under the same rules as govern trials in the superior courts of this State, and have the same powers to punish for non-attendance, or other failure on the part of any one as the judge of the superior court. In all criminal or quasi criminal matters he shall have power to require the attendance of witnesses from any place throughout the bounds of the State of Georgia; provided, that where witnesses are required to attend who reside without the limits of Worth county, they shall be entitled to the per diem fee and mileage allowed witnesses attending the superior court in such cases. He shall, and is hereby empowered, to issue warrants for offenses committed against the laws of this State within the limits of the said city, and also for all offenses created against any of the laws, ordinances, by-laws, rules, orders, and other enactments of the said city, and all warrants issued by him for offenses against the laws, etc., of the said city, shall be
directed as the ordinary State's warrant, and shall have the same force and effect, and the same may be executed by any arresting officer anywhere in the State of Georgia, wherever the offender may be found. He is further empowered to hold committal trials, bind over to a court of competent jurisdiction, grant bail, and to do all acts and exercise all powers of justices of the peace in this State, in the same manner and to the same extent as said justices; all appearance bonds taken under the authority of the said recorder to be valid and binding, and capable of being enforced in any court of this State having jurisdiction of the same. All bonds taken for the appearance of offenders at the said recorder's court may be enforced therein in the same manner and with like procedure as like bonds for appearance at the superior courts are enforced therein, all process to be issued by the clerk of council, who is hereby made ex officio clerk of the said recorder's court, and bear test in the name of the said recorder; the penalty of bonds for appearance at the recorder's court shall not exceed one hundred dollars. The clerk of council shall be ex officio clerk of this court, and shall keep all necessary and proper records; it shall not be necessary to draw up any formal charge or accusation against the defendant in this court; the recorder shall keep a docket and enter thereupon all cases, stating the charge, in a general way, and shall inform the defendant of the charge against him, and, after giving the defendant a reasonable time to prepare for trial, shall proceed in a summary way with the trial, and shall enter up his judgment on the said docket. The defendant shall have the right of certiorari from the decision and judgment of the said recorder, the same to be procured, heard and determined in the same manner as certioraries in criminal cases from the county courts of this State; all laws applicable to county courts with reference to certioraries being hereby made applicable to this court. The mayor of the said city shall exercise all of said powers, and the mayor's court continue for the present time. The first recorder to be appointed after the January, 1905, election. The mayor and council shall, at the time of his appointment, fix the salary of the recorder, and fix the time and terms of payment. The mayor and council shall, by ordinance, fix the feebills of the officers of the said court, provide for the payment of same, and provide a method of collecting same; provided, that the fees of the officers shall be first paid, and the officers are hereby given first lien on the fine and forfeiture fund arising in said court. After the officers' cost have been paid, the fines and forfeitures
of said court shall be paid into the treasury of the said city. The ministerial officers of the said court shall be a chief of police and as many policemen and patrolmen, and such other like officers as the mayor and council may see proper to appoint from time to time; provided, that the mayor and council may, in their discretion, consolidate the offices of marshal and chief of police, and appoint the same person to both, or keep them separate, just as they see proper from time to time. The marshal, chief of police, all regular policemen and patrolmen, and all special policemen that may be at any time appointed by the mayor and council, shall have the same powers as to arrest in executing warrants, and in doing all other acts necessary and proper in the discharge of their duties, as are now, or may hereafter be, given the sheriffs of this State; and they are hereby made subject to rule, and liable for trespass, false imprisonment, etc., the same as sheriffs, action to be brought in any court of Worth county having jurisdiction. The recorder's court shall have jurisdiction over them for neglect of duty, improper conduct, and for violating any of the laws, ordinances, rules, regulations, orders, or other enactments of the mayor and council of the said city. The mayor and council shall have the right to pass all necessary and proper ordinances, rules and regulations for the government of said officers, and prescribe their duties, and fix their salaries. All rules, orders and processes of the recorder's court shall be issued by the clerk of council, as ex officio clerk of said court, bear test in the name of the recorder, and may be served by the marshal, chief of police, or by some policeman of the said city, or by any sheriff or constable of this State to whom the same may be directed. It shall be the duty of the marshal, chief of police, or some policeman designated by the recorder, when both of the other officers named are absent or can not attend, to attend all sessions of the said court. The recorder's court shall meet at a place to be designated by the mayor and council, in the said city as often as may be necessary to dispose of all the business of the said court promptly and without delay, the recorder to have the right to fix the time and hour of meeting for all regular and special sessions of the said court. In the event the recorder is absent or can not act for any reason, the mayor, and, in the event the mayor is absent or can not act for any reason, then the mayor pro tem. shall perform all of the duties and exercise all of the powers of the recorder, and preside over the recorder's court. Police court. Recorder. Jurisdiction. Punitive powers. Contempts Powers and procedure. Appearance bonds. Clerk of court. Docket. Certiorari. Recorder, appointment and salary. Fees. Police force, Arrests. Improper conduct of, punishment for. Government and salaries of. Processes. Recorder's court, sessions. Recorder, absence of.

Sec. 18. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the
mayor and council shall have the authority, and they are hereby empowered, to levy and collect from each male inhabitant of the said city who is now, and who may at the time the levy is made, be subject to road duty under the existing laws of this State, the sum of three dollars per annum, the same to be collected quarterly, as a street tax; provided, that any person subject to the said tax may relieve himself of the same by working on the streets of the said city, under the direction of the authorities in charge of the street work, for six days; the mayor and council are hereby authorized to enact an ordinance, and to change or amend the same from time to time, as they see proper, providing the time and manner of collecting same. If any person subject to work upon the streets of the said city, because of having failed to pay the said tax shall decline, fail or refuse to work upon the same when summoned to do so by the officer in charge of the street work, as provided by the ordinance governing the same, it shall be the duty of the officer, or officers, in charge of the street work to report the same to the recorder; it shall be the duty of the recorder, upon information from any source of the defendant of any one as to, or in violation of the street ordinance, to enter a charge against such person and cause him to be brought before him for trial; and he may punish such offender by fine, imprisonment, or compulsory work upon the streets, or other public works within the limits of his authority, as above provided. Street tax and work. Defaulters.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council shall have, and they are, hereby granted power to lay out and open new streets, and to widen or change in any way they see proper those already open; to abolish and discontinue any street or alley in the said city; to alter and change any of the streets and alleys of the said city, as they see proper; to regulate the width of streets, sidewalks and alleys of the said city; to provide by ordinance for the removal of any obstruction, nuisance or objectionable thing from the streets, alleys and sidewalks; and the recorder may enforce the said ordinance and punish offenders against the same within the limits of his authority. The mayor and council are hereby empowered to condemn private property for public use whenever, in their judgment, the same shall be of public utility and necessary for the purpose of the said city, and in that event the owners of such property shall be compensated; the value of the property condemned and the amount to be paid the owner shall be determined as follows: The clerk of the council shall issue a notice to the
owners, notifying them of the property sought to be condemned, which notice may be served upon the owner, or the tenant in possession, and the owner shall, within ten days after the service of the said notice, file with the clerk of council a statement of the amount of damages claimed by him, and at the same time naming an arbitrator to serve in the event his charge is not agreed to and paid; it shall be the duty of the mayor and council to meet promptly and consider his claim for damages, and to notify him of their acceptance or rejection of same, and in the event they do not accept and pay the same, to notify the owner of the property sought to be condemned, and at the same time nominate an arbitrator. It shall be the duty of the two arbitrators to meet within five days after they have been notified of their appointment and consider and determine the amount of damages that will be done the property owner by condemning his property as proposed, and to make up their award in writing and file it with the clerk of council, and their decision shall be final. In the event the two thus appointed can not agree, they may select a third man, and in the event they can not agree upon the third man, then the judge of the superior court of Worth county shall appoint the third man upon application being made to him by the mayor of said city, and the three shall proceed to make up and file their award. After the amount of damages has been fixed, in the manner above provided, it shall be the duty of the authorities of the said city to tender that amount to the owner before beginning to use the property sought to be condemned; upon tender being made, whether the same be accepted or not, the authorities of the said city may proceed to use and appropriate the property sought to be condemned, and it shall not be legal for the owner or owners, or any other person, to interfere with them in any way. Streets, sidewalks, etc. Condemnation for.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council may, and they are hereby empowered to, establish a system of water-works, sewerage, electric lights, open and build parks and driveways for the said city, as they may deem proper and necessary from time to time, and to levy a tax to maintain and operate the same. In the event more than one thousand dollars should be required to do the work proposed, or to establish the improvement proposed at any one time, the same shall not be done except upon issue and sale of bonds of said city, to be issued in usual manner; the mayor and council shall not have a right to use and appropriate more than one thousand dollars in any one year for public improvements, or purposes outside of the regular current expenses of maintaining the different
branches of the city government, keeping up the streets, public buildings, and other property belonging to the city, and such other things as are already a charge upon the city at any particular time, but may use and appropriate that much during any one year in any manner they see proper for the improvement, general welfare and advancement of the said city, and the comfort and convenience of its citizens. If the mayor and council at any time deem it necessary and expedient to establish or make any public improvement, which it is authorized by law to establish, requiring an expenditure of more than one thousand dollars in any one year, they may call and have held in the usual, and according to the Constitution and laws of this State, an election for the purpose of voting upon the question of the issue and sale of the bonds for the proposed purpose; and should the required two-thirds vote be in favor of the issue of the proposed bonds, the same may be issued and sold in the manner provided by the laws of this State, and the proceeds arising therefrom be used or appropriated in the manner and for the purpose or purposes proposed, and may thereafter levy and collect a sufficient tax to maintain the work or improvement thus established. Water-works, sewerage, lights, etc. Bonds for. Appropriations. Election for bonds.

Sec. 21. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council may, and they are hereby empowered, to sell and grant to any person or persons, firm or corporation, the exclusive franchise to establish, maintain and operate a water-works plant, electric light plant, or any like improvement or convenience for a term not exceeding forty years; or they may delegate to others any rights or powers with reference to same, that they may see proper, by contract or otherwise, fixing the terms and conditions, and limiting and restricting the same, and retaining any right or interest in the same, as they see proper; provided, they shall not have the right to make any contract the time of which shall exceed forty years; provided, that no franchise shall be sold, leased or granted, and no contract shall be made with reference to same delegating any rights or powers to outside parties to establish, maintain and operate a water-works plant, electric light plant covering a period and for a term exceeding one year, except upon a two-thirds vote of the qualified voters of the said city at an election to be held for that purpose, notice to be given of the election, and the same to be conducted and the result to be declared in the same way as in bond elections, the ballots to have written or printed thereupon the words For Sale of Franchise or Against Sale of Franchise. Should such election result favorably, the mayor and council may proceed
to sell, lease or grant the franchise, or make the contract proposed, with the highest and best bidder for same, in such manner as they may provide. Public improvements, franchises for. Sale of franchises, election for.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Act establishing a system of public schools for the town of Sylvester, approved December 18, 1900 (Acts of 1900, page 440), town of Sylvester, Worth county, Georgia; to empower the mayor and council of the said town to levy and collect a tax for the support and maintenance thereof; to provide for the issuance of bonds of the said town for the purpose of purchasing school property, building schoolhouses, etc.; to create a board of school commissioners for the said town; to authorize and require the county school commissioners of Worth county to pay or turn over to the said school commissioner of the said town such part of the State and county school fund as may be the just pro rata share of the said town, and for other purposes, be, and the said Act is, hereby adopted and re-enacted for the city of Sylvester, created under this Act to succeed the town of Sylvester, and the present system of public schools of the town of Sylvester shall continue and be maintained by the city of Sylvester, and all rights thereunder, and all property and other things acquired by the said town thereunder, shall become, and are hereby made, the right and property of the city of Sylvester, and all debts and other liabilities of the said town contracted and made under and by virtue of the said Act are assumed and are hereby made the debts, liabilities and obligations of the city of Sylvester. Wherever the word town appears in the heading or body of the said Act, throughout, the same is hereby stricken and the word city inserted in lieu thereof, so that the same shall read the city of Sylvester throughout, instead of the town of Sylvester. Public schools.
Sec. 23. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in addition to all of the foregoing the mayor and council of the said city shall have the following powers: Mayor and council, powers.

First. To provide for the protection and security, and for the quiet and peaceable enjoyment of life, liberty and property of the citizens of the said city; to provide by ordinance for the suppression and punishment, in a quick and summary way, of all riotous and disorderly persons, and of all persons offending against any of the ordinances of the said city; to authorize the marshal and policemen of the said city, and require them to be diligent in their efforts to discover and apprehend and to bring charges against all offenders against the laws of this State, and against the laws
and ordinances of the said city; the marshal, chief of police, and all regular and special policemen appointed by the mayor and council, are hereby authorized, and it is hereby made their duty to arrest any and all offenders against the laws and ordinances of the said city without a warrant, or other formal charge against them where the offense is committed in their presence, and where they have reliable information and probable cause to suspect the guilt of any person or persons of any offense against the laws or ordinances of the said city; in all cases where they have good reason to suspect that offenses are being committed behind closed doors, or that offenders are secreted or being harbored, they shall have the right to force an entrance for the purpose of discovering and apprehending the offenders. Protection of life, liberty and property. Punishment of offenders. Arrests.

Second. To provide for a license fee, and to levy and collect a special tax on all theatrical exhibitions, circuses, shows, exhibitions and entertainments of all kinds, and on all billiard, pool, and other kinds of tables, bowling-alleys, all kinds of games and places of amusement and entertainment, and to regulate all of the same. License taxes.

Third. To abate all nuisances, and provide for the punishment of those who maintain the same; to define what shall constitute a nuisance; to cause any nuisance that, in their opinion, endangers the health of the people of said city, or any citizen thereof, to be abated in a summary manner; where any nuisance is not promptly abated by the party maintaining it, upon notice from the mayor and council to do so, the same may be removed by the authorities of the city, the expense of abating same to be charged against the party maintaining or causing the nuisance, and be enforced against him by execution in the same way as taxes; they shall also provide by ordinance for charges to be preferred against persons declining to abate nuisance when ordered to do so, and see that they are punished. Nuisances, abatement of.

Fourth. To regulate markets, butcher-pens, butcher-shops, livery-stables, fish stands, restaurants, and all like businesses, and to confine the same to any locality in the said city that they see proper; to revoke the license and discontinue any and all of such places at any particular locality at any time, upon five days' notice, in writing, to the party or parties running the same. Markets, etc., regulation of.

Fifth. To fix and define the fire limits of the said city, and to prescribe the kind of material to be used in all buildings, fences, and all and everything to be erected or established within such limits, and to extend the same wherever they see proper; to regulate and control the sale and storing of combustibles in the said city; to
regulate and control blacksmith-shops, forges, foundries, steamengines, machinery, mills, etc., and remove them when necessary, in their judgment, for the safety of property, and to confine them to certain limits; to regulate chimneys, stoves and all other heating apparatus, and to condemn and cause same to be removed whenever necessary, in their judgment, to secure safety from fire; to regulate the construction of doors, and to require places of exit, fire-escapes, etc., in public buildings, assembly halls and like places wherever they deem it necessary and proper. Fire limits and buildings therein.
Sixth. To regulate and control all hotels and public houses within the said city. Hotels and public houses.

Seventh. To take up and impound dogs, horses, mules, cattle, hogs, and all other domestic animals running at large on the streets of the said city; require the same kept up by their owners, fix a fee for impounding the same, and to provide for the punishment of offenders against such ordinances as may be enacted with reference to and regulating the same. Stock pound.

Eighth. To license, levy special tax upon, and to regulate hacks, drays, the use of bicycles, automobiles, and all other machines and vehicles used for public transportation and carriages; to provide for the inspection of same, and to regulate the rates to be charged. Public vehicles, regulation and license of.
Ninth. To grant encroachments upon the streets and alleys of the city on such terms and with such limitations and restrictions as they see proper. Encroachments.

Tenth. To prohibit idleness and loitering upon the streets, and define the offense of vagrancy, and to punish offenders against the ordinances that may be enacted with reference to same, the recorder's court to have jurisdiction. Vagrancy.

Eleventh. To institute and provide for the enforcement of all measures that they deem necessary for the preservation of the public health, and for the prevention of all infectious and contagious diseases; to exercise absolute power over the subject of quarantine, and pass and enforce all regulations that they see proper with reference to same; to provide for and enforce compulsory vaccination; to provide for the punishment of all offenders against any ordinance that may be enacted with reference to any of the above subjects, and to see that all of the same are strictly enforced. Public health. Quarantine. Vaccination.

Twelfth. To prohibit the renting of any house in the said city for any immoral purposes, or for any purpose that renders the same disagreeable to others in the same vicinity, from noise or disorderly conduct, or for any other reason, on account of the kind of business carried on therein. Houses for immoral purposes, renting of prohibited

Thirteenth. To provide for the inspection of buildings, and condemn the same for being unsafe, and require the same to be made safe, or to be torn down; and they are hereby granted full power to provide and enforce a method of condemning such buildings or structures. Buildings inspection and condemnation of

Fourteenth. To pass all ordinances necessary and proper for the peace, security, welfare, health, comfort and convenience of the said city and its inhabitants, and to provide for and see to the enforcement of the same. General welfare.

Fifteenth. To exercise all additional powers not hereinbefore enumerated that may be necessary and proper for the good government of the said city, and for the welfare of its citizens, and which can be conferred upon the said city under the Constitution and laws of this State. Additional powers.

Sixteenth. The mayor and council may, in their discretion, create at any time the office of city attorney, and prescribe his duties, fix his salary, and the time and terms of payment, and appoint some competent attorney of the said city to the said office to serve for such time as they may by order on the minutes designate, not to exceed one year from the time of his appointment; the mayor and council may, at any time, employ any attorney they see proper for any special service, or for advice and counsel, under special contract. City attorney.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this Act shall constitute the charter of the city of Sylvester, located as above designated, and the same shall go into effect immediately upon the passage and approval of an Act to abolish the charter of the town of Sylvester.
Sec. 25. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: TENNILLE, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to provide a new charter for the city of Tennille, in the county of Washington; to grant certain powers and privileges to said city, and for other purposes, approved October 24, 1897, so as to create for the city of Tennille a recorder's court, to define its powers and jurisdiction, to provide for the election of a recorder, his duties, powers, and the manner of his compensation, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act there shall be in and for the city of Tennille a recorder's court, which shall supersede the court now held by the mayor, or mayor pro tem., so far as concerns the jurisdiction to try and punish offenses against the city laws or ordinances, and all the laws or ordinances of the city of Tennille in reference to the police court, now held by the mayor, or mayor pro tem., shall be applicable to the recorder's court, including the mode of procedure now in vogue in the mayor's court, and all the power and authority, and jurisdiction heretofore held and exercised by the mayor, or mayor pro tem., in the trial of offense against the city ordinances and laws, shall be held and exercised by the said recorder. The said recorder's court shall have exclusive jurisdiction to try and punish all offenses or infractions of the laws and ordinances of the city of Tennille; provided, however, that any party convicted in said recorder's court shall have all the rights of appeal, and review of the recorder's judgments, as now exists from the judgments of the mayor or mayor pro tem. Tennille, recorder's court for

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and city council of the city of Tennille shall have full power and authority to elect a recorder; and they shall, on the second Monday in August, 1904, elect a recorder, who shall serve until the second Monday in May, 1905; and said recorder shall be elected on the second Monday in May, 1905, for a term of two (2) years; and that the mayor and council are empowered and directed to elect a recorder every two (2) years thereafter, whose term of office shall be two (2) years. The mayor and city council shall also have the power and authority to remove said recorder from office
for any malfeasance or malpractice, or any failure to attend to the duties of his office. And in the event of such removal, or in the event of a vacancy occurring in the office in anywise, the mayor and council shall have authority to elect another recorder for the unexpired term. In the event the recorder is disqualified to act, or sick, or for other reasons, why he can not hold his court, the mayor or mayor pro tem. shall have the power and authority to act in his place, and assume his functions. Recorder.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the salary or compensation of recorder for his services shall be as the city council may prescribe, and it shall have the power to fix his compensation, and prescribe how it shall be paid. Compensation.

Sec. 4. Be it further provided, That the mayor shall still have the right to suspend or remit all fines, and shall have power to pardon any person, or persons, convicted in the recorder's court. Remit of fines and pardon, mayor may.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: THOMASVILLE, CITY OF, ELECTRIC LIGHTING PLANT AUTHORIZED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act approved October 3, 1889, entitled an Act to reincorporate the town of Thomasville, as the city of Thomasville, and for other purposes, so as to confer upon the city of Thomasville the authority to buy or build and equip an electric lighting plant in said city, for the purpose of furnishing electric lights for the streets and buildings of said city and contiguous territory thereto, and with power to operate such a plant for her own benefit, and to sell electric lights and power to consumers, and to elect all necessary officers and employees to operate said plant, and to control the same.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the city of Thomasville, Georgia, is hereby authorized and empowered to buy or build and equip an electric lighting plant in said city for the purpose of furnishing electric lights for the streets and buildings of said city, and to contract with any person, persons,
firm or corporation for the furnishing of electric lights, electric power, and all other purposes for which electricity generated by such plants are now, or may hereafter, be used, for use in streets, roads, buildings in and on contiguous territory to said city of Thomasville. Thomasville, electric lights for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That said city is hereby authorized and empowered to operate such an electric plant for her own benefit, and sell electric lights and power to consumers. Electric plant, city may operate.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of said city are hereby authorized and empowered to employ all necessary officers and employees to operate said plant, and to control the same. Employees for.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws militating against this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: THOMASVILLE, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act approved October 3, 1889, entitled an Act to reincorporate the town of Thomasville as the city of Thomasville, and for other purposes, so as to confer upon the city of Thomasville the authority to buy or build and equip an electric lighting plant in said city, for the purpose of furnishing electric lights for the streets and buildings of said city and contiguous territory thereto, and with power to operate such a plant for her own benefit, and to sell electric light and power to consumers, and to elect all necessary officers and employees to operate said plant, and to control the same.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the city of Thomasville, Georgia, is hereby authorized and empowered to buy or build and equip an electric lighting plant in said city for the purpose of furnishing electric lights for the streets and buildings of said city, and to contract with any person, persons, firms or corporations for the furnishing of electric lights, electric power, and all other purposes for which electricity generated by such plant are now, or may hereafter be, used, for
use in streets, roads, buildings in and on contiguous territory to said city of Thomasville. Thomasville, electric lighting plant for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That said city is hereby authorized and empowered to operate such an electric plant for her own benefit, and sell electric lights and power to consumers. Light and power, sale of, authorized.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of said city are hereby authorized and empowered to employ all necessary [Illegible Text] and employees to operate said plant, and to control the same. Employees for plant.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws militating against this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: THOMASVILLE, CITY OF, ACT INCORPORATING AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act incorporating the city of Thomasville, in the county of Thomas, approved October 3, 1889, and the Act amendatory thereof, approved December 17, 1902, so as to provide for the election of the city clerk by the qualified voters of said city.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act the charter of the city of Thomasville, as embodied in the Act of October 3, 1889, and the amendatory Acts thereof, approved December 17, 1902, be amended by inserting in line three, section 1 of said amendatory Act, after the word treasurer in said line, the word clerk, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows: That the power heretofore vested in the mayor and aldermen of the city of Thomasville to elect the marshal, treasurer, clerk and sexton, is hereby revoked, and said officers shall be hereafter elected by the qualified voters of said city, and at the same time, and in the same manner as the mayor and aldermen of said city are now elected. All vacancies caused by death, resignation, or otherwise, of any of said officers shall be filled by election by the mayor and aldermen to fill the unexpired term of said officers. And the salaries of said officers shall be fixed by the mayor and aldermen
of the preceding year, and prior to the election of said officers. The officers so elected shall be subject to the same management and control of the mayor and aldermen as now provided by said Act, or as shall hereafter be adopted by them relating to their qualifications, bonds and general conduct as officers of said city. Thomasville, clerk, how chosen.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: TIGER, TOWN OF, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the town of Tiger, in the county of Rabun, State of Georgia; to define the corporate limits thereof; to provide a municipal government for said town; to confer certain powers and privileges of the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act the town of Tiger, in the county of Rabun, be, and is, hereby incorporated as a town under the name of the town of Tiger. Tiger, town of, incorporated.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the corporate limits of said town of Tiger shall extend in every direction the distance of nine hundred yards from the Tallulah Falls Railway depot, as now located. Corporate limits.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the municipal authorities of said town shall be a mayor and four councilmen, who are hereby constituted a body corporate by the name of the town of Tiger, and by said name may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, purchase and hold real estate necessary to enable them the better to discharge their duties and needful for the good order, government and welfare of said town, and by said name shall also have perpetual succession. Mayor and councilmen.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the passage of this Act that R. E. Cannon, of said town, be, and he is, hereby appointed and constituted mayor of said town; H. B. Stonecypher, V. C. Taylor, H. L. Hestner
and V. B. Thompson, all of said town, be, and they are, hereby appointed and constituted councilmen of said town; the said mayor and councilmen to hold their respective office until their successors in office are duly elected and qualified, as hereinafter provided. Mayor and councilmen appointed.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by said authority, That on the last Saturday in December, 1904, and annually thereafter, on the same day, and in the same month, an election shall be held in said town for a mayor and councilmen thereof; said election to be under such supervision, rules and regulations (not inconsistent with the laws regulating county elections) as the council may prescribe. Election for.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all persons who have been bona fide residents of said town for three months next preceding an election held therein, and who are qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly, shall be allowed to vote at any election held in said town, provided a registration of voters shall not be a condition precedent to such voting, unless said council shall so order. Electors.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and councilmen, and other officers of said town, as hereinafter provided for, shall, after election or appointment to his office, and before he shall enter upon the duties thereof, take and subscribe the following oath (which may be administered by any officer authorized by the Code of Georgia to administer oaths): I do solemnly swear, or affirm, that I will faithfully discharge all duties incumbent upon me as mayor or councilman, or other officer of the town of Tiger, according to the best of my ability; so help me, God. Said oath, with the certificate of the officer administering the same, shall be filed with the officer entrusted with the records of said town. Official oath.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and councilmen shall have power and authority to elect such marshals, clerks and other subordinate officers as may be deemed necessary for carrying on the powers herein granted, and to prescribe the duties and compensation of such officers and require of them such bonds as they may deem necessary payable to such town in its corporate name. Subordinate officers.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the council of said town shall have power therein to lay off, close, open and keep in good order and repair roads, streets and sidewalks, for the use of the public or any citizen thereof; to prevent
injury or annoyance to the public or individuals from anything dangerous or unwholesome, to protect places of divine worship in and about the premises where held; to abate or cause to be abated anything which in the opinion of the majority of the whole council, shall be a nuisance, to protect the property and person of the citizens of said town, and to preserve the peace and good order therein, and for this purpose to appoint, when necessary, a police force to assit the marshal in the discharge of his duties; to provide for the annual assessment of taxable property therein, which, in no event shall be greater than one per centum of the value of the taxable property; to adopt rules for the regulation and government of its own body. The council shall have power to make and pass all needful orders, ordinances and by-laws not contrary to the Constitution anl laws of Georgia, to carry into effect the foregoing enumerated powers and all others conferred upon said town, and to this end may prescribe, impose and enact reasonable fines, penalties and imprisonment in the town prison, if there be one, for a term not exceeding thirty days. Council, powers of.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said town shall have the power and right to organize work-gangs and to confine at labor therein for a term not exceeding thirty days, persons convicted of violating the ordinances of said town; provided, that said penalty be inflicted only as an alternative for failure or refusal to pay fine imposed for such violations. Work-gangs and punitive powers.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor of said town shall have authority to bind over or commit to jail, offenders against any criminal law of Georgia, whenever, in the course of investigation before him a proper case therefor shall be made out by evidence. Mayor, power as a committing magistrate.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and councilmen shall have the power to elect a mayor pro tem., who shall perform all the duties of the mayor when, from any cause, he can not be present to perform the duties of his office; also to fill any vacancy that may occur in the office of mayor or councilmen or any subordinate office of said town. Mayor pro tem.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by authority of the same, That the mayor of said town shall be chief executive officer thereof; he shall see that the ordinances, by-laws, rules, and regulations of the council are faithfully executed; he shall have control of the police of said town, and may appoint special police when he
may deem it necessary; he shall have power to issue executions for all fines, penalties and costs imposed by him or he may require the immediate payment thereof; and in default of such immediate payment he may imprison the offender as hereinbefore provided. Mayor, powers.
Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: TOOMSBORO, TOWN OF, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the town of Toomsboro, in the county of Wilkinson; to provide for a mayor and council, prescribe their powers and duties; to define the corporate limits of said town, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That on and after the passage of this Act, the town of Toomsboro, in the county of Wilkinson, be, and is hereby, incorporated as a town, under the name of Toomsboro. Toomsboro, town of, incorporated.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the aforesaid authority, That the corporate limits of said town of Toomsboro shall be as follows: Line running from foot of county bridge at south end where it crosses Commissioner's creek, parallel with creek east until it reaches first trestle of the Central of Georgia Railway Company; then running south in line with creek until branch is reached, said branch running west; said line running then until the original land line between estates of W. F. Cannon and J. I. Deese is reached, thence down said land line running north to Commissioner's creek line running east parallel with creek until it intersects with first described line at county bridge. The same being boundary of said town at previous incorporation. Corporate limits.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the municipal authorities of said town shall be a mayor and five councilmen, who are hereby constituted a body corporate, by the name of the town of Toomsboro, and by said name may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, purchase and hold real estate necessary to enable them
to better discharge their duties, and needful for the good order, government and welfare of said town, and by said name shall also have perpetual succession. Mayor and councilmen, corporate powers.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That from and after the passage of this Act, that H. A. Hall, of said town, be, and is hereby, appointed and constituted mayor of said town, and W. H. Freeman, J. T. Hobbs, M. W. Pournell, P. C. Lord and J. A. Ashley, all of said town, be, and they are hereby appointed and constituted councilmen of said town; the mayor and councilmen to hold their respective office until their successors in office are duly elected and qualified, as hereinafter provided. Mayor and councilmen appointed.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That on the second Saturday in September, 1904, and annually thereafter on the same day and in the same month, an election shall be held in said town for a mayor and councilmen thereof, said election to be under such supervision, rules and regulations (not inconsistent with the laws regulating county elections) as the council may prescribe. Election for.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That all persons who have been bona fide residents of said town for three months next preceding an election held therein, and who are qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly, shall be allowed to vote at any election held in said town. Electors.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and councilmen and such other officers of said town as hereinafter provided for, shall after election or appointment to his office, and before he shall enter upon the duties thereof, take and subscribe the following oath (which may be administered by any officer authorized by the Code of Georgia to administer oaths): I do solemnly swear or affirm, that I will faithfully discharge all duties incumbent upon me as mayor or councilmen or other officers of the town of Toomsboro, according to the best of my ability; so help me, God. Said oath with the certificate of the officer administering the same, shall be filed with the officer entrusted with the records of said town. Official oath.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and councilmen shall have power and authority to elect such marshals, clerks and other subordinate officers as may be deemed necessary for carrying on the powers herein granted, and to prescribe the duties and compensation of such officers, and require of them such bonds as they may deem necessary, payable to such town in its corporate name. Subordinate officers.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the council of said town
shall have power therein to lay off, close, open and keep in good order and repair, roads, streets and sidewalks, for the use of the public or any citizen thereof; to prevent injury or annoyance to the public or individuals from anything dangerous or unwholesome; to protect places of divine worship in and about the premises where held; to abate or cause to be abated, anything which, in the opinion of the majority of the whole council, shall be a nuisance; to protect the property and person of the citizens of said town, and to preserve the peace and good order therein, and for this purpose to appoint, when necessary, a police force to assist the marshal in the discharge of his duties; to provide for the annual assessment of taxable property therein, which, in no event shall be greater than one-fourth of one per cent. of the value of the taxable property; to adopt rules for the regulation and government of its own body. The council shall have power to make and pass all needful orders, ordinances and by-laws not contrary to the Constitution and the laws of Georgia; to carry into effect the foregoing enumerated powers and all others conferred upon said town, and to this end may prescribe, impose and enact reasonable fines, penalties and imprisonments in the town prison, if there be one, for a term not exceeding twenty days. Council, powers.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That the said town shall have the power and right to organize work-gangs and to confine at labor therein, for a term not exceeding twenty days, persons convicted of violating the ordinances of said town; provided, that said penalty shall be inflicted only as an alternative for failure or refusal to pay fine imposed for such violation. Work-gangs and punitive powers.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That the mayor of said town shall have the authority to bind over, or commit to jail, offenders against any criminal law of Georgia, whenever, in the course of investigation before him, a proper case therefor shall be made out by evidence. Mayor, power as a committing magistrate.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and councilmen shall have the power to elect a mayor pro tem., who shall perform the duties of the mayor when, from any cause, he can not be present to perform the duties of his office; also to fill any vacancy that may occur in the office of the mayor or councilmen or any subordinate office of said town. Mayor pro tem. Vacancies.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That the mayor of said town shall be chief executive officer thereof; he shall see that the ordinances, by-laws, rules and regulations of the council are faithfully executed; he shall have control of the police of said town, and may appoint special police when he may deem it necessary;
he shall have the power to hold his police court for the trial for the offenders of the ordinances of said town at any time he may fix, and the defendant shall have the right of appeal to the whole council upon such terms as may be provided for by ordinance; he shall have power to issue executions for all fines, penalties imposed by him, costs imposed by him, or he may require the immediate payment thereof; and in default of such immediate payment he may imprison the offender as hereinbefore provided. Mayor, powers.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the board of councilmen shall have power and authority to levy and collect taxes on all professions, trades, business, occupations, theatrical exhibitions, shows or other performances within the town; on all peddlers, venders of medicines, itinerant traders, salesmen or soliciting agents, hotels, boarding-houses, livery-stables and transportation companies, and on the bowling-alleys, skating rinks, pool or billiard tables, and on all other games kept or played within corporate limits of said town; to grant license for the same and to regulate them by ordinance. Specific taxes.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That said corporation shall have and enjoy all the rights, powers and privileges incident to such corporations and not repugnant to the Constitution and laws of the United States and of this State. Corporate powers.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, That the board of councilmen shall have power and authority to establish quarantine regulations against all persons who have been exposed to smallpox, yellow fever, or any other contagious or infectious disease, or against infected locality; to enforce and make effective such regulations to establish a pest-house or camp of detention, within or without said town, and to cause the removal hereto and detention therein of all persons afflicted with such diseases or who have been in infected localities or exposed to such diseases. Said board shall have power in its discretion to allow such persons to remain on its premises as provided by themselves, where such persons at their own expense, provide suitable and sufficient guards, to successfully quarantine such premises. Said board shall have power to require all persons within said town whether resident or transient, to be vaccinated whenever in the opinion of the said board the same shall be advisable. It shall have full power to enforce such regulations and to provide penalties for their violation. If the pest-house or camp of detention is located beyond the corporate limits of said town, the town authorities shall have the same jurisdiction over it so long as it is used for these purposes, as it were within corporate limits. Said board of councilmen
shall have authority to appoint a board of health and such other health officers as may be necessary to carry out and enforce the above regulations, and all such other sanitary or health regulations as may be prescribed by the board of councilmen. The powers, duties and compensation of such officers to be prescribed by the board of councilmen. Quaran tine. Vaccination. Board of health.
Sec. 17. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: UNION POINT, CITY OF, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the city of Union Point, in the county of Greene; to provide for the election of a mayor and councilmen; to prescribe their duties and to provide for all matters of municipal concern, and to establish therein public schools, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, That the municipality of Union Point is hereby incorporated under the name and style of the city of Union Point, with the municipal government therof vested in a mayor and six aldermen who are hereby constituted a body corporate, and by that name and style shall have perpetual succession, shall have a common seal and be capable in law to have and to hold, receive and enjoy possession, and retain to them and their successors for the use of the city of Union Point, any estate, real or personal, of whatsoever kind or nature, and shall by the said name of the city of Union Point, be capable to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in any court of law and equity in this State, and shall succeed to all the rights and liabilities of the present corporation of the town of Union Point. Union Point, city of, incorporated.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the corporate limits of the city of Union Point shall be three-quarters of one mile in all directions from the white Baptist church in said city. Corporate limits.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That
on the first Wednesday in January, 1906, and every two years thereafter, there shall be held in said city an election for a mayor and six aldermen of said city, who shall hold office for the term of two years and until their successors are elected and qualified. Until the first election provided for the following-named persons, to wit: W. J. Newsom, for mayor; J. A. Wotton, J. H. Sibley, W. O. Fluker, B. F. Daniels, H. B. Hart and W. P. Carlton, Jr., for aldermen, are hereby constituted the officers in charge of said city government. Mayor and aldermen, election for. Appointees.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all elections for officers of said city shall be held at the court grounds and the polls shall be opened at 9 o'clock in the forenoon and close at 2 o'clock in the afternoon. Said elections shall be under the superintendence of two or more councilmen. Each of said managers entering upon his said duties shall take an oath before a person authorized to administer oaths, or to swear each other that he will faithfully and impartially conduct said election and prevent all illegal voting. No person shall be allowed to vote at said election unless he is qualified under the law to vote for members of the General Assembly, and has paid all city taxes. Elections. Electors.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case of a vacancy in any of the offices of mayor and aldermen by death or resignation all authority is hereby given to the remaining council to elect his successors. Vacancies

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person shall be eligible to the office of mayor or alderman unless he has been a bona fide resident of said city twelve months prior to the election. The persons elected shall be notified of their election by the managers and they shall on the following Wednesday next after the election, or so soon thereafter as may be practicable, take the oath of office before some person authorized to administer oaths, which oath shall be in writing and shall be spread on the book of minutes of the council and which shall be as follows: I , do solemnly swear, or affirm, that I will well and truly perform the duties of mayor, or alderman of the city of Union Point, by adopting such measures as in my judgment will be best calculated to promote the general welfare of said city and not violative of the spirit of intention of this Act of incorporation; so help me, God. Eligibility. Official oath.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and councilmen shall have the power, should they see fit to do so, to elect a mayor pro tem., a clerk of council, a city treasurer (such officers
to be also members of the council), and a city marshal, to hold their offices for the term of one year, or until removed by the mayor and council, and to receive such compensation, if any, as may be fixed by the mayor and council. The duty of the city marshal shall be determined by ordinances. Before entering on the discharge of his duties, the marshal shall take and subscribe to an oath to faithfully perform the duties of his office.
