law.shorttitle: APPROPRIATION TO BUY PORTRAIT OF GENERAL JOHN B. GORDON.
law.p: Whereas, In the providence of the Great Ruler of the destinies of States and of men, death has removed General John Brown Gordon, one of Georgia's most eminent servants in peace, and the pre-eminent soldier of this proud State, who, as Governor of Georgia, and Senator from Georgia in the Senate of the United States, illustrated every civic virtue, who initiated great industrial developments, and crowned his life by becoming the most eloquent apostle of American fraternity, the best safeguard of lasting civil peace, who, without military training, but with the true genius of war, fought his glorious way from the captaincy of one company to the grade of lieutenant-general in the army of Northern Virginia, and was noted for heroism in that Army of unparalleled exploits, and who had a heart of love for all his fellow men, and the grace of the Southern gentleman, and is fit exemplar of the noblest virtues of our State in the noblest part of her history, and fit example for the children and patriots of the State in coming times; it is, therefore. General John B. Gordon.

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That a committee of one from the Senate and two from the House be appointed to procure a life-size oil-painting of the Hon. J. B. Gordon, to be placed by them in the capitol of this State, as a memento of his distinguished services in the halls of national council. Portrait of.

Resolved further, That the sum of five hundred dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, be, and the same is, hereby appropriated to pay for said oil-painting, and the Governor is authorized to draw his warrant on the treasury therefor, to be paid out of money not otherwise appropriated.

law.shorttitle: APPROPRIATION FOR CHEMICAL LABORATORY FOR TECHNOLOGICAL SCHOOL.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to appropriate to the trustees of the State University for the use of the State Technological School, the sum of ten thousand dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, for the erection and arrangement of a building for a chemical laboratory, and for other purposes; provided, that the sum of ten thousand dollars is raised by private subscription, and said sum so raised is paid over and united with the amount appropriated by this resolution, the whole sum of twenty thousand dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, to be paid over and expended as hereinafter provided.
law.p: Section 1. Be it resolved by the General Assembly of this State, That the sum of ten thousand dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated to the trustees of the State University, for the use of the State Technological School, to be applied to the erection of a building for a chemical laboratory, and making proper arrangements therefor; provided, that the sum of ten thousand dollars is first raised by private subscription for the purposes of this resolution, and paid over to the treasurer of the State University, said sum so raised to be united with the amount provided for herein, out of the public funds for the carrying out of the purpose of this resolution; the whole sum of twenty thousand dollars to be paid over and expended as hereinafter provided. School of Technology, chemical laboratory for.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the money hereby appropriated shall be paid over to the treasurer of the State University on his application therefor, and be by him turned over to the treasurer of the local board of trustees of the State Technological School, to be expended by the said board for the purpose aforesaid. The said board shall furnish to the Governor an itemized statement of the expenditures of said money on the completion of said building, and from time to time, so far as practicable, before said money is drawn. Appropriation for, disbursement of.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: APPROPRIATION FOR REBUILDING SCIENCE HALL AT UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to appropriate the sum of $29,000 to the trustees of the University of Georgia, being one-half the value of Science Hall, at Athens, Ga., recently destroyed by fire, said building being insured under the law for one-half its value, $23,000; and the personal property destroyed in said building of the value of $6,000.
law.p: Whereas, Out of an appropriation by the Legislature to the trustees of the University of Georgia, Science Hall was built on the campus of the University of Georgia, at Athens; and, University of Georgia, Science Hall.

Whereas, Under the law it is provided that all buildings belonging to the State shall be insured for only one-half of their value, and said Science Hall, under said law, was insured for the sum of $23,000, being one-half the value of the same; and,

Whereas, On the seventeenth day of November, 1903, said Science Hall was totally destroyed by fire, together with all furniture in the same, and the equipments of the chemical and biological laboratories, and the amount of insurance collected was $23,000; and,

Whereas, The State was in effect carrying its own insurance on the remaining $23,000 of the value of said building, and this amount of risk carried by the State for the University is a total loss to said institution; and,
Whereas, The furniture, apparatus and equipment in said building was also destroyed in said fire, and was a total loss to said University of six thousand ($6,000) dollars; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the sum of $29,000 be, and the same is, hereby appropriated to the trustees of the University of Georgia to replace the amount of said loss, and for the purpose of reconstructing and equipping said building, and that the Governor is hereby authorized to draw his warrant on the treasury for the payment of said sum out of any funds in the treasury, not otherwise appropriated. Appropriation for rebuilding.

law.shorttitle: APPROPRIATION FOR DORMITORY OF STATE INDUSTRIAL COLLEGE.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to make an appropriation of the sum of four thousand ($4,000) dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, with which to complete the third story of the dormitory of the State Industrial College, near Savannah, Georgia; therefore be it
law.p: Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the sum of four thousand ($4,000) dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, be, and the same is, hereby appropriated for the purpose of buying material with which to complete the third story of the dormitory of the State Industrial College, near Savannah, Georgia. State Industrial College, dormitory for.

law.shorttitle: APPROPRIATION FOR WATER-MAIN AT CONFEDERATE SOLDIERS' HOME.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to make an appropriation to enable the trustees of the Confederate Soldiers' Home to lay down and connect a water-main leading from the city of Atlanta, the nearest available point, to the site of the Confederate Soldiers' Home, to supply the building with water, and to afford ample protection against loss by fire to said property; therefore, be it
law.p:
Resolved, by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the sum of six thousand dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, be, and the same is, hereby appropriated out of any money in the treasury not otherwise appropriated, to enable the trustees of the Confederate Soldiers' Home to lay a water-main from the nearest available point in the city of Atlanta, to the site of the Confederate Soldiers' Home, to supply the building with water and to afford ample protection against loss by fire to the said property, and the Governor is authorized to draw his warrant
on the State treasury upon requisition of the board of trustees whenever a contract is made to furnish and lay down and connect the water-main for the purposes herein set forth. Soldiers' Home, water supply for.

law.shorttitle: ROBERTS, SENATOR, DECEASED, MILEAGE AND PER DIEM OF.
law.p: Resolved, by the Senate, the House concurring, That the State Treasurer be authorized to pay to the widow of the late Senator L. H. Roberts, of the sixth district, the full amount of per diem and mileage that would have been due him had he lived and served the full term of the Legislature, 1904, less any amount drawn by him. Senator L. H. Roberts, per diem and mileage.

law.shorttitle: APPROPRIATION FOR FILING-CASES FOR COMMISSIONER OF PENSIONS.
law.p: Whereas, The office of the commissioner of pensions is greatly in need of filing-cases to preserve the valuable papers therein from waste; be it therefore Commissioner of pensions, filing cases for.

Resolved, That the sum of seven hundred and fifty ($750.00) dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, is hereby appropriated for the purpose of purchasing filing-cases for the office of the commissioner of pensions. When said cases have been purchased and put in place, accepted by the keeper of public buildings, the Governor is authorized, upon a cretified statement of the cost thereof by the keeper of public buildings, to draw his warrant upon the Treasurer for the same.

law.shorttitle: DADE COUNTY, REIMBURSEMENT OF, FOR INCARCERATION AND EXECUTION OF CONVICT.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to reimburse the county of Dade for the incarceration and execution of Charlie Phillips, a State convict, and for other purposes.
law.p: Whereas, Charlie Phillips was found guilty and sentenced to hang for the offense of murder committed in the county of Dade, and he being a State convict at the time; and,

Whereas, The said Phillips was under order of the proper court of said county of Dade confined in the jail of said county and legally hanged on the first day of May, 1903, incurring considerable expense to said county, to wit: $175.61; therefore be it

Resolved, by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the said sum of $175.61 be, and the same is, hereby appropriated for the payment to said county of Dade as a reimbursement for said amount so expended, and the Governor is hereby authorized to draw his warrant on the Treasurer of said State for said amount, to be paid out of any funds not heretofore appropriated. Dadecounty, reimbursemen of, for incarceration and execution of State convict.

law.shorttitle: JAMES R. ATWATER, PAYMENT TO, FOR ARMORY RENTS FOR UPSON GUARDS.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to provide for the payment of one hundred and twelve and [UNK] dollars for advanced money paid by Capt. James R. Atwater for armory rent for the Upson Guards.
law.p: Whereas, for the three quarters ending Dec. 31, 1900, June 30, 1901, and Sept. 30, 1901, Capt. James R. Atwater paid and advanced for the State of Georgia armory rent for the Upson Guards, Company H, 2d Regiment Infantry, Georgia State troops; and Upson Guards, armory rent for.

Whereas, The said sum of one hundred and twelve and [UNK]
dollars having not been paid or refunded to the said Capt. James R. Atwater; therefore, be it

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, and the Senate concurring, That the said sum of one hundred and twelve and [UNK] dollars be paid to Capt. James R. Atwater, and that the Governor be, and he is hereby, authorized to draw his warrant on the State treasury in favor of the said Capt. James R. Atwater for the sum as the above stated.

law.shorttitle: H. O. THORNTON, TAX-COLLECTOR, REFUND TO, OF OVERPAYMENT TO STATE.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay $83.08 to H. O. Thornton, tax-collector of Terrell county, being the amount of money which he, by oversight, paid to the State for the year 1902 on tax fi. fas. issued for taxes due the State, which he did not collect, and which should have been allowed him on the insolvent list.
law.p: Whereas, H. O. Thornton, tax-collector of Terrell county, has by oversight paid to the State $83.08 on sixty-seven tax fi. fas. issued by him as tax-collector of Terrell county for the year 1902, which amount was due the State for taxes for the year 1902, and which was not collected, and which should have been allowed him on the insolvent cost list; therefore, be it Overpayment to State, refund of [Illegible Text] tax-collector.

Resolved, by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the sum of $83.08 be, and the same is, hereby appropriated to H. O. Thornton to reimburse him for this amount, paid by him as tax-collector of Terrell county for the year 1902 to the State by oversight, and the Governor is authorized to draw his warrant on the treasury therefor, to be paid out of any money in the treasury not otherwise appropriated.

law.shorttitle: GOVERNOR AUTHORIZED TO BORROW MONEY TO SUPPLY CASUAL DEFICIENCIES.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution authorizing the Governor to borrow money to supply casual deficiencies.
law.p: Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That should it become necessary at any time previous to the next meeting of the General Assembly to supply casual deficiencies in the revenue of the State, the Governor shall be, and he is, hereby authorized to borrow, on the best terms he can, a sum of money sufficient, not to exceed two hundred thousand dollars, to supply said deficiencies within the terms of the Constitution; and the money so borrowed shall be used for the purpose specified and no other. Casual deficiencies, Governor may borrow to supply.

law.shorttitle: SARAH BLACKMON, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay pension to Sarah Blackmon, of Harris county, Georgia.
law.p: Whereas, Sarah Blackmon, of said county, was regularly entered on the pension rolls of this State as the widow of Jack Blackmon, a Confederate soldier; and Pension of Sarah Blackmon.
Whereas, said Sarah Blackmon died on day of January, 1903, after her pension had become due; and,

Whereas, the Hon. W. A. Wright, as attorney in fact for said Sarah Blackmon, drew said pension and transmitted her check for the amount of same, sixty dollars ($60.00) to said pensioner, but before the same was received by said Sarah Blackmon she had departed this life, and by reason thereof said check was by the ordinary of Harris county returned to the said W. A. Wright and by him was canceled and the amount of pension due said Sarah Blackmon was repaid to the treasurer and the same now remains in the treasury of the State; be it, therefore,

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That the treasurer of the State be, and he is hereby authorized and
directed to pay said pension of sixty dollars to Mrs. Ella Harrington, widowed daughter of said Sarah Blackmon, to be applied by her to paying the expenses of her last sickness, burial expenses, and for supplies furnished her by C. H. Cook.
And the Governor is hereby directed to draw his warrant on the treasurer for the same.

law.shorttitle: J. F. M. CAIN, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay the pension of J. F. M. Cain, of Gwinnett county, to his widow.
law.p: Whereas, J. F. M. Cain, of Gwinnett county, drew a pension for years as a wounded Confederate soldier, and Pension of J. F. M. Cain.
Whereas, said Cain died on November 27, 1902, leaving an unpaid pension due him for the year 1903, and
Whereas, said Cain left a widow who is now in life; therefore, be it

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That the sum of $50.00 be, and the same is hereby appropriated to pay the said widow the pension due the deceased husband, and the proper officials are hereby directed to pay said sum to said widow.

law.shorttitle: THOMAS DUNMON, PENSION OF.
law.p: Whereas, Thomas Dunmon, a pensioner from Crawford county, died February 12, 1904, after the pension for the year 1904, had accrued, and after the check for the payment of said pension had been issued, but before its receipt by said pensioner, and Pension of Thomas Dunmon.
Whereas, said pensioner died at the home of his sister, Caroline Dunmon, who is in indigent circumstances, and who nursed and cared for said pensioner during his last illness; therefore, be it

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, that said pension of $60.00 be paid said Caroline Dunmon, sister of said pensioner
on the warrant of the Governor on the Treasurer of the State out of any fund not otherwise appropriated.
That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: A. L. ERWIN, PENSION OF.
law.p: Whereas, A. L. Erwin, late of Floyd county, died on the fourth day of February, 1903; and,
Whereas, Said deceased left a daughter, Sallie Erwin, in an indigent and destitute condition; and,

Whereas, The said deceased A. L. Erwin was on the indigent pension roll of Confederate soldiers, for the county of Floyd, and entitled to a pension of sixty ($60.00) dollars for the year 1903, due on January 1, 1903; and, Pension of A. L. Erwin.
Whereas, Said pension was not paid said deceased, nor to any one for him; and,

Whereas, Owing to the failure of said daughter to submit proof that she was entitled to said pension, until after the fund out of which this pension should have been paid had been refunded into the treasury; be it therefore

Resolved, by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the sum of sixty ($60.00) dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated for the payment of pension, and that the Governor is hereby authorized to draw his warrant on the treasury for said amount in favor of said Sallie Erwin.

law.shorttitle: JOHN S. FLYNT, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay pension of John S. Flynt, of Monroe county, Georgia, to Lucy Flynt, his daughter.
law.p: Whereas, John S. Flynt, late of Monroe county, Georgia, died on January 4, 1903; and,

Whereas, The said deceased, John S. Flynt, had been drawing
a pension of fifty ($50.00) dollars per year, under existing laws of Georgia for the payment of pensions to invalid ex-Confederate soldiers; and, Pension of John S. Flynt.
Whereas, It appearing that there is still due and unpaid a pension of fifty ($50.00) dollars due to said deceased; be it therefore

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the said sum of fifty ($50.00) dollars due to said deceased John S. Flynt be paid to Lucy Flynt, the daughter of said John S. Flynt, deceased. And the Governor is hereby authorized to draw his warrant on the treasury for the payment of said sum out of any funds in the treasury not otherwise appropriated.

law.shorttitle: MRS. S. F. FULLER, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay pension of Mrs. S. F. Fuller, deceased, to her son, J. P. Fuller.
law.p: Whereas, Mrs. S. F. Fuller, deceased, late of Paulding county, Georgia, an indigent pensioner, who was regularly enrolled and paid a pension; and, Pension of Mrs. S. F. Fuller.
Whereas, The said Mrs. S. F. Fuller died on January 3, 1903, after her pension had become due, and was not received by her; and

Whereas, The said Mrs. S. F. Fuller had no property or any means of support, but lived with and was cared for by her son, J. P. Fuller, late of Paulding county, but now a citizen of Carroll county, Georgia, a very poor, but hard-working man; and
Whereas, The said J. P. Fuller paid all expenses incident to the sickness, death and burial of said Mrs. S. F. Fuller, deceased; be it therefore

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the said sum of sixty ($60.00) dollars be paid to J. P. Fuller, son of the said Mrs. S. F. Fuller, deceased, and the Governor is authorized to draw his warrant on the treasury for the payment of said sum out of any funds in the treasury not otherwise appropriated.

law.shorttitle: WILLIAM FUTCH, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay the pension of William Futch, of Fulton county, to his widow.
law.p: Whereas, On the twenty-fifth day of July, 1901, William Futch, of the county of Fulton, applied for a pension as an indigent Confederate soldier; and, Pension [Illegible Text] William Futch.
Whereas, The applicant was duly approved by the commissioner of pensions; and,

Whereas, The said William Futch having departed this life on February the 18th, 1902, and said pension having accrued and was collectable, but the said William Futch having failed to collect the same, and the said William Futch having left a widow, who is still in life; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, and the Senate concurring, That the sum of sixty ($60.00) dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated with which to pay to the said Mary Futch, the widow of William Futch, the pension that was due the said husband, William Futch, and that the proper officials of the State be directed to pay said sum to his said widow.

law.shorttitle: MRS. MARY GUY, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution providing for the payment of the pension due Mrs. Mary Guy, at the time of her death, to the ordinary of Schley county, for the use of such persons as may be entitled thereto by reason of service rendered said deceased in her last illness, and to such persons as furnished food, clothing, medical attention, and burial necessities to said pensioner.
law.p: Whereas, Mrs. Mary Guy, of the county of Schley, was, prior to her death, which occurred on March 13, 1904, duly and lawfully on the pension rolls of Georgia, as an indigent widow of a Confederate soldier; and, Pension [Illegible Text] Mrs. Mary Guy
Whereas, Her pension for said year was due and payable at and prior to her said death; and,

Whereas, A warrant was duly issued to her for said pension by the proper authorities of the pension department, and was not collected by her by reason of death, and said warrant was therefore returned; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That the sum of sixty ($60.00) dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated with which to pay the pension due said Mrs. Mary Guy at the time of her death, and that the proper officials of the State be, and are, hereby directed to pay to the ordinary of said county of Schley, for the use of such persons as may be entitled thereto by reason of services rendered said deceased in her last illness, and to such persons as furnished food, clothing, medical attention and burial necessities, to said deceased pensioner, the balance remaining if any, of said sum, after paying said amounts, shall be returned by said ordinary, to be covered in the State treasury; be it further
Resolved, That all laws and resolutions contrary to this be, and are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: J.J.W. GLENN, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to authorize the commissioner of pensions to reinstate J.J.W. Glenn, of Rockdale county, Georgia, upon the pension rolls of 1903, and to pay him a pension for said year.
law.p: Whereas, J. J. W. Glenn, of Rockdale county, was duly entered upon the pension rolls of this State under section 1254 of the Code, and was paid a pension of sixty dollars for the year 1901; and Pension of J. J. W. Glenn.

Whereas, Said J. J. W. Glenn, in the month of April, 1901, made a visit to Fayette, Alabama, where certain of his children resided, with the intention, if suitable arrangement could be made for himself and family, of becoming a citizen of said State of Alabama, and making his home there; and,

Whereas, Said J. J. W. Glenn was unable to enter into and make satisfactory arrangements in regard to the advisability of
changing his domicile from this State and becoming a citizen of Alabama; and,

Whereas, During his sojourn there (while on a visit as aforesaid, to his children, never, in the meantime, having unpacked all of his family effects, nor registered, or exercised, or claimed any act of citizenship in said State of Alabama) did conclude to return to his home in this State; and,

Whereas, On or about the 25th day of December, 1902, said J. J. W. Glenn returned to his home in Rockdale county, Georgia, where he had all along and for more than forty years claimed as his domicile; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That the commissioner of pensions of the State is hereby authorized and directed to reinstate said J. J. W. Glenn on the pension rolls of this State for the year 1903, under section 1254 of the Code.

Resolved further, That the sum of sixty ($60.00) dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated to pay said J. J. W. Glenn his pension for said year 1903, and the Governor is hereby authorized to draw his warrant on the treasury for said amount in favor of said J. J. W. Glenn.

law.shorttitle: MRS. ADELINE HAINES, PENSION OF.
law.p: Whereas, A pension of sixty dollars was due Mrs. M. Adeline Haines, of Coweta county, on January 1, 1904, and for which she had signed the proper voucher to collect same on January 15th, following; and, Pension of Mrs. Adeline Haines.

Whereas, The said Mrs. Haines died on January 29th following, before the ordinary of said county could turn over to her the money he had collected for her, and the money is now in the treasury of the State; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That the said sum of sixty dollars be paid to her son, James M. Haines, to reimburse him for money paid for expenses of burial and last sickness of said pensioner, and that the treasurer be, and he is, hereby authorized to pay the same.

law.shorttitle: HANNAH HARRIS, PENSION OF.
law.p: Whereas, On the 16th day of January, 1904, Hannah Harris, who was then and there a regular pensioner, enlisted on the rolls in the office of pension commissioner, signed voucher and receipt for pension for the year 1904; and, Pension of Hannah Harris.
Whereas, Said application and voucher was approved by the pension commissioner; and,
Whereas, Said Hannah Harris died on the 25th day of January, 1904, before she had received said pension, receipted for by voucher, and receipt dated as above; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That the sum of sixty dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated with which to pay to A. L. Harris, son of said Hannah Harris, for pension due said Hannah Harris, to cover doctor's bill and burial expenses, and that the proper officials of this State be directed to pay said sum to said A. L. Harris, son of said Hannah Harris.

law.shorttitle: A. J. HOBBS, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to authorize the payment of pension of A. J. Hobbs, deceased, to his son, John I. Hobbs.
law.p: Whereas, A. J. Hobbs, of Taylor county, was an invalid Confederate soldier, and was a regularly enrolled invalid pensioner under the laws of Georgia; and, Pension of A. J. Hobbs.

Whereas, There was due and payable to said Hobbs an invalid's pension of $60.00 on the first day of January, 1904, the same having been approved and ordered paid to said Hobbs, and said amount having been on the 19th day of February, 1904, sent to the ordinary of said county, to be delivered to said Hobbs; and,
Whereas, The said pensioner died on the first day of February, instant, and before receiving said pension; and,
Whereas, His son, John I. Hobbs, paid all the expenses of the last illness, and the funeral expenses of said pensioner; therefore be it

Resolved, by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the said John I. Hobbs be paid said pension of $60.00, due the said A. J. Hobbs, and said amount is hereby appropriated for said purpose, and the treasurer is hereby authorized to pay the same upon the warrant of the Governor.

law.shorttitle: IRWIN HUMPHREYS, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution for the relief of Irwin Humphreys, a disabled Confederate soldier, of Montgomery county.
law.p: Whereas, Irwin Humphreys, of Company E, Forty-ninth Georgia Regiment, of Montgomery county, was, in the year 1885, upon a regular application, and on proof, from the county of Wilcox, placed on the pension rolls in the office of the commissioner of pensions of this State, as a disabled or invalid Confederate soldier, and as such pensioner did receive a pension from and including the year 1885 to and including the year 1900; and, Pension of Irwin Humphreys.

Whereas, The pension duly allowed him as aforesaid was withheld from the said Irwin Humphreys during and for the years 1901, 1902 and 1903, because it was reported to the office of the commissioner of pensions that he, the said Humphreys, had removed from the State; and,

Whereas, It is not true that he, the said Humphreys, at that time, or at any other time, ever removed from the State of Georgia, but that he has been a resident of said State during his entire life, having never at any time claimed residence, or had permanent abode out of said State; and,
Whereas, The said Humphreys was not restored to pension roll in the office of the commissioner of pensions of this State till the present year, 1904; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the Governor be, and he is, hereby authorized to draw his warrant on the treasury in favor of the said Irwin Humphreys for the sum of three hundred dollars; that is, one hundred dollars per year for the years 1901, 1902 and 1903 (the said sum of one hundred dollars being the sum previously paid the said Humphreys as pensioner aforesaid), and the said sum of three hundred dollars is hereby appropriated for the payment of the same.

law.shorttitle: SARAH KING, PENSION OF.
law.p: Whereas, On the 16th day of January, 1904, Sarah King, who was then and there a regular pensioner, enlisted on the rolls in the office of pension commissioner, signed voucher and receipt for pension for the year 1904; and, Pension of Sarah King.
Whereas, Said application was approved by the pension commissioner; and,
Whereas, Said Sarah King died on the day in January, 1904, before she had received said pension receipted for by voucher and receipt dated as above; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That the sum of sixty dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated with which to pay to George W. King, son of said Sarah King, for pension due said Sarah King, to cover doctor's bills and burial expenses, and that the proper officials of this State be directed to pay said sum to said George W. King, son of said Sarah King.

law.shorttitle: NANCY SUSAN LYNCH, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay pension of Mrs. Nancy Susan Lynch to her daughter.
law.p: Whereas, Nancy Susan Lynch had been drawing pension from Butts county, Georgia, as widow of James Lynch, deceased, as widow of invalid soldier and moved to Jasper county in 1902, and died in Jasper county February 3, 1903, and had made application for pension for 1903, which had been appropriated in 1902; and, Pension of Nancy Susan Lynch.
Whereas, Said pension would have been paid February II, 1903, had she not died on date hereinbefore stated; and,
Whereas, The said Nancy Susan Lynch left a daughter dependent for support upon said pension; be it therefore

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring,
That the sum of sixty dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated for the benefit and support of the daughter of said deceased pensioner.

law.shorttitle: HARRIET E. MALONE, PENSION OF.
law.p: Whereas, Mrs. Harriet E. Malone, widow of Franklin Malone, of Jasper county, was placed on the pension roll in the pension office in the city of Atlanta, Georgia, by the order of Hon. J. W. Lindsay, commissioner of pensions, in May, 1899, as the widow of Franklin Malone, a deceased Confederate soldier, who died from the effects of wounds received while in the service of the Confederate States, on January 25, 1888; and, Pension of Harriet E. Malone.
Whereas, The said Harriet E. Malone drew her pensions for the years 1899, 1900 and 1901; and,

Whereas, She died on January 28, 1902, without receiving her pension for said year, which was due her, and which had been appropriated and sent to the ordinary of Jasper county for her, but returned to the treasury on account of her death before receiving same; and,
Whereas, She was at the time of her death living with her son, Walker B. Malone, who had his home and contents burned just prior to her death; and,
Whereas, The said Walker B. Malone defrayed all the burial expenses, as well as medical bills, and had to sustain his mother in every way while she was in life; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the Governor be, and he is, hereby authorized to draw his warrant on the treasurer in favor of the said Walker B. Malone for the sum of sixty ($60.00) dollars, the amount due his mother at the time of her death, for the year 1902, with which to enable him, the said Walker B. Malone, to pay the expense consequent upon the board, medical and burial expense of his mother, and the said sum of sixty dollars due his mother for the year 1902 is hereby appropriated for the payment of the same.

law.shorttitle: GEORGE MICHAEL, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay pension of Geo. Michael.
law.p: Whereas, On January 1, 1903, Geo. Michael, of Echols county, Georgia, was duly enrolled in the office of the commissioner of pensions as an indigent pensioner; and, Pension of George Michael.

Whereas, During the month of January, 1903, said Geo. Michael signed his voucher and receipt for the pension due him for the year 1903, which voucher and receipt were duly approved by said pension commissioner, and a check for the sum of $60.00 was issued to said Geo. Michael; and,
Whereas, Before the said Geo. Michael received said check, and during the latter part of February, 1903, the said Geo. Michael died before he had gotten the money on said check; and,
Whereas, Said Geo. Michael died in destitute circumstances, and without sufficient means for a decent burial; and,

Whereas, Elbert Withington, of said county of Echols, did, at considerable expense and trouble, defray the expenses of the preparation and burial of said Geo. Michael, and in a very short time did defray the expenses of preparation and burial of Rachel Michael, widow of the said Geo. Michael; therefore, be it

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That the sum of sixty ($60.00) dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated with which to pay to said Elbert Withington for money expended by him as aforesaid, as pension due the said Geo. Michael for the year 1903, and that the proper officers of this State be directed to pay said sum to the said Elbert Withington, as aforesaid.

law.shorttitle: MARY E. MIZE, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay the pension of Mary E. Mize to her son Thomas N. Mize.
law.p:
Whereas, Mary E. Mize, of Milton county, Georgia, was duly
entered upon the pension rolls of said State as a Confederate soldier's widow, and drew the pension allowed by law prior to the year 1903; and, Pension of Mary E. Mize.
Whereas, The said Mary E. Mize died during the month of January, 1903, after her pension had accrued and was payable to her for the year 1903; and,
Whereas, She left a son, Thomas N. Mize, of said county, with whom she had resided for a number of years prior to her death, who is a very poor man with a large family; and,
Whereas, The said Mary E. Mize was sick for a long while prior to her death, and dependent on the said Thomas N. Mize for support and medical attention; and,

Whereas, The said Thomas N. Mize has now outstanding and unpaid a medical bill of fifty dollars, besides other expenses incurred in the last illness of the said Mary E. Mize, which he is unable to pay; therefore be it

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the said pension of sixty ($60.00) dollars due the said Mary E. Mize, deceased, for the year 1903, be paid to her said son, the said Thomas N. Mize, and that the Governor of the State be, and he is, hereby authorized to draw his warrant on the treasury in favor of the said Thomas N. Mize, for the same.

law.shorttitle: WILLIAM ROBERSON, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to appropriate to Martha Martin of the county of Richmond, daughter of William Roberson, late of said county, deceased, the sum of sixty ($60) dollars, being the amount of an indigent pension due said William Roberson by the State of Georgia at the time of his death.
law.p: Whereas, William Roberson, late of Richmond county, deceased, was on the 25th of January, 1903, properly upon the indigent pension roll of the State of Georgia, and, Pension of William Roberson.

Whereas, The ordinary of Richmond county did on the 26th day of January, 1903, receipt for the indigent pension of said William Roberson for the year 1903, a few hours after the death of the said William Roberson, said death occurring the night
of January 25, 1903, and the said ordinary was required by the commissioner of pensions to return to him the said check uncancelled; and

Whereas, Martha Martin, daughter of said Roberson, did nurse and care for said Roberson during his last illness, and for more than six months prior to his death, during which period he was an invalid, and she did also pay his funeral expenses; therefore, be it

Resolved, by the House of Representatives of the State of Georgia, the Senate concurring, That the sum of sixty dollars being the amount of pension due William Roberson for the year 1903, be, and the same is, hereby appropriated to Martha Martin of the county of Richmond, out of any sums in the treasury not otherwise appropriated, and the Governor is hereby authorized and directed to draw his warrant on the treasury in favor of said Martha Martin for said sum.

law.shorttitle: ELIZABETH C. SHEAROUSE, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay sixty dollars, the pension due Mrs. Elizabeth C. Shearouse, of Effingham county, whose name was on the indigent pension roll for the year of 1903, to her lawful representative, Mrs. Shearouse having died just a few days before she was to have been paid.
law.p: Resolved, By the House of Representatives and Senate of the State of Georgia, That sixty dollars be, and is hereby, appropriated to pay to the lawful representative of Mrs. Elizabeth C. Shearouse, whose name was on the indigent pension roll for the year 1903, Mrs. Shearouse having died only a few days before the pension would have been paid her. Pension of Elizabeth E. Shearouse.

law.shorttitle: B. G. SMITH, PENSION OF.
law.p: Whereas, B. G. Smith, late of Baker county, died on February 9, 1902; and

Whereas, The pension commissioner had approved his application for a pension under existing laws for $60 and said B. G. Smith died before said pension was paid; be it, therefore, Pension of B. G. Smith.

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the said sum of $60 be paid to D. D. Smith of said county, as administrator of the estate of said B. G. Smith, deceased, and the Governor is hereby authorized and directed to draw his warrant on the treasurer of said State for the payment of said sum out of any fund in the treasury not otherwise appropriated.

law.shorttitle: I. N. TAYLOR, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay pension of I. N. Taylor of Carroll county, Georgia, to his widow, Mrs. I. N. Taylor.
law.p: Whereas, I. N. Taylor of Carroll county, Georgia, was duly entered upon the pension rolls of said State as an invalid pensioner, and drew the pension allowed by law for the years 1897, and 1898; and, Pension of I. N. Taylor.
Whereas, Said I. N. Taylor died during the month of January, 1899, after his pension had accrued and was payable to him for the year 1899; and,
Whereas, He left a widow, Mrs. I. N. Taylor, in dependent circumstances, and said pension should be paid to her for the year 1899; and,
Whereas, The commissioner of pensions had issued a check to the said I. N. Taylor for the amount of sixty dollars, ($60) and sent it to him through the ordinary of said county; and

Whereas, The said I. N. Taylor died before receiving said
check, and the said ordinary returned it to the pension commissioner; therefore, be it

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the amount of sixty ($60) dollars, due the said I. N. Taylor for the year 1899, shall be paid to his widow, Mrs. I. N. Taylor, and the Governor of the State is authorized to draw his warrant upon the treasury in her favor for the same.

law.shorttitle: MATILDA A. WEST, PENSION OF.
law.p: Whereas, Mrs. Matilda A. West, late of Hancock county, Georgia, deceased, was the widow of Thomas James West, also of said county, and a Confederate soldier; and Pension of Matilda A. West.

Whereas, the said Mrs. M. A. West as such Confederate widow, had on April 23, 1901, made application for a pension, which application, conforming to all the requirements of law, was granted, and her name regularly placed on the pension roll; and

Whereas, The said Mrs. West departed this life on the 13th day of January, 1902, one month before she was to have received the first payment on said pension, and has never received any payment on same; and
Whereas, She, the said Mrs. West, had contracted debts incident to her last illness and death, to which she looked to this amount to pay; therefore,

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the sum of sixty dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated for the purpose of paying the pension that was due the said Mrs. West, and the Governor is hereby authorized to draw his warrant on the treasurer in favor of Hon. Lester C. Culver, ordinary of Hancock county, as trustee, to pay the physician's bill, burial expenses, and the other expenses incident to her last illness and death.

law.shorttitle: CARRIE WILSON, PENSION OF.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to pay pension of Carrie Wilson, of Muscogee county, to Mrs. J. T. Sistrunk, her daughter.
law.p: Whereas, Carrie Wilson, late of Muscogee county, Georgia, died during the month of April, 1903; and Pension of Carrie Wilson.
Whereas, Said deceased had been regularly placed on the pension roll as the widow of a Confederate soldier, and received her pension annually up to the year 1903; and
Whereas, It appearing that there is still due and unpaid a pension of $60 due said deceased prior to her death; and,

Whereas, Mrs. J. T. Sistrunk, daughter of deceased, had entire care and support and bore all the expenses of said deceased during her last illness, and paid for the entire burial expenses of deceased; and

Whereas, Said deceased had no property whatsoever and she, as well as her daughter, Mrs. J. T. Sistrunk, had confidently expected to draw said pension and use same for defraying said necessary expenses; be it, therefore,

Resolved, By the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the said sum of $60 be paid to Mrs. J. T. Sistrunk, daughter of deceased, of Houston county, and the Governor is hereby authorized and directed to draw his warrant on the treasury for the payment of said sum out of any funds in the treasury not otherwise appropriated.

law.shorttitle: FOR RELIEF OF I. J. SLAUGHTER.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution for the relief of I. J. Slaughter.
law.p: Whereas, I. J. Slaughter of Butts county, on the 30th day of March, 1898, became surety on the bond of Henry Moore, of Butts county, to answer the charge of larceny from the house in Butts superior court; and I. J. Slaugher, relief of.

Whereas, At the February term, 1898, of said court, said bond
was forfeited and scire facias issued thereon, which was [Illegible Text] on said surety; and

Whereas, At the August adjourned term of said court, held in December, 1898, final judgment was entered on said bond against the said surety, I. J. Slaughter, for the sum on one hundred dollars, the penal sum named in said bond; and

Whereas, After the giving of said bond, the said Henry Moore fled, and was not present in court at the August adjourned term, 1898, and the said I. J. Slaughter, for this reason, was unable to produce him in court at said time; and

Whereas, Since final judgment on said bond the surety, I. J. Slaughter, has, at considerable trouble and expense to himself, delivered the said Henry Moore up to the sheriff of Butts county, where he has been tried, convicted and served a term in the chaingang for said offense; be it, therefore,

Resolved, by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That said surety, I. J. Slaughter, be, and he is, hereby released from all liability on said bond, and the judgment entered on the forfeiture of the same, upon the payment of costs, if any be due.

law.shorttitle: FOR RELIEF OF LESTER PARKS, W. H. GOOCH AND VIRGIL PARKS.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution for the relief of Lester Parks, principal, W. H. Gooch and Virgil Parks, sureties on the bonds of the said Lester Parks.
law.p: Whereas, Lester Parks did on the 4th day of August, 1903, give bond for his personal appearance at the February term, 1904, with W. H. Gooch and Virgil Parks as sureties; and Lester Parks, W. H. Gooch and Virgil Parks, relief of.

Whereas, The said Lester Parks, as principal, and Virgil Parks did, on the 6th day of August, enter into another appearance bond for the appearance of the said Lester Parks at the February term, 1904, of Dawson superior court; and
Whereas, On the 6th day of August, 1903, in Dawson superior court, both of said bonds were forfeited and scire facias issued thereon; and

Whereas, At the February term of said superior court, to wit: On February 9, 1904, final judgment was entered up against the said Lester Parks, principal, and W. H. Gooch and Virgil Parks, sureties on the first bond aforesaid, and the said Lester Parks, principal and Virgil Parks surety on the second bond aforesaid, the judgment on the first bond being for two hundred dollars and costs and on the second for one hundred dollars and costs and fi. fas. have issued accordingly; and,

Whereas, On the said 9th day of February, 1904, the said Lester Parks was in the custody of the United States authorities and confined in Fulton county jail under charge of violation of the internal revenue laws and could not, therefore, appear and relieve his bondsmen from their liability, and for such failure to appear judgment absolute was taken against him and his sureties upon said bonds; and

Whereas, Since his release by the said United States authorities the said Lester Parks has given two other bonds with good security for his personal appearance at the next term of Dawson superior court to answer to said charges for which the forfeited bonds were given; be it, therefore,

Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the said Lester Parks as principal, and W. H. Gooch and Virgil Parks, as principal and sureties upon the first bond aforesaid and Lester Parks as principal, and Virgil Parks as sureties on the second bond aforesaid, they be, and are, hereby relieved from the payment of said judgments except the costs on each, due the officers of court, and that said judgments absolute be settled in full by the payment of the costs in each case to the clerk of said Dawson superior court, and he is hereby authorized and directed to enter the same as satisfied.

law.shorttitle: FOR RELIEF OF P. P. EVANS.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution for the relief of P. P. Evans, of Meriwether county, Georgia, as security on the bond of Albert Clayton, of said county.
law.p:
Whereas, P. P. Evans of Meriwether county became security
in the sum of one hundred and fifty ($150.00) dollars on the bond of Albert Clayton, of said Meriwether county, indicted in the superior court of said county for a misdemeanor, larceny from the house; and P. P. Evans, relief of.

Whereas, At the August term, 1903, said bond was duly forfeited, the said Albert Clayton failing to appear, judgment was rendered by said superior court against said P. P. Evans, security, for the appearance of said Albert Clayton; and

Whereas, The said P. P. Evans has paid a reward of twenty-five dollars for the capture of the said Albert Clayton, who was captured and brought to trial in the city court of Greenville, of said county of Meriwether, to which court the said case was transferred on August 26, 1903; and
Whereas, The said Albert Clayton, when brought to trial in the said city court of Greenville, plead guilty and was sentenced to twelve months in the chain-gang, which sentence he is now serving.

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That the said P. P. Evans, security as aforesaid, be, and he is, hereby relieved from any and all further liability on said bond, and the judgment and execution based on said forfeiture are hereby declared to be null and void and of no effect, upon the payment of the costs, if any be due thereon.

law.shorttitle: COMMISSION ON REGISTRATION OF LAND TITLES CONTINUED IN FORCE.
law.p: Whereas, The commission on the registration of land titles has made a report to this General Assembly of the work done by the commission and its inability to complete the discharge of its duties by the present session of the General Assembly; and Commission on registration of land titles, time for making report extended.
Whereas, The said commission asks for additional time in which to complete its work; therefore, be it,

Resolved, by the House, the Senate concurring, That The Commission on the Registration of Land Titles, appointed under the joint resolution of the House and Senate, approved August 5, 1903, be, and the same is, continued in full force and effect,
with all of its powers and duties as now constituted, and the said commission is directed to report to the next session of the General Assembly whether a system for the registration of land titles is advisable and practicable for this State.

law.shorttitle: COMMISSION ON REVISION OF BANKING LAWS CREATED.
law.p: Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That a commission of two from the Senate, three from the House, and three members of the Bankers' Association of this State, the last named to be appointed by His Excellency, the Governor, be appointed for the purpose of considering the necessity for a revision and consolidation of the banking laws of this State, with instructions to report by bill or otherwise as soon as may be convenient and practicable. Be it further Commission on revision of banking laws created.
Resolved, That this commission shall serve without expense to the State.

law.shorttitle: CONSENT FOR INTERURBAN RAILWAY COMPANY TO CROSS TRACKS OF W. A. RAILROAD.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution consenting, on the part of the State, that the Atlanta Interurban Railway Company may make two overhead crossing over the tracks of the Western Atlantic Railroad in Cobb county, Georgia, and one overhead crossing over the tracks of the Western Atlantic Railroad in Fulton county, Georgia. Be it
law.p:
Resolved, By the General Assembly of Georgia, That the consent of the State is hereby given to the Atlanta Interurban Railway Company to construct two overhead crossings across the right of way of the Western Atlantic Railroad in Cobb county, Georgia, one near the Chattahoochee river and one near the town
of Marietta, Georgia, where the rights of way of said two railroads intersect, the right to make such crossings having already been granted by the lessees of said Western Atlantic Railroad; and further, that consent is also given to the said Atlanta Interurban Railway Company to construct one overhead crossing across the right of way of the said Western Atlantic Railroad in Fulton county, Georgia, at the point where its right of way as finally located may intersect the right of way of the Western Atlantic Railroad upon said Atlanta Interurban Railway Company procuring the right so to do from the lessees of said Western Atlantic Railroad. W. A. Railroad Company. consent to cross tracks given.

law.shorttitle: BURNING OF CANCELLED BONDS AND COUPONS.
law.p: Resolved, by the Senate, the House of Representatives concurring, That the Treasurer of the State of Georgia be instructed to destroy, by burning, the accumulated cancelled bonds and coupons which have been paid and are consequently of no value, now to be found sealed in boxes and in the vaults of the State treasury, and that he further do this in the presence of the Governor, the Secretary of State, the Comptroller-General and the Attorney-General, or a majority of them; and, Cancelled bonds, treasurer to burn.
Resolved further, That the Secretary of State preserve a copy and description of these coupons and bonds thus destroyed, as shown by memorandum on these boxes sealed with the executive seal.

law.shorttitle: MEDICAL COMMISSION AUTHORIZED.
law.p:
Resolved, By the Senate, the House concurring, That the Governor of the State of Georgia be, and he is hereby, authorized to raise a medical commission to consist of one physician from each congressional district and ten from the State at large, who shall make a thorough investigation touching the propositions hereinafter
set forth and numbered, and embody the same in a report to be submitted to the next session of the General Assembly of Georgia. 1. The number of cases of tuberculosis in the State of Georgia. 2. The annual number of deaths from tuberculosis in the State of Georgia. 3. The number of cases contracted within the State, and the number imported. 4. The measures that are being taken in the various localities for preventing the spread of the disease. 5. Whether or not the physicians of the State are in favor of taking measures for its prevention. Be it further Tuberculosis, commission to investigate authorized.
Resolved, That said commission shall serve without compensation and without entailing any expense whatever upon the State of Georgia in connection with said investigation.

law.shorttitle: JOINT COMMISSION FOR JAMESTOWN EXPOSITION.
law.p: Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That a commission of five be appointed to represent the State at the Jamestown (Va.) Exposition, in 1907. The Commissioner of Agriculture, the State Geologist, and three citizens, to be designated by His Excellency the Governor, shall constitute said commission. Jamestown Exposition, joint commission for.

Resolved, That the commission may take such steps as in their judgment may seem practicable to manifest the interest which the people of Georgia feel in Virginia's great enterprise; provided, that the commission shall serve without expense to the State, and shall not incur any liability in any manner on account of the State. Duties.

Resolved, That the Commissioner of Agriculture and the State Geologist may display at said exposition such exhibits of the State's resources as are now, or in 1907, may be, in their possession; provided, that this can be done without expense to the State. Exhibits.

law.shorttitle: TABLES SHOWING PROGRESS OF STATE INSTITUTIONS OF LEARNING PROVIDED FOR.
law.p: Resolved, By the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That it is the sense of the General Assembly that there should be incorporated in each annual report of the trustees, and in the catalogue of each of the State institutions of learning hereinafter named, a statement or table which will show the avocation or profession (classified) of the parent or guardian of the students in attendance and the place of residence (classified) whether country, village, town or city. State educational institutions, report of trustees to show occupations of parents of students.

Resolved, That it is particularly desired that each such annual report and catalogue shall contain a statement or table which will show, as to the alumni or the alumnae of the institution, the avocation or profession adopted, and especially the per centum of those who have chosen an avocation or profession in line with the studies pursued by them in college. The institutions referred to are: The University of Georgia proper, the State College of Agriculture, the Industrial department of the Georgia Normal and Industrial College, the School of Technology, the North Georgia Agricultural College. Report to show occupation of alumni and alumnae.

law.shorttitle: TREASURER OF JACKSON COUNTY AUTHORIZED TO PAY OUT MONEY COLLECTED UNDER ALTERNATIVE ROAD LAW.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to authorize and require the treasurer of Jackson county to pay out a certain sum of money collected under the alternative road law upon the warrant of the chairman of the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Jackson county, and for other purposes.
law.p: Whereas, There is now in the treasury of Jackson county a sum of money, $6,000 or more, collected and paid in under the alternative road law; and Road law, fund collected under in Jackson county, disbursement of.
Whereas, the alternative road law has been abolished in Jackson county; and

Whereas, Under the existing circumstances the treasurer of said county is uncertain as to whether or not he has the authority to pay out said sum of money, and refuses to pay out the same; therefore, be it,

Resolved, By the House, the Senate concurring, That the treasurer, A. C. Appleby, be and he is, hereby authorized and required to pay out said sum of money so collected upon the warrants drawn on him by the chairman of the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Jackson county. Said sum of money shall be used for road purposes only, and shall be distributed over the county, as equitably as possible for the chairman to do.

law.shorttitle: PRISON COMMISSION AUTHORIZED TO PROVIDE WORK FOR SPECIFIED CLASS OF CONVICTS.
law.fulltitle: A Resolution to authorize the prison commission to provide work for a certain class of convicts, and to make contracts for the same.
law.p: Whereas, It frequently happens that a surplus of labor is had at the State Farm, which can not be profitably used there and which can not be used on regular contracts; be it, therefore, Male convicts at State Farm, hire of.

Resolved, By the House, the Senate concurring, That the prison commission is hereby authorized, whenever such a surplus of male convicts shall exist at the State Farm, to make such contracts for such labor, by competitive bids, or private contracts, as may be deemed best, for such employment as may be suited to the physical condition of such convicts. Be it further
Resolved, That all funds arising from this source shall be collected, and paid into the State treasury, as now provided by law.

law.shorttitle: SPECIAL JOINT INVESTIGATING COMMITTEE, PRINTING OF REPORT.
law.p: Resolved, by the Senate, the House of Representatives concurring, That five hundred copies of the report submitted by the special joint investigating committee of the House of Representatives and Senate, be printed for the use of the House of Representatives and the Senate. Special joint investigating committee, printing of report.

law.shorttitle: CORRECTION OF ERRORS IN ACT INCORPORATING TOWN OF WESTMINSTER.
law.fulltitle: A Joint Resolution authorizing the correction of certain errors and omissions in an Act (No. 494) passed at this session of the General Assembly, incorporating the town of Westminster, approved July 26, 1904.
law.p: Whereas, An Act (No. 494) incorporating the town of Westminster, passed at the present session of the General Assembly, approved July 26, 1904, there are certain errors and omissions, to wit: (1) In line 20 of section 2 of the Act the word and before the word also should be stricken. (2) In line 10 of section 4 the word and occurs instead of or. (3) In the last line of section 7 the word for is omitted before the word herein. (4) The word all is omitted before the word other in line 16 of section 8. (5) In line 3 of section 11 the word public is used improperly instead of police. (6) The words of section seventy-two (72), volume one (1) are omitted between the figure 7 and the word of in the sixth line of section 5. (7) The word option in the tenth line of section 14 is improperly used instead of license. Therefore, be it, Westminster, act incorporating, errors in corrected.

Resolved, By the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That said errors and omissions may be corrected in said Act,
an4 the proper officers and the Secretary of State be authorized to make said corrections in said Act.

law.shorttitle: UNFINISHED BUSINESS OF GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
law.p: Resolved, By the House, the Senate concurring, That the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate, the Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate be, and they are hereby, authorized to remain at the capitol for five days after adjournment of the General Assembly for the purpose of affixing their official signatures to all bills and resolutions passed previous to said adjournment, and that they be allowed their per diem for the time. Unfinished business of General Assembly.

Resolved further, That the chairman, respectively, of the Enrollment and Auditing committees of the House and Senate together with five members of the Enrollment Committee of the House, and four members of the Enrollment Committee of the Senate and two members of the Auditing Committee of the House and Senate, to be designated by the chairmen thereof be, and they are, hereby authorized to remain at the capitol for five days after adjournment of the General Assembly for the purpose of bringing up the unfinished business of the session, and that they be allowed their per diem for said time. That the postmistress be, and she is, hereby authorized to remain at the capitol for five days after adjournment of the General Assembly, for the purpose of distributing and forwarding members' mail, and that she be allowed her per diem for said time.

Resolved, further, That two porters of the House and one porter of the Senate be, and they are, hereby authorized to remain at the capitol for five days after adjournment of the General Assembly, and that they be allowed their per diem for said time.

law.shorttitle: CAMILLA, AMENDMENT OF NEW CHARTER, REPEALED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the town of Camilla, Georgia, approved October 24, 1887, so as to add to section 26 of said Act the following proviso, to wit: Provided, that said mayor and council shall not have power and authority to issue any license to any person whatsoever to sell ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, ciders, or other intoxicants within the corporate limits of said town, except upon the written consent of two-thirds of the bona fide resident freeholders of said town owning real estate within the corporate limits of said town, approved December 2, 1889.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act an Act entitled an Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the town of Camilla, Georgia, approved October 24, 1887, so as to add to section 26 the following proviso, to wit: Provided, that said mayor and council shall not have power and authority to issue any license to any person whatsoever to sell ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, ciders, or other intoxicants within the corporate limits of said town, except upon the written consent of two-thirds of the bona fide resident freeholders of said town owning real estate within the corporate limits of said town, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Camilla, sale of intoxicating liquors in.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.

preface.p: The following Act is an exact copy of the Act on page 539. Both copies having been signed the Compiler thinks that both should be published.

law.shorttitle: McDONOUGH, BONDS OF, FOR PUBLIC SCHOOLS, AUTHORIZED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the mayor and council of the town of McDonough, in the county of Henry, to issue bonds not to exceed the amount of $10,000 for the purpose of erecting and equipping a school building, or school buildings, in the said town of McDonough; to provide for the payment of principal and interest of said bonds by levying a tax therefor; to provide for the ratification of the provisions of this Act; to designate what officers are to carry into effect the provisions of this Act, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the mayor and council of the town of McDonough be authorized and required to issue and sell bonds not to exceed in the aggregate $10,000 of the denomination of $100 each, to be due and payable at such time or times within twenty years after the date of issue thereof as said mayor and council may determine, and bear not exceeding six per cent. interest per annum, payable annually; such bonds are not to be sold for less than par. McDonough, bonds of.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of the town of McDonough pay over to the city treasurer the proceeds of sale of said bonds, after first requiring and receiving a good and sufficient bond from him for the proper disbursement of said money in accordance with the provisions of this Act. Proceeds of sale paid to treasurer.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of the town of McDonough be, and the same are, hereby authorized and required to levy and collect such tax upon the taxable property in said town as will be necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this Act. Tax.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the location, erection and equipping of said school buildings shall be under the direction of the board of education of the town of McDonough, and that said school board shall have full authority to let contract for plans and the erection and equipping of said school building or
school buildings, and perform any and all other acts necessary for carrying into effect the provisions of this Act. School buildings.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That the vouchers upon which the town of McDonough shall pay out money or funds arising under this Act for the purposes herein mentioned, shall bear the signature of the secretary and chairman of said board of education, and the town treasurer shall be required to pay all bills arising under this Act when properly made out and presented. Vouchers.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of the town of McDonough shall order an election, after notice being given as required by law for such elections, at which election shall be submitted to the qualified voters of the town of McDonough, under the same rules and regulations as the elections held for mayor and aldermen of said town, the question of issuing said bonds. Those in favor of the issuing of said bonds shall have written or printed upon their tickets the words For Bonds, and those against the issuing of said bonds shall have written or printed upon their tickets the words Against Bonds. Should the requisite constitutional majority vote at said election in favor of issuing said bonds, the mayor and council of said town are hereby empowered and directed to issue and dispose of said bonds in accordance with the provisions of this Act. Should the requisite majority fail to vote for the issuing of said bonds, then, and in that event any number of elections may be held under the provisions of this Act, after due notice being given as required by law for such elections; provided, no election can be held within six months from the date of the last election; the power to order said elections being vested in the mayor and aldermen of said town by a plurality vote among these corporate officials. Election for bonds.
Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Repealing clause.
